fields.headline: Can independents save their brands?
fields.standfirst: Independent TV producers like Hat Trick have right on their side, but their chances of hanging on to their brands are slim.
fields.trailText: December 7:Independent TV producers like Hat Trick have right on their side, but their chances of hanging on to their brands are slim, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
In an open letter to the government, four leading independent production companies have put the case for keeping rights to their own programmes.

Current practice, apart from ITV, is for broadcasters who commission programmes to insist on purchasing all rights. The independents' case is that they are the drivers of creative programming and they need to hold on to their resources. The big broadcasters have no time or energy to promote programmes as individual brands, or adequately market them, whereas the indies "have a passion and a hunger which no broadcaster could ever match".

Passion and hunger are certainly true of Hat Trick, judging from its horoscope (April 30 1985). As a hungry Taurus with a triangle of planets in money-minded earth signs, this is a company with sound business sense which is well capable of maximising its resources.

But it is no dull clod, with sparky, irreverent Uranus rising in enterprising Sagittarius.

Its innovative abilities are clear in its standard-bearing programme, Have I Got News For You, and in its foreign transactions it has made a big impact in the competitive US market with Whose Line Is It Anyway?. Hat Trick gets its name from a lively Mercury, the planet of tricks and trade, linked to pushy Mars, and this also gives it brilliant potential to increase revenue for new research and production through brand development.

Leading the battle at Hat Trick are joint managing directors Jimmy Mulville and Denise O'Donoghue.

Despite his comic streak, Mulville is a strategic Capricorn (January 5 1955) - he was, after all, president of Cambridge Footlights Review - and Capricorns have politics in their bones. This coming year, his horoscope is dominated by aggressive, swashbuckling Mars, and ex-wife O'Donoghue is also a come-out-and-fight Aries (April 13 1955).

Will they pull it off? The astrology shows that the independents have right on their side but sadly, it doesn't support them through to victory next year. Hat Trick's Mercury is moving to oppose Pluto and since Pluto is a god with no altar of appeal, the likely response is refusal from the broadcasters and a deaf ear from the government.

The indies are going to have to find a different contractual way of sorting this out and protecting their brands, but with such a smart Mercury, expect Hat Trick to pull some other ingenious rabbit out of its hat.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Michelle Ellicott
fields.trailText: I moved out here to Washington DC about three weeks ago. Here are just a few ideas I can think of, of what you can do...
fields.body:
Hi Sam

Welcome to the USA! How are you finding it so far?

I worked in Derby up until about three weeks ago, when my husband and I moved out here to Washington DC on secondment with our jobs. I've just been on to the Netjetters page to get your email address - what a fantastic trip you have lined up, what an experience. It sounds great - I guess it's a bit like the Channel 4 Big Brother thing, except with more freedom and privacy!

Unfortunately we've not been here in the DC area very long but I will tell you what little I do know about the place. We are living in Arlington, right next to the Virginia Square metro stop on the orange line - about two or three miles west of DC. You will figure out where this is when you get here, as everyone uses the metro to get around. Bit like the tube really, but a lot less grotty than the northern line! It's so cheap - a $5 pass will let you use the Metro all day, it's very clean and safe. Where will you be staying when you get here?

It's quite interesting here at the moment with all this election fiasco. Last week people were queuing up to go and sit at a hearing in the Supreme Court, something to do with the recount. Here's just a few ideas I can think of, of what you can do ( I think you can still do most of this at this time of year).

Old Town Trolley Tour - costs about $24, but you get a pass that lets you hop on and off the Trolley as you want (they have these in a lot of the main US cities). It's a good way to see the sights in DC and there is some narration from the driver too. You can pick it up at Union Station.

Most other things are free.

White House Tour - US Capitol and Supreme Court - probably quite topical at the moment.

Tour of FBI building - this is quite a good one, I think.

Arlington Cemetery, where the Kennedy's are buried - you can get the metro there.

Loads of monuments to past presidents - the Lincoln one is good - and I hear they are well worth seeing at night, when they are all lit up.

Washington Monument - not been yet, but I gather you get a fantastic view of the city.

Smithsonian museums and art galleries - again, all free. The National Gallery of Art has some Monets & Van Goghs on exhibit at the moment. There is also an Andy Warhol exhibition on at the Corcoran.

The Vietnam & Korean war memorials are quite amazing - the first time I saw the Vietnam memorial it moved me to tears, just seeing all those names. There is also a Holocaust museum, which I've not visited yet.

Georgetown is well worth a visit - it's an historic area of DC and a university town (I think Bill Clinton went there). It's quite quaint and there are loads of bars and restaurants. Old Town Alexandria is also nice if you want to get out of the city - get the metro to King Street (yellow line, I think) and then it's about a 15 minute walk.

The Newseum (Rosslyn metro stop on the blue and orange lines) also has a good exhibition on at the moment of some award winning photos of journalists and the like.

You can get a free weekly paper called the City that will tell you about concerts, gigs and things that are going on. The main newspaper here is the Washington Post - will you get to go there in connection with the Guardian?

Well, I am sure you have got loads of other emails to read so I will sign off now. Wherever you are staying, it's easy to pick up leaflets of things to do. I will send your name on to a couple of (American) people here who will know much more about the place than me; they may be able to give you some good ideas of about bars and restaurants. Try Fado next to the Chinatown metro, which is a good Irish bar (plus the food is cheap and plentiful!)

The Americans are a very friendly and helpful bunch, and people are always willing to give you advice. I bet if you tell them what you are doing as well, they'll be really impressed and even more willing to help.

Have a fantastic time; I am sure you will. Please send me an email if I can help you out at all.

PS Bring warm clothes, it's quite cold!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Constance
fields.trailText: When you're in Vancouver, for some jazz and blues there's a bar at the Cecil Hotel which is good fun (a little dodgy though); the music is awesome, and lots of guys from UBC go there for a pint or two. Trendy spot to go to.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,
How long are you staying in Vancouver. This is a very cold and rainy time of the year there, so I hope you have a brolly!

If you have some time, try to take the bus to Whistler. You can board the bus on Georgia Street (at Burrard) in front of the Royal Bank of Canada. You have to wave the bus to a stop. Call Whistler Express to find out at what time the bus goes by. It is an extraordinary trip along the fjord.

Once there you must try the onion rings at the Chateau Whistler, and go for a pint or two at the Brewhouse.

As for Vancouver, Delilas on Comox (at Denman) has the best Martinis in town. It is well known and fun. You must try also to go to Babaloo which is downtown on the corner of Granville, I think.

For some jazz and blues there is a bar at the Cecil Hotel which is good fun (a little dodgy though); the music is awesome and lots of guys from UBC go there for a pint or two. Trendy spot to go to.

For shopping... Robson Street is the best and only place to shop... But nothing compared to London.

Food wise, make sure you eat some salmon - it is fresh and delicious. Vancouver also has some fabulous sushi restaurants.

But be cautious, Vancouver is very expensive.

As for hostels, there is a hostel on Seymour Street near Hastings. Anything east of Seymour Street you should avoid; it's a dangerous area. The best hostel in Vancouver is at Jericho Beach and is part of Hosteling International . It is by the UBC sailing club, but I don't know if it's open over the winter.

Last but not least, you can claim your seven percent GST tax when you leave Canada. You must claim all your purchases which you are taking with you out of the country and get your money back. You can get a form at any hotel concierge desk.

Good luck and enjoy!

fields.headline: The open road and an open mind
fields.standfirst: Milly reaches Vancouver - skyrise buildings, snow-capped mountains, fish and chips, bald eagles and just a hint of homesickness
fields.trailText: Week 1: Heathrow to Vancouver. 'Last night I was contemplating staying in Canada for Christmas. I'm having such a good time, I just don't want to leave. This diary barely scratches the surface of the fun and experiences I'm having, and it's only been a week. Roll on the next eight months'
fields.body:
So, after weeks of preparation, I've finally experienced my first week as a traveller. I've only got one thing to say about it - it's fantastic. Whoever you are, whatever you're doing, I would so recommend you go and see a bit of the world. I promise you won't regret it.

One of my biggest worries was that I'd be travelling on my own, and I'd be all alone in a strange country. This couldn't be further from the truth. I first met someone on the plane on the way over - a Scottish guy who'd decided to leave home only two days before. We got into conversation and ended up spending the next couple of days together while we both found our feet.

My first couple of nights were booked at Global Village Backpackers, which is an absolutely central hostel. My first impression was that it was pretty basic, but as I got to know it, I discovered that it is the best hostel in the city. There is a great atmosphere, and you're guaranteed to meet a friendly face.

I have to admit, the first two days I felt a bit homesick and overwhelmed by the city. Vancouver is an incredibly stunning city - just around the corner from the skyrise buildings, snow-topped mountains poke through.

However, the size was a bit daunting at first. We went for a walk round the city, and down the incredibly trendy Robson Street, but after that I didn't really know what to do with myself. The best way to start seemed to be by going out drinking for the night. I just regret that my drinking partner was a Scot who believed I could keep up with him. One tip - all Vancouver's bars and restaurants are non-smoking. For me this was brilliant but smokers may find it frustrating.

On Saturday, I had arranged to go out with Trish, one of the first people to send me advice. She and her boyfriend took me down to Stevenston, to the Fraser river south of Vancouver. It was a gorgeous day and seeing a couple of friendly faces and getting fish and chips really made me start to feel good about the whole trip. They were really hospitable and filled me in about the Vancouvan way of living. We passed loads of film crews - apparently loads of American films are set here because of the low taxes and the incredible similarity of Vancouver to some parts of suburban America.

That night, I met a really nice group of people at the hostel and we arranged to hire a van and drive to Whistler the next day. That's the great thing about travelling - if you keep an open mind and don't have any fixed plans, so many opportunities are open to you.

Hiring a van turned out to be an absolute bargain and meant we had freedom to stop at the gorgeous scenic spots en route. We had a mixed van of Aussies, Kiwis and pommies, and it turned out to be a brilliant day. The size of the lakes and mountains is incredible and it was nice to see some real snow. At a place called Squamish, we stopped to watch bald eagles soaring over huge, snowy mountains which, as one guy said, made you feel pretty insignificant.

That evening we all headed to Malone's, where the beer is cheap. In general, beer in Vancouver is pricey so it made a nice change. We ended up having piggy-back races along the streets of Vancouver back to the hostel, which shows you the kind of high spirits present in nearly everyone you meet.

Two days after that, after a day of thinking it over, I decided to head east with four others to try living in Banff for a bit. We hired a van for a week, again to give us freedom, and set off. As someone else in the hostel said, where else do people sit down, say "Let's go to Banff," and the next day it's done? It's probably a little more expense than I thought I'd need for the Canada part of my trip, but then I thought what does it matter? My money's only there to be spent, and I really want to try some decent skiing.

I hope to return to Vancouver in a week to finish (or start) exploring it. So far I have only really been to Stanley Park in the city itself. Stanley Park is beautiful - a wildlife haven smack in the middle of the city. After four hours of walking, I saw only a fraction of it.

Last night I was contemplating staying in Canada for Christmas. I'm having such a good time I just don't want to leave. This diary barely scratches the surface of the fun and experiences I'm having and it's only been a week. Roll on the next eight months.

webTitle: NHS to break even, says Reeves

fields.headline: NHS to break even, says Reeves
fields.trailText: 12.45pm update: The government's recent massive cash boost for the NHS means it is set to break even financially after years of failing to live within its budget, outgoing NHS director of finance Colin Reeves said today. By Steve Brown
fields.body:
The government's recent massive cash boost for the NHS means it is set to break even financially after years of failing to live within its budget, outgoing NHS director of finance Colin Reeves said today.

But he revealed that auditors would had refused to give the service's annual accounts a clean bill of health this year because of "minor" discrepancies at a single health authority.

"I am confident that for the first time in many years, the NHS overall will achieve financial balance," said Mr Reeves.

However, some health bodies will record overspends at the end of the financial year in April.

In 1999-2000 the NHS reported a £220m overspend. But a £660m cash injection last spring has rejuvenated this year's health service finances, dampening earlier fears that the NHS could run up debts of about £500m.

The NHS failed to extend its five-year record of "unqualified" accounts by the closest of margins because a health authority has received a qualified opinion from auditors on its accounts for 1999-2000.

It ends a five-year run in which the accounts of all health authorities and trusts have remained unqualified, a feat seen as the direct result of the introduction of corporate governance arrangements to tighten financial controls.

"The accounts of one health authority received a minor qualification, which is a great shame. But let us keep it in perspective. Over the last six years, one set of accounts out of a total of 3,115 has been qualified - that is not a bad record," said Mr Reeves.

Mr Reeves, who is stepping down as NHS finance director in February after nearly seven years in the job, also claimed that this year's major injection of cash into the health service was enough to start delivering the NHS plan.

NHS funding is increasing by more than £16bn in England over the four years from April 2000, a rise that is claimed to be the most substantial increase in the service's 50-year history.

Even taking account of the rising costs of pay and prescribing, Mr Reeves said this still represented a "massive injection of resources".

In November the NHS executive announced an 8.5% increase in allocations to health authorities for next year. "We believe that if efficiency can increase by about 2%, then about 5% will be needed to respond to the various cost pressures such as activity, prescribing, pay, prices and pensions," he said.

"This leaves us with about 3%, or approximately £1bn, for implementing the NHS plan in areas such as waiting, coronary heart disease and cancer. I believe this will provide us with a very solid foundation on which to build the NHS plan."

But Mr Reeves admitted that implementing the plan would be challenging. "We need more staff, more undergraduate medical students, more consultants, more GPs and more nurses.

"We need an improved infrastructure - we have done very well at the private finance initiative and public private partnerships over the past three years but we need to do even better."

He added: "We need more hospital schemes, better primary care premises, more acute and intermediate care beds and a greater focus on information technology."

Mr Reeves was speaking to NHS finance managers at the annual conference of the Healthcare Financial Management Association in central London.

webTitle: Prison leavers and former soldiers to get housing priority

fields.headline: Prison leavers and former soldiers to get housing priority
fields.trailText: Freed criminals, former soldiers and care leavers are to be allowed to go to the top of council house queues in a radical shake up of homelessness policy. By Oliver Finegold
fields.body:
Freed criminals, former soldiers and people brought up in care are to be allowed to go to the top of council house queues in a radical shake up of homelessness policy.

The homes bill announced in the Queen's speech yesterday has widened the definition of people who are homeless. It also reverses the Tories' removal of the duty on local authorities to find permanent housing for homeless families. Local authorities are still obliged to find temporary accommodation for all homeless people under the new bill.

The bill reintroduces the legal obligation on local authorities to provide temporary accommodation for people who have come out of "institutions" - such as former members of the armed forces, teenagers leaving local authority care and young offenders released from prison. These categories of homelessness were scrapped by the Conservative government under the Housing Act 1996.

Around 1,000 people are believed to sleep rough, with many thousand more in temporary accommodation or "sleeping on friends' floors".

It also extends the right to housing to homeless young people leaving care and those between the ages of 16 and 18 and ties in with government policy of reducing rough sleeping by two-thirds by 2002.

The bill, published next week, has been broadly welcomed by housing groups, who said it bridged a vital gap in existing provision.

"This bill has a lot of things in it which we approve of because it widens the definition of who is homeless. It will provide much needed cover to more vulnerable groups of people - especially 16 and 17-year-olds," said Helen Williams, National Housing Federation policy officer.

The Local Government Association said it supported the main thrust of the bill, which it sees as a platform to deliver local solutions to homelessness problems, while ensuring there is a "safety net" for the most vulnerable members in society.

The bill will also pave the way for the first census of "rough sleepers" in England and Wales by requesting councils to record the number of homeless peoples in their boundaries once a year. Local authorities argue that the census will help them to determine whether they have set aside enough housing for the homeless.

Manchester city council said the bill will act as a "useful gauge" in assessing how well they are tackling the problem of homelessness. A Birmingham council spokesman said he hoped it will strengthen ties between officers and local housing groups.

Under the Housing Act 1996, people with disabilities or who have children can get priority but those who are simply homeless cannot. New allocation policies in the act also led to homeless people losing their automatic priority in the queue for a permanent home. This, the Tories argued, was to stop people deliberately sleeping on the street for a period in order to jump the queue.

The 1996 act, however, replaced what was essentially a 20-year duty on homelessness based on the Homeless Persons Act 1977 and reaffirmed in the Housing Act 1985. In so doing, it removed the duty of councils to provide permanent accommodation to applicants accepted as homeless and in priority need.

A spokesman for housing charity Shelter said: "The 1996 act meant that some people were not being given official homeless status. It also meant that councils which did not regularly review their lists were sometimes forced to have a 'clean out'.

"This new homes bill should swing back the pendulum towards local authorities and will place pressure on them to find temporary accommodation for some of the most vulnerable people in society."

fields.headline: Paternity tales
fields.trailText: Two working fathers share their experiences
fields.body:
Flexible approach
Geoff Meall, 31, is a booking agent for bands which include Super Furry Animals, the Last Poets and Barenaked Ladies, and lives in north London. His sons, Luca and Charlie, are three and two years old.

"When we had our first child, he had to have an operation when he was just seven days old. He came home in the morning and had to be rushed to hospital the same night.

"My second son, born 13 months later, was six weeks premature and my partner was in hospital for 19 days after the birth. So I was looking after the oldest while visiting my partner in hospital for nearly three weeks.

"I was in an unusual position at work, in that we are not self-employed but my boss is very flexible about the time we can take off. I took off quite a bit of time when the two boys were born and my boss just gave me the nod that I could take it as paternity leave.

"The proposed paternity leave wouldn't actually have made any difference to me, as we do our own hours and there is no rigid 9-5 culture. As long as I bring in the commissions, I can work the hours I like.

"Having said that, I do spend a lot of time going to see the bands when they are on tour, as I am their representative for their live career. The more time you take off, the more work you have to do when you eventually get back to work."

Generous allowance
Anselm Gurney, 34, is a recreation manager at mid Suffolk leisure centre. His daughter, Martha, is three months old.

"I would have liked the extra time off that has been proposed. I got five days' paternity leave under the local authority guidelines and the time off was paid the same as a holiday would have been.

"I also took two weeks off as holiday, one week at a time, in the first month after Martha had been born, in additional to the paternity leave.

"The time off that the local authority allows is quite generous compared with the private sector, where some companies don't allow paternity leave at all.

"From an employer's point of view it might become more difficult if the paternity leave meant that you were losing a key member of staff for a longer period of time. On balance, though, I think it is probably better that the father gets the extra time off with his child.

"It seems unfair to assume that the father should have to be at work on the day the baby is born, or very soon afterwards. I can see, however, that the extra leave might have a greater impact on a smaller company, where the loss of a manager or key member of staff for two or three weeks would have a more significant effect.

"If you wanted to be much more radical, one way to make leave more equal would be to allow the mother to go back to work early while the father continued with the equivalent of maternity leave.

"This might make sense for couples where the father has decided that long term he is going to give up his job but his partner is going to go back to work. That type of role reversal would be fairer to both men and women."

 Interviews by Marianne Curphey

fields.headline: Outstanding progress in surprising places
fields.standfirst: Primary results Blunkett welcomes evidence of success of government's numeracy and literacy strategies
fields.trailText: Outstanding performances in surprising places illuminate the government's performance tables for primary schools in England, published in the Guardian today.
fields.body:
Outstanding performances in surprising places illuminate the government's performance tables for primary schools in England, published in the Guardian today.

The most dramatic year-on-year improvement in test scores was at Cleeve primary in the notorious Bransholme district of Hull, the biggest council estate in Europe.

And the government's list of most improved schools, which measures increases in national test scores in English, maths and science from 1997-2000, is headed by two schools in deprived parts of Rotherham, Dalton Foljambe school and St Joseph's Catholic primary school.

It is a measure of the improvements that all local education authorities have better results overall, by some distance, than the average in 1996. Only the city of Nottingham has overall results below the average in 1997 and 1998 - fuel to the government's claim that the improvements in literacy and numeracy are percolating to all parts.

The government looks on course to hit its target of 80% reaching level four in English and 75% in maths by 2002. This year 75% achieved the required level in English and 72% in maths. In science, 85% achieved level four.

The National Association of Head Teachers said the performance tables should start including results for the higher level five, which about a quar ter of pupils achieve, and lower levels.

David Blunkett, who threatened to resign if the level four targets were not met, said results in the 25 education action zones were improving by more than the national average.

The education secretary said: "These results are very good and show how well the government's literacy and numeracy strategies have been working. The decision to introduce phonics, grammar and whole class maths teaching to all schools was not without opposition, but the challenge has been embraced by teachers and schools across the country."

Based on primary school results, the best-performing local education authority is Richmond-upon-Thames in London, followed by Rutland, Wokingham, Surrey, and the Isles of Scilly.

Nottingham has the worst overall results and the poorest results in English and science. The London borough of Hackney, and Bradford (which has the worst maths results), are respectively the second and third worst performing LEAs.

In 148 schools, all pupils achieved level four in English, maths and science. Shenington C of E primary in Banbury, Oxfordshire, maintained its record of achieving 100% in all subjects every year since the tests began. Its head, Coral Jessop-Burnell, described the record as "a millstone". Next year she expects to have only nine children taking the tests, which would mean she would not have to report her results. "I'll be glad to take the opportunity to drop out of this silly contest," she said.

Hutton Rudby school in North Yorkshire got 100% for the fourth year running.

Of all schools to achieve 100%, Yeadon Westfield junior, on the edge of Leeds, achieved it with the greatest number of pupils taking the exam, 54 - making it arguably the top primary school in England. "I don't feel the best," said headteacher Phil Metcalf.

Mr Metcalf, who also marks science papers, said exams had become more predictable. "There is a limited number of ways you can frame a question. You can tell - it's a very small curriculum in science."

Wandle primary school in Earlsfield, south-west London, achieved the lowest overall score, with just six of its 29 pupils achieving level four in English and three in maths and science.

Paul Larkey, the headteacher, said 38% of the pupils had joined part way through the year. The school is surrounded by prosperous homeowners but itself serves the difficult Henry Prince estate. More than half the children speak English as a second language and 60% are on free school meals.

But he said: "There is a very good atmosphere in school at the moment and I'd like to be talking to you in a year's time, when the school will be unrecognisable."

webTitle: Determined teachers get 'no hope' Cleeve soaring up the league

fields.headline: Determined teachers get 'no hope' Cleeve soaring up the league
fields.trailText: "The long held view is that if you live in HU7, you haven't got a hope of a job," said Steve Graham, head teacher of Cleeve primary.
fields.body:
"The long held view is that if you live in HU7, you haven't got a hope of a job," said Steve Graham, head teacher of Cleeve primary.

But his school - same postcode, same Barnsholme estate which more often makes the newspapers because of crimes and drugs - has shown more dramatic improvements in its test scores than any other this year.

The proportion of 11-year-old pupils reaching level four, the accepted benchmark, in English has soared from 32% in 1999 to 78% this year, and in maths from 37% to 71%. In science, 98% got level four.

It is all the more impressive against the wider context of the city, whose secondary schools achieved the worst results in the country this year. "We have a low achievement culture. Over the years it is apparent that self esteem has reached rock bottom," said Mr Graham.

About half his children have special educational needs, though that has gone down from over 60% a few years back. But Mr Graham is hands-on and determined. So are his teachers, much praised by inspectors.

Money from the education action zone has oiled wheels. A 12-point improvement plan became a 22-point one. And the school set specific targets.

About 10 were taken out of the class and given special help. "We looked at the children who would normally have achieved level three and we decided we had to put strategies in place to achieve level four.

"That has had a knock-on effect; we've moved a huge number of level fours to level five. And some of the children become more confident - we had a level three who actually achieved a level five."

The government is keen to credit the literacy and numeracy strategies, and Mr Graham would not argue with that.

"The strategies have been very beneficial in terms of extra input ... the numeracy strategy has had a big impact in terms of the change of approach.

"Writing was a big issue for us - in general I would say the improved English results are a result of our improvements in writing. Our reading was always pretty solid but we put in place a timetable for improving writing so that by the time they reached the end of school they knew how to structure a story."

Through the education action zone, for nine weeks the school had an extra teacher every morning. They got extra money to fund "early intervention" on potentially problem children. And Ofsted's verdict that their computer suite was "totally inadequate" has helped get another £20,000 out of the action zone to upgrade equipment. The lottery's opportunities fund will help pay for a steel band.

The school is open every night and weekends. The area is improving, slowly. And parents are taking more of an interest, slowly. "Having had the Ofsted and then getting the results, it's a really big plus for us," said Mr Graham. "If they are told they are good teachers but they don't get the results, it's a big anti-climax."

It is a common fear of primary school teachers that their well-balanced, well-educated youngsters may have their gains knocked out of them through difficult adolescence. But if that worries Mr Graham, it does not show.

"I don't want to lose sight of the fact that what we are in it for is to give these children a start in life," he said. "It would not necessarily be academic; it might be in arts or music or sport. I feel they ought to have the opportunities they deserve.

"We have got to lift the profile of the city and one of the ways you do that is through education. I'm optimistic."

webTitle: Dedicated staff the key to a troubled city school's vast improvement

fields.headline: Dedicated staff the key to a troubled city school's vast improvement
fields.trailText: Lawdale junior school in Tower Hamlets, in London's east end is this week enjoying a double celebration. As well as being ranked the 23rd most   improved primary school in England by the Department for Education and Employment - it has also just been told by the schools watchdog Ofsted that it is being removed from special measures.
fields.body:
Lawdale junior school in Tower Hamlets, in London's east end is this week enjoying a double celebration. As well as being ranked the 23rd most improved primary school in England by the Department for Education and Employment - it has also just been told by the schools watchdog Ofsted that it is being removed from special measures.

Headteacher Tim McLoughlin was understandably happy at the news, although he pointed out that he had scarcely been in the job long enough to be credited with engineering the dramatic turnaround.

He paid tribute to his hard-working staff, "who were prepared to stick it out and stay with the school when others might have gone elsewhere". A supportive local education authority and governing body have also been instrumental in achieving the transformation.

The school's position in the tables is down to aggregate scores in its key stage two test results increase from just 49 in 1997 to 215 this year. The most marked increase has been in English - no mean feat given the high proportion of youngsters for whom it is a second language. Over half the pupils are Bangladeshi, and many are now asked to read the school's newsletters to their parents as part of their homework.

In 1996-97 already-poor science and maths results were even worse, with only two pupils achieving the required standard in science.

The 20-storey tower block outside Mr McLoughlin's office window says much about the catchment area of the inner city junior school, which draws its 275 pupils (aged 7-11) from the sprawling council estates and terraces clustered nearby. Around 75% of pupils are entitled to school meals - not high by local standards but well above the national average. The school was finally put into special measures - the official term for failing - in January 1999 - after steady decline led to it being identified by Ofsted as having 'serious weaknesses'.

Mr McLoughlin joined as headteacher in September last year - the fourth head in a year. "It was a difficult time for the staff but they were so optimistic and determined to try and improve things. I felt the school had enormous potential". He agreed he took on an enormous challenge in swapping his previous post as deputy head of a primary school in a leafy Bristol suburb for the unknown territory of a failing inner city school. "I was appointed in April last year", he said, "but I spent quite a lot of time between then and September travelling up to London and meeting inspectors. It was important to get a feel for the place."

Once in the school, Mr McLoughlin could not afford to waste any time, despite the distractions of a major refurbishment when the tatty Victorian building was re-modelled and redecorated. An Ofsted manual titled Learning Lessons from Special Measures was invaluable in helping to draw up the school's action plan for improvement. Priorities were identified which included raising the attainment in science, English, maths and information and communica tions and technology; improving the quality of teaching; and introducing a system of monitoring individual pupil progress and attainment using target-setting.

The school has been built on the government's literacy and numeracy strategies, with extra tuition in spelling, for example, for pupils who need particular help. The core teaching staff are backed up by a support team of bilingual classroom assistants and special needs staff. Booster classes for year six pupils before this year's tests were also highly effective.

Mr McLoughlin believes the special measures label helped the school to focus on the action it had to take, although understandably he is not a fan of the word "failing", which is difficult to shake off.

"In all the adverts for staff I've placed I've said this is one of Tower Hamlets' most improving schools. But there is still a lot more work to do".

webTitle: Future care to be provided by cyber doctors

fields.headline: Future care to be provided by cyber doctors
fields.trailText: Patients' first contact with the NHS in 20 years time will be via interactive "cyber-physicians" accessed through domestic television sets, according to a government-sponsored study. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Patients' first contact with the NHS in 20 years time will be via interactive "cyber-physicians" accessed through domestic television sets, according to a government-sponsored study.

Patients will be able to electronically access their medical records from home using a swipe card, and monitor their illness recovery programmes without visiting a hospital or GP surgery.

This and other developments in information technology, science and genetics will revolutionise healthcare, says the report, published today by Foresight, a Department of Trade and Industry sponsored research body, tasked with looking at how developments in science and industry will affect the UK society in the future.

It predicts that many traditional forms of hospital-based, face-to face care delivered by health professionals will disappear as new technologies transform the way healthcare is provided.

Other predictions in the report, Healthcare 2020, include:
 Patient interest groups will gain greater power as they organise on an international basis. Rather than volunteering for clinical trials, disease groups may strike deals with companies for services or cash in return for their involvement
 Each patient will have his or her "health biography" containing clinical, genetic and other personal details held in encrypted form on the internet. Patients would own their record and be able to sell it to private companies
 Much hospital based care will be carried out at home, using internet-based advice, with care and advice provided by community pharmacists, and lay health advocates

But the report admits that NHS is not currently geared up to properly exploit the possibilities of technology. "It is widely recognised that the organisation is at least a decade behind the commercial sector in information technology and its uses."

The panel was chaired by Sir Michael Peckham, of University College London's school of public policy. Sir Michael is a former head of NHS research and development.

The report says that within two decades, most NHS services and health service research and development, may be carried out by licensed non-public service providers.

"It is conceivable that the NHS in 20 years time will concentrate on the developmental aspects of health care and on the use of its brand name to permit a range of carefully chosen organisations to provide specific services to explicit quality standards," says the report.

But the report, which builds up a picture of UK healthcare in 2020, also believes the essential principles of the NHS - of universal care free at the point of delivery - will survive, not least because of because its value to the UK economy.

"The opportunities for society in terms of physical, mental and economic health offered by comprehensive health care are clear," the report adds.

"A comprehensive national system with universal coverage and registration such as the NHS offers great potential advantages, particularly in terms of access to health care and equity of outcome.

"This will be increasingly important as new growth areas, such as genomics and informatics, risk exacerbating disparities between individuals and groups in society."

webTitle: Rangers home for Christmas once more

fields.headline: Rangers home for Christmas once more
fields.trailText: Kaiserslautern swept to a 3-0 victory over Rangers in a rain-sodden Uefa Cup third-round, second-leg match this afternoon to reach the last sixteen 3-1 on aggregate.
fields.body:
Kaiserslautern swept to a 3-0 victory over Rangers in a rain-sodden Uefa Cup third-round, second-leg match this afternoon to reach the last sixteen 3-1 on aggregate.

Miroslav Klose opened the scoring in the eighth minute, dribbling his way past Scott Wilson before flicking the ball past goalkeeper Stefan Klos.

Andreas Buck scored the crucial second goal in the 65th minute with a high-speed breakaway and Vratislav Lokvenc's close-range header in the 79th minute sent the Glasgow giants out of Europe before Christmas once again.

"The team gained a lot of confidence from the early goal," said Kaiserslautern's coach Andreas Brehme. "It was a well-deserved win."

webTitle: Telecoms network 'too small' for next phase of mobiles

fields.headline: Telecoms network 'too small' for next phase of mobiles
fields.trailText: Debt-laden telecoms companies face further financial woe when they build networks for the next wave of mobile phones, according to experts, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Debt-laden telecoms companies face further financial woe when they build networks for the next wave of mobile phones, according to experts.

Quotient Communications, which advised the UK government on the mobile phone licence auction this spring, has warned that the current system will not be able to support new services such as video conferencing, internet browsing and email.

Rodney Stewart, managing director of Quotient, said: "It has dawned on us that everyone in the third-generation mobile phone business is quite low on the learning curve. They are not fully aware of what they are dealing with."

By simulating a 3G network in Cambridge, Quotient discovered that doubling the amount of base stations, which transmit mobile phone traffic, might not be enough to run the network.

It found that holes appeared in network coverage when email and video services were added to voice calls and internet browsing.

"It will affect operators' investments in mobile phone licences and therefore their costs. It might result in an increase in their financial burden, and this is why they have to do more analysis," added Mr Stewart.

However, a spokesperson for BT Wireless, the mobile phone arm of the UK telecoms giant, said BT is already increasing the number of base stations for its networks, and is fully aware of the problems it faces.

"We have drawn up our plans for 3G development and there is a high degree of awareness in the industry," said the spokesman.

Quotient estimates that the five licence holders, which include Vodafone, BT, Orange, One2One and Hutchison, will have to pay between £1bn and £2bn to build their networks.

The auction raised an astonishing £22bn for the UK government.

Telecoms operators are under financial pressure due to the cost of securing European mobile phone licences and rolling out the new systems.

German mobile phone operator Mobilcom has admitted it is struggling to raise the funds to build a network.

Concern is mounting that telecoms companies will not be able to pay off their huge investments if the networks fail, or consumers fail to take up services such as video and music downloads over a handset.

fields.headline: NewsCorp-backed web firm closes
fields.trailText: NewsCorp-backed internet firm eVentures has been shut down with the loss of 12 jobs, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
News Corporation-backed internet firm eVentures has been shut down after joint shareholder Softbank decided the business model was not viable.

The outfit has been closed with the loss of 12 jobs.

eVentures was part of a business set up last year by Mark Booth, former chief executive officer at BSkyB.

His company, ePartners, launched eVentures in partnership with Japanese internet investor Softbank. Each party invested £35m to get the business off the ground.

Mr Booth said eVentures was being shut down because stock market conditions were too tough to bring US dot.coms to the UK.

Since its high-profile launch, eVentures has only managed to introduce two UK versions of US websites: E-loan.com and buy.com.

E-loan.com has since been sold to E-loan Europe, while Buy.com remains jointly owned by Softbank and ePartners.

eVentures started to look shaky in the summer after a number of management departures and the closure of its business-to-consumer division.

The news will come as a blow to NewsCorp chairman Rupert Murdoch, who has struggled to make a mark in the new media world, following the closure of Delphi Internet and Currantbun.com and the axe hovering over Firedup.com and Revolver.com.

Softbank has also pulled the plug on @viso, a £310m joint venture with Vivendi in France.

fields.headline: Tears at Damilola's memorial service
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Damilola Taylor's brother paid moving tribute to the murdered boy today at a memorial service in the church the family attended.
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor's brother paid moving tribute to the murdered boy today at a memorial service in the church the family attended.

More than 1,000 people, including the Home Office minister Paul Boateng and the local MP Harriet Harman, were at the Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries to pay their respects to the 10-year-old who bled to death in a Peckham stairwell 10 days ago.

Tunde, Damilola's 21-year-old brother, apologised to his little brother for not having been there to protect him.

"Please forgive me for not being there for you. I am deeply sorry for not being there for you," he said.

Loud sobs came from the mourners as Tunde delivered his emotional tribute. His father went to his side to support him as he took deep breaths to overcome his emotion.

Tunde said Damilola had brought great joy and happiness to the Taylor family. "He was a God-fearing, friendly, intelligent, loveable boy that any expectant mother would always like to have. He is part of my life that can never be erased."

Addressing Damilola, he continued: " My life can never be the same without you. I always wanted a brother, to share things with each other and obviously someone I could properly call my brother." In Nigerian culture a younger person must address all older men as either uncle or brother.

Tunde continued: "Damilola only spent 10 years of his life but there was never any time when he was sick. He was a healthy, strong boy. Mostly he enjoyed playing football. Damilola, I can go on and on if I have to talk about you."

He expressed his thanks to the police and to everybody who had supported his family.

Mr Boateng paid tribute to Damilola as a "bright rising star".

"Respect and love were at the heart of Damilola's life," he said. "Respect for his parents, respect for his big brother, respect for his teachers and respect for authority."

He urged people with information about the killing to come forward. "Speak, speak, tell the police what you saw."

Mr Boateng also indicated that there should be more police officers, saying that we need "new faces on the beat".

"We know that, we respect that and we are determined that you will have that. But you know that it counts for nothing without love and respect. Love for one another whatever colour we are, whether we are African or Caribbean - yes, that too."

Fighting back tears, he said that these were the values Mr Taylor and his family had taught Damilola. "I hope and pray you can teach us too."

He added: "God bless Damilola, God keep his family and God help us find again those values of respect and love."

The Rev Joel Edwards, general director of the million-strong Evangelical Alliance of which the church is a part, told the congregation that Damilola's death was an "absolute catastrophe".

"All of us must do all we can for the rhetoric and the publicity to ensure that we work together for a better community."

He said the police, politicians and the churches could not solve the problems of crime and community alone. But he said the greatest "desecration" of Damilola's memory would be to let the publicity and political reaction obscure the pain of his death.

Damilola's father Richard, 55, put his arm round the boy's mother, Gloria, 49, as they arrived with Tunde at the church in Old Kent Road.

It is the church Damilola had attended three times a week with his family since they arrived in Britain from Nigeria four months ago.

Today's service replaces what should have been a celebration of the boy's 11th birthday. His father said Damilola had planned to mark the day by taking treats to school and sharing them with his friends.

The service was conducted by Pastor Olukayode Owolabi, who knew Damilola personally as the schoolboy used to attend Sunday school at the Pentecostal church.

Two Bible readings were taken from the Old Testament Book of Genesis, recounting the story of Joseph, who was bullied, thrown down a pit by his brothers and cast out of society, but who later recovered and prospered.

Hymns sung at the service were Rock of Ages, Abide with Me and Blessed Assurance, with three more special songs being sung by children of the church's choir.

Earlier a small group of Damilola's Sunday school friends sang a moving tribute to him entitled Thank You Lord. One said it had been a "privilege" to know Damilola. Damilola's father wept as a short piece of saxophone music was played.

The Metropolitan Police were represented at the service at a very high level by Commander Joe Kay. The borough commander, Acting Chief Superintendent Rod Jarman, could not attend because he was deeply involved in the murder investigation.

Organisers of the memorial service, which was put together in less than 48 hours, today received apologies for absence from the Prince of Wales, the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, and the home secretary, Jack Straw.

webTitle: Protesters and police clash at EU summit

fields.headline: Protesters and police clash at EU summit
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Riot police fought pitched battles with anti-capitalism protesters today as the opening of the EU summit in Nice descended into mayhem.
fields.body:
Riot police fought pitched battles with anti-capitalism protesters today as the opening of the EU summit in Nice descended into mayhem.

Teargas grenades were used on protesters and acrid clouds of the gas hung outside the conference centre in the south of France as the 15 heads of state and government prepared to meet leaders of applicant countries wanting full European Union status.

And as the prime minister, Tony Blair, flew into the Mediterranean resort for what is likely to prove the most challenging EU summit of his premiership, his predecessor John Major urged the European commission to show it did not want to create a European superstate.

Mr Blair is facing pressure to give up the British veto on taxation and border controls - something he has vowed to resist - as part of the drive to streamline the swollen EU procedures ahead of enlargement.

Meanwhile Mr Major called on commissioners to end speculation about a federal Europe by publishing a clear draft statement setting out how far they wanted to see EU powers grow.

The EU foreign affairs commissioner Chris Patten, a former Tory party chairman, insisted that the threat of a federal Europe was "about as likely as the discovery that the moon is made of cheese".

But the Tory leader, William Hague, accused Mr Blair of losing control of the situation in Europe and warned that he would concede too much to Britain's EU partners.

Over the three day summit, the EU is likely to give final approval for a strategy of intensified negotiations that could see the top candidates from the 13 applicant eastern European nations joining the EU by 2004.

Jacek Saryusz-Wolski, Poland's minister for European affairs, said: "The Europe of today has to take the opportunity offered by the courageous changes in Eastern Europe to unite the continent." Poland is among the leading group of candidates, along with Hungary, Slovenia, Estonia, Cyprus and the Czech Republic.

In Nice, what the French had hoped would be a dignified summit ending with an historic treaty, began with running battles between hundreds of anti-globalisation demonstrators and police.

Protesters hurled fireworks and furniture at the police, who responded with volleys of teargas grenades and what sounded at times like stun grenades.

Up to 50,000 demonstrators took to the streets and there was alarm in diplomatic circles that they had come so close to the main conference venue.

A pall of choking teargas greeted the dignitaries as they arrived at the Acropolis centre in the heart of this normally tranquil Riviera city, popular with French retirees and sun-seekers.

The French president, Jacques Chirac, who is hosting the summit, sneezed as he entered the mammoth, concrete building.

A fragmented group of several hundred Spanish anarchists, radical trade unionists, Basque and Corsican separatists fought pitched battles with the police as they sought to break through the ring of steel encircling the Acropolis.

On one occasion, the demonstrators fought their way to within 100m of the centre's main entrance.

A crowd attacked the car of a motorist who had collided with several protesters. Using sticks and pipes, they smashed the windows and forced the driver to flee in reverse. Undeterred, he again scattered demonstrators like dominoes.

Two blocks from the Acropolis, a bank was set on fire, and protesters, some masked, attacked the fire engine that came to extinguish the flames. But the blaze was quickly put out.

Protesters then turned on a real estate agency, smashing windows as terrified staff fled to an inner courtyard. Owner Luc Mercier said, "I feel discouraged and disgusted. They attacked the windows with sledgehammers. I am happy that no one was injured."

Banks and businesses were covered in graffiti - with slogans ranging from "Long live Eta," referring to the Basque separatist terrorists, to "Death to money."

At least 20 police officers were lightly injured in the clashes and two protesters were detained.

By midmorning, the worst of the violence seemed to be over - and an uneasy calm descended. However, Mr Mercier said: "This summit lasts three days. What will happen over three days?"

Some of the protesters who had taken part in an early march, were angry about the later descent into violence. Javier Pla, a 20-year-old student from Valencia in Spain, equipped with a gas mask, said: "We are peaceful protesters. We don't want any violence. These people are terrorists."

In Nice, what the French had hoped would be a dignified summit ending with an historic treaty, began with running battles between hundreds of anti-globalisation demonstrators and police. Protesters hurled fireworks and furniture at the police, who responded with volleys of teargas grenades and what sounded at times like stun grenades. Up to 50,000 demonstrators took to the streets and there was alarm in diplomatic circles that they had come so close to the main conference venue. A pall of choking teargas greeted the dignitaries as they arrived at the Acropolis centre in the heart of this normally tranquil Riviera city, popular with French retirees and sun-seekers. The French president, Jacques Chirac, who is hosting the summit, sneezed as he entered the mammoth, concrete building. A fragmented group of several hundred Spanish anarchists, radical trade unionists, Basque and Corsican separatists fought pitched battles with the police as they sought to break through the ring of steel encircling the Acropolis. On one occasion, the demonstrators fought their way to within 100m of the centre's main entrance. A crowd attacked the car of a motorist who had collided with several protesters. Using sticks and pipes, they smashed the windows and forced the driver to flee in reverse. Undeterred, he again scattered demonstrators like dominoes. Two blocks from the Acropolis, a bank was set on fire, and protesters, some masked, attacked the fire engine that came to extinguish the flames. But the blaze was quickly put out. Protesters then turned on a real estate agency, smashing windows as terrified staff fled to an inner courtyard. Owner Luc Mercier said, "I feel discouraged and disgusted. They attacked the windows with sledgehammers. I am happy that no one was injured." Banks and businesses were covered in graffiti - with slogans ranging from "Long live Eta," referring to the Basque separatist terrorists, to "Death to money." At least 20 police officers were lightly injured in the clashes and two protesters were detained. By midmorning, the worst of the violence seemed to be over - and an uneasy calm descended. However, Mr Mercier said: "This summit lasts three days. What will happen over three days?" Some of the protesters who had taken part in an early march, were angry about the later descent into violence. Javier Pla, a 20-year-old student from Valencia in Spain, equipped with a gas mask, said: "We are peaceful protesters. We don't want any violence. These people are terrorists." fields.headline: Trawling for abuse victims defended
fields.trailText: Police have defended the trawling methods used in investigating past abuse in children's homes and said they would continue to use them despite criticism that they were touting for victims.
fields.body:
Police yesterday defended the trawling methods used in investigating past abuse in children's homes and said they would continue to use them despite criticism that they were touting for victims.

After the former manager of Southampton football club, David Jones, was cleared of care home child abuse when his trial collapsed because an alleged victim refused to give evidence, campaigners for falsely accused carers said the "dip sampling" method used to collect evidence could lead to people fabricating stories of abuse to get compensation.

Under the method, used by Merseyside police who led the investigation against Mr Jones, officers first receive a written statement of complaint about past abuse at an institution. Police then "dip sample" people who attended the institution as children, writing to or interviewing them asking if they remember any abuse.

The assistant chief constable, Mike Tonge, of Merseyside police, said: "There is no other method of doing it. If an allegation was made about a crime committed this week, police would conduct house to house inquiries, stage reconstructions and call on the media to help us encourage witnesses to come forward.

"When an allegation relates to events that happened over 20 years ago, we can't do that. But we have to establish what the facts are and one way of doing that is contacting people who were there at the time. If there is a better way of doing it, I would love to find it."

Mr Tonge said police were not deliberately setting out to find victims, but were responding to complaints referred to them.

In the case of Mr Jones, further alleged victims had come forward after publicity over his arrest. Merseyside police's Operation Care, a model of best practice in its field, began in 1996 in response to child abuse allegations in care homes and special schools in north Wales and across the north-west.

More than 80 institutions have been investigated, leading to 27 convictions and five acquittals, including Mr Jones's.

The method has been used by other forces including Cheshire police, who three years ago spent more than £250,000 on inquiries codenamed Bugle, Emily and Granite after allegations of abuse at a children's home in Congleton.

During investigations, they traced former residents of homes where one social worker, Keith Laverack, suspected of being a career paedophile, had worked.

About 140 people were contacted by a letter which gave few details of the inquiry. Many former residents who rang a hotline in response said without prompting: "This is about Laverack, isn't it?"

He was later convicted of 11 charges of buggery and four of indecent assault on children aged 11 to 16.

A spokeswoman for Cheshire police said: "Our use of these techniques has been tested in court and, in our experience, the courts are happy with the techniques, which have resulted in a number of guilty verdicts."

Charles Mills, an Ofsted inspector and former headteacher of a residential school on Merseyside which was investigated using the method, said police had set up an office at his school to interview each of the 120 male pupils, aged between six and 18, after a former staff member was arrested over allegations relating to another home.

The police had conducted the interviews sensitively, he said, but there was a mindset that all care homes were infected with abusers. "I am not saying abuse has not occurred - it has - but the issue has been highly exaggerated."

Harry Fearns, whose brother-in-law was convicted after an Operation Care investigation, is chairman of the Campaign for Falsely Accused Carers and Teachers. "We feel that trawling methods are equal to touting for allegations. By the nature of police methodology they will collect false accusations as well as true," he said.

Stephen Pollard, David Jones's solicitor, said child abuse allegations must be more rigorously investigated to ensure innocent people did not suffer.

webTitle: M&S puts in outsiders at children's wear and food

fields.headline: M&S puts in outsiders at children's wear and food
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer has hired top name retailers to head two of its key departments - food and children's wear.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has hired top name retailers to head two of its key departments - food and children's wear.

Former Asda executive Justin King has been appointed the new head of M&S foods - which accounts for 40% of M&S's annual sales - while Michele Jobling, previously managing director of department store Liberty is to take over the children's wear operation.

Mr King, 39, joined Asda in 1993, when the supermarket was still in the early stages of its recovery. After the grocer's takeover by Wal-Mart he was appointed managing director of Wal-Mart hypermarkets UK, with responsibility for Asda's hypermarket developments and its 21 largest superstores.

His decision to quit Asda comes in the wake of other re cent high-level departures from the supermarket, including chief executive Allan Leighton and George Davies, who developed Asda's George range of clothing. There is mounting speculation that senior executives at Asda are unhappy about the way Wal-Mart is running the group.

The top job within M&S's food operation became vacant earlier this year when Roger Whiteside quit the group to start a new online grocery business. The new web retailer, which has £35m of funding from Waitrose, the John Lewis-owned supermarket, plans to launch next year.

Ms Jobling, 40, took the helm at Liberty after the store in the wake of a boardroom bust-up. She was credited with restoring some of the lost cachet of the Liberty brand before the store was sold earlier this year. She previously worked at B&Q, Sainsbury's and Tesco.

Rob Anderson, previous head of the M&S children's wear business, left in the summer.

Mr King and Ms Jobling will both report to Roger Holmes, the former Kingfisher executive who is to join M&S as managing director of UK retail in January. Mr Holmes' appointment has not been universally welcomed by City analysts, who claim that he lacks crucial experience in the food and fashion sectors.

Chairman Luc Vandevelde said: "Our aim has been to recruit the highest calibre candidates for these two key positions. We are delighted to increase the breadth of experience within the UK retail business."

Before the arrival of Mr Vandevelde, M&S rarely appointed from outside the organisation.

webTitle: Skint Ken, Poor Neil, and Tight Doug

fields.headline: Skint Ken, Poor Neil, and Tight Doug
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WARNING! The following story contains elements which may, in some unstable minds, suggest that Kuddly Ken Bates has made rather a cack hand of organising the development of the new Wembley and that his pals at the FA no longer trust him to do the job properly. This is, of course, in no way true and if your mind starts thinking in that direction we suggest a quiet drink of lithium to calm you down.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MASTER BATES

FA Chief Executive and Del Boy for the new Millennium Adam Crozier is to increase his involvement in the new Wembley stadium after troubles over financing and continued delays in demolishing the old Wembley caused fears that the whole project could end up as big an embarrassment as the Dome. Or the old Wembley.

Crozier is already on the board of the Wembley National Stadium Limited company, as are finance director Michael Cunnagh and chairman Geoff Thompson, who will also be getting involved on a day-to-day basis. But the changes look set to curtail the influence of Kuddly Ken Bates on the project, and could spell the end for the vaunted hotel and restaurant complex that Kuddly wanted to tack on the side. Plans for the world's biggest ping-pong table and a band of gibbons playing show tunes where the twin towers used to be could still get the go-ahead, however.

A scaling down does seem inevitable if the WNSL are to get the necessary investment from the city. So far, reluctance on the part of banks to invest has been blamed on a 'dead market' (the Fiver would also rather spend its money on corpses than boring old stadiums). However, after the developments today, an FA spokesman said: "If there is a need to take a step back in order to take two steps forward in the area of funding over the next few weeks, then we don't see that as a big issue." The new Wembley: the home of crown bowls. It could happen.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 7: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ANOTHER FIVER FIRST: A STORY ABOUT SOMEONE CALLED LENNON WITH NO UNNECESSARY MENTION OF A CERTAIN LATE POPULAR ENTERTAINER OR ANY RELATED UPCOMING ANNIVERSARIES

Every young lad from Northern Ireland would jump at the chance to wear the green and white hoops of Celtic Football Club (note to sub: check this if you can spare a minute). So it's no surprise that Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon was willing to agree to a "big drop" in his £30,000-a-week wages just so he could realise his dream. And don't you dare accuse the suits at the 18th-richest club in the world of taking advantage of the situation.

"I am very excited at the prospect of becoming a Celtic player and I just can't wait to get up there and see the place for myself," said the down-on-his-uppers combative midfielder. "I hope the fans, who have always been good to me here, will understand that the chance to join Celtic may not come around again and I had to take it," Lennon continued, his lilting brogue barely audible over the tinkling of bawbies cascading from his tattered pocket.

Leicester will look to fill the hole left by their departing pauper by spending all of the £6m transfer fee on new players: Derby's Seth Johnson and Jody Morris of Chelsea are said to be targets. In the meantime, however, Peter Taylor will have to name Stefan Oakes in his team, which may, more than anything, explain why the manager is "very disappointed" at Lennon's exit.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"While we do not want to be seen as spoilsports, there are regulations. This is the first case of its kind we have had but we cannot have players using nicknames or in-jokes" - A Football League spokesman after Neil Ruddock was fined £100 for having RAZOR on the back of his shirt. Really, there's no need to apologise.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE SHARPEST TOOL IN THE BOX

John Gregory, football's Mr You-Haven't-Got-Any-Half-Decent-Strikers-Going-Spare-Have-You?, looks like he could be on to a winner in his long-running pursuit of Celta Vigo's Benni McCarthy. And, what's more, he's managed to do it while both unsettling the player and staying on the moral high ground at the same time. If we didn't know any better, we'd say the boy Greg is learning.

According to McCarthy's agent, the £10m-rated striker has told Celta he wants out. Of the cupboard they've locked him in since Greg first came a-calling a few months ago. This is good news for Villa and also resembles the situation involving a certain G Southgate - something that hasn't been lost on football's Mr Ooh-Ain't-That-A-Coincidence. "He has put himself in a position similar to Gareth Southgate did with us in the summer and it's not fair for the situation to drag on indefinitely," Greg said. "He either has to come to us or get his head down and focus on Celta Vigo."

Drawing the lesson to a close, Greg said: "We have set a deadline of December 15 for the deal to be done. If Benni McCarthy is not with us by then we will walk away once and for all." Since the consensus seems to be that the only reason McCarthy has not yet moved to Villa Park is that Deadly Doug Ellis has not offered enough money, this is quite cute on Gregory's part, forcing the Galician club (not exactly rolling in money) to make the decisive move. John Gregory - footballing mastermind. Honestly, it's a wonderful world.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Barcelona are still interested in Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, according to Planet Football. Chelsea are unlikely to get rid of their £15m striker, but the Catalan side (we thought about calling them giants, but decided against it) could offer a whole heap of players, including Dani and Boudewijn Zenden, in part-exchange.

Goalkeeper Matt Clarke could leave Bradford after rumours linked him with a £5m move to Arsenal. "If one day he has the chance to move to a bigger club we would not stand in his way," said Jim Jefferies today.

Liverpool have denied reports in the Yorkshire Evening Post linking them with a move for Internazionale's Robbie Keane.

Newcastle have been linked with a loan move for Blackburn striker Egil Ostenstad.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Malmo director of football Hasse Borg has claimed that Arsenal want to sign his striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic. "The interest has been there for a good while," said Borg. "They have watched Zlatan in several matches during the season. We have told Arsenal that Zlatan is not for sale."

Hearts striker Darren Jackson has admitted that he was "gutted" by the club's decision to allow him to leave. "I am very disappointed at the decision as I feel I still have three years playing in me. I am gutted at what has happened," he said. "Financially, I suppose I can understand it. But if you look at it in terms of players capable of playing in the first team, you can't just get rid of players for the sake of it."

Manchester City have given defender Richard Jobson a free transfer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match of the Day - Live (8pm) A nice easy European tie for Liverpool against a team with an abysmal away record. Oh dear oh dearie me.

ITV: World Football (3.15am) Hold on this is the second football programme on terrestrial television today! There's something you don't see too often.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.50am) Three! Good God! Are we in heaven?

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12midnight) A fourth?!? Look, you'll have to stop soon. This fare is too rich for our austere tastes.

Dutch Football (12.30am) Argh! For Christ's sake will you pack it in? Five free-to-view football programmes in one day really is too much.

Argentinian Football (2.10am) That's it, we've haemorrhaged. Happy now?

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 4.30am) The McCaff story, part three: Rob soon became a news producer on Radio Shropshire! Before anybody knew it, he was whisked away by Granada Television to make his screen debut as a reporter and presenter of popular regional football round-up programme The Elton Welsby Experience.

Australian Soccer League (3.30am) "I can't get near the goal for all these portable barbecues, Bruce." "Never mind, Bruce, I couldn't cross the ball to you anyway, because I'm trapped under this big crate of tinnies."

Sky Sports 3: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1 12.30am SS1) Re-re-view. The crowd say Bolton Wanderers.

Fifa TV (7pm, 12midnight SS1) Football's world governing body discovers the power of television. This could have serious implications for the game as we know it.

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am SS1) Like the Premiership except it actually holds your interest.

Classic World Cup Football (10pm) This 1974 match between East Germany and West Germany is "memorable", so we're led to believe.

British Eurosport: Football (9.45pm) You've really sold us this one.

ONsport 1: Panathinaikos v Valencia (6.20pm) Do you think ONdigital

Real Madrid v Anderlecht (8.10pm) have the rights

Lazio v Leeds (10pm) to anything apart from Big Cup?

Radio 5 Live: Harry Redknapp's Reject Shop (7.30pm) What the hell is this?

5 Live Football (8pm) Hear Alan drink seven pints of water before doing something unmentionable to a Manchester United shirt.

fields.headline: Unions aim to swallow Amazon
fields.standfirst:
The internet's new economy still has the old problems, Seumas Milne reports
Net news
fields.trailText: The internet's new economy still has the old problems, Seumas Milne reports
fields.body:
The dot.com economy is supposed to have left behind trade unions and collective negotiation. But initial skirmishes between managers and union organisers at the internet giant Amazon.com in recent weeks suggest the workings of the new economy may turn out to be more familiar than previously imagined.

In the electronic retailer's home base of Seattle, union organisers from the Communication Workers of America have been busy signing up Amazon customer service reps, while across the US the United Food and Commercial Workers Union is drumming up support among the thousands who parcel up and send out the books and CDs ordered from Amazon on the internet.

Parallel recruitment drives have also been taking place among Amazon employees in Germany, France and Britain, where workers at the company's warehouse near Milton Keynes complain of low pay and gruelling shift patterns. "Amazon is a beacon of the new economy, with the wages and conditions of an old economy sweatshop," declares Greg Denier of the Washington-based UFCWU.

The company - whose 36-year-old founder Jeff Bezos made $20m from selling Amazon shares this year - is fighting back with resolutely traditional union-busting tactics.

Since news of the drive for unionisation leaked out prematurely, Amazon man agers in the US have called workers in for group and one-to-one sessions to lay out the company's case against unions - claiming, according to an internal corporate website, that they "foster distrust towards supervisors" and "create an unco-operative attitude".

Steve Frazier, Amazon's UK managing director, insists the firm is not anti-union, but "pro-customer, pro-employee and pro-shareholder - we don't currently believe that having our employees represented by a union would best allow us to achieve those three goals." He adds that Amazon's basic British wage rates of around £5 an hour are part of a "competitive package" including health cover, pension contributions and share options.

The sharp fall in dot.com share prices is, according to Peter Skyte of the British technical staff union MSF, one factor behind a new receptiveness to trade unions among new economy workers, who have in the past been prepared to tolerate poor pay and conditions in return for potentially lucrative shares.

"With the law guaranteeing employees the right to individual union representation since September, there are now no no-go areas for unions in the new economy. Our IT membership is growing by 10% a year and internet service providers in particular are ripe for the taking. The companies may be virtual, but the issues faced by staff are very real."

The main grievances centre around lack of job security and poor conditions, according to Skyte, who this autumn negotiated the first major union recognition agreement in the sector, with US-owned IT services company, CSC, covering all 7,000 of the company's UK-based employees.

The deal was a new economy breakthrough for British unions. But the traditional dot.com start-ups - a handful of nerds working in a trendy inner city loft - are likely to remain an uphill struggle for union organisers, who complain of an "anti-union culture".

Richer pickings are to be had in the internet spinoffs and extensions of long-established businesses, in finance or the media, where unions are well-established and dot.com union agreements have already been signed. The other main areas targeted for unionisation are those where, as in the Amazon case, a traditional service is being delivered online, backed up by armies of staff in warehouses and call centres. "We've got our hands full," one organiser remarks.
