webTitle: Consumer: Pick of the pocket PCs

fields.headline: Pick of the pocket PCs
fields.standfirst: The truly mobile personal computer is the latest must-have gadget, but which one of the dozens on the market is right for you? In the latest of our collaborations with the Good Housekeeping Institute, we put 12 through our own screen test
fields.trailText: The truly mobile personal computer is the latest must-have gadget, but which one of the dozens on the market is right for you? In the latest of our collaborations with the Good Housekeeping Institute, we put 12 through our own screen test.
fields.body:
If all you need is an address book, appointments diary, memo pad and calculator, an electronic personal organiser will do the trick, but if you're after a portable extension to your desktop PC, it's worth paying more for one of these mobile computerss. You'll be able to run programs such as word processors and spreadsheets, record and store voice memos, and play games and CD-quality music - without having to move up to the size, weight and price ticket of a notebook or laptop.

By attaching a modem and a phone line, you can send and receive emails, and search for and download software from the internet. And, of course, you can transfer information between your mobile and desktop PCs.

Extras, such as modems, MP3 players, memory cards, digital cameras and games, can be added to the basic unit by slotting optional modules - also known as "springboards" or expansion kits - into the basic unit.

The Good Housekeeping Institute compared 12 mobile computers for weight, size, ease of use, features and ease of interfacing (synchronising") with a PC. Eight are palmtops - which are small enough to rest in the palm of your hand, leaving the other free to input information via a touch-sensitive screen using a special stylus. The other four are handhelds, which have a separate small keyboard attached by a hinge to the display section, like a mini-laptop.

All models tested are battery operated, by either standard AA or AAA batteries or rechargeable batteries; have an infrared port for "beaming" information to another infrared device such as a mobile phone, printer or portable computer; include a stylus for activating functions on the touch-sensitive screen.

All but the Ericsson and Palm m100 have a docking cradle - useful for sitting the computer in while "synchronising" with a desktop PC.

Size is given as height x width x depth. Battery life is based on manufacturers' estimates of average use.

For this price, expect at least 16Mb of memory and word processing and spreadsheet options. Your choice is between lightweight, compact palmtops and the convenience of a handheld with its hinged keyboard.

Over £400

Compaq iPAQ H3630
£449. Score 8/10
32Mb palmtop. Size: 134x90x 20mm. Weight: 224g. Colour screen: 78x58mm. Rechargeable batteries (14-hour life) plus AC adapter. Microsoft Windows CE operating system. Voice recorder. Microsoft Reader and Money, audio and games. Microsoft Word, Excel, Pocket Streets. Optional extras: Modular expansion kit - new products available from early 2001.

Pros

Clear navigation and command buttons. Easy-to-use voice recorder. Clear home page. Easy to write on screen - you don't need to be too precise.

Cons

Instructions poor and only in CD-rom format, which is inconvenient. On-screen "wizard" not as comprehensive as others tested. Expansion kits are specific to Compaq.

Verdict: Comprehensive and easy to use.

Stockists: Compaq 0845-2704215

HP Jornada 720
£665. Score: 9/10

32Mb handheld. Size: 100x190 x34mm closed. Weight: 516g. Colour screen: 54x 150mm. Rechargeable battery (nine-hour life) and AC adapter. Modem. Microsoft Windows CE operating system. Voice recorder. Smart card reader slot. PC slot. Microsoft Word, Excel, Media Player.

Pros

Can use as a dictaphone without opening. Good colour rendition and clear screen. Extremely easy to synchronise with your PC. Simple to download and upload files and documents. Good sound quality - great for downloading music from the web. Good-sized keyboard.

Cons

Very heavy for a handheld. Quite pricey - you could get a notebook for just a fraction more.

Verdict: A good choice for the business user.

Stockists: HP 0990-474747

Psion Series 5mx
£429.95. Score: 8/10

16Mb handheld. Size 95x172x25mm closed. Weight: 361g. Monochrome screen: 133x50mm. 2xAA batteries (one-month life). EPOC operating system. Voice recorder. Microsoft Word and spreadsheet, spell-checker. Optional extras: memory cards, modem.

Pros

Sturdy construction with a good, uncluttered keyboard. Logical and well-labelled icons around the screen. If you are used to using Windows, you'll find this really easy to follow.

£300-£400

In this price range, expect to find a choice between colour-screen palmtops and monochrome-screen handhelds.

Casio Cassiopeia E125

£399.99. Score: 8/10

16Mb palmtop. Size: 135x85x25mm. Weight: 250g. Colour screen: 79x60mm. Rechargeable batteries (six-hour life) and AC adapter. Microsoft Windows for Pocket CE operating system. Voice recorder. Windows, Pocket Word and Excel, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Money and Reader, Windows Media. Optional extras: Camera and modem.

Pros

If you are used to Windows, it's useful to have Word and Excel options. Clear, sharp screen. Easy to navigate.

Cons

Instructions supplied on a CD-rom, not in print.

Verdict: Versatile performer, good value

Stockists: Casio 020-8450 9131

Ericsson MC218

£379.99. Score: 7/10

16Mb handheld. Size: 95x179x 25mm closed. Weight: 359g. Monochrome screen: 54x138mm. 2xAA batteries (one-month life). Infrared modem that connects with Ericsson phones. EPOC operating system. Voice recorder. Wap-enabled. Word, spreadsheet, games. Soft case.

Optional extras: Memory cards.

Pros

Can transfer information from your Ericsson mobile phone. Very easy-to-use voice recorder - you don't even need to open it up. Good-sized, uncluttered keyboard.

Cons

Wap lets you access selected web-sites, but you need both a phone and the handheld. Limited software options to synchronise with PC. Need the backlight to read the screen clearly, but this uses up more power. Not logical to use.

Verdict: Expensive but useful if you already have an Ericsson mobile phone.

Stockists: Ericsson 0990-237237

Palm IIIc
£300. Score: 8/10

8Mb palmtop. Size: 133x89x 15mm. Weight: 212g. Colour screen: 58x58mm. Rechargeable batteries (two-week life) and AC adapter. Palm OS operating system. Optional extras: mobile internet software, camera, modem.

Pros

Comprehensive, step-by-step instructions are given when loading the Palm Desktop program on to your PC. Good weighty stylus. Very easy to input information, particularly via the PC. Simple to synchronise with a PC.

Cons

Flimsy plastic cover. No word processing or spreadsheet options - a major drawback if you are used to Windows. Colours on screen not very sharp. Very small and dark writing area.

Verdict: Basically an organiser, but you can manage your emails and download more applications from the internet.

Stockists: Palm 020-7365 9820

Also tested:

Handspring Visor Prism palmtop (similar to Handspring Visor Deluxe, but with a colour screen) £400, 8/10.

Stockists: Handspring 020-7309 0134

HP Jornada 545 palmtop £369, 8/10.

Stockists: HP 0990-474747

Psion Revo Plus handheld £379, 7/10.

Stockists: Psion 0990-143050


At this price you would expect to get a colour screen. Not very logical to use.

Verdict: Excellent build quality.

Stockists: Psion 0990-143050

In this price range, expect to find lightweight, low-memory monochrome-screen palmtops - organisers you can link to your PC.

Below £300

Handspring Visor Deluxe

£200. Score: 7/10

8Mb palmtop. Size: 135x80x23mm. Weight: 187g. Monochrome screen: 60x60mm. 2xAAA batteries (one-month life). Palm OS operating system. Optional extras: memory modules, games, digital camera, MP3 player, modem.

Pros

Easy to use and navigate. Buttons well positioned and clearly labelled. Easy-to-remove stylus doubles as screwdriver to remove back case. Good range of expansion kits. Very easy to synchronise with a PC. Simple to input information.

Cons

Small screen. Limited font options. No word processing or spreadsheets - a drawback if you're used to using Windows. Add-on expansion kits not compatible with other PC equipment.

Verdict: Good value and easy to use.

Stockists: Handspring 020-7309 0134

Palm m100

£130. Score: 7/10

2Mb palmtop. Size: 128x83x22mm. Weight: 141g. Monochrome screen: 50x48mm. 2xAAA batteries (two-month life). Palm OS operating system. Optional extra: mobile internet software.

Pros

Contoured so fits neatly in the hand. Useful basic set-up "wizard" guides you through basic functions but needs to be more interactive. Lightweight and very compact. Very easy to synchronise with a PC.

Cons

Small screen, sometimes difficult to read characters. Fiddly to input information. No word processing or spreadsheets - a drawback if you're used to using Windows. Screen cover doesn't feel very secure.

Verdict: Not very versatile, more like a personal organiser.

Stockists: Palm 020-7365 9820

Also tested:

Palm Vx palmtop £299.99, 7/10.

Stockists: Palm 020-7365 9820

The questions people ask

As well as publishing test reports, the Good Housekeeping Institute answers readers' queries. Here are the four questions most often asked about handheld computers.

1. Do I need a desktop PC too?

Yes, if you want your mobile to be more than a personal organiser. Link up with a PC and you can copy documents and work on them while you are out, then upload them when you return. The two devices "talk" to each other ("synchronise") when you connect them with a cable or via a docking cradle. Check before you buy that your PC has the right type of socket (USB or serial) to fit the mobile, and that the system requirements match your PC. A mobile computer with an infrared (IR) port can "talk" to any compatible device that also has an IR port.

2. How do you input information?

With handhelds, you type in information via a small keyboard, and tap icons and menus on the screen with a stylus to select functions. This can be frustrating because the keyboards are so small. On palmtops, the screen is divided into a writing area and the display; you use the stylus to either tap the keys of an on-screen graphic keyboard or write on the touch-sensitive screen, which converts your handwriting into text. Both methods can be time-consuming and tricky if you have less than perfect vision. With some models, writing by hand involves following special rules, which takes a bit of getting used to. Palm and Handspring sell fold-up full-size keyboards that can be connected to their palmtops.

3. How much memory will I need?

Go for as much as you can afford. Consider what you want to store - storing pictures and music from the net will use up a lot of memory. Most mobile PCs have optional extra memory cards.

4. Which operating system is best?

There are four main systems - EPOC, Palm OS, Windows CE and Pocket PC. Palm OS is the simplest - adequate if you just want an organiser. The other three are useful if you want word processing and spreadsheet facilities. The OS determines what the screen looks like and which applications it offers.

fields.headline: Scottish councils receive funding boost
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has announced record grant levels for local authorities, boosting the amount of central funding for council services north of the border to around £6.5bn over the next three years.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has announced record grant levels for local authorities, boosting the amount of central funding for council services north of the border to around £6.5bn over the next three years.

The rise promises to increase the total funding Scotland's councils receive for running services such as education and social care by around 16% over the same period.

Finance and local government minister Angus McKay also promised minimum annual grant rises for all authorities, with a 5% floor set for next year.

He added that council capital investment would go up by nearly 40% in the three-year period - raising it to around £3.6bn by 2003-04.

This is the first time the executive has announced funding over a three-year period, and the move is aimed at giving councils greater financial stability. Authorities rely on the central support for some 80% of service spending.

This round of funding will also see the end of spending guidelines, which limited local authorities' spending and, consequently, their freedom to set council tax rates. In return, ministers have called on Scottish local government to show restraint when setting tax levels.

Mr McKay told MSPs: "In the past, the local government finance settlement has sparked an annual debate about the relative winners and losers between councils. These discussions distracted from the real issue of how local authorities could make the most effective use of their resources. We have made the local government finance arrangements simpler and fairer."

The announcement was welcomed by Scottish councils. Norman Murray, president of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities, said: "Today's announcement will help councils in their financial planning for the longer term. By covering both revenue and capital, these figures mean that councils can work with their communities to identify priorities and plan service delivery."
fields.bodyText: The Scottish executive has announced record grant levels for local authorities, boosting the amount of central funding for council services north of the border to around £6.5bn over the next three years. The rise promises to increase the total funding Scotland's councils receive for running services such as education and social care by around 16% over the same period. Finance and local government minister Angus McKay also promised minimum annual grant rises for all authorities, with a 5% floor set for next year. He added that council capital investment would go up by nearly 40% in the three-year period - raising it to around £3.6bn by 2003-04. This is the first time the executive has announced funding over a three-year period, and the move is aimed at giving councils greater financial stability. Authorities rely on the central support for some 80% of service spending. This round of funding will also see the end of spending guidelines, which limited local authorities' spending and, consequently, their freedom to set council tax rates. In return, ministers have called on Scottish local government to show restraint when setting tax levels. Mr McKay told MSPs: "In the past, the local government finance settlement has sparked an annual debate about the relative winners and losers between councils. These discussions distracted from the real issue of how local authorities could make the most effective use of their resources. We have made the local government finance arrangements simpler and fairer." The announcement was welcomed by Scottish councils. Norman Murray, president of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities, said: "Today's announcement will help councils in their financial planning for the longer term. By covering both revenue and capital, these figures mean that councils can work with their communities to identify priorities and plan service delivery."

webTitle: Workplace racism laws are not tough enough

fields.headline: Workplace racism laws are not tough enough
fields.standfirst: Government's acceptance that institutional racism exists in the UK is good news, but tougher measures are needed to stamp it out in the workplace, writes Wilf Sullivan
fields.trailText: Government's acceptance that institutional racism exists in the UK is good news, but tougher measures are needed to stamp it out in the workplace, writes Wilf Sullivan.
fields.body:
The death of Stephen Lawrence and the subsequent report by Sir William MacPherson shattered the illusion that racism was no longer a problem in British institutions.

Until this tragic event, local authorities were busily dismantling their race equality structures and other employers in the public sector were abandoning the monitoring of their workforce, or not using the information they were collecting. For the black community, the report's revelation was nothing new.

For the first time a government accepted the concept of institutional racism, which black employees have spent years trying to combat by bringing claims of direct and indirect discrimination to employment tribunals.

Part of the government's response was to amend the Race Relations Act by placing a new duty on public authorities not to discriminate on racial grounds in carrying out any of their functions; the Commission for Racial Equality's powers of enforcement were extended.

While the strengthening of the legislation is welcome, the question still remains: has the government gone far enough to change what has been a notoriously weak and ineffectual piece of legislation?

Employees seeking a remedy for discrimination and harassment still have to prove that they were treated differently on racial grounds, something that is notoriously difficult to do. The changes proposed in the legislation are not likely to make it any easier to pursue a successful claim. In 1998-99 a total of 837 race discrimination cases were heard at an employment tribunal. Of these, 706 cases were unsuccessful (84%) and only 131 succeeded (16%).

The results do not mean that 84% of those who brought cases to court had not been discriminated against, just that they were not able to satisfy the very high standards of proof required to win a case. While this situation exists, the race relations legislation will not be a deterrent to employers discriminating against employees in the workplace.

Ironically, the hope for a solution may come as a result of an anti-racism agenda that has recently become a major feature of the European parliament's work. In the past year a new race directive (article 13) and employment directive will compel member states to rewrite their laws by the end of 2003. The article enforces the principle of equal treatment irrespective of ethnic origin, and is based on the Amsterdam treaty. This means that the Race Relations Act will have to be changed again by 2003, following the amendments currently being considered by parliament.

A key feature of the race directive, which has implications for the UK, is the reversal of the burden of proof requirement. This recognises that because of the difficulty of obtaining evidence in discrimination cases, where necessary information is often in the hands of employers, there is a need to shift the burden of proof from the complainant once a case has been established.

When the debate on how this feature should be incorporated into British legislation starts, there will be many disapproving voices trying to insist that it is unfair because the accused are innocent until found guilty. However, these dissenters need to remember that except for discrimination, in all other employment areas considered by employment tribunals, the burden of proof is on the respondent once the complainant has established their case.

This is the kind of change in legislation which will start to make inroads into the entrenched racism that exists in the workplace in this country. Employment is fundamental to the economic and social wellbeing of all communities. Currently the unemployment rate in the black community is three times higher than in the white community, and where black employees do have jobs, they are often concentrated at the lower levels of the workforce.

Until we have seriously tackled the issue of discrimination at work we cannot start to claim that racism is no longer a problem in our society.

 Wilf Sullivan is the national black members officer for Unison

webTitle: Government unveils plans to help working parents

fields.headline: Government unveils plans to help working parents
fields.trailText: Fathers could be given two weeks' paid paternity leave and mothers' jobs may be held open for a year under government proposals to help working parents. Fathers would receive £60.20 a week and be allowed unpaid time off.
fields.body:
Fathers could be given two weeks' paid paternity leave and mothers' jobs may be held open for a year under government proposals to help working parents. Fathers would receive £60.20 a week and be allowed unpaid time off.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers today said the reforms, to be deferred until after a general election, were needed to compensate for recent dramatic changes in working patterns. The proposals would bring Britain closer to Europeans, many of whom already benefit from more generous paternity leave, particularly in Norway, Sweden and Spain.

The plans were published as a green paper Work and Parents: Competitiveness and Choice. Mr Byers also detailed proposals to increase maternity payments from the current £60 per week and apply the new rate to mothers and fathers, and allow paid parental leave to be taken later in a child's life.

Women currently get statutory maternity pay at 90% of earnings for six weeks and then at £60 a week for a further 12 weeks. They can take a total of six months off with the remainder unpaid.

Estimates of the cost to business suggest employers would face a bill of up to £77m over five years if fathers took one week paid parental leave each year.

fields.headline: Partnership scheme for modernising services
fields.trailText: Money from banks and pension funds will be used to modernise GP surgeries, particularly in the run-down inner cities, under a public private partnership established by a NHS and Social Care Bill to be published later this month.
fields.body:
Money from banks and pension funds will be used to modernise GP surgeries, particularly in the run-down inner cities, under a public private partnership established by a NHS and Social Care Bill to be published later this month.

Ministers expect this first private finance initiative in primary health care to generate £1bn to renovate up to 3,000 of England's 10,000 family doctor premises by 2004.

They hope to attract a bank or pension fund as a partner. Long-term returns would come from rents from GPs, pharmacists, opticians and non-medical commercial outlets that would be clustered in newly-built or modernised high street premises.

The government expects the scheme to be less controversial than other recent private partnerships because GPs already lease premises from private landlords, often in unsatisfactory buildings with upkeep problems.

The scheme will be run by an "equity stake company" to be called the NHS Local Improvement Finance Trust (NHS Lift).

Over the next four years it will get £175m from the Department of Health, £175m from the Treasury's equity stake initiative Partnership UK, and a similar amount from a commercial partner.

The equity fund will be used to support borrowing from other financial institutions to raise £1 bn over four years.

A Department of Health spokesman said the company's priority would be to invest in parts of the country, such as inner cities, where primary care services were most in need of expansion.

The initiative would assist regeneration and relieve GPs from the commercial risk of developing premises in the run-down areas where they were most needed.

Leases would be made available to GPs whether they were salaried, independent or working in partnerships.

The terms would make it easier for a GP to move after a few years and pass the practice to a successor.

The British Medical Association said it could not tell whether the scheme would work until the government gave more details. "Nonetheless, the intention to improve GP premises, particularly in inner cities, is clearly one we would support," said John Chisholm, chairman of the association's general practitioners committee.

Other parts of the bill will give Alan Milburn, the health secretary, more power to intervene against poorly performing hospitals. In cases of "persistent or catastrophic failure", he will be able to sack the whole management team.

All health authorities will benefit from a £500m performance fund. The best performers will get discretion on how to spend this to improve standards, but the worst will be told what to do by a new NHS modernisation agency.

The King's Fund, an independent health research charity, said the system was unfair. If it had been in place this year, Manchester and Liverpool would have been identified as the worst performers, while Dorset and East Surrey would have been the best.

The bill will also:

 Give more prescribing rights to nurses, chiropodists, physiotherapists and pharmacists.

 Encourage health authorities and local councils to integrate NHS and social services by merging their powers under "care trusts" - with a reserve power for ministers to require this.

 Make the NHS responsible for paying for nursing care in homes for older people, but not personal care as a royal commission recommended.

A second health bill will ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco. Ministers wanted this to be done through an EU directive, but that was struck down by the European court.

Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the legislation was "the beginning of the end for the tobacco industry in Britain".

He congratulated the government on ignoring "the persistent bleatings of the tobacco manufacturers, who even now refuse to accept responsibility for the needless deaths of millions of people worldwide".

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, said the advertising ban would save up to 3,000 lives a year. The brands most heavily advertised were those most heavily smoked by children, she said.

webTitle: Participation should be a reality, not just a buzz word

fields.headline: Participation should be a reality, not just a buzz word
fields.standfirst: Participation and user-involvement are popular buzz words in government but the reality remains rather different
fields.trailText: Participation and user-involvement are populat buzz words in government but the reality remains rather different, writes Ruth Lister
fields.body:
Just occasionally, we are challenged to rethink some of our basic premises about what we do and how we do it. The process is an uncomfortable one, but it can also be very rewarding. I have spent the last year as a member of an independent Commission on Poverty, Participation and Power, established by the UK Coalition on Poverty. Our remit was to identify the barriers faced by people experiencing poverty who want to participate in decision-making that affects their lives, and to propose ways forward.

The commission emerged from a national "grassroots" consultation exercise, Voices for Change. What also made the commission different was that it was made up not just of the usual "great and the good", but also people with direct experience of poverty. It has convinced me of the value of the expertise borne of experience.

The commission's report - published today - has important implications for welfare professionals as well as politicians (local and national). Participation and user-involvement increasingly are buzz words in government but the reality, as experienced by many people living in poverty, is rather different. The message that came across loud and clear from our consultations was that people in poverty are neither listened to nor respected.

Voices for Change in south-west England told us of a meeting they'd organised: "We invited so many councillors and council officials and they are not here. The leader of the council and the MP made their speeches and then scarpered. One councillor said he had to go to another meeting in the council house. They were discussing 'citizenship and democracy'! They should have been discussing it with us, here."

Even where officials "talk the participation talk", all too often they fail to "walk the walk". Phoney participation, we were told, is experienced as the ultimate disrespect. If, for example, it involves incomprehensible forms, or the outcomes are not fed back, it can lead to cynicism and disillusionment.

Professionals and officials act as important gatekeepers. They can use their position to keep people at arms length or they can facilitate their participation. Using plain English rather than jargon is critical. Yet few professionals are trained to work in a participatory way, nor do their organisations recognise and reward attempts to do so. Genuine participation also takes time.

It also means addressing the kind of practical barriers that the Commission was told about, including:
 lack of money;
 fear that benefit will be withdrawn if participation is deemed as affecting availability for employment;
 transport and childcare difficulties;
 not having the right clothes.

The report ends with a set of recommendations and principles for participation. They are premised on the central proposition that "participation in the decision-making process of people with experience of living in poverty must be recognised as a basic human right".

Among the principles of particular relevance to welfare professionals are:
 we must all be prepared to change how we think and act to make participation genuine and effective;
 participation should be a strategy, not a device, and should take place throughout the process - from first steps to evaluation;
 people who hold power must learn to listen properly to the voices of people living in poverty, to understand, to communicate in ways that everyone can understand, to respect people's contributions, and to act on their voices;
 louder voices must not be allowed to drown out the weaker or more marginalised ones.

No-one promised that participation would be easy, as we learned on the commission. But the prizes are worth it: stronger democracy and citizenship, together with better informed policy-making.

 Ruth Lister is professor of social policy at Loughborough University
 Listen Hear - The Right to be Heard is available for £10.99 from Policy Press, 34 Tyndall's Park Road, Bristol, BS8 1PY or email tpp@bristol.ac.uk

 A summary of the report can be found at www.church-poverty.org.uk or is available from UKCAP, 17 Grove Lane, London SE5 8RD.
 Information on participatory approaches can be found also at www.ids.ac.uk/ids/particip/

webTitle: Homeless under-fives have a special place in Glasgow

fields.headline: Homeless under-fives have a special place in Glasgow
fields.standfirst: A unique support project brings some cheer to babies and toddlers who often have to endure difficult situations in B&B accommodation
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 families with children present themselves as homeless in Glasgow every year. Some are fleeing domestic violence or violence from neighbours, drug dealers and loan sharks. Others are chaotic families who find it impossible to maintain a tenancy. Often they suffer from social problems created by alcohol or drug addiction, which is reckoned to be five times higher in Glasgow than anywhere else in Britain.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 families with children present themselves as homeless in Glasgow every year. Some are fleeing domestic violence or violence from neighbours, drug dealers and loan sharks. Others are chaotic families who find it impossible to maintain a tenancy. Often they suffer from social problems created by alcohol or drug addiction, which is reckoned to be five times higher in Glasgow than anywhere else in Britain.

Homeless families can be offered bed and breakfast accommodation or placed in one of almost 600 temporary furnished flats across the city. If there are children under five, they can also be referred to the city council's Pre-Fives Homeless Support Project, which offers nursery places to children living in temporary accommodation.

Noelle Harvey, the project's manager, believes it is the only one of its kind in the UK. Established for almost 10 years, it was originally funded by an Urban Aid grant but is now part of the council's mainstream education service. In addition to the manager, the project has a full-time family support worker, a team of seven child care staff and an administrator.

The scheme is housed in a former school in Glasgow's east end. Up to 16 children aged from two to five years, and up to six babies aged from six weeks to two years can be accommodated in the nursery, which is open from 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday.

Families are referred to the project by health visitors, social workers, GPs, housing officers and the Homeless Families Healthcare Service. They can also refer themselves. The only criteria are that the family must be homeless and living in temporary furnished or bed and breakfast accommodation and there is a child under five.

The project receives more than 300 referrals a year and children stay in the nursery as long as their family remains in temporary accommodation. This can mean a couple of days to more than a year, although the average stay is around four to five months.

When families are referred they are visited to establish their circumstances. "We look at everything that is going on for that family and liaise with other agencies as necessary, to give them as much help as possible," Harvey says. "There is no blueprint. Each family is different and we tailor what we offer to their individual needs."

For instance, it may suit the family better to have their child enrolled in a local nursery, rather than having to travel to the project premises. To enable local nurseries to take on extra children, the project will supply one of its own childcare staff as an extra pair of hands.

Ms Harvey's budget allows her to recruit sessional childcare workers to make sure the project maintains a balanced child:staff ratio. Families with babies may be offered a "home play experience", rather than a nursery place. This involves a childcare worker going to the family's temporary home and creating a play environment there for a few hours a week, offering a welcome break for parents. "Wherever possible, especially if a family is in a B&B hotel, we like to take the child out of that environment for a short while," Ms Harvey says.

One client who appreciates the scheme is Angela. Her four-year-old twins attend the nursery five days a week, allowing her the time to sort out housing and social security issues and do the shopping. "The children recently lost their father and the nursery staff have been particularly good at helping them to express their grief," says Angela. "They really are fantastic."

Pat Hughes, a health visitor with the Homeless Families Healthcare Service, part of the Greater Glasgow Primary Care trust, says the project allows children to come out of often difficult situations in bed and breakfast accommodation where they might not have toys or other young company. "It is great for their development," says Ms Hughes. "The project is also particularly useful because it will accept babies, whereas most mainstream nurseries will not accept children until they are three."

When the family moves into permanent accommodation the project team can help put them in touch with nurseries, schools and other agencies in the new area. "We do the best for every family, regardless of the circumstances that led to their becoming homeless," says Ms Harvey. "But we never forget the most important person in all of this is the child."

This involves a childcare worker going to the family's temporary home and creating a play environment there for a few hours a week, offering a welcome break for parents. "Wherever possible, especially if a family is in a B&B hotel, we like to take the child out of that environment for a short while," Ms Harvey says. One client who appreciates the scheme is Angela. Her four-year-old twins attend the nursery five days a week, allowing her the time to sort out housing and social security issues and do the shopping. "The children recently lost their father and the nursery staff have been particularly good at helping them to express their grief," says Angela. "They really are fantastic." Pat Hughes, a health visitor with the Homeless Families Healthcare Service, part of the Greater Glasgow Primary Care trust, says the project allows children to come out of often difficult situations in bed and breakfast accommodation where they might not have toys or other young company. "It is great for their development," says Ms Hughes. "The project is also particularly useful because it will accept babies, whereas most mainstream nurseries will not accept children until they are three." When the family moves into permanent accommodation the project team can help put them in touch with nurseries, schools and other agencies in the new area. "We do the best for every family, regardless of the circumstances that led to their becoming homeless," says Ms Harvey. "But we never forget the most important person in all of this is the child."

fields.headline: Tiscali completes World Online takeover
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Italian internet company Tiscali has completed its £3bn takeover of World Online, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Italian internet company Tiscali has completed its £3bn takeover of World Online, as the long-awaited consolidation of the sector gains momentum.

The news comes a day after Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, was snapped up by French rival Wanadoo in a £1.6bn takeover.

Bob Kommers, internet analyst at ABN Amro, said: "The main reason behind the consolidation is that share prices in the sector have come down so much. It is much more attractive to buy now."

Tiscali's protracted takeover bid has been delayed by World Online's disgruntled shareholders, who have been suing the company over its controversial flotation in March.

Nina Brink, the former chairwoman of World Online, was forced to resign earlier this year when it was discovered that she sold part of her stake for a bargain price before the flotation.

There are still plenty of attractive targets on the continent, including LibertySurf of France, Freenet of Germany and LineOne of the UK.

T-Online, Europe's largest ISP is tipped to enter the acquisition race after resolving its drawn-out management crisis.

The European ISP sector has been opened up by a stock market battering, caused by the general turmoil in technology stocks and growing doubts over the revenue models of major ISPs.

The negative sentiment left Freeserve to be snapped up cheap at 157p per share, when it had scaled the heights of 900p earlier in the year.

webTitle: Comment: Blood on the Belfast streets

fields.headline: Blood on the Belfast streets
fields.standfirst:
Bloody chaos returns to Northern Ireland, writes Derek Brown, putting a few more holes in the battered peace process
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
Bloody chaos returns to Northern Ireland, writes Derek Brown, putting a few more holes in the battered peace process
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
Three shootings within 36 hours have underlined the hideous fragility of the Northern Ireland peace process.

The very word 'peace' is in question, after the outbreak of what could be a new phase of sectarian warfare. We don't know yet what is behind the bloodshed, but there are sinister and ruthless forces at work.

The first victim was Trevor Kell, a 35-year-old Protestant taxi driver was shot dead on Tuesday night after picking up a bogus summons to an address in a loyalist area of north Belfast close to the nationalist Ardoyne district.

Then on Wednesday Gary Moore, a Catholic, was shot while working on a building site in Monkstown, also in north Belfast. Just 15 minutes later another Catholic man, as yet unnamed, was shot and critically wounded outside a taxi depot in the same part of the city.

The shootings were grimly reminiscent of the darkest days the modern Troubles, when tit-for-tat sectarian murders rocked the province almost daily. Now, with renewed tension gripping Belfast, there is intense speculation that dissident activists are trying to resume their sordid little wars.

The RUC says it is treating the murder of Mr Kell as sectarian in motivation. But informed sources say that it could be connected with the unresolved feud between the loyalist paramilitary groups, the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force.

Others believe that militant republicans are trying to force a new crisis on the province. The so-called Real IRA, one of the breakaway groups which has repudiated the IRA ceasefire, has vehemently denied involvement.

fields.headline: Radio Times editor quits
fields.trailText: 1.30pm update:, Radio Times editor Sue Robinson has quit after 20 years at the BBC TV listings magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Radio Times editor Sue Robinson has quit after an incredible 20 years at the TV listings magazine.

In a decision that has shocked the magazine's owners, she is quitting to take over at the helm of Sainsbury's magazine.

Ms Robinson has been editor of the BBC-owned magazine for the past four years and is believed to have agonised over the decision to leave one of the biggest and most prestigious jobs in consumer magazines.

Today BBC Worldwide was playing down her departure.

A Radio Times spokesman said that BBC Worldwide doesn't want to rush the appointment of "the biggest job in magazine publishing".

She will be replaced in the short-term by her predecessor, Nicholas Brett, head of the Radio Times arts and factuals group.

Ms Robinson, who joined the Radio Times in 1980 as a subeditor, won the British Society of Magazine Editors' award for best magazine editor in 1999 and 2000.

The award recognised that she has presided over stiff challenges to the 77-year-old magazine, with increased competition after the deregulation of the TV listings market.

More recently, the Radio Times has come under pressure from multi-channel television and the growth of the electronic programme guide, and has recently signed deals with personal video recorder manufacturer Tivo and broadcaster ONdigital.

Although Radio Times is now outsold by IPC Media's What's On TV?, which sells 1,707,815 copies, it comes a close second at 1,250,134.

More importantly, according to BBC Worldwide, it is the most profitable magazine in the UK. In 1999, it generated £32m in advertising revenue and £56m in copy sales.

A BBC spokesman said she went "with the goodwill of all" at Worldwide.

fields.headline: The true worth of councillors
fields.standfirst: The wholesale review of members' allowances will do more to change the role of councillors than any reform of local government structure, writes Declan Hall
fields.trailText: Analysis: The wholesale review of members' allowances will do more to change the role of councillors than any reform of local authority structure, writes Declan Hall
fields.body:
Traditionally, councillors in the UK have been poorly paid and being a councillor has often been seen as something to do when one retires, or as a public service, or even as being part of an exclusive local gentlemen's club.

Until 1995, allowances were capped by central government, meaning many able councillors were essentially subsidised by sympathetic partners or had to forgo career advancement to pursue a local political career. This will not be the case in the future.

The Local Government Act 2000 requires all authorities to review their councillors' allowances on the advice of independent local advisory panels. Recommended allowances of up to £30,000 per annum for leaders of large authorities are no longer uncommon.

The reform of members' allowances is the one area within the whole modernisation agenda that has not been subject to strict government control, regulation and direction. Councillors have no choice about best value or new political structures, but after setting up review panels, they are free to pay themselves whatever they want.

This is why the real revolution in local government is manifesting itself in the way councillors are remunerated. The possibility of higher rates of pay is leading to full-time councillors, who will be giving strong political direction and leadership to their authority, and non-executive councillors, who can afford to devote substantial time to their roles without being unduly penalised.

Most authorities have either already reviewed their allowances or are in the process of doing so. Yet, it is the one area that has not attracted the attention of the media or government - with Cardiff as the exception that proves the rule. There, leader Russell Goodway took flak over his £58,000 allowance. Yet the wholesale review of members' allowances will do more to change the role of councillors than any reform of structures.

Previously, most councillors' allowances were made up mainly of an attendance allowance, with a small basic allowance paid to all members equally. Now most members will receive the basic payment only, with special responsibility allowances for leading members. In practice, councils are likely to increase their basic allowances to make up the shortfall in politicians' incomes.

But the end of the attendance allowance has forced many party groups to think about a more equal distribution of work between non-executive councillors, as well as to consider mechanisms to ensure councillors perform.

Allowance reviews have often set out a councillors' expected minimum inputs, making an explicit and unprecedented link between remuneration and workload. Some individual authorities have put in place more punitive measures. These include Leicester city council's "clawback" mechanism, which fines councillors for not turning up at meetings or filling approved duties.

Other reviews have handed the matter of allowances to new standards committees, designed to ensure probity in local government, which each authority must set up.

Councillors, in turn, are also being forced to reconsider what they should be doing, how they should prioritise their activities and what their role entails. In particular, many authorities have developed job descriptions - partly from the need to clarify new executive roles - but also to ensure that members know what they are supposed to do in return for their enhanced flat rate basic allowance.

Ultimately, the revolution in councillors' pay needs to be assessed in terms of how it has impacted on the recruitment and retention of councillors and how it has affected their work. It is these reforms, more than any other, that are altering how local politicians work, what they do and how they relate to the public.

The proof of the pudding will be when professional and business people see local government as a career alternative, a prospect that is already frightening many officers used to providing policy and strategic leadership in their authority.

Moreover, it places demands on local politicians that signal the end of the gentleman councillor. In future, better pay will mean higher expectations, and councillors will be expected to work across a range of activities. It will lead to local government politics becoming both an attractive career choice and run by highly paid professionals, who will be less willing to defer to officer expertise so readily. Apply now, while the competition is weak.

 Declan Hall teaches at the University of Birmingham's Institute of Local Government Studies. He has been involved in around 30 council allowance system reviews.

webTitle: Explainer: the EU summit in Nice

fields.headline: The EU summit in Nice
fields.standfirst: Once again, European national leaders are in conclave, defending national interests and pursuing national goals in the name of international cooperation. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: What is the EU summit in Nice all about? Derek Brown explains
fields.body:
Why and where are the EU leaders meeting?
They always meet twice a year, at the end of each presidency, which rotates among member states in alphabetical order. Since July 1 France has been the president-nation, and in the EU tradition of gracious, not to say lavish, hospitality, it is hosting this summit on the Mediterranean coast, at Nice. A very nice winter location.

What's on the agenda?
Institutional reform. As ever. Basically, the old European Economic Community consisted of six countries: West Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. It has expanded hugely to take in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Denmark, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Austria and Finland, and now has 374m citizens. Each expansion has brought new and often conflicting ideas about how the Union should develop.

Has the expansion stopped?
Not at all. EU leaders have ambitions extending eastwards to the borders of Russia. The number of member states could double in a decade.

How on earth do they all agree?
They don't. That's why they introduced the concept of qualified majority voting. Each state is given a number of votes, weighted by population. But on some issues the member governments retain the right to veto European legislation.

And not everyone is happy with that?
Bet your life. The Germans, ten years on from reunification, are demanding more votes than the other big member states - France, Italy, and Britain - on the grounds that they have 20m more citizens. The French, who have always seen themselves as the prime movers in Europe, are appalled.

And the British?
They're always appalled. Ever since joining the old EEC in 1973, successive governments have been in mortal fear of Britons' instinctive hostility to Johnny Foreigner. The Wilson government thought it could settle the issue with the 1975 referendum. In the mid-1980s Margaret Thatcher swung her handbag with her (successful) demand for a cut in Britain's contribution to the common exchequer. In the mid-1990s the Conservative party turned decisively against Europe. The present government is more amenable, but won't hear of giving up its veto on key issues, primarily taxation.

So Britain is out of step with its continental colleagues?
Not really. Every national government, whatever nonsense it spouts about integration, has its visceral reservations. France - to pick a random example - did not hesitate to defy the European Commission in banning imports of British beef. That's what the people demanded. The EU is littered with other examples, great and small, of national objections to common action. The Greeks will not hear of Turkish entry to the Union. The environmentally correct Danes will not import canned drinks, believing that bottles are better. The Germans will not give up their right to drive at any speed they choose. Britain insists on keeping control of immigration.

How do they all get away with it?
It's not difficult, when the whole structure is based on continuing national sovereignty. Contrary to the Eurosceptic line, all decisions of importance in Europe are taken in the national capitals.

What about the European Commission?
It is supposed to come up with policy initiatives, which it does in spades. But the real power rests with the Council of Ministers, which means the 15 national governments. The ultimate authority lies with the European Council, which means summit meetings like the one in Nice.

And the European Parliament?
Is a lamentable, toothless, ludicrous gravy train. More's the pity.

webTitle: Powers of wellbeing set to strengthen council leadership

fields.headline: Powers of wellbeing set to strengthen council leadership
fields.standfirst: Local authorities have new powers to identify and tackle priority needs in their area, writes Dermott Calpin
fields.trailText: Local authorities have new powers to identify and tackle priority needs in their area, writes Dermott Calpin.
fields.body:
Any doubts about local government's ability to lead communities should be dispelled by its new "power to promote wellbeing", set out in the Local Government Act 2000 and seen as a vital part of government attempts to regenerate the country's towns and cities.

Councils do not yet know exactly how to use this landmark power to promote the economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas, since all they have to go on is draft guidance published in June. But in practice, many have been hard at work developing community plans for several years.

The law currently requires councils to prepare community strategies that identify the needs of their areas. Though ministers have allowed considerable room for manoeuvre, authorities are obliged to work closely with other local organisations such as business, voluntary groups, residents, and other public agencies such as doctors or police to establish local priorities.

This emphasis on public consultation and the involvement of partner organisations is a major step towards modernising local government. It gives councils a key leadership role because they are made up of elected community representatives.

The objectives that emerge from the community planning process are also expected to inform the best value review process by encouraging councils to address "cross-cutting issues". These include community safety and sustainable development that are beyond the reach of conventional service delivery.

It is easy to see how this approach can be extended to give councils a more prominent role, where they work with local health authorities to identify and develop policies to tackle health inequalities or forge strategic partnerships to promote neighbourhood renewal or economic development.

Brian Pote-Hunt, strategic head of regeneration and partnership for Sutton council, says that its first attempt at a community plan provided the council with a list of priorities that ranged from reducing crime and creating a safer environment, to caring for the elderly and more vulnerable people.

"It was very much a list of general aspirations," explains Mr Pote-Hunt. "Work has already started on a second plan. We learned a lot from the experience the first time around and expect to build on that by setting more specific targets and addressing some of the wider community issues."

Sutton Borough Forum is the key agency for bringing together all the local organisations and Brian describes this as a "partnership of partnerships". The forum, rather than the council, has "ownership" of the community plan, according to Mr Pote-Hunt.

In Coventry, the city council began work on its first community plan in 1997. It was officially launched in February 1998. The key organisation is the City Forum, which meets four times a year with a membership drawn from 25 strategic partner bodies.

The forum agreed a set of general priorities - to create more jobs, to tackle crime, to combat poverty, to invest in young people, to create an exciting city centre and to meet the needs and aspirations of older people. It then set up six programme delivery groups charged with developing more detailed action programmes that would help deliver the objectives set out in the community plan.

For policy and planning manager Peter Strachan, the plan plays a vital function in identifying community priorities. The latest newsletter will highlight a list of 32 targets set by the City Forum but he still believes there is room for greater public awareness of its role.

"We did succeed in getting a high level of involvement by working closely with our partner organisation when the scheme was first launched, but there is room for improvement so that people feel more involved and have greater ownership. In the end the plans to belong to their communities," he says.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 8.
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola is planning to increase the amount it spends on online marketing next year.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is planning to increase the amount it spends on online marketing next year.

Channel 5 marketing boss Jim Hytner and BBC head of corporate marketing Jane Frost are among the final candidates competing for the corporation's top marketing job.

fields.headline: Global ad agencies to prosper
fields.trailText: 2pm:Global ad agencies will continue to perform well next year even without growth in the worldwide advertising market. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Global advertising agencies will continue to perform well next year even if there is no growth in the worldwide advertising market, according to a report from investment bank ABN Amro.

But smaller local agencies will suffer as clients increasingly turn to single global agencies with a full range of marketing services.

The bank has issued a 'buy' recommendation on Europe's four biggest marketing services groups: WPP, Publicis, Havas and Aegis.

It believes the four companies will perform well next year as spending from new accounts they have won this year begins to kick in.

The report said: "2000 has been an exceptional year in terms of new billings won by the global advertising agencies.

"We estimate that the new billings won in 2000 will feed through into double-digit organic revenue growth in 2001, even with no growth in the global advertising market."

The world's biggest advertisers are increasingly consolidating their business into a single global agency, giving a boost to those agencies that can service their clients internationally.

This has helped Aegis, Havas, Publicis and WPP to win new business worth more than £1bn this year alone.

fields.headline: Financial junk mail 'counter-productive'
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: The mountains of junk mail sent out by banks and credit card companies may be doing more harm than good, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The mountains of junk mail sent out by banks and credit card companies may be doing more harm than good, according to a survey commissioned by marketing consultants Primeresponse.

The survey found that financial services companies are the worst culprits when it comes to sending out unwanted mail.

Many consumers feel that banks and credit card companies are jeopardising customer relationships in the rush to gain more business and increase profits.

In the UK, credit card companies were voted the worst offenders, with 38% of UK respondents saying such junk mail annoys them the most.

Peter J Boni, chief executive of PrimeResponse, said: "This research demonstrates that companies need to listen to their customers and deliver a more personalised service, which in turn will inspire customer loyalty."

fields.headline: Section 28 left out
fields.trailText: The running controversy over repeal of section 28, the local government law which prevents the "promotion" of homosexuality, has slipped off the official timetable, at least until after the coming election.
fields.body:
William Hague was quick to spot holes in the government's legislative programme where promised bills on sensitive issues like adoption law and vaccine damage compensation have still not materialised.

The running controversy over repeal of section 28, the local government law which prevents the "promotion" of homosexuality, has also slipped off the official timetable, at least until after the coming election.

Ministers had accepted that it will not get past the Lords in the present climate, though the same calculation is being made about the bill to ban hunting with dogs - also likely to face stiff resistance in the upper house.

Some bills attracted Conservative criticism unfairly, including the promised transport safety bill which is being postponed until after completion of Lord Cullen's inquiry into the fatal Paddington rail crash.

Last night the prime minister's spokesman stressed that there may be many more bills introduced before election day - widely expected on May 3 - thus keeping his options open.

Pressed about the repeated promise to reform the payments system for victims of vaccine damage he insisted "it will be done". That will not appease campaigners any more than the resort to draft bills only on controversies like the long-promised register for arms exporters.

A draft version of the reform will be published, but not acted upon until after the election - unless it is unexpectedly postponed.

There were also complaints from consumer lobbyists that the programme does not contain bills on customer protection from shoddy products and services.

Intimidation of "bully boy" debt collectors because the credit licensing system is "too lax and feeble to expel the worst offenders", the National Consumer Council also protested.

Ministers had published a green paper looking at reducing corporate perks so shareholders could vote on the extravagant packages which remuneration committees sometimes award each other. That too has disappeared for now.

fields.headline: New attack on black economy
fields.trailText: Persistent benefit fraudsters will lose their right to state support, as part of a crackdown on the black economy in a social security fraud bill.
fields.body:
Persistent benefit fraudsters will lose their right to state support, as part of a crackdown on the black economy in a social security fraud bill.

The government will withdraw or reduce benefits for anyone convicted twice of committing a benefit offence over the previous three years.

The department of social security said the scheme would deter hard-core fraudsters. DSS and local authority investigators would be able to demand information from banks, building societies and specified private and public sector bodies where fraud was suspected.

The DSS would also be able to exchange information with overseas social security departments to combat international fraud rings.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said: "This is the 43rd time that the government has promised to crack down on welfare fraud. It is time we finally saw some action."

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said the "two strikes and you're out'" proposal was unacceptable. "Benefit fraud is already a criminal offence and there is a criminal justice system in place to deal with it. Fraudsters, not their families, should pay for their crimes in the courts.

"Benefit fraud is fast becoming another Dutch auction. Labour are proposing savings of £1bn. The Tories, who never even managed to measure benefit fraud let alone tackle it, have pledged to double that. This is a meaningless war of words."

The bill will also let the DSS offer a fine of between £1,000 and £5,000 as an alternative to criminal prosecution in cases of employers colluding with employees to commit benefit fraud.

webTitle: Help for buyers priced out of homes 'hotspots'

fields.headline: Help for buyers priced out of homes 'hotspots'
fields.trailText: Ministers will next week unveil a new housing package designed to help people priced out of property 'hotspots' and improve the image of council housing.
fields.body:
Ministers will next week unveil a new housing package designed to help people priced out of property 'hotspots' and improve the image of council housing. The aim is to underpin a homes bill, announced yesterday with a 'starter homes initiative' involving interest-free top-up loans and cash for deposits to help people on average incomes, particularly in the south east, get a mortgage.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford is also keen to persuade many more councils to transfer their housing stock to new 'social' companies and trusts which can borrow on the open market to push improvement schemes ahead.

New measures announced yesterday include plans to accelerate the buying and selling of houses and improving protection given to homeless people. A sellers' information pack will be brought forward as part of the new bill, which will see the onus on property checks passing from buyers to sellers in England and Wales.

The pack, which is expected to cost from £500 to £1,000 will include information about house condition reports and local authority searches - while selling a property without a report will become a criminal offence. The move follows a pilot study in Bristol.

Industry experts warned that the study did not prove the efficiency of the scheme, with only 189 sellers volunteering for the experiment. The Council of Mortgage Lenders said the survey was not a clear enough indicator that the sellers' pack would work. It said further research was needed.

But other plans to scrap the current system of leasehold on many houses were welcomed. The government is proposing a new 'commonhold' system which would provide owners in flats the same security as freehold owners, while giving them greater rights to buy the freehold.

The charity Shelter welcomed plans to give the homeless new rights by extending the homelessness safety net to 16 and 17-year-olds and those who are vulnerable when leaving care.

But the Chartered Institute of Housing said it was disappointed by the government's failure to deliver on a manifesto pledge to licence houses in multiple occupation. Such houses represented "some of the worst housing conditions in the country, with tenants at risk from fire and unsafe appliances". It called for an additional draft bill to include this measure.

webTitle: Election looms as Labour launches drive against drunks

fields.headline: Election looms as Labour launches drive against drunks
fields.trailText: There is a remarkably close similarity between Labour's Queen's speech yesterday and John Major's last legislative programme in 1996-7. Both programmes were designed as a shameless, populist appeal to the swing voters in marginal seats.
fields.body:
There is a remarkably close similarity between Labour's Queen's speech yesterday and John Major's last legislative programme in 1996-7. Both programmes were designed as a shameless, populist appeal to the swing voters in marginal seats.

For the single-minded focus of those who assemble a government's final legislative programme is middle England, and their enemies - drunks, drug pushers, benefit fraudsters, car thieves, kerb crawlers, teenage yobs, and liberal judges.

Thus, in the autumn of 1996 Mr Major published no less than five law and order bills, beating Mr Straw's current four. Michael Howard, the then home secretary, described his programme "as the most radical attack on crime this century", highlighting plans to impose mandatory minimum sentences on people convicted more than once for drug trafficking or burglary. Like Labour yesterday, Mr Major also added a social security fraud bill and introduced measures to give councils powers to confiscate alcohol being consumed by anyone under-18 in public places, a theme to which Mr Straw has returned with his anti-yobs package.

The Conservatives' hope in 1996 was that Tony Blair's "tough on crime" message could be punctured by manoeuvring Labour into opposing sentencing measures that had outraged the judiciary. Mr Blair saw a political trap and declined to oppose any of it. It was left to the appeal court judge Lord Bridge to fulminate against "the Satanic pact between the two main political parties to see that this ill-considered legislation is forced through".

Mr Blair even urged Mr Howard to introduce extra measures to hit paedophiles and stalkers. Fearing he was being outbid in an anti-crime auction, Mr Howard hastily tabled the measures.

Four years later, Mr Blair has now returned to the same auction with his own package. The message was supplemented last night with an anti-crime TV political broadcast advertising the Crimestoppers number.

Mr Blair has been prompted by a stream of eloquent messages from his pollster, Philip Gould, in the spring that William Hague was gaining ground on crime. Fear of crime is on the rise.

Labour strategists also concede that the overall drop in police numbers in this parliament could be its achilles heel in the election. The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, certainly intends to cite the figures in every TV studio in the country right through the election campaign. As to the bills themselves, Miss Widdecombe will not oppose them - just dismiss them.

Labour clearly hopes that the headline measures, such as fixed penalty fines and extended curfews, will reassure its doubters. Most Labour MPs yesterday swallowed the anti-crime gimmickry as a necessary evil. But they fear overall that the speech looks too thin and too obviously constructed with a spring election in mind. The relative thinness is, in part, because Labour struggled with its previous legislative programme, due to its lack of overall majority in the Lords.

Again a comparison with the 1997 election run-in is instructive. In the run-up to the May 1997 election, the house started meeting from October 23 to March 21 with 86 sitting days over 718 hours. The late start to this session, the latest for decades, leaves only 14 weeks before Mr Blair will fire the election starting pistol.

But Labour strategists insist there is enough to keep the New Labour coalition together. There is a nod to Labour activists through the fox hunting measure, even if Mr Straw does not expect the bill reaches the statute book. Human rights activists may be mollified by jam tomorrow on arms exports.

The laws needed to impose the NHS plan may be obscure, but they are a sign of intent, along with the shedloads of cash for the NHS in the summer spending review. And in the end it will be the economy and the state of public services which will determine this election.

Bills in brief

Education

Children with disabilities and special educational needs will have greater rights to be educated in mainstream schools under the terms of a bill unveiled in the Queen's speech. Schools, colleges, universities and local authorities in England and Wales would have to ensure they do not treat disabled pupils less favourably than non-disabled children.

Northern Ireland

A radical overhaul of the criminal justice system in Northern Ireland is planned in the Criminal Justice System in Northern Ireland (Draft) Bill, which seeks to put in place a raft of recommendations of a review group set up under the Good Friday agreement.

The draft bill, which will be published in April 2001, will seek to implement the review's conclusions - which range from banning the practice of saying: "God save the Queen" when a judge enters a court, to setting up a commission for the appointment of judges, to ending the RUC's role in prosecuting 30,000 minor offences each year.

Armed forces

Military law will be updated to bring it in line with civilian law in the armed forces bill, which is introduced every five years to iron out anomalies. Procedures for investigating offences committed by service personnel will be altered, to bring them in line with the Police and Criminal Evidence Act.

Child protection

The powers of the children's commissioner in Wales - a post introduced this year in the wake of the Waterhouse report - will be greatly extended ensuring the as-yet-unappointed commissioner can review and monitor arrangements for complaints and advocacy on behalf of children in schools and NHS hospitals, not just those in the care of local authorities.

Will Woodward and Sarah Hall

fields.headline: Washington leaves world in limbo
fields.standfirst: Foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall examines how the Florida poll fiasco is affecting trouble spots around the globe
fields.trailText: Foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall examines how the Florida poll fiasco is affecting trouble spots around the globe.
fields.body:
The policy-making vacuum in Washington - as eight years of the Clinton administration draw to a close and Capitol Hill awaits the arrival of a new Congress - is having a profound, often negative impact on a range of key international issues and disputes.

The lengthy transition between governments is always problematic. It has been rendered more so this time around by the continuing dispute over who won last month's presidential election. But even if the contest is finally resolved in the next few days, precious time and focus has been lost in managing the changeover.

Although President Bill Clinton has promised to devote the remaining 50 days or so of his incumbency to foreign policy issues, particularly the Middle East, his influence is much diminished. In truth, his effectiveness has been circumscribed for months by the perception of him as a "lame duck" president. Any actions he may take between now and inauguration day on January 20, such as his visit to Ireland next week, will perforce be largely symbolic.

The impact of the drift in Washington is far-reaching. In the Middle East, where US diplomacy has monopolised the conduct of the peace process, negotiations are at a standstill.

Less than six months after hopes of an Israeli-Palestinian settlement were sky-high, there is an almost total impasse, punctuated by sporadic violence. Israel is once again threatening to attack Syria if the security situation on its border with Lebanon continues to deteriorate. Meanwhile the long-serving US mediator, Dennis Ross, has announced that he will quit his job next month.

The US has taken its eye off the ball in a number of other crucial areas. In Iraq, Saddam Hussein is deftly exploiting the hiatus to chip away at UN sanctions and unsettle international oil markets, with the active connivance of many Arab states. The US has been reduced to looking on helplessly.

In Yugoslavia, the new government of Vojislav Kostunica is facing renewed, low-level conflict on Serbia's border with Kosovo and an attempted political comeback in next month's elections by the deposed Slobodan Milosevic. No progress has been made since the Belgrade revolution in delivering Mr Milosevic to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Russia's leader, Vladimir Putin, has been busy exploiting the situation, too. To great American alarm, Russia has quietly resumed arms exports to Iran - a country that the US has attempted to isolate for the past eight years. Moscow has also increased its weapons dealing with China, identified as the biggest 21st-century security threat to the US, and stepped up its contacts with the "rogue state" North Korea. Mr Putin recently visited Pyongyang and - provocatively - will soon travel to another traditional US foe, Fidel Castro's Cuba.

On the bigger question of international arms control agreements, the confusion is palpable. Mr Putin has offered deep cuts in Russia's nuclear weapons arsenal - but only if the US drops plans to deploy a new national missile defence (NMD) system known as "son of Star Wars".

This proposal has merely added to American embarrassment. Nobody can say if and when NMD will go ahead. Mr Putin is left looking like a responsible and serious international leader while the US looks well, embarrassed.

Meanwhile a distracted Washington has fallen foul of the European Union on two fronts. Apparently uncertain of the future or limitations of its own policy, American negotiators clashed disastrously with EU countries at the recent climate change talks in the Hague. The result was the collapse of the delicate Kyoto process to combat global warming.

And this week, the outgoing US defence secretary, William Cohen, threw an unexpected spanner in the works of the EU's nascent rapid reaction force, claiming that it could destroy the Nato alliance. Mr Cohen's statement was at odds with previous pronouncements by the state department and the White House - a sure sign that, increasingly, nobody is really in charge in Washington.

Some of these logjams may ease if, say, George W Bush is confirmed as US president-elect. He is firmly committed, for example, to NMD and does not believe in global warming. On these issues, at least, it will be clear where the US stands.

But Mr Bush's approach to international affairs is so vague that US policy in other areas may continue to be a puzzle for some time to come. What does Mr Bush make of the possible collapse of democratic government in Indonesia? What might he do if faced by the failure of the UN peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone? What is his view on the still dangerous Indo-Pakistan confrontation over Kashmir? What will he do if terrorists again attack US targets in the Middle East?

Despite his lame duck status, President Clinton may still have a few surprises up his sleeve. Once the presidential succession is settled, watch out for increased US diplomatic and military pressure on terrorists in Afghanistan whom the FBI has linked to the bomb attack in Aden on the USS Cole. This week the Washington Post, house journal of American government, called for a tough US riposte.

In 1992, after losing the presidential election to Mr Clinton, former president George Bush Sr looked around for one last big gesture. He chose Somalia, where the UN was at the mercy of warlords, and sent in the Marines - with disastrous long-term results. But the intervention ensured that he appeared to leave office in a blaze of glory. Mr Clinton may succumb to a similar, symbolic temptation.
