Moscow has also increased its weapons dealing with China, identified as the biggest 21st-century security threat to the US, and stepped up its contacts with the "rogue state" North Korea. Mr Putin recently visited Pyongyang and - provocatively - will soon travel to another traditional US foe, Fidel Castro's Cuba. On the bigger question of international arms control agreements, the confusion is palpable. Mr Putin has offered deep cuts in Russia's nuclear weapons arsenal - but only if the US drops plans to deploy a new national missile defence (NMD) system known as "son of Star Wars". This proposal has merely added to American embarrassment. Nobody can say if and when NMD will go ahead. Mr Putin is left looking like a responsible and serious international leader while the US looks well, embarrassed. Meanwhile a distracted Washington has fallen foul of the European Union on two fronts. Apparently uncertain of the future or limitations of its own policy, American negotiators clashed disastrously with EU countries at the recent climate change talks in the Hague. The result was the collapse of the delicate Kyoto process to combat global warming. And this week, the outgoing US defence secretary, William Cohen, threw an unexpected spanner in the works of the EU's nascent rapid reaction force, claiming that it could destroy the Nato alliance. Mr Cohen's statement was at odds with previous pronouncements by the state department and the White House - a sure sign that, increasingly, nobody is really in charge in Washington. Some of these logjams may ease if, say, George W Bush is confirmed as US president-elect. He is firmly committed, for example, to NMD and does not believe in global warming. On these issues, at least, it will be clear where the US stands. But Mr Bush's approach to international affairs is so vague that US policy in other areas may continue to be a puzzle for some time to come. What does Mr Bush make of the possible collapse of democratic government in Indonesia? What might he do if faced by the failure of the UN peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone? What is his view on the still dangerous Indo-Pakistan confrontation over Kashmir? What will he do if terrorists again attack US targets in the Middle East? Despite his lame duck status, President Clinton may still have a few surprises up his sleeve. Once the presidential succession is settled, watch out for increased US diplomatic and military pressure on terrorists in Afghanistan whom the FBI has linked to the bomb attack in Aden on the USS Cole. This week the Washington Post, house journal of American government, called for a tough US riposte. In 1992, after losing the presidential election to Mr Clinton, former president George Bush Sr looked around for one last big gesture. He chose Somalia, where the UN was at the mercy of warlords, and sent in the Marines - with disastrous long-term results. But the intervention ensured that he appeared to leave office in a blaze of glory. Mr Clinton may succumb to a similar, symbolic temptation. webTitle: Interest rates: Waiting for the move down

fields.headline: Waiting for the move down
fields.standfirst: The City believes interest rates have peaked, but the Bank of England wants to be sure inflation is cowed before they go lower, writes economics correspondent Mark Atkinson
fields.trailText: The City believes interest rates have peaked, but the Bank of England wants to be sure inflation is thoroughly cowed before they go lower, writes economics correspondent Mark Atkinson.
fields.body:
Mervyn King, one of the two deputy governors of the Bank of England, once said that he wanted to make monetary policy boring. Doing away with the uncertainty surrounding interest rate decisions would be proof that the economy really had entered a period of stability, so craved by business and homeowners alike.

Judging by the torpor surrounding yesterday's meeting of the Bank's interest rate-setting committee, he has succeeded.

The monetary policy committee left the cost of borrowing on hold at 6% for the 10th month in a row - the longest period of stability for 10 years -and absolutely no one was surprised. So obvious was the outcome that some seasoned watchers of the MPC had forgotten the meeting was taken place.

The consensus in the City is that rates have peaked and, given the slowdown in global economic growth and the weakness of inflation, will soon be heading downwards. That, indeed, is the most likely outcome.

But homeowners and business borrowers hoping for an early reduction in their debt servicing costs could be kept waiting for several months yet.

Despite the global slowdown, there is precious little evidence so far that consumer spending in the UK is coming off the boil. And with the Chancellor's extra public spending plans kicking in and a crucial January wage round still to be negotiated, there is still a chance that inflationary pressures could begin to build up, especially while the labour market remains so tight.

Until the danger of inflation overshooting the government's 2.5% inflation target becomes more distant, the MPC will remain wary of cutting. Instead, it is likely to leave rates on hold until the early spring.

By that time it will be much clearer in which direction inflation is heading. At the moment it could still go either way.

webTitle: Pearson shares hit by ad revenue fears

fields.headline: Pearson shares hit by ad revenue fears
fields.standfirst:
Dec 5: Carlton braced for ad slump
Nov 29: Granada bullish despite ad fears
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Shares in Financial Times owner Pearson have been hit by fears of a global slump in advertising revenue, writes Dan Milmo.
Dec 5: Carlton braced for ad slump
Nov 29: Granada bullish despite ad fears
fields.body:
Mounting concerns over a global slump in advertising revenue have hit shares in Financial Times owner Pearson, after an American rival posted a profits warning.

Pearson saw its stock fall 3%, or 50p, to 1595p in early trading after Dow Jones, publisher of the Wall Street Journal, said fourth quarter earnings would fall below analysts' expectations.

Dow Jones attributed the shortfall to a decline in financial advertising at its flagship publication, with November ad volumes down 12% compared with the previous year.

A softening in the US economy has had a trickle-down effect, with fewer flotations leading to fewer advertisements from banks announcing their participation in initial public offerings.

Analysts said Dow's figures were no surprise, given the high advertising revenue the same time last year.

But they said the signs could be ominous for Pearson.

Simon Baker, analyst at SG Securities, said: "There is the possibility of a knock-on effect, in that other IPO markets could begin to weaken as well.

"Although Pearson's short-term figures might remain intact, perhaps next year there could be some weakening in figures and down-grading pressure."

A Pearson spokesman said advertising revenue at the Financial Times for the first six months of the year was up 40% compared with the same period last year, and that circulation was also increasing.

However, the media sector is currently experiencing an across-the-board slump in advertising revenue, with analysts predicting a decline in revenue growth to 2%.

Big media stocks such as Walt Disney and News Corporation have been savaged on the back of concerns of a decline in advertising revenue, and UK companies Granada Media and Carlton have experienced similar problems.

But shifts in the advertising scene are benefiting some companies. Analysts predict that roster consolidation will see a 12%-17% growth in advertising billings in 2001 for sector giants Aegis, Havas, Publicis and WPP.

webTitle: Express hits out at Hollick in print

fields.headline: Express turns on Hollick in print
fields.standfirst: Click here for full round-up of Express stories
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The Express newspaper has lashed out at Lord Hollick only weeks after he sold the publication to Richard Desmond, writes Dan Milmo.
Click here for full round-up of Express stories
fields.body:
The Express newspaper has lashed out at former owner Lord Hollick, only weeks after he sold the publication to OK! tycoon Richard Desmond.

A two-page story in today's Daily Express claims that Lord Hollick is one of four "Blair businessmen" that have used government-approved loopholes to reduce their corporation tax bills.

Under the provocative headline "Taxation Scandal of Blair Tycoons", the article states that Lord Hollick's United News & Media expected to pay no UK corporation tax for 1999 and also received a corporate tax refund of £16.5m last year

It quotes Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman saying: "This is money that would otherwise go to important areas such as pensions and the NHS."

The multimillionaire, who received £125m for the Express titles, has been a Labour supporter since his teens and gave £25,000 to the party before the last election.

Staff at the paper were highly amused at the sight of Lord Hollick's face beaming out from the page 11 today.

One insider said: "They wouldn't have dreamed about doing this when Clive was around. Is this revenge for the £40,000 bonuses? Somebody here is being very mischievious."

Last week Lord Hollick caused near mutiny at the Express after it emerged that he had handed 25 select staff cash bonuses of around £40,000 each just days after he had sold the group.

Even editor Rosie Boycoott, who received a cheque, was horrified at the clumsiness of the donations. On Monday she branded the donations "horribly divisive" in an email to staff.

Today's newspaper pulled no punches. It said United is renowned in the City for using "skilful financial techniques."

webTitle: Casting news: Penn and Pfeiffer in Oscar-friendly custody battle

fields.headline: Penn and Pfeiffer in Oscar-friendly custody battle
fields.standfirst: Plus: De Niro may buddy up to Eddie Murphy in Showtime; Anjelica Huston joins star cast of Wes Anderson's Rushmore follow-up; Wes Craven to transfer video game to big screen
fields.trailText: Plus: De Niro may buddy up to Eddie Murphy in Showtime; Anjelica Huston joins star cast of Wes Anderson's Rushmore follow-up; Wes Craven to transfer video game to big screen
fields.body:
 Sean Penn (pictured) and Michelle Pfeiffer are in negotiations to take the lead roles in Sam I Am, which is due to begin filming towards the end of January. In what sounds like sure-fire Oscar material, Penn would play the role of a retarded disabled man who fights for custody of his infant daughter, while Pfeiffer will co-star as the icy lawyer who takes up his case and (wouldn't you know it?) learns a little compassion into the bargain.

 Moving from one double-bill to another: Robert De Niro and Eddie Murphy are currently chewing over the possibility of teaming up in Showtime, a buddy picture to be co-financed by Village Roadshow and Warner Bros. De Niro will star as a tough veteran cop thrown together with a flamboyant rookie as part of a TV reality show. The script is currently being fine-tuned by Miles Millar and Alfred Gough.

 Anjelica Huston looks set to join the cast of The Royal Tenenbaums, the new film from Rushmore creators Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson. By playing the lofty matriach of a family of dysfunctional geniuses, Huston will round out an all-star cast that already includes Ben Stiller, Gene Hackman, Bill Murray and Gwyneth Paltrow.

 Scream director Wes Craven appears to be set to take the helm for the dark Lewis Carroll-flavoured horror-fantasy Alice Wonderland, based on the video game American McGee's Alice. The script is currently being written by John August (who worked on the scripts of Go, Charlie's Angels and Jurassic Park 3). According to leaked reports picked up by Aint it Cool News, Natalie Portman is rumoured to be considering taking the role of Alice.

fields.headline: Boycott lashes out at Desmond
fields.standfirst:
Boycott letter in full
Express takeover: news round-up
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Express editor Rosie Boycott has warned owner Richard Desmond that his "heavy handed" management techniques could lead to a mass exodus, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
Boycott letter in full
Express takeover: news round-up
fields.body:
Express editor Rosie Boycott has lambasted the paper's owner, Richard Desmond, about his treatment of staff, warning that his "heavy handed" management techniques could lead to a mass exodus.

Her excoriating letter to Mr Desmond comes the day two more senior editorial staff quit the paper - award-winning home affairs editor David Taylor and veteran columnist Peter Hitchens.

Ms Boycott registered her dismay at the way 60 staff, including a pregnant woman and a disabled man, learned they were made redundant yesterday.

"I understand that Sharon Harte, seven months' pregnant, was asked to distribute 'in' and 'out' letters round the floor," she said.

"She took the two bundles and then discovered that her name was on the list to go."

Ms Boycott also complained about the way one of the paper's strategic researchers was cruelly dispensed, without any regard to the paper's commitment to him following a car crash.

She says she fears contracts will not be honoured and many more editorial staff will walk in protest at the management team used by Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell.

"There are human and inhuman ways of dealing with people whose services are no longer required," she writes.

"The journalists on the Express are - to a man and woman - good and honourable people, who will not stand easily by and watch colleagues lives being trashed by heavy handed management techniques."

Mr Hitchens leaves the paper after 24 years, while Mr Taylor has been head-hunted by the Evening Standard where he was once a reporter. Editor Max Hastings has created a new post for Mr Taylor as home affairs editor.

The letter underlines the increasingly bitter relations between Ms Boycott and Mr Desmond, who bought the Express titles two weeks ago as part of a £125m deal with United News & Media boss Lord Hollick.

She has already been forced to write to staff about £40,000 bonuses that Lord Hollick sent to 25 apparently arbitrarily selected staff.

Ms Boycott and Mr Hitchens were among the 25 who benefited from his largesse, but Mr Taylor and hundreds of others were not.

In an email to heads of department, she branded the payments "horribly divisive".

fields.headline: Rosie Boycott's letter in full
fields.trailText: 3.15pm:Rosie Boycott's letter in full.
fields.body:
Dear Richard,

I want to register my dismay at hearing how the 'proposed redundancies' on Express Newspapers staff were handled yesterday.

I understand that Sharon Harte, seven months pregnant, was asked to distribute 'in' and 'out' letters round the floor.

She took the two bundles and then discovered that her name was on the list to go.

Furthermore, two other pregnant women are on the 'out' list.

Furthermore, I understand you are also considering dismissing Simon White, who has worked for the company for 21 years.

Fourteen years ago, Simon was hit by a car and left with a speech impediment, a limp and a disabled arm.

He is a strategic researcher in business development and, according to all his colleagues, "excellent at his job".

But the real point is that following his accident, Simon was guaranteed a job for life with Express Newspapers as his disabilities mean it is virtually impossible for him to find other employment.

Now he is in danger of being unemployed and faces never working again.

I am concerned that the contracts of people leaving the company may not be fully honoured and would appreciate being told just how these people are being compensated for the loss of their jobs.

If my information is incorrect, then please tell me. Everyone understands that any new management will want new teams.

But there are human and inhuman ways of dealing with people whose services are no longer required. You might say: "What has this got to do with editorial?"

The answer is a great deal. I have put enormous effort into building trust and relationships between departments: by treating people like this you just destroy all this work and good feeling.

Furthermore, the journalists on the Express are - to a man and woman - good and honourable people, who will not stand easily by and watch colleagues lives being trashed by heavy-handed management techniques.

As you are probably aware, many people are leaving the editorial floor because they are not happy to work for Northern and Shell.

This type of behaviour will only hasten the exodus. The latest in this line is Peter Hitchens,a formidable columnist who has been on the paper for 24 years.

His weekly mail bag is the largest of any columnist on the Express. He joins the Mail on Sunday early in 2001.

David Taylor, our excellent Home Affairs Editor, has also resigned today.

Rosie Boycott

fields.headline: Lennon set for Celtic switch
fields.trailText: Neil Lennon looks set to complete a £6m move to Celtic later today, with the Northern Ireland international taking a pay-cut to play for the Parkhead club.
fields.body:
Neil Lennon looks set to complete a £6m move to Celtic later today, with the Northern Ireland international taking a pay-cut to play for the Parkhead club.

The deal, which looks likely to be agreed today, will include an initial payment of £5.75m to the Foxes, followed by an extra payment dependant on Celtic's results with Lennon in the team.

Peter Taylor will be given all the money from the transfer for new players and he has already been linked with Derby's Seth Johnson and Chelsea's Jody Morris.

"Obviously I am very disappointed at the outcome, but it is just one of those things that happens in football," Taylor said today.

"I tried to talk Neil out of it. But he said he just had to play for Celtic - and in that sense we have just been a bit unlucky in that it was Celtic who were the club who came in for him.

"He is taking a big drop in his wages to go there, and that should show how genuine he is about the matter.

"Once he had made it clear that this was the move he wanted then there was not much we could do about it. In the end Celtic are going to pay a bit more than the fee we agreed they had to pay before the Tuesday deadline I set."

Stefan Oakes is set to replace Lennon in the Leicester side for Sunday's Premiership encounter with Coventry at Highfield Road.

Lennon himself admitted it was a wrench to leave the Foxes but said: "I am very excited at the prospect of becoming a Celtic player and I just can't wait to get up there and see the place for myself.

"It was always going to be a difficult decision because I have had so many great years at Leicester City.

"But I hope the fans, who have always been good to me here, will understand that the chance to join Celtic may not come around again and I had to take it.

"Peter Taylor has been brilliant with me throughout this matter, and it is easy to see why he is always so popular with players at every level he has managed at.

"I'm leaving Leicester City in the best state they have ever been in - third in the Premiership and looking good for the top six. I am sure the lads will keep on striving to stay up there."

fields.headline: Hitchens quits Express
fields.standfirst:
Boycott lashes out at Desmond
Boycott letter in full
Express takeover: news round-up
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The Express's rightwing columnist, Peter Hitchens, has quit the paper after 24 years to go to work for the Mail on Sunday, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Boycott lashes out at Desmond
Boycott letter in full
Express takeover: news round-up
fields.body:
The Express's rightwing columnist, Peter Hitchens, has quit the paper after 24 years to go to work for the Mail on Sunday as a commentator and essay writer.

Mr Hitchens, one of the circle of Express staff to collect a £40,000 bonus from Lord Hollick, was unwilling to give away too much detail, but told MediaGuardian.co.uk he was leaving "for obvious reasons".

"I'm not happy with the new ownership," he said. When asked whether his staunch conservative views will find a more natural home at the Mail on Sunday, he said: "You can draw your own conclusions."

It is known that Mr Hitchens, along with other senior journalists, objected to new owner Richard Desmond's background and managerial style.

Mr Hitchens' resignation follows those of columnists Stephen Pollard and Mary Kenny and political editor Anthony Bevins, all of whom have said on the record that they do not want to work for Mr Desmond.

An email sent by Express editor Rosie Boycott to Mr Desmond and other senior management praises Mr Hitchens as a "formidable columnist".

Ms Boycott notes that "his weekly mail bag is the largest of any columnist on the Express".

It is known that Mr Hitchens, along with other senior journalists, objected to new owner Richard Desmond's background and managerial style. Mr Hitchens' resignation follows those of columnists Stephen Pollard and Mary Kenny and political editor Anthony Bevins, all of whom have said on the record that they do not want to work for Mr Desmond. An email sent by Express editor Rosie Boycott to Mr Desmond and other senior management praises Mr Hitchens as a "formidable columnist". Ms Boycott notes that "his weekly mail bag is the largest of any columnist on the Express".

fields.headline: Channel 4's Gambler pays off
fields.trailText: 12.15pm TV overnights: Channel 4's The Gambler proved a high-roller in the audience stakes last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Gambling is becoming the new rock 'n' roll for Channel 4, with Late Night Poker already a fixture in the schedule and now documentary The Gambler proving a high-roller in the audience stakes.

The Gambler, the first instalment of a series that follows writer Jonathan Rendell as he bets £12,000 of Channel 4's money on everything from horses to scratchcards, was an instant hit.

It averaged 1.5m and a 12% share last night between 10.35-11.35pm.

Elsewhere last night, an average audience of 7.8m - 35% of available viewers - tuned in to watch Manchester United's 2-0 Champions League win over Sturm Graz on ITV's The Big Match - Live!, over two-and-a-quarter hours from 7.30pm.

fields.headline: Interest rates held for 10th month
fields.standfirst:
Budget 2000
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today kept interest rates on hold at 6% for the 10th consecutive month, as City forecasters predicted.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today kept interest rates on hold at 6% for the 10th consecutive month, as City forecasters predicted.

The decision, by the bank's nine-member monetary policy committee was announced, as usual, promptly at midday and commentators believe interest rates will stay pegged until after the Budget in the spring.

Analysts believe that signs of slower domestic and world growth rule out the prospect of an increase in borrowing costs.

And in the City, despite the bank governor, Sir Edward George, steadfastly refusing to signal that rates have peaked, there is a growing belief that the next move could be down.

In its last quarterly inflation report last month, the bank said the outlook for prices was "a little softer", raising hopes of a rate cut in the new year.

Nick Parsons, chief currency strategist at Commerzbank, said: "Our prediction is that we will see a first birthday at 6%, which will be the longest period rates have remained unchanged."

webTitle: View from New York: Show me the money

fields.headline: Show me the money
fields.standfirst: New Yorkers may be brash but don't expect them to tell you how much they earn, not least because it is probably not as much as you think, writes Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: View from New York: New Yorkers may be brash, but don't expect them to tell you how much they earn, not least because it is probably not as much as you think, writes Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
Some people will sidle up at a party and tell you about their liposuction before they ever let slip their name.

Bob Dole, the defeated presidential candidate four years ago, is always on the television, telling you what Viagra has done for him (Al Gore should be keeping an eye on this one).

And the daytime talk shows, it seems, will never exhaust the reservoir of otherwise bland individuals competing to outdo each other with the gaudiness of their confessions.

But ask any of these exactly how much it is that they are paid for their trouble and they will look at you as though you have left the house with your dog, but without the means to cover the animal's tracks.

New Yorkers might conform to many of the stereotypes attached to them and throw around tips so large as to suggest that money means nothing, but it does not follow that they will let you know what they have left in their back pockets as a result.

The city's teachers are trying to get a decent settlement from the administration and have been offered a merit pay system, three weeks without wages and more time in the classroom.

These suggestions have been embraced with all the variety of outrage that might be expected, but that does not mean that anyone would do anything so gauche as to disclose what they are paid or what they want.

In fact, a teacher with a BA starting out in the city makes $31,910 (about £22,000) a year, or nearly $8,000 less than many in the same position in the suburbs where, it is fair to surmise, many of the inquiring young minds in the beginner's charge will not be quite so challenging. After 22 years, this salary goes up to a maximum of $70,000 (£48,500) for a classroom teacher.

Among other public servants, at least the police have the satisfaction of being dubbed The Finest in the popular newspapers. It's just as well that they receive this recogition in return for their no-win jobs, because their starting pay is $31,305 a year, again below that for those new to the uniform in some of the doziest nooks in nearby Long Island.

Five years later, assuming they have managed to avoid shooting someone dead without good reason, they will be on $51,987. But unless they acquire a more elevated rank, they can go no higher than $54,978 after 20 years.

The Bravest - that would be the firefighters - start on $32,724 and move up to $49,023 after six years. And garbage collectors - amazingly known as The Strongest - start on $27,842 and hit the heights with $44,441 after five years, about $4,000 less than a teacher or a policeman.

Of the other caring professions, social workers start on up to $34,000 and can hope for about $55,000 by the time they are supervisors, about eight years later. Their employers say that, due to the rewarding, vocational nature of their work, it can be almost impossible to get social workers to go home at night; or maybe it's because they can't face the long journey now that the average two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan costs about $750,000.

The designer Calvin Klein would probably concede that his, too, is a rewarding calling, irrespective of his consideration of $21.5m a year. The same goes for Tommy Hilfiger and his $26.9m.

Compensation for aesthetic services comes in all shapes and sizes in New York, as elsewhere. The soprano Renee Fleming receives $14,000 for a performance at the Metropolitan Opera, or just $900 below what the average actor makes in a year. The weekly minimum on a Broadway stage is $1,215 and in the orchestra pit $1,220.

Apparently doctors believe that people have a warped notion of their earning power; but then it turns out that they would be hard-pushed to start on under $115,000 a year (and even more in other parts of the country, where there are fewer of them).

Of course, this is nothing alongside the few who get to practise the closest thing there is to cerebral celebrity: evening television news show anchors on about $7m; financiers (name your millions); or successful real estate brokers (standard commission for residential properties 6%).

But perhaps the reason most relatively normal people will say nothing about their salaries is because they just aren't quite as big as you'd like to believe.

webTitle: A study in stereotypes: English identity under scrutiny

fields.headline: A study in stereotypes: English identity under scrutiny
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive essay from the London Review of Books David Bell considers Paul Langford's look at how the English have historically been regarded by others
fields.trailText: David Bell on Paul Langford's study of Englishness
fields.body:
Englishness Identified: Manners and Character, 1650-1850 by Paul Langford. Oxford, 389 pp., £25, 20 April, 0 19 820681 x
Buy it at BOL

The Americans have 'American exceptionalism'. The French have 'l'exception française'. The Germans have 'der deutsche Sonderweg'. The English, on the other hand, have no equivalent catchphrase: it seems they take their exceptionality so much for granted that they don't even bother putting a name to it. Does such a thing as 'Englishness' really exist? Most current thinking on national identities suggests that it doesn't. Apparently innate and immutable national characteristics, the argument goes, are mere illusion and representation, a funhouse mirror which shows observers nothing but distorted images of their own desires, fears and preconceptions. To think of these characteristics as 'real' is to indulge in the deadliest of present-day academic sins, 'essentialism', patriarchal godfather to racism, sexism and all other noxious 'isms'.

This view is easy to ridicule. Even the most sternly post-modern cultural studies professor is likely to lapse into essentialism when confronting a rude Parisian shopkeeper, or a lazy Italian bureaucrat. Yet however obvious national differences appear at first glance, attempting to document them usually ends up looking silly as well. Take the recent scientific study, summarised in the Independent, which attempted to rank nations as more or less neurotic by measuring rates of suicide, crime, divorce and the consumption of alcohol and caffeine. The UK came out as the world's eighth most stable, extroverted nation (just ahead of Germany), while Hungary and France ranked as the most neurotic and introverted. The fact that the US came out as the nation in the best psychological health should perhaps have raised some doubts in the authors' minds about their methods.

Given the empirical difficulty and political incorrectness involved in measuring national differences, it's no surprise that most historians have long since turned to studying the representations and stereotypes themselves. On one level, these have served to demonise and dehumanise foreigners, and to exclude unwanted groups from the national community. On another, they have promoted national unity and pride. Instilling the people with properly national characteristics has been a central preoccupation for educators, artists and scholars.

There is a shoal of new cultural history books about such matters. They tend to proceed from the assumption that visions of national character are by nature multiple, variable and competing. Paul Langford begs to differ. In Englishness Identified, he admits that stereotypes of the English have often contradicted each other. The island race has been seen as alternately lazy and industrious, honest and hypocritical, polite and uncouth, taciturn and bombastic. He nonetheless insists that between the mid-17th and mid-19th centuries, these characterisations fell into distinctive patterns. The themes he identifies are energy, candour, decency, taciturnity, reserve and, of course, eccentricity. He does not go so far as to say that the themes reflected actual traits present in the English population. Rather, "stereotypes resemble a kind of solera, to which each new pen adds but a drop." Observers saw, in other words, what they had been led to see, and helped others to see the same thing. The result was a recognisably English collection of traits.

Langford sets out to prove his case in a robust, no-nonsense, thoroughly empirical manner (typically English, one might almost say). He has assembled a large database of descriptions of the English, above all by foreigners, analysed it and found his six common themes. He has further divided each theme into four to seven sub-themes, so that candour, for instance, is broken down into plainness, openness, separateness, domesticity, honesty and humbug. He has written up chapters and sub-chapters with these headings, illustrated them with a thousand illustrative quotations and paraphrases, thrown in a brief introduction and conclusion, and voilà !

His focus on England and Englishness, as opposed to Britain and Britishness, is timely. Earlier this summer, a leader in the Times attacked Tom Nairn, Eric Hobsbawm and especially Linda Colley for supplying a tendentious, politicised justification for the break-up of Britain. Citing a recent article by JCD Clark, the Times claimed that Britain and Britishness, far from being 'forged' largely in the 18th century as Colley claims, have deeper historical roots. Devolution, and the concurrent resurgence of 'English' nationalism are not therefore inevitable steps on the road to a decentralised, Europeanised Britain, but perverse attempts to cut against the grain of history. Langford's evidence, however, shows that the undeniable success 'Britain' enjoyed as a political concept never carried over very strongly into the realm of ethnic and cultural identification. "It is difficult to discover any alleged British characteristic that does not in practice coincide with an alleged English characteristic," he observes, and adds that the word 'Britishness' did not appear until the late 19th century. The label 'Britain' applied to the state far more than it did to the people, who remained, for the most part, firmly Scots, Welsh, Irish or English. From this point of view, one of Colley's central arguments seems correct: as the religious and imperial justifications for having a powerful British state have faded away, what more natural than for the component pieces of the UK to reassert their individual identity?

Langford has found some real gems in his vast mine of material. I learned, for example, that the word 'eccentricity' only entered into common circulation in the 1790s, and that 'silence is golden,' which I thought to be a quintessentially English proverb, is actually Swiss in origin (it was popularised in England by Carlyle). In 18th-century France, Langford has discovered, 'une conversation à l'anglaise' was slang for a long silence. He also tells the story of the poet Samuel Rogers who, in 1815, asked a passerby on the streets of Paris, "Are you an Englishman?" and received the reply: "Thank God I am, Sir." He quotes Washington Irving's wonderful description of the English traveller in Italy who had his servant prepare and serve his meals in his carriage: beefsteak, "ketchup and soy, and Cayenne pepper, and Harvey sauce, and a bottle of port wine, from that warehouse the carriage, in which his master seemed desirous of carrying England about the world with him." In the 18th century, typical English cooking did not involve conscientiously boiling something to remove all traces of taste, but rather over-spicing it. We learn, too, about the French traveller Joseph Fiévée, who thought English women hypocritical for not receiving visitors in their bedrooms in the name of modesty, while rushing to their windows without shame to watch half-naked boxers. And there is Lord Castlereagh's reply to Mme de Stael's complaint that the English language had no equivalent for the French word sentiment: "No, there is no English word, but the Irish have one that corresponds exactly - 'blarney'." Langford himself has a pleasantly dry wit, as in this comment on the supposed English aversion to kissing: "Perhaps English men could sleep more secure in their beds when they were assured that the sexual sensibility of wives had not been precociously stimulated by frequent kissing in adolescence."

Another favourite of mine is the story of the two Englishmen who, every day, at the same hour, adjourned to neighbouring 'shades', or stalls, alongside the Thames, to rest from their labours. For 27 years they did not exchange a single word. Then, one day, one of the men lifted his voice and said "Sir, you and I have sat here with a board between us now for 27 years. May I venture to ask your name?" The reply from the other side of the board was: "Sir, you're a very impertinent fellow." The ingredients are good enough, but the finished product puts one in mind of a tasty bread made without enough yeast. Langford's style is fluid but all too unvarying. He tends to begin a paragraph by paraphrasing some commonly held view of the English: "Removing the lower-class Englishman from his own environment evidently had the effect of loosening his moral moorings"; "The English were proud of their lack of vindictiveness"; 'For the English the most savage war seemed a kind of patriotic game"; "There was a sense in which the English did not seem neglectful of their past." He provides a short discussion, four or five quotations, and then moves on to the next point. "The majesty of English law also owed much to this sense of decency"; "English dress sense lacked flair and panache, but had a kind of solidity"; "The traditional image of the English was of excess and exhibitionism"; "The decency of Englishwomen had much to do with sexual mores."

After a hundred pages or so of such relentless generalisation, the six themes flow into each other like watercolours under a shower (particularly taciturnity and reserve - half the quotations adduced for the one could serve the other equally well). Langford doesn't help matters by doing so little to put his source material in context. Joseph Fiévée, for instance, was a French hack journalist and intellectual, of elastic political loyalties, who might have walked out of the pages of Balzac's Lost Illusions. Here, however, he's left as a disembodied voice talking about the English, and Langford does the same with nearly all his other sources. It would no doubt have inflated the book beyond reasonable measure to deal adequately even with the French, and the rich brew of jealousy, admiration, distaste and resentment which fed into their collective attitudes towards England, to say nothing of their individual biases and passions. The French historian Edmond Dziembowski's excellent monograph, Un nouveau patriotisme français (not cited by Langford) takes over five hundred pages to discuss French attitudes towards Britain during the period 1750-70 alone. But Langford hardly deals with his sources' national contexts at all, and misses some of the best French material altogether (such as Robert Martin Lesuire's corrosively funny 1760 novel Les Sauvages de l'Europe, a virtual catalogue of anti-English stereotypes). And without contextualisation, the observers, like the observed, blend together into a homogeneous mass.

This problem undermines Langford's general conclusions. He has worked hard to uncover the broad outlines of 'Englishness', but at the expense of identifying the changes which, in the end, are of greatest interest. At the start, he suggests a general shift in a typical Englishman from barbaric fanatic at the time of Charles I's execution to vigorous, civilised entrepreneur two hundred years later. He also makes the (not entirely surprising) assertion that images of the English as lazy became less frequent during the Industrial Revolution. Yet he never follows up on these remarks in any systematic manner, and undercuts them by juxtaposing quotations from the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. In the end, 'Englishness' emerges from the book as curiously static, despite the fact that between 1650 and 1850 England changed from a predominantly rural, isolated, heavily religious country dominated by the aristocracy into a quasi-democratic, increasingly urban and secular industrial society, and the centre of a worldwide empire. Langford has little to say about these transformations, especially the last. His European and American sources have observed the English in their native habitat, and as tourists abroad, but not as soldiers, sailors and imperial bureaucrats, the capacities in which most of the world knew them.

Similarly, Langford has relatively little to say about disagreements over Englishness, and what was at stake in them. He says he prefers to quote foreigners because of "the likelihood that if their testimony is not objective, it is at least disengaged". But it is hard to think of French observers, for example, as particularly disengaged, given how much of the period they spent at war with Britain. Even in peacetime, memories of multiple defeats and other aspects of the perennial rivalry indelibly coloured their perceptions. But Langford deals as little with international conflict as he does with empire. Otherwise he might have remarked that the exchange "Are you an Englishman?" - "Thank God, I am, Sir!" would have been more telling had it taken place in Copenhagen in 1820, rather than in Paris in the year of Waterloo. His preference for amusing and quotable observations, as opposed to angry or ideological ones, obscures the extent to which Englishness was a contested terrain. Many foreigners - the Highlanders after Culloden, or the Mahrattas after Assaye, for example - did not actually perceive the English as attractively John Mortimerish compounds of energy, candour and decency, but as something altogether less benign.

It is instructive to compare Englishness Identified with Ian Buruma's recent book, Voltaire's Coconuts, to which an American publisher has given the more bland but descriptive title Anglomania. Buruma did only a small fraction of Langford's research and his impressionistic, personal survey of admiring attitudes towards England, from Voltaire's France to Major's England, lacks Langford's scholarly rigour. But he has a keen eye for the sort of anecdote which reveals more than a long page of quotations and he gives a strong, clear sense of his sources' backgrounds and outlook. Most important, he evokes how these men and women, including his own parents' Dutch and Jewish families, responded to England as a model and as a refuge. He also provides a savage account of the 'young fogies' who gathered around Charles Moore's Spectator in the 1980s, trying and succeeding to become walking parodies of the most blimpishly insular sort of Englishman. I can think of few better illustrations of the way national stereotypes are shaped and reinforced.

 To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. The extensive online archive of essays from past editions includes John Lanchester on the rise of Microsoft, Alan Bennett's Diary and much more.

I learned, for example, that the word 'eccentricity' only entered into common circulation in the 1790s, and that 'silence is golden,' which I thought to be a quintessentially English proverb, is actually Swiss in origin (it was popularised in England by Carlyle). In 18th-century France, Langford has discovered, 'une conversation à l'anglaise' was slang for a long silence. He also tells the story of the poet Samuel Rogers who, in 1815, asked a passerby on the streets of Paris, "Are you an Englishman?" and received the reply: "Thank God I am, Sir." He quotes Washington Irving's wonderful description of the English traveller in Italy who had his servant prepare and serve his meals in his carriage: beefsteak, "ketchup and soy, and Cayenne pepper, and Harvey sauce, and a bottle of port wine, from that warehouse the carriage, in which his master seemed desirous of carrying England about the world with him." In the 18th century, typical English cooking did not involve conscientiously boiling something to remove all traces of taste, but rather over-spicing it. We learn, too, about the French traveller Joseph Fiévée, who thought English women hypocritical for not receiving visitors in their bedrooms in the name of modesty, while rushing to their windows without shame to watch half-naked boxers. And there is Lord Castlereagh's reply to Mme de Stael's complaint that the English language had no equivalent for the French word sentiment: "No, there is no English word, but the Irish have one that corresponds exactly - 'blarney'." Langford himself has a pleasantly dry wit, as in this comment on the supposed English aversion to kissing: "Perhaps English men could sleep more secure in their beds when they were assured that the sexual sensibility of wives had not been precociously stimulated by frequent kissing in adolescence." Another favourite of mine is the story of the two Englishmen who, every day, at the same hour, adjourned to neighbouring 'shades', or stalls, alongside the Thames, to rest from their labours. For 27 years they did not exchange a single word. Then, one day, one of the men lifted his voice and said "Sir, you and I have sat here with a board between us now for 27 years. May I venture to ask your name?" The reply from the other side of the board was: "Sir, you're a very impertinent fellow." The ingredients are good enough, but the finished product puts one in mind of a tasty bread made without enough yeast. Langford's style is fluid but all too unvarying. He tends to begin a paragraph by paraphrasing some commonly held view of the English: "Removing the lower-class Englishman from his own environment evidently had the effect of loosening his moral moorings"; "The English were proud of their lack of vindictiveness"; 'For the English the most savage war seemed a kind of patriotic game"; "There was a sense in which the English did not seem neglectful of their past." He provides a short discussion, four or five quotations, and then moves on to the next point. "The majesty of English law also owed much to this sense of decency"; "English dress sense lacked flair and panache, but had a kind of solidity"; "The traditional image of the English was of excess and exhibitionism"; "The decency of Englishwomen had much to do with sexual mores." After a hundred pages or so of such relentless generalisation, the six themes flow into each other like watercolours under a shower (particularly taciturnity and reserve - half the quotations adduced for the one could serve the other equally well). Langford doesn't help matters by doing so little to put his source material in context. Joseph Fiévée, for instance, was a French hack journalist and intellectual, of elastic political loyalties, who might have walked out of the pages of Balzac's Lost Illusions. Here, however, he's left as a disembodied voice talking about the English, and Langford does the same with nearly all his other sources. It would no doubt have inflated the book beyond reasonable measure to deal adequately even with the French, and the rich brew of jealousy, admiration, distaste and resentment which fed into their collective attitudes towards England, to say nothing of their individual biases and passions. The French historian Edmond Dziembowski's excellent monograph, Un nouveau patriotisme français (not cited by Langford) takes over five hundred pages to discuss French attitudes towards Britain during the period 1750-70 alone. But Langford hardly deals with his sources' national contexts at all, and misses some of the best French material altogether (such as Robert Martin Lesuire's corrosively funny 1760 novel Les Sauvages de l'Europe, a virtual catalogue of anti-English stereotypes). And without contextualisation, the observers, like the observed, blend together into a homogeneous mass. This problem undermines Langford's general conclusions. He has worked hard to uncover the broad outlines of 'Englishness', but at the expense of identifying the changes which, in the end, are of greatest interest. At the start, he suggests a general shift in a typical Englishman from barbaric fanatic at the time of Charles I's execution to vigorous, civilised entrepreneur two hundred years later. He also makes the (not entirely surprising) assertion that images of the English as lazy became less frequent during the Industrial Revolution. Yet he never follows up on these remarks in any systematic manner, and undercuts them by juxtaposing quotations from the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. In the end, 'Englishness' emerges from the book as curiously static, despite the fact that between 1650 and 1850 England changed from a predominantly rural, isolated, heavily religious country dominated by the aristocracy into a quasi-democratic, increasingly urban and secular industrial society, and the centre of a worldwide empire. Langford has little to say about these transformations, especially the last. His European and American sources have observed the English in their native habitat, and as tourists abroad, but not as soldiers, sailors and imperial bureaucrats, the capacities in which most of the world knew them. Similarly, Langford has relatively little to say about disagreements over Englishness, and what was at stake in them. He says he prefers to quote foreigners because of "the likelihood that if their testimony is not objective, it is at least disengaged". But it is hard to think of French observers, for example, as particularly disengaged, given how much of the period they spent at war with Britain. Even in peacetime, memories of multiple defeats and other aspects of the perennial rivalry indelibly coloured their perceptions. But Langford deals as little with international conflict as he does with empire. Otherwise he might have remarked that the exchange "Are you an Englishman?" - "Thank God, I am, Sir!" would have been more telling had it taken place in Copenhagen in 1820, rather than in Paris in the year of Waterloo. His preference for amusing and quotable observations, as opposed to angry or ideological ones, obscures the extent to which Englishness was a contested terrain. Many foreigners - the Highlanders after Culloden, or the Mahrattas after Assaye, for example - did not actually perceive the English as attractively John Mortimerish compounds of energy, candour and decency, but as something altogether less benign. It is instructive to compare Englishness Identified with Ian Buruma's recent book, Voltaire's Coconuts, to which an American publisher has given the more bland but descriptive title Anglomania. Buruma did only a small fraction of Langford's research and his impressionistic, personal survey of admiring attitudes towards England, from Voltaire's France to Major's England, lacks Langford's scholarly rigour. But he has a keen eye for the sort of anecdote which reveals more than a long page of quotations and he gives a strong, clear sense of his sources' backgrounds and outlook. Most important, he evokes how these men and women, including his own parents' Dutch and Jewish families, responded to England as a model and as a refuge. He also provides a savage account of the 'young fogies' who gathered around Charles Moore's Spectator in the 1980s, trying and succeeding to become walking parodies of the most blimpishly insular sort of Englishman. I can think of few better illustrations of the way national stereotypes are shaped and reinforced.  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. webTitle: In brief: Drew's the girl for students

fields.headline: Drew's the girl for students
fields.standfirst: Plus: Robert Downey Jr in hospital again after another drugs arrest; Hollywood plastic surgeon to spill the beans about his celebrity patients
fields.trailText: Plus: Robert Downey Jr in hospital again after another drugs arrest; Hollywood plastic surgeon to spill the beans about his celebrity patients
fields.body:
 In a move guaranteed to incense traditionalists, a university in Ohio is offering students a novel new course to take as part of their degree - one term's worth of expert tuition in The Life and Times of Drew Barrymore (pictured). The new addition to the curriculum at Oberlin College involves an in-depth study of the Barrymore oeuvre culminating in a tense final exam in which the students must perform a satirical sketch based on a scene from one of Drew's movies. No surprise to learn that the course has been engineered by "the Experimental College", a student-run body which has previously encouraged the study of the "Art and Science of Home Brewing" and "Whiskey Appreciation". Given Drew's own painful battle with the bottle, either course could provide valuable background research for any student seeking to properly get to grips with the Charlie's Angels star. Students, eh? They're our future, apparently.

 Robert Downey Jr spent last weekend in hospital after reportedly checking himself into Cedars Sinai Medical Centre suffering from depression. The actor, who has a regular part in the TV series Ally McBeal, had been arrested last week at the Palm Springs resort and charged with drugs possession. Currently on police bail, Downey Jr is due to appear for arraignment on December 27 and his lawyers are promising a "vigorous defence".

 A plastic surgeon to the stars is planning to publish a potentially explosive dirt-dishing book next year after a gagging order imposed by an LA court was lifted this week. Steven Hoefflin (dubbed "Doc Hollywood") has caused controversy with his supposedly cavalier treatment of his glitzy clientele. But readers will have to wait until 2001 to read the real juice on how Hoefflin allegedly sniggered at a nude Liz Taylor, openly mocked the size of Don Johnson's penis and tweaked the hands on Michael Jackson's watch to make him believe an operation went on longer than it actually did.

fields.headline: Malcolm Bradbury
fields.standfirst: Prolific novelist and critic renowned for his wry observations of academia and his support for new talent

fields.body:
"The door of a room adjoining opens a little; a dark, tousled-haired head, with a sad visage, peers through, looks at Howard for a little, and then retreats. The face has a vague familiarity; Howard recalls that this depressed-looking figure is a lecturer in the English department, a man who, 10 years earlier, had produced two tolerably well known and acceptably reviewed novels, filled, as novels then were, with moral scruple and concern.

"Since then there has been silence, as if, under the pressure of contemporary change, there was no more moral scruple and concern, no new substance to be spun. The man alone persists; he passes nervously through the campus, he teaches, sadly, he avoids strangers."

In these words Sir Malcolm Bradbury, who has died aged 68, made his own Hitchcockian, though uncharacteristically reclusive, appearance in The History Man (1975), his greatest and most influential novel. His death marks the close of half a century of academic and literary history, of which he was the chronicler.

Malcolm Bradbury was born in Sheffield, the son of Arthur Bradbury, a railway worker, and his wife Doris, and grew up in Nottingham. He took a first-class degree in English at the then fairly new University of Leicester, and did postgraduate work at Queen Mary College, London, at Manchester and in the United States, before taking up his first full-time appointment in 1959, in the adult education department at Hull University.

In 1961 he moved to the English department of Birmingham University, where he met another recently appointed lecturer, David Lodge, with whom he was to form a long and close friendship and amiable rivalry. In 1965 he joined the new University of East Anglia; he was to remain in Norwich for the rest of his life.

Bradbury was a prolific writer - as an academic critic, as a novelist and humorist, and for television, a medium that increasingly fascinated him. Bradbury, however, made no secret of the fact that fiction, and in particular the novel, was his true love. "Like most comic novelists, I take the novel extremely seriously," he said. "It is the best of all forms - open and personal, intelligent and inquiring. I value it for its scepticism, its irony and its play."

His first novel, Eating People Is Wrong, which picked up the baton from Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim, appeared in 1959 and was an instant success. From then on his novels appeared at the rate of roughly one a decade. In almost all, the most frequently recurring theme is that of the slightly naive, liberal innocent, usually an academic, hilariously abroad in an unfamiliar and occasionally slightly threatening context.

Of all his novels, it was The History Man by which he will be most lastingly remembered, and which indeed was one of the outstanding novels of the 70s. It charts the successful career of the manipulative and promiscuous radical sociologist Howard Kirk at the University of Watermouth (which bears more than a passing resemblance to East Anglia).

Bradbury's contribution to the literary life of his time was as extraordinary as his prolific output. He will be properly remembered for his part, with Angus Wilson, in founding in 1970 the creative writing programme at East Anglia - at the time the only MA of standing in the subject in Britain, and today, in spite of many imitators, still the most distinguished.

His generosity to all literary ventures he regarded as worthy was remarkable, and his inability to reject appeals for help was a severe trial to his agent. To few, however, did Bradbury give as much time and attention as he did to the affairs of the British Council, of whose literary work he was an invaluable supporter. His tours overseas for the council, many of which reappeared transmogrified in his novels, were invariably marked by unscheduled revelry, as well as by serious literary discussions.

If he was pre-eminently a gregarious man, and generous with his friendship, Bradbury was even more markedly a devoted family man. In 1959 he married Elizabeth Salt, who was the greatest single source of happiness and support to him, and by whom he had two sons. He was appointed CBE in 1991, for services to literature, and was knighted in 2000.

The literary world is much the poorer for the loss of its own History Man, and of a voice unequalled for its humanity and wit.

webTitle: View from Los Angeles: Closing the drum circle

fields.headline: Closing the drum circle
fields.standfirst:
Newcomers to the Venice beach area of Los Angeles can't stand the noise longstanding residents make, reports Duncan Campbell

Venice Beach Drum Circle
fields.trailText: Newcomers to the Venice beach area of Los Angeles can't stand the noise longstanding residents make, reports Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
One of the great old film cliches that Hollywood gave the world was that famous cry from beleaguered white explorers in Africa: "It's the drums I can't stand! The drums!" Now the drums have come rather closer to home but still the beleaguered adventurer is crying: "It's the drums I can't stand!"

The location this time is Venice, the sea-side playground of Los Angeles, which at weekends is the home of probably a wider variety of races, ages, sexes, sexual persuasions, sizes, colours, fashions, belief systems, tattoos and artistic notions regularly assembled anywhere in the world.

Along the walkway is everyone from Peruvian singers to Chinese masseuses, Nevadan weight-lifters to Indian mystics with a smattering of LA gang style kings, out-of-state-tourists, sexologists, musclemen, stand-up comedians, preachers, psychics, psychos and sidekicks.

One enduring feature for the last 40 years has been the drum circle which is open to all comers who want to play or listen and keeps up its beat throughout the weekend days until the sun dips down over the Pacific.

But now the drums are under threat. Some beachfront residents have started to complain that the noise is so great that they have to move off their decks and entertain their guests inside their beachfront houses. Others claim that it is just a damn cacophony and much too close to residential areas.

At the heart of the problem is that, as Venice becomes more fashionable, people are moving in from other areas in the city and do not always like what they see or, in this case, hear. Matters reached a head when the police were approached last month by a small group of residents who suggested that the drummers were in breach of a city noise ordinance and should be moved from their current site.

The drummers are fighting back. "The enemy is not the city officials and the police per se," says the circle's website which is put together by Sandra Tatum, "but the narrow-minded uncompromising attitude of some individuals who think they can dictate their own selfish agendas against the wishes of the whole community they purportedly belong to.

"If the character of the community is not to your liking, it's time to rent a u-haul truck...These people will not stop complaining. We are a nation of complainers - people who abuse their freedom, unable to enjoy life, and make others' lives miserable."

The residents who have complained say that they do not want to close the circle, as it were, merely move it down the beach and away from the houses. But the drummers say that the whole point of the circle is to have it where it can be seen and heard and joined by passers-by.

The drummers and their supporters have responded to the challenge by getting together a petition of 10,000 signatures. Compromise may yet be reached and this weekend will be a test of whether the drums are to be silenced.

The police, who patrol the area on bicycles, wearing nifty shorts and cycle helmets, are far from anxious to have another confrontation to add to all their current problems. And the last people they want to take on are surely those who march to the beat of a different drum.

webTitle: Poor are sold down the river

fields.headline: Poor are sold down the river
fields.trailText: In 1997, when the World Commission on Dams was set up, anti-dam activists were divided over the wisdom of cooperating with the World Bank. Since the 60s the bank had been the main force that financed and legitimised the dam building boom that has transformed the world's rivers.
fields.body:
In 1997, when the World Commission on Dams was set up, anti-dam activists were divided over the wisdom of cooperating with the World Bank. Since the 60s the bank had been the main force that financed and legitimised the dam building boom that has transformed the world's rivers.

Activists who had participated in the bank's consultation processes felt that they had been ignored or misrepresented. Others had seen progressive policies adopted on paper, then ignored. The commission, they agreed, must produce a report that would examine the record and rationale of dams. Dam promoters, guilty of 40 years of ecological and social destruction, were to be held accountable. Reparations for dispossessed people and restoration of river ecosystems would be advocated. Most importantly, the report must not become another endorsement of the "benefits" of dams, leaving unchallenged the keystone of the dam builders' ideology: that dams are needed for economic development that benefits the poor.

Last month in London leading anti-dam activists joined Nelson Mandela, the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, and representatives of the dam-building industry for the release of the commission's final report. It documented the huge social costs of large dams, with up to 80m people dispossessed and millions more impoverished. It acknowledged the shoddy economics and human rights violations that attended dam construction. It advocated more rigorous standards for planning future projects. So shouldn't activists feel vindicated? No.

The commission, evading its main task of adjudicating on the "development effectiveness" of dams, emphasised that poor planning has caused unnecessary harm. This contradicts critics' charges that it is the dams themselves, no matter how well planned, that inevitably have deleterious social and ecological impacts.

Critics also say that dams are the very antithesis of development for the poor because they enable the expropriation of the resources of a river valley, placing the livelihood of people who depend on rivers at the disposal of those who have the power to exploit them.

This was no truth commission, more of a peace process. The report is the product of a settlement negotiated between human rights activists, water policy experts and dam builders; not a scientific inquiry. Those activists who facilitated the commission's process are pleased with the outcome. They believe that much of the evidence will support their future campaigns, and they argue that the commission's recommendations for transparent planning processes and "prior informed consent" of the people affected, if enacted, would virtually preclude future dams.

Others see the failure to challenge the rationale for dam building as a setback, and the failure clearly to advocate reparations as a disappointment. Environmentalists too will disagree with the commission's view of the impact of dams on river ecosystems - that with better planning dams can mitigate their impact or even enhance the river environment.

Pressure for consensus blinded the commission to what could have been its most important contribution: to address the global cumulative impact of dams. Except for global warming there is no more drastic human alteration of the physical and ecological landscape in the past 40 years. To say that dams affect 60% of the world's rivers greatly understates their effect on the transformation of river valleys, estuaries, coastlines and coastal seas in temperate and tropical zones.

The destruction of species dependent on floodplains, wetlands and natural river flows is not just an environmental tragedy, it affects the food supply and livelihood of millions. Cities, river valleys and whole countries are now held hostage for their water supply and flood protection to the operation of big dams upstream - dams that are silting up, ageing and growing more dangerous every year.

The real problem in the big dams debate is similar to that posed by nuclear power plants: not how to improve their planning, but how to get rid of them.

Over the past three years plans for new projects such as Ilisu in Turkey, Wloslawek on the Vistula, resurrected projects such as Arun in Nepal, or Bakun in the rainforest of Sarawak have moved ahead. Construction of Itoitz in Spain, Boguchany in Siberia and the Three Gorges in China has continued.

Most poignant of all, in October the Indian Supreme Court approved completion of the World Bank-initiated Sardar Sarovar dam. It was the argument of presumed development benefits, not the vigorous "prior informed dissent" of 500,000 people of the Narmada valley that the court found most persuasive.

No. The commission, evading its main task of adjudicating on the "development effectiveness" of dams, emphasised that poor planning has caused unnecessary harm. This contradicts critics' charges that it is the dams themselves, no matter how well planned, that inevitably have deleterious social and ecological impacts. Critics also say that dams are the very antithesis of development for the poor because they enable the expropriation of the resources of a river valley, placing the livelihood of people who depend on rivers at the disposal of those who have the power to exploit them. This was no truth commission, more of a peace process. The report is the product of a settlement negotiated between human rights activists, water policy experts and dam builders; not a scientific inquiry. Those activists who facilitated the commission's process are pleased with the outcome. They believe that much of the evidence will support their future campaigns, and they argue that the commission's recommendations for transparent planning processes and "prior informed consent" of the people affected, if enacted, would virtually preclude future dams. Others see the failure to challenge the rationale for dam building as a setback, and the failure clearly to advocate reparations as a disappointment. Environmentalists too will disagree with the commission's view of the impact of dams on river ecosystems - that with better planning dams can mitigate their impact or even enhance the river environment. Pressure for consensus blinded the commission to what could have been its most important contribution: to address the global cumulative impact of dams. Except for global warming there is no more drastic human alteration of the physical and ecological landscape in the past 40 years. To say that dams affect 60% of the world's rivers greatly understates their effect on the transformation of river valleys, estuaries, coastlines and coastal seas in temperate and tropical zones. The destruction of species dependent on floodplains, wetlands and natural river flows is not just an environmental tragedy, it affects the food supply and livelihood of millions. Cities, river valleys and whole countries are now held hostage for their water supply and flood protection to the operation of big dams upstream - dams that are silting up, ageing and growing more dangerous every year. The real problem in the big dams debate is similar to that posed by nuclear power plants: not how to improve their planning, but how to get rid of them. Over the past three years plans for new projects such as Ilisu in Turkey, Wloslawek on the Vistula, resurrected projects such as Arun in Nepal, or Bakun in the rainforest of Sarawak have moved ahead. Construction of Itoitz in Spain, Boguchany in Siberia and the Three Gorges in China has continued. Most poignant of all, in October the Indian Supreme Court approved completion of the World Bank-initiated Sardar Sarovar dam. It was the argument of presumed development benefits, not the vigorous "prior informed dissent" of 500,000 people of the Narmada valley that the court found most persuasive.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 8.
fields.trailText: December 8: Coca-Cola has handed its £1m corporate PR account to Cohn & Wolfe as part of a major communications review.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has handed its £1m corporate PR account to Cohn & Wolfe as part of a major communications review. Its long-time agency, Clarion Communications, will no longer work on the account.

Burston-Marsteller's London office has slashed more than 10% of its staff in a bid to return the troubled agency to profit. The move is part of a global plan to cut the headcount by 5%.

Starbucks is reviewing its PR arrangements as it gears up to expand across Europe.

Consumer PR specialist Clarion Communications is to handle the PR for all the brands belonging to the recently-merged household goods group Reckitt Benckiser.

Financial PR agency Buchanan Communications has been briefed to raise Coffee Republic's profile in the City. The appointment follows Coffee Republic's decision to change its listing from the Alternative Investment Market to the London Stock Exchange.

Publisher H Bauer has turned to an external PR agency for the first time to handle communications surrounding its legal battle with WH Smith. Financial PR agency College Hill has won the brief.

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 7.
fields.trailText: December 7: Online ad sales house TSMSi is being shut down, with its operations absorbed into Granada Enterprises Interactive.
fields.body:
TSMSi, the online ad sales house, is being shut down, with its operations absorbed into a new venture called Granada Enterprises Interactive.

The Internet Advertising Bureau (UK) is planning the first ever set of standards for sales representation by internet companies to "get rid of bad sales practices".

ABC Electronic's partnership with data-mining and analytics specialist WhiteCross could call into question the body's authority as an independent site traffic auditor.

Digital download site iCrunch is cutting and reorganising staff as it reforms into a pure business-to-business player.

Capital Interactive will unveil its first niche narrowcast web radio station on Monday, followed by two others and the central Kikido site before Christmas.

Iballs Media has teamed with Victoria Real to launch a nationwide network of interactive kiosks.

The International Olympic Committee has given the strongest indication yet that it is planning to give TV broadcasters rather than a new media specialist the web rights for future Olympic Games.

The British Internet Publishers Alliance is to renew calls on the government to regulate against what it sees as anti-competitive moves by the BBC online.

webTitle: Directing still a man's job, says report

fields.headline: Directing still a man's job, says report
fields.trailText: Despite several successful releases by female film directors recently, the overall situation for women behind the camera is getting worse according to a report by the Directors Guild of America
fields.body:
Despite a few high-profile examples to the contrary, film directing remains very much a male preserve and things, it would seem, are only getting worse. According to the Hollywood Reporter, a report published this week suggests that the percentage of women entrants to the Directors Guild of America is actually falling.

The DGA report confirms that the number of women film-makers entering the Guild in 1999 was the lowest in five years. Some 26.6% of the total new entrants were female last year, down from 28.5% in 1998.

Even after they have made it through the door, women directors may have trouble finding regular work. The proportion of total days worked by women under DGA contract in 1999 fell to 7.4%, down from 8.5% the previous year.

But there is a crumb of comfort in some of the report's other findings, as there has been a slight rise in the number of film-makers from the racial minorities who are plying their trade as film directors.

But the report shows that the immediate picture may only tell only half the story as this year has seen the release of various critically acclaimed and financially profitable movies from women directors, including Kimberley Peirce (Boys Don't Cry), Julie Taymor (pictured) (Titus) and Sofia Coppola (The Virgin Suicides). But away from its few bright lights, the industry looks as macho and male-dominated as it was in the days of John Ford.

fields.headline: Gibson named Mail sports editor
fields.trailText: 11.15am Former Sunday Telegraph sports editor Colin Gibson is to take over as sports editor at the Daily Mail, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Sunday Telegraph sports editor Colin Gibson is to take over as boss of the sports pages on the Daily Mail.

His appointment ends a three-month search for a new sports editor, which involved talks with several executives on rival papers including the Mirror sports editor Des Kelly.

Mr Gibson, who left the Sunday Telegraph a year ago to work on the Australian in Sydney, replaces Bryan Cooney, who retired because of health problems.
