fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Missing connections

It has been a while since we were visited by our old friends at Cable & Wireless, now part of NTL. Nick Posford of London wanted to sign up with the company but the engineers who turned up failed to install his phone line. Twenty-odd calls over the next few weeks got Posford nowhere. C&W couldn't decide whether the junction box needed an upgrade or there was a network fault. Finally he was given an installation date then told the day before that the engineers would not be able to carry out an installation because there weren't enough phone lines available. Posford wonders why they signed him up in the first place.

 C&W replies that NTL will rescue it from such pickles by upgrading its lines. It does concede that Posford's experience was unacceptable so he has been promised compensation.

Complex packages

Three years ago R Ladoux of London and his flatmate signed up for a C&W package offering cable TV and free local calls. Earlier this year his flatmate moved out and terminated her account and Ladoux found he too had been disconnected. C&W admitted its error and promised to reconnect him, but when his next bill arrived he found he'd been transferred to a different, costlier tariff and charged a reconnection fee.

 C&W/NTL claims that Ladoux's original package is no longer available but has now attempted to reconnect him "although", it laments, "this is a more complex process technically".

Costly unlimited calls

Keith Grant of Southampton paid C&W a £10-a-month tariff for unlimited evening and weekend calls to his internet service provider. Then he began noticing charges of up to £60 for these calls. Twice he rang and asked for the bill to be remedied before his account was debited, but was told that was not company policy. He was also told that since this year's telephone number changes, discounted calls would be charged in full and the money refunded at the end of each month.

 "Mr Grant was affected by a billing error and we have explained that his account will be recredited," says a spokeswoman.

Hitch in doing a switch

The telecoms regulator Oftel's usual reaction to such sad tales is that customers are free to switch companies if they are unhappy. So, unhappy NTL customers can, for instance, flee to BT.

This summer Julie Meech of Worcester waited for a vital call, noticed a BT engineer up the telegraph pole outside her house and discovered her phone line was dead. Out she tripped to request his assistance but was told that, although he was busy fixing her neighbours' lines because they'd rung to report the same fault, he couldn't help her because she hadn't reported her problem.

The fact she was reporting it then and there wasn't good enough; instead she'd have to go to a phone box and dial 151. This done she was given a repair date three days later, but no one turned up. She was given another date; no one turned up. The following day an engineer arrived and declared that it was a job for a colleague. No colleague appeared.

On the sixth day Meech spent a morning in the call box being passed round BT's automated system and was told the original engineer should have fixed it. That afternoon an engineer resolved the problem. It took five minutes.

 "We make no bones that we let her down on a number of fronts and can only offer apologies rather than excuses," says a BT spokesman, explaining that by a remarkable coincidence a letter had been sent to Meech the day Consumer got in touch. Her account has now been credited in compensation.

Premature transfer

When Richard Proctor of London moved house he arranged for BT to install a new line and transfer the number from his old home on moving day. His old phone line was cut off a week prematurely, however, and, like Meech, he experienced the torments of BT's automated answer service on a daily basis before managing to report his problem. He asked to lodge an official complaint, was given a number and told he could only complain once an in-house complaints procedure had been initiated and that the complaints department only dealt with mishandled complaints. To initiate a complaint he had to go back to the automated answer maze.

 "Mr Proctor has had a full explanation, apology and compensation for the undue time he was without service," says BT. "The central issue was that no one at BT took proper ownership of the problem and that has been brought to the attention of the managers involved."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are off for a quick fag in the allocated area
fields.trailText: Barcelona are back in for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, according to Planet Football. Chelsea are unlikely to get rid of their £15m striker, but could be sorely tempted with the offer of Dani and Boudewijn Zenden in part-exchange.
fields.body:
Barcelona are back in for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, according to Planet Football. Chelsea are unlikely to get rid of their £15m striker, but could be sorely tempted with the offer of Dani and Boudewijn Zenden in part-exchange.

Arsenal, Chelsea and Manchester United are all keeping tabs on Emmanuel Petit's situation at Barcelona. "I am not going to waste my time being a sub," the long-haired Frenchman has been reported as saying.

AC Milan and Lazio both want Leeds boss David O'Leary as their coach for next season, according to the Sun.

Celtic and Manchester City are the latest clubs to shown an interest in Wimbledon striker John Hartson. Martin O'Neill wants to take the big Welsh striker, who nearly joined Rangers in a £7m deal earlier this year, on loan until the end of the season with a view to a permanent transfer. But Wimbledon will turn down any such move because they want a straight cash deal now. That's where City come in: Joe Royle is ready to put £5m on the table.

Newcastle defender Alain Goma will rejoin Paris St Germain for £4m after Christmas.

Blackburn are poised to pull out of a £2.5m deal for Manchester United defender Henning Berg over a row about wages.

webTitle: Dear Cyber Santa, all I want ...

fields.headline: Dear Cyber Santa, all I want ...
fields.standfirst: What are gadget freaks desperate to find in their Christmas stockings this year?  Ashley Norris  has the answers
fields.trailText: What are gadget freaks desperate to find in their Christmas stockings this year? Ashley Norris has the answers
fields.body:
Father Christmas isn't noted for being particularly gadget-savvy. He's obviously well up on the socks and underpants market, but not so hot on MP3 players and digital cameras.

To help you point him in the right direction we have created our very own virtual stocking crammed with hi-tech toys.

It includes what we believe to be the year's best gadgets. Some are great value products that will last years. Others will be gathering dust in your loft by this time next year. But however you use them, they are guaranteed to give you much more fun this Christmas than another bottle of dodgy after-shave.

Mobile phones
Throughout 2000, the major phone companies paraded futuristic-looking concept mobiles designed to make the most of the forthcoming super-fast 3G networks.

Arguably a more honest glimpse of the future was provided by an actual product launched in late Summer. Ericsson's £300 R-380 smart phone married the Symbian operating system to a clever touch-screen and at a stroke made many of its rivals seem a tad old fashioned. For once a phone that promised simple to operate email, web browsing and PDA functionality lived up to its billing.

Next year Nokia will attempt to re-capture lost ground with the latest version of its Communicator phones. The 9210 keeps its predecessor's keyboard, but adds a colour screen, Symbian's Epoc operating system, and, if you are using the Orange network's High Speed Circuit Switch Data (HSCSD) system, faster download times than standard GSM.

2000 was also the year that the Japanese finally made good their promise to take a serious crack at the world's mobile phone market. Sony unveiled two innovative and stylish models, one of which, the £30 CMD-J5, is arguably the most sensibly designed out of the basic Wap models. However, Panasonic's GD-93 phone is our Wap model of the year. It is stylish, sports a large screen, and has a fun selection of ring-tones (you can also record your own). Best of all, it lets you access your existing email account rather than be lumbered with a new one offered by your network. Motorola's newly launched £100 Timeport Ti250 and Philips' £100 Xenium 9@9 Wap, which uses voice activation to fire up its web browser, also merit further attention.

MP3

2000 was the year that MP3 personal audio players went from being the preserve of PC geeks to a serious option for any discerning music fan.

This year's best-sounding model was undoubtedly the long-awaited Sony Memory Stick Walkman, the £300 NW-MS7. However, its daft copyright protection software, which almost makes you feel as though you are committing a minor crime every time you use it, prevents it from receiving a warmer recommendation. Our favourite player is the £230 Samsung YP-Neu 64, a dinky little number wrapped in an I-Mac-style translucent finish which paired a quality performance with 64MB of embedded memory. Other models worth listening to include the £220 Philips Rush, LG's £180 MF-PD360 and the £160 Rio 600.

Next year look out for units with MP3 encoders like the £300 Aiwa MM-FX500 that can record directly from CDs with no need to use a PC.

Personal audio
Since the summer, the UK has been flooded with personal audio players touting mini hard disks that promise to store half of your CD collection in one brick-like box. Some, like the £350 Neo 25 which boasts an enormous 12 gigabyte hard drive, work reasonably well. Others are so flaky that getting them to play back any kind of music seems like a major achievement.

An easier and cheaper solution is to invest in a personal CD player that also plays CD-Roms with MP3 files, such as the £200 eXpanium from Philips. You can burn up to 850MB of music (over 200 average length tunes on MP3) on one £1.50 CD-R disc. Even the Argos-friendly Goodmans has got in on the act. Its CDMP-350 plays MP3-loaded CD-roms yet retails for around £80.

Digital cameras
The digital camera world appears to be splintering between serious mega-pixel fixated photographers and gadget-fans out to impress their more gullible friends. However, both groups gave an enormous thumbs up to the £600 Canon Digital Ixus which, in spite of its lovely chrome finish and pocketable size, is actually capable of high resolution images.

Almost as sexy is Fuji's £700 Finepix 4700 Zoom, which integrated an excellent quality camera into the kind of gadget you'd imagine James Bond touting in the 60s.

Serious camera enthusiasts will probably prefer the £800 Olympus C-3030Z - a digital model with the look, feel and many of the features of an analogue SLR.

2000 was also the year the digital camera crashed through the £100 price barrier with companies such as Jenoptik, Kodak and Agfa unveiling web-friendly budget models. Samung's £250 SDC-80 is another camera sure to feature on many Christmas wishlists. It may only be modestly specified, but with its funky translucent orange finish it sure is cute.

Consumer electronics
In the CE world 2000 will be remembered as the year that the TiVo personal video recorder arrived in the UK. Yet despite the amazing tricks, including a highly intelligent programme guide which among other things guesses what you want to watch and records it for you, the TiVo system has not exactly had people queuing in the rain outside Dixons.

Perhaps its £600 price tag has something to do with it.

Don't expect the hard disk/personal video system technology to go away though. Next year Pace will launch a Sky Digital decoder which offers both an intelligent hard disk recording system and two tuners (for watching one channel while recording another).

JVC is also set to bring its hard disk/S-VHS combi recorder to the UK, while home cinema fans dream of the day Toshiba's hard disk/DVD-ram recorder lands on these shores.

DVD
Undoubtedly this year's success story, sales of both players and discs have gone stratospheric - apparently the DVD movie of Gladiator sold more last week than the number one CD single by Destiny's Child.

Among our favourites is the £400 Toshiba SD-200E courtesy of an excellent performance, a comprehensive roll call of facilities, and a very sensible price.

If you are feeling naughty, consider the Chinese-made £180 Mico DVD-A980 from www.unbeatable.co.uk. Not only will it play back imported American "Region Two" discs as well as standard European ones, it can also spin MP3-laden CD-roms.

The hi-fi fraternity has been drooling over the performance of the £800 British-made Arcam DV88, while for gadget-fans there's little to rival the DVD personal and mini screen of the £800 Sony DVP-FX1.

Gadgets
2000 was tipped as being the year of the watch with companies promising mobile phones, personal organisers and even music players integrated into a timepiece. The one company that delivered was Casio, whose amazing MP3 watch (the £280 WMP-1 ) and digital camera watch (the £200 WQV-1) were among the year's grooviest gadgets.

Even more fun than the camera watch was the Spypen, an £80 ballpoint-shaped digital camera from Plawa, which is sure to get a great deal of use in the next few weeks capturing Christmas parties shenanigans.

Two internet-friendly gadgets also caught the eye. Ricoh's £1,000 RDC-1700, a top-end digital camera with a cool 70s styling that allows you to peruse web pages via its 3.5inch LCD screen and instantly email images, would be a must were it not so pricey. More of a bargain is Bush's Net TV, which at £180 a set is sure to bring the wonders of the web to many new homes this Christmas.

Our favourite player is the £230 Samsung YP-Neu 64, a dinky little number wrapped in an I-Mac-style translucent finish which paired a quality performance with 64MB of embedded memory. Other models worth listening to include the £220 Philips Rush, LG's £180 MF-PD360 and the £160 Rio 600. Next year look out for units with MP3 encoders like the £300 Aiwa MM-FX500 that can record directly from CDs with no need to use a PC. Personal audio Since the summer, the UK has been flooded with personal audio players touting mini hard disks that promise to store half of your CD collection in one brick-like box. Some, like the £350 Neo 25 which boasts an enormous 12 gigabyte hard drive, work reasonably well. Others are so flaky that getting them to play back any kind of music seems like a major achievement. An easier and cheaper solution is to invest in a personal CD player that also plays CD-Roms with MP3 files, such as the £200 eXpanium from Philips. You can burn up to 850MB of music (over 200 average length tunes on MP3) on one £1.50 CD-R disc. Even the Argos-friendly Goodmans has got in on the act. Its CDMP-350 plays MP3-loaded CD-roms yet retails for around £80. Digital cameras The digital camera world appears to be splintering between serious mega-pixel fixated photographers and gadget-fans out to impress their more gullible friends. However, both groups gave an enormous thumbs up to the £600 Canon Digital Ixus which, in spite of its lovely chrome finish and pocketable size, is actually capable of high resolution images. Almost as sexy is Fuji's £700 Finepix 4700 Zoom, which integrated an excellent quality camera into the kind of gadget you'd imagine James Bond touting in the 60s. Serious camera enthusiasts will probably prefer the £800 Olympus C-3030Z - a digital model with the look, feel and many of the features of an analogue SLR. 2000 was also the year the digital camera crashed through the £100 price barrier with companies such as Jenoptik, Kodak and Agfa unveiling web-friendly budget models. Samung's £250 SDC-80 is another camera sure to feature on many Christmas wishlists. It may only be modestly specified, but with its funky translucent orange finish it sure is cute. Consumer electronics In the CE world 2000 will be remembered as the year that the TiVo personal video recorder arrived in the UK. Yet despite the amazing tricks, including a highly intelligent programme guide which among other things guesses what you want to watch and records it for you, the TiVo system has not exactly had people queuing in the rain outside Dixons. Perhaps its £600 price tag has something to do with it. Don't expect the hard disk/personal video system technology to go away though. Next year Pace will launch a Sky Digital decoder which offers both an intelligent hard disk recording system and two tuners (for watching one channel while recording another). JVC is also set to bring its hard disk/S-VHS combi recorder to the UK, while home cinema fans dream of the day Toshiba's hard disk/DVD-ram recorder lands on these shores. DVD Undoubtedly this year's success story, sales of both players and discs have gone stratospheric - apparently the DVD movie of Gladiator sold more last week than the number one CD single by Destiny's Child. Among our favourites is the £400 Toshiba SD-200E courtesy of an excellent performance, a comprehensive roll call of facilities, and a very sensible price. If you are feeling naughty, consider the Chinese-made £180 Mico DVD-A980 from www.unbeatable.co.uk. Not only will it play back imported American "Region Two" discs as well as standard European ones, it can also spin MP3-laden CD-roms. The hi-fi fraternity has been drooling over the performance of the £800 British-made Arcam DV88, while for gadget-fans there's little to rival the DVD personal and mini screen of the £800 Sony DVP-FX1. Gadgets 2000 was tipped as being the year of the watch with companies promising mobile phones, personal organisers and even music players integrated into a timepiece. The one company that delivered was Casio, whose amazing MP3 watch (the £280 WMP-1 ) and digital camera watch (the £200 WQV-1) were among the year's grooviest gadgets. Even more fun than the camera watch was the Spypen, an £80 ballpoint-shaped digital camera from Plawa, which is sure to get a great deal of use in the next few weeks capturing Christmas parties shenanigans. Two internet-friendly gadgets also caught the eye. Ricoh's £1,000 RDC-1700, a top-end digital camera with a cool 70s styling that allows you to peruse web pages via its 3.5inch LCD screen and instantly email images, would be a must were it not so pricey. More of a bargain is Bush's Net TV, which at £180 a set is sure to bring the wonders of the web to many new homes this Christmas.

fields.headline: Dudley Moore in "not dead" shock
fields.trailText: After talking frankly about his serious illness in a BBC documentary, Dudley Moore rages against the way that his words have been distorted by the international media
fields.body:
Dudley Moore yesterday hit out at an international media, which he clearly regards as behaving like a flock of gathering vultures, to insist that the reports of his imminent demise have been greatly exaggerated.

The 65-year-old actor is suffering from Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, a degenerative and incurable brain disorder similar to Parkinson's disease, but in an e-mailed statement entitled "Open Letter to the International Press", Moore appeared to be in fighting form.

Moore had discussed his illness in a BBC documentary broadcast on Monday when he admitted that: "I am facing a short and uncertain future I know I am going to die from it." But the actor has been "outraged" by the way the media has handled his condition.

He feels that the BBC unofficially hyped its documentary as Moore's last ever interview and that other sections of the press further sensationalised the story. "Imagine my surprise to be informed this morning by the BBC's website and other press that I have only weeks to live," Moore writes in his statement.

"I should, I imagine, let my doctor know, as when I saw him last week, he thought I was much better," Moore went on to remark. "I suppose my imminent death will sell papers while my positive and life-affirming work is of no interest to anyone. I am hurt and discouraged by your cruelty."

After starting out on the British fringe comedy scene before establishing himself on television, Moore broke into movies when he teamed up with comedy partner Peter Cooke on the 1967 Faustian caper Bedazzled (recently remade with Brendan Fraser in the Moore role). Following a move to the USA, he starred with huge success in the hit films 10 and Arthur.

But the 1990s saw his career damaged by a string of flop films (Crazy People, Blame it on the Bellboy) and a short-lived television series (Dudley). Moore made his last film appearance, playing himself, in 1996's The Disappearance of Kevin Johnson.

webTitle: First non-journalist to take over at Reuters

fields.headline: First non-journalist to take over at Reuters
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Reuters yesterday said that Tom Glocer, the American lawyer who heads its biggest division, would take over as chief executive in July, writes Nicholas Bannister.
fields.body:
Reuters, the news and information group, yesterday said that Tom Glocer, the American lawyer who heads its biggest division, would take over as chief executive in July.

Mr Glocer will be the first non-journalist and second foreigner to hold the post. Outsiders saw the appointment as further recognition that Reuters, in addition to being a global news agency, was also a global business.

The group derives about 78% of its revenue from selling its services to the financial community around the world and just under 10% from sales to the media. Its Instinet online brokerage business, which accounts for 17% of revenue, is due to be floated.

Mr Glocer was the leading internal candidate, though former finance director Rob Rowley, now head of the new Reuterspace division, and Philip Green, head of the Reuters Trading Solutions division, had been in the running. The group also considered a number of outside candidates.

Peter Job, the current chief executive who retires next year, announced in February that Reuters would be concentrating more on internet-based services. A group spokesman said that Mr Glocer had worked on evolving the new strategy and would be carrying it forward.

Sir Christopher Hogg, the group chairman, said Reuters owed much to Mr Job who joined the company as a trainee journalist in 1963 and has been chief executive since 1991. "The strong position of the group today reflects his direction and guidance," Sir Christopher said.

"Announcing Peter's successor now will ensure an orderly transfer of responsibilities and avoid any vacuum in the decision-making process within the company."

Reuters' founder, Sir Julius Reuter, was a German-born immigrant who took British nationality. Glen Renfrew, an Australian, was the first foreigner to head the group, being managing director from 1981-1991.

Mr Glocer, who will be moving from New York to London to take up his new post, is currently in charge of Reuters Information, which accounts for about half the group's total revenue.

Before joining Reuters' legal department in 1993, he worked as a merger and acquisitions lawyer for American law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York, Paris and Tokyo.

webTitle: Miss the crush, shop by SMS

fields.headline: Miss the crush, shop by SMS
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The first retail service to sell direct to customers through mobile phone text messages was launched in Britain yesterday.
fields.body:
The first retail service to sell direct to customers through mobile phone text messages was launched in Britain yesterday.

With every high street jammed full in the run-up to Christmas, the German-based 12snap claims it can give 98% of mobile phone users the chance to duck out of the crowds and enjoy wireless shopping.

The company hopes to have 700,000 shoppers buying through its SMS messaging services by December of next year.

Each day, 12snap offers around 90 items - including concert tickets, travel and consumer electronics - for auction, with a text message alerting registered customers to specific deals according to their personal interests.

Managing director Anne de Kerckhove insisted that the company would not send out unsolicited junk mail. "The future of our business relies on the trust we develop with our customers," she said. "It would not be in our interest to send out unwanted messages."

She said that the service, which already has more than 400,000 users in Germany, will be targeted at 18 to 35 year-olds as a "young, dynamic and irreverent brand".

Mobile bidding, which can also be done through wap and the internet, will operate in much the same way as many internet auctions, with many of the items for sale being from stock that has not performed well at a fixed price on the high street. Around 65% of the items will be sold by auction, with the rest offered at a fixed price.

12snap recently raised €37m (£22m) from venture capitalists which its said would sustain the business until it broke even at the beginning of 2002.

Company founder Michael Birkel said the European market for mobile phone shopping was expected to be worth €23.6bn by 2003.

fields.headline: Working the web Christmas
fields.standfirst: Hazel Southam  experiments with the virtues of a virtual Christmas
fields.trailText: Hazel Southam experiments with the virtues of a virtual Christmas
fields.body:
Last weekend my boyfriend and I took a wrong turning in a major department store and found ourselves in the toy department - for about five seconds. We couldn't get out of there fast enough.

Children were screaming, shouting, and waving toys around. The adults weren't much better. My boyfriend has now vowed to do all his Christmas shopping online. And this set me thinking, can you celebrate Christmas on the internet without having to go out and face the crowds, or indeed unwanted relatives?

The answer, happily, is yes. You will never have to elbow your way to the front of the queue again, or sit next to the man who is tone deaf during a carol service.

Shopping is the first hurdle to get over. According to a new survey from BlueCarrots, three quarters of internet users will shop online this Christmas, compared with a third last year. The difference, apparently, is that we're no longer scared of someone making off with our Barclaycard number and running up a huge bill with it.

So where do you go for Christmas goodies? Father Christmas of course. At www.santa.claus.com you'll find six floors of gifts, toys, games, sweets and decorations. These include stocking fillers such as gold, frankincense and myrrh or essential oils for £12.99, through to a fake white Colorado Christmas tree for £19.99 and a five-piece Santa suit for £24.99.

At www.christmas.co.uk, you can email Santa asking him to phone your child with a special Christmas message, just for £5. Or, if you want to be particularly mean, Santa can be recruited to play Scrooge, placing an unseasonal call to your boss. If you've had a hard year at work, this may seem like £5 well spent.

While in a Lapland frame of mind, book a sleigh ride (though obviously, you'll have to leave the house for the real thing). www.sleighrides.com provides a 40-minute sleigh ride with a stop for hot chocolate for about £53 per person. If your taste runs to something a tad speedier than a reindeer, then you could try a four-hour snowmobile ride (including lunch) for around £110. However, to take advantage of this offer you will first have to get to the Adirondack mountains in New York State.

Back indoors, it's time to decorate your house. At www.sun-sentinel.com, the Bossack Family will sell you the dream Christmas tree and deliver it to your home. A 6ft Douglas fir will set you back £63.

At www.hillier.hants.gov.uk, you can check out Christmas decoration and wreath making workshops over the next fortnight, costing £27.50.

And of course, there's endless scope for Christmas kitsch. My particular favourites come from www.bronners.com, which sells a 14 inch fibre optic angel for £40 and a fibre optic red poinsettia, which is unbelievably nasty, for £34.

What about Christmas lunch? My boyfriend tells me that he likes a slow-cooked giant ham and roast beef. The thought of stinking the house out with these is too much. So, I turn to www.balduccis.com, which will bring Christmas dinner to the door. You get the full works for a family of four (except the Christmas pudding) for £85. This is excellent for meat eaters, but there is no vegetarian option.

Does the internet provide an opportunity to go to church without having to enter a cold, dimly-lit building? From this week it does, in the shape of www.church.co.uk, founded by TV vicar, Steve Chalke.

The site, shaped like a house (the house of God, get it?) currently includes Bible readings, prayers, a talk about how to cope with the stress of Christmas, a post-Christmas work out with Rosemary Conley, and even advice on how to stuff a turkey.

And according to Chalke, events are being planned around the UK for web lovers to attend Christmas celebrations "in pubs and clubs". Online events are also planned for the festive season. And all of the cyber vicar's sermons are up for debate by those visiting the site, which is less embarrassing than picking an argument with a priest in a pulpit.

Chalke says: " www.church.co.uk is for people who are searching spiritually, but they don't think that the church down the road has the answers, though they will explore the net.

"It helps people because they are anonymous. No one will want to invite you for tea in a cracked cup and shake your hand.

"There's nobody under 30 who doesn't think in terms of spirituality. We are not human beings having a spiritual experience, we are spiritual beings having a human experience."

So that's my Christmas fixed up. At least it would have been if I hadn't already bought most of my presents and been invited out for several meals. Next year I'll have my Christmas on the net.

fields.headline: The Weakest Link
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk has introduced a new daily service for  busy TV execs who are missing out on Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link. Every day we pay homage to the woman dubbed the rudest presenter on TV by revealing her best put-down.
fields.trailText: MediaGuardian.co.uk has introduced a new daily service for busy TV execs who are missing out on Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link. Every day we pay homage to the woman dubbed the rudest presenter on TV by revealing her best put-downs.
fields.body:
Anne: Johnathon, despite the fact that one of the other contestants can't even spell your name correctly, they have voted YOU the Weakest Link. Goodbye.


Wednesday December 6

Anne: Darren, adding up not one of your strong points?

Darren: No, not really.

Anne: You're a member of the Eurovision song contest fan club, aren't you? What do you do when they're working out the scores?

Darren: Just sit there and sing the songs.

Anne: Do you think you're on the right show today?


Tuesday December 5

Anne: It was certainly interesting to find you thinking of a parka as a pen rather than an overcoat... Goodbye!


Monday December 4

Anne: Alistair, not a brilliant start. You've voted off Carol, but she didn't get as many wrong as you, did she?

Alistair: No.

Anne: No. That would have been difficult, actually. But Gordon, you managed it.


Friday November 24

Anne: (referring to the ornately written name on the voting board)) Maurice, that's a very very pretty name you've drawn there.

Maurice: If I don't win this I'll go for artistic merit.

Anne: I don't think you'll win that either, Maurice.


Thursday November 23

Anne: Jim, why Pete?
Jim: In the first round I voted for him because I thought he could beat me, and in the second I wanted him out.
Anne: Okay, so you're not a team player?
Jim: In this case not.
Anne: Well, not at all actually.


Wednesday November 22

Anne: Aaron, you had a surprisingly good round. Was that a mistake?


Tuesday November 21

Anne: Well let me tell you, team, you got six questions wrong in a row. The idea is that as you vote off the Weakest Links you get better not worse.

Anne: Gordon, you've woken up!


Monday November 20

Anne: Well Caroline, you certainly did us proud when I asked you how many pennies in the pound pre-decimalisation. You thought there were one hundred. Wouldn't have been much point in decimalisation would there, Caroline?


Friday November 17

Anne: Jon, all four questions wrong - couldn't you be bothered to answer them?


Thursday November 16

Pat: I've drawn moths - I'm very artistic you see.

Anne: Well, that's a matter of opinion.


Wednesday November 15

Anne: Jill, are you a member of any clubs?
Jill: Yes (laughing).
Anne: What's funny about that?
Jill: I'm a former member of Mensa.
Anne: Former member of Mensa.... did they throw you out?


Tuesday November 14

Anne: Kaye, when you are staff training is there any arithmetic involved?
Kaye: No.
Anne: That's just as well isn't it, you took so long we thought you were counting it out.

webTitle: MoD loses bid to halt SAS book

fields.headline: MoD loses bid to halt SAS book
fields.standfirst:
Special report: freedom of information

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Government attempts to ban books by former security and intelligence officers were dealt a blow yesterday when a New Zealand court dismissed Ministry of Defence efforts to suppress an account of an ill-fated Gulf war mission by an ex-SAS soldier
fields.byline: Patrick Barkham  in Sydney and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Government attempts to ban books by former security and intelligence officers were dealt a blow yesterday when a New Zealand court dismissed Ministry of Defence efforts to suppress an account of an ill-fated Gulf war mission by an ex-SAS soldier.

The judge, Peter Salmon, dismissed MoD claims that the book, Soldier 5, being published in New Zealand by a New Zealander who uses the pseudonym Mike Coburn, could jeopardise the security of future SAS operations.

His ruling, like the Spycatcher affair, has widespread implications for the writers of other books on the security and intelligence agencies, not least Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5.

TheMoD, with MI6, has led the attack on Dame Stella for her decision to write her memoirs, citing the precedent it would give former SAS soldiers. She has agreed to redraft some passages but insists she has the right under the Human Rights Act to publish a personal memoir.

"The Ministry of Defence has used its power to issue orders for the improper purpose of restricting the defendant's right to freedom of speech and expression," said Mr Justice Salmon in Auckland.

He ruled that Mr Coburn was subjected to "illegitimate" economic pressure to sign a confidentiality agreement, after the MoD threatened to force him out of the SAS, and relinquish its special pay scales, if he refused to sign the lifetime ban.

During the hearing, much of it held behind closed doors, MoD witnesses, including the head of the SAS, warned that the publication of Soldier 5 could jeopardise the integrity of its confidentiality clause.

The botched Bravo Two Zero mission has already inspired two bestselling accounts, by patrol leader Andy McNab and another member, Chris Ryan, the only one of the eight man team to have escaped.

Both soldiers had left the force by the time the MoD introduced a confidentiality agreement for special forces soldiers in 1996, designed to prevent the publication of further accounts of undercover missions without the permission of senior officers.

A spate of earlier books by former SAS soldiers were written after the authors voluntarily submitted manuscripts to the MoD for vetting.

During open sessions in court, Mr Coburn, 36, accused senior officers of issuing the Bravo Two Zero patrol with faulty equipment, dropping it too close to enemy lines, and delaying a rescue attempt because the men were "expendable".

He said he wanted to restore the reputation of Vince Phillips, a member of the SAS patrol whose suitability for the task has been criticised by one of the patrol team as well as in a leaked SAS report.

The New Zealand ruling also has significant implications for the MoD's attempts to suppress books about undercover operations in Northern Ireland.

The MoD said yesterday it was "disappointed" with the ruling. Though it has 28 days to appeal, officials suggested it would not do so. They acknowledged the significance of the ruling for former security personnel wanting to publish their memoirs in Britain.

webTitle: A difficult man to pin down

fields.headline: A difficult man to pin down
fields.standfirst: After the international success of Irma Vep, Olivier Assayas was determined not to repeat himself. Xan Brooks finds out what the versatile writer-director did next
fields.trailText: After the international success of Irma Vep, Olivier Assayas was determined not to repeat himself. Xan Brooks finds out what the versatile writer-director did next
fields.body:
Compare and contrast two films - the playful, airy, self-referential Irma Vep with the weighty, literate modernist Les Destinees Sentimentales - and you'd hardly imagine they belong to the same medium, let alone the same man. Both, however, are the work of Olivier Assayas. The mercurial French writer-director shot to international art-house acclaim with Irma Vep in 1997, chased that up with the similarly supple, Paris-set Late August, Early September in 1999 and then flipped guises completely.

Based on the whopping novel by Jacques Chardonne, Les Destinees Sentimentales shoehorns some thirty years into its three-hour running time, starting out in the late 19th century in the Limousin region of central France and winding up in the years after world war one. In the interim its hero (Charles Berling) starts out as a Protestant minister and finishes up as an industrialist; begins with one woman (Isabelle Huppert as his cold-blooded bride) before jumping ship to another (free-spirit Emmanuelle Beart).

The film is such a change of pace from Assayas' earlier work that I half suspect he is playing some kind of joke on his critics. After all, the man cut his teeth as a writer for France's revered Cahiers du Cinema, the magazine that championed the auteur theory in the 50s and 60s, yet his latest picture seems to be making a mockery of the whole concept.

Not so, says Assayas; a slight, bright-eyed man of 45 with a laugh like a hiccuping hyena. It comes down more to a case of sheer bloody mindedness. "As soon as I feel pigeonholed I have this bad boy instinct. As soon as I felt that people were expecting me to make Irma Vep I wanted to run in the other direction."

So he admits that the two films could not be further apart? "Yes," says Assayas and then abruptly U-turns. "No. I don't know. This is a very metaphysical question for me, because all my films represent deep aspects of myself. I feel very comfortable with every one." He hunts for a metaphor. "How can I put it? I can get immense pleasure from visiting a Pierre Bonnard retrospective and then the next day I can listen to Never Mind the Bollocks by the Sex Pistols with just the same pleasure. I don't see any conflict there. For me, cinema is about exploring the complexities of your own person and the complexities of the modern world."

In the event, Les Destinees Sentimentales has run as a kind of parallel current to all his other recent movies. A long-term fan of Chardonne, Assayas first planned to make the film some four years ago until the backing fell through. This, says, Assayas was a blessing in disguise. "I was majorly pissed off when it first fell through but when I eventually went back to the project I felt a much deeper relationship with the story, it added new layers. I'd spent so much time with these stories thinking of them as living human beings." He shrugs. "In the meantime I made Irma Vep, which was fairly successful and played everywhere, plus I also got married." Assayas, in fact, is married to Maggie Cheung, who played the bemused, cat-suited star of Irma Vep.

Assayas pours himself a glass of water and falls to remembering his writing days. He says he has started to miss it. "I've always considered myself as a writer as much as a director," he says. "Writing film criticism was like my film school, it helped me to understand the medium. Then I went through a phase where I didn't think it was as fun as writing screenplays, but I've recently started scribbling stuff down - I wrote an article on Kenneth Anger that's just been published in France. In a sense, writing theory and making films is one and the same thing for me." Still, that's Assayas for you. Wispy post modern fancy or sprawling modernist epic. Writing about films or making them. The man offers living proof that you can do the lot.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 8.
fields.trailText: December 8: Associated Newspapers believes its rival in the Metro wars, the Swedish Modern Times Group, is close to conceding defeat.
fields.body:
Associated Newspapers believes its rival in the Metro wars, the Swedish Modern Times Group, is close to conceding defeat and bowing out. Press Gazette reports that Modern Times Group has failed to break even in Newcastle, and does not consider the city the ideal place for a free morning paper.

ITV head of current affairs Steve Anderson has called for an overhaul of the rules on election coverage for broadcasters, including scrapping the requirement that broadcasters have to give airtime to every candidate.

BA has put its multimillion pound contract for High Life, the in-flight magazine for British Airways, out to tender, with the incumbent Premier Media Partners, Conde Nast's contract publishing division and Redwood Publishing to bid. The magazine, which has won several awards, is thought to generate an annual turnover of £18m for the company.

The Press Complaints Commission is likely to approve new guildelines for financial journalists this week, pre-empting proposals by the Treasury to make disclosure of a journalist's shareholding in every story mandatory.

Janice Turner, editor of H Bauer's monthly That's Life, is to edit the company's new women's glossy launch.

fields.headline: Travel sickness benefit for Houllier
fields.trailText: If the bleakest scenario unfolds at Anfield this evening and Liverpool are ousted from the Uefa Cup by Olympiakos, the groans of incredulity will echo not just through Merseyside but across Europe.
fields.body:
If the bleakest scenario unfolds at Anfield this evening and Liverpool are ousted from the Uefa Cup by Olympiakos, the groans of incredulity will echo not just through Merseyside but across Europe.

It is possible, of course, but by holding the Greek champions to a 2-2 draw a fortnight ago, Liverpool constructed a platform from which they should move forward into the last 16 of a cumbersome, over-populated tournament that will resume in February.

For to describe Olympiakos as highly proficient hosts but extraordinarily poor tourists is to understate things. Like Bulgarian wine, they do not travel well. Over the past three sea sons, they have played 15 ties in the Champions League against the exceptional, the good, the indifferent and the average. Not one of the home fixtures was lost, yet only one of the away games was won.

"It is true that they do not travel well," said Gérard Houllier. "Even so, it could be fatal to go into a demanding game believing that we are already through into the next round."

By delivering the traditional, "complacency-could-be-our-biggest-enemy" line, Houllier was doing no more than underscoring the sense of disappointment that overtook both the manager and his players two weeks ago when Olympiakos were allowed back into a match that should have been over, stealing a draw deep into added time.

But if Liverpool can maintain their imperious home form - nine wins and two draws in 11 games - then they should gallop home with something to spare.

Houllier added: "We are enjoying playing at Anfield, it has proved a productive venue for us so far this season. We have one foot in the next round."

Olympiakos parted company with their coach, Yiannis Matzoyrakis, 48 hours after the first leg and their spirits will hardly have been lifted by the news that Michael Owen is poised for a return to arms having recovered from the back injury sustained beneath Athens' polluted skies.

Owen may replace the fit but worringly listless Robbie Fowler whom Houllier chose to remind last week of his responsibilities - both professional and spiritual - when he remarked that Fowler needs to consider his actions both on and off the pitch.

fields.headline: Advocaat out to buck trend
fields.standfirst: Kaiserslautern (0) v Rangers (1)
fields.trailText: Rangers are not exactly in search of glory tonight in the lower Rhineland but progress towards the Uefa Cup fourth round and a stay in Europe beyond Christmas for the first time in eight years would still seem a minor triumph for the Scottish champions.
fields.body:
Rangers are not exactly in search of glory tonight in the lower Rhineland but progress towards the Uefa Cup fourth round and a stay in Europe beyond Christmas for the first time in eight years would still seem a minor triumph for the Scottish champions.

Defending their 1-0 advantage from an occasionally fractious first leg at Ibrox, and with historic strains of Dutch-German tension being exaggerated in both camps, there are some here who would like to depict this afternoon's game at the Fritz-Walter stadium as some sort of sequel to the Battle of Arnhem. The truth will probably be less dramatic.

Dick Advocaat, Rangers' Dutch manager, and Andreas Brehme, his German counterpart, were affable about each other yesterday with Brehme scoffing at suggestions of animosity between the two coaches.

"I've had nothing at all to say against Dick Advocaat," said Brehme. "Both he and I are simply trying to do the best for our clubs. In fact if I win tomorrow then I shall be the lucky one."

Advocaat has certainly not felt overly lucky in his encounters with German sides in his 30 months at Ibrox. Rangers lost against Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund last season, the first after hitting the Bayern woodwork three times, the second in the game's dying seconds. Today, at least, if Rangers score, Kaiserslautern will require three in reply.

"I have never gone out to defend a lead - my teams always go out to score," said Advocaat. "This game, though, will be a physical battle. They will try to get the ball in quickly behind my defenders and they will certainly play with more attackers than they did at Ibrox. So our concentration will be vital."

Advocaat will have to do without his suspended captain, Barry Ferguson, although, perversely, this might not be the loss it first seems. In Ferguson's place will come the little Turk, Tugay Kerimoglu, whose intelligent, scheming football is perfectly suited to this away tie. Michael Mols is also expected to play.

webTitle: Scholes makes United feel at home

fields.headline: Scholes makes United feel at home
fields.standfirst: Sturm Graz 0 Manchester United 2 (Scholes 17, Giggs 89)
fields.trailText: For all their omnipotence in the Premiership and the carefree abandon with which they are strutting towards their seventh title in nine years, Manchester United have waited a long time for this moment.
fields.body:
For all their omnipotence in the Premiership and the carefree abandon with which they are strutting towards their seventh title in nine years, Manchester United have waited a long time for this moment.

Unspectacular yet effective, Sir Alex Ferguson's team rediscovered the winning formula in Europe here last night, bolstering their challenge for a fifth successive Champions League quarter-final with their first victory on foreign soil for nine months.

They are now two points clear in Group A courtesy of a goal in each half from Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs - in the type of controlled performance that seemed to have deserted them on recent Continental excursions.

The Austrian champions had not lost in Graz in a European match since United plundered a 3-0 win here 15 months ago, while Ferguson's team arrived in Styria without a win on the Continent since beating Bordeaux in March. It was a sequence, Ferguson privately conceded, that was threatening to sap morale.

United's foreign problems had long perplexed the United manager but now, with last year's runners-up Valencia drawing 0-0 at Panathinaikos last night, his side will resume European duties in February as the overwhelming favourites to progress.

Realistically, they need only four points from their remaining four games to book a place in the last eight and, as Ferguson was at pains to emphasise, their chances will be enhanced by the return from injury of Jaap Stam and Andy Cole.

"We've got a 100% record going into the two-month break and when we come back I think our double-header against Valencia will have a bearing on who wins the group," said Ferguson. "This was a good win for us but the result in Greece was exactly what we wanted, too. I'm more than satisfied."

Graz have reserved their best performances for the Champions League this season, but United soon assumed an air of authority and their first serious attack on 17 minutes saw an opening goal that was exquisite in its creation and clinical in its execution.

Dwight Yorke started the move with an incisive pass to the fringe of the Graz penalty area but it was Teddy Sheringham's sublime flick back that did the damage. Scholes timed his run to perfection before expertly lifting the ball over the oncoming goalkeeper Kaz imierz Sidorczuk for United's first goal in open play on the Continent for seven hours and 53 minutes.

That took Scholes level with Denis Law, at least in the European Cup, with 14 goals, three behind Cole. "It was a wonderful goal," eulogised Ferguson. "Paul has always been a good finisher since he was a kid and it's incredible how many he scores from midfield."

Graz seemed to be engulfed by an inferiority complex for the rest of an opening half in which Fabien Barthez had to make only one save, diving to his right to keep out Ivica Vastic's 25-yard free-kick.

The second half was not so comfortable, with Tomica Kocijan hitting the United crossbar with a rasping drive and only the brilliance of Barthez sparing what would have been a spectacular headed own-goal by Roy Keane.

But as the temperature dropped so did the heads of the Graz players and, after Sheringham had had a goal ruled out for offside, much to the irritation of Ferguson, Giggs sealed victory with an emphatic left-foot drive beneath Sidorczuk's body eight minutes after replacing Nicky Butt. Mission accomplished.

 Milan and Galatasaray went joint top of Group B after 1-0 victories last night, the Italians winning at the Spanish league leaders Deportivo La Coruna when the Denmark midfielder Thomas Helveg struck from 20 yards out in first-half injury-time. In Istanbul, Galatasaray beat Paris St-Germain thanks to Umit Davala's 51st-minute penalty, which means PSG have now gone nine matches without a win - and without the injured Nicolas Anelka as a starter.

Sturm Graz (3-5-1-1): Sidorczuk; Prilasnig, Popovic, Neukirchner (Strafner, 81min); Schopp, Fleurquin, Mamedov (Mahlich, 85), Korsos (Reinmayr, 70), Minavand; Vastic; Kocijan.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin (P Neville, 89), Brown, G Neville, Silvestre; Beckham, Butt (Giggs, 80), Keane, Scholes; Sheringham, Yorke (Solskjaer, 89).

Referee: A Frisk (Sweden).

Graz have reserved their best performances for the Champions League this season, but United soon assumed an air of authority and their first serious attack on 17 minutes saw an opening goal that was exquisite in its creation and clinical in its execution. Dwight Yorke started the move with an incisive pass to the fringe of the Graz penalty area but it was Teddy Sheringham's sublime flick back that did the damage. Scholes timed his run to perfection before expertly lifting the ball over the oncoming goalkeeper Kaz imierz Sidorczuk for United's first goal in open play on the Continent for seven hours and 53 minutes. "Paul has always been a good finisher since he was a kid and it's incredible how many he scores from midfield." Graz seemed to be engulfed by an inferiority complex for the rest of an opening half in which Fabien Barthez had to make only one save, diving to his right to keep out Ivica Vastic's 25-yard free-kick. The second half was not so comfortable, with Tomica Kocijan hitting the United crossbar with a rasping drive and only the brilliance of Barthez sparing what would have been a spectacular headed own-goal by Roy Keane. But as the temperature dropped so did the heads of the Graz players and, after Sheringham had had a goal ruled out for offside, much to the irritation of Ferguson, Giggs sealed victory with an emphatic left-foot drive beneath Sidorczuk's body eight minutes after replacing Nicky Butt. Mission accomplished.  Milan and Galatasaray went joint top of Group B after 1-0 victories last night, the Italians winning at the Spanish league leaders Deportivo La Coruna when the Denmark midfielder Thomas Helveg struck from 20 yards out in first-half injury-time. In Istanbul, Galatasaray beat Paris St-Germain thanks to Umit Davala's 51st-minute penalty, which means PSG have now gone nine matches without a win - and without the injured Nicolas Anelka as a starter. Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin (P Neville, 89), Brown, G Neville, Silvestre; Beckham, Butt (Giggs, 80), Keane, Scholes; Sheringham, Yorke (Solskjaer, 89). Referee: A Frisk (Sweden).

webTitle: Madonna's wedding plans hit a high note in the Highlands

fields.headline: Madonna's wedding plans hit a high note in the Highlands
fields.trailText: Celebrities are a rare a sight in quiet little towns in remote Easter Ross. Rarer still is the sound of the most famous pop singer in the world belting out Ave Maria in the local kirk.
fields.body:
Celebrities are a rare a sight in quiet little towns in remote Easter Ross. Rarer still is the sound of the most famous pop singer in the world belting out Ave Maria in the local kirk.

But as rumours of the impending nuptials of Madonna and film director Guy Ritchie gather pace, the American pop star has been spotted checking out the acoustics at 776-year-old Dornoch cathedral.

On Tuesday Madonna's private jet arrived at Inverness airport. Surrounded by bodyguards, she was whisked off to Skibo Castle - now the most exclusive club in Scotland.

A few hours later, however, Madonna left the privacy of Skibo for Dornoch town centre and the local cathedral. It was there that bemused onlookers heard her impromptu rendition of Ave Maria.

It seems all but certain that the rumours are true and Madonna and Ritchie will tie the knot in the royal burgh before Christmas. The heaviest money is on December 22 - and the date could be known within days.

If Madonna wants to marry in Scotland she must post her banns at the local registry office within at least 14 days of the big day.

There is speculation that she will marry at the cathedral before holding her reception at Skibo castle - speculation that the local minister, Susan Brown, has not confirmed, or denied.

But as Madonna slipped into Scotland on Tuesday, the tabloids were on her tail and she may opt for a wedding at Skibo castle away from the paparazzi lenses. Skibo castle has long experience in allowing stars privacy: Robert Carlyle married there; Sean Connery and Michael Douglas are regulars.

Ritchie, maker of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, has ordered a kilt in Hunting Macintosh tartan in tribute to his Scottish roots. Madonna has been spotted in Paris having fittings at Chloe.

fields.headline: The day the dream died
fields.standfirst: No hotels or office space for new Wembley as Bates's plan is sidelined
fields.trailText: There will be no hotels or office space at the new Wembley, as Ken Bates's plan is sidelined.
fields.body:
As David Dein settled into his seat for the Champions League clash against Bayern Munich on Tuesday night, Wembley and not Highbury figured foremost in the Arsenal deputy chairman's mind.

After weeks of damaging publicity, problems in raising finance and lack of information about the state of the Wembley project, Dein, along with other senior FA officials, had already decided that a change of leadership was needed.

Before the match, Dein had explained to officials close to the project, whom he was entertaining at Highbury that evening, that the time had come for the FA's top brass, led by the chief executive Adam Crozier, to take control of the new Wembley. Not only was it becoming a public relations disaster but it was too costly and the FA needed to act rapidly if it did not want to become the laughing stock of the football world.

It had already emerged that Chase Manhattan, the US bank hired by Wembley National Stadium Limited, the FA's subsidiary company, to raise finance for the project, was having trouble convincing corporate banks that it would prove to be a sound investment. The Guardian revealed last week that 30 banks had rejected Chase's approach to invest in the stadium and that it was attempting to convince another 20 to raise the £410m needed to build the new stadium.

What concerned Dein, Crozier and the FA chairman Geoff Thompson was not just the reluctance of the banks but that the new Wembley bore all the hallmarks of an expensive white elephant.

From the moment plans for the new £660m stadium were unveiled, the ambitious project had Ken Bates written all over it. Bates, as an FA board member and chair of WNSL, ensured the project would bear his fingerprints and be a virtual replica of Stamford Bridge with an emphasis on commerce as well as football.

The new Wembley stadium would include a hotel, office space, lavish banqueting facilities and 14,000 of the 90,000 seats would be set aside for VIPs and corporate hospitality guests, pushing up its cost.

After weeks of heated meetings, both at the FA and WNSL, Dein, along with the Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale and other senior FA officials, voiced their concerns. They protested that they were being kept in the dark and that too much money was being spent on non-essential areas of the stadium such as the hotel and office space.

Concerns were also raised at Bates's handling of the project, with Dein, his old adversary, most vociferous in criticising the Chelsea chairman. At one meeting, Dein asked for his concerns to be minuted.

Something radical had to be done, resulting in Bates being marginalised within the Wembley project and his dream of a hotel and office space being rejected.

The FA has already decided that plans to build a hotel at Wembley should be scrapped, cutting back its cost and making it more attractive to banks. There are also proposals to trim back the amount of office space and make banqueting facilities more economic.

One possibility now is to go back to something akin to the plan launched six years ago, which could have led to a new Wembley for less than half the current cost.

The redevelopment, which would have cost £130m, was designed by Lobb Sport, the Australian stadium architects who subsequently joined forces with Lord Foster and HOK, a US stadium company, to devise the current plans.

Drawn up in 1994 at the request of the Genesis consortium, which included a former Wembley chief executive, the design retained the east-west orientation of the pitch along with the perimeter wall and the main entrance. The integration of the twin towers into the design lacks the bravura of Lord Foster's 300-foot steel arch but enables the stadium to maintain its established visual signature. There would have been seating for 100,000 spectators and provision for a 10-lane running track, but no hotels, office space for rent, or banqueting facilities.

According to David Griffiths, a former army officer who was the stadium's general manager from 1971-76 and its chief executive from 1986-88, the Genesis consortium offered Wembley plc £75m for the stadium and £25m for the remainder of the complex, including the arena, the conference centre and the car-parking space.

At the time Wembley's share price was in steep decline, from a high of 150p in the mid-80s to a low of 3.5p in 1994, after the company had diversified into a number of projects including night clubs in the Far East and greyhound tracks in the United States. Sir Brian Wolfson, Wembley's chairman, declined the Genesis offer, subsequently accepting a cash-for-equity deal with Barclays Bank. More recently he and his board agreed to sell the stadium and its car parks to the FA for £103m.

Griffiths, who staged the first rock concert on the Wembley pitch in 1973, believes that if the FA decided to jettison the Bates-Foster-HOK-Lobb idea, the main elements of his consortium's plan could easily be revived. "Wembley needs to get back to the drawing board," he said this week.

webTitle: Gazza operation adds to Everton sicklist

fields.headline: Gazza operation adds to Everton sicklist
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne, the Everton midfielder, had a hernia operation yesterday that may rule him out for up to six weeks.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne, the Everton midfielder, had a hernia operation yesterday that may rule him out for up to six weeks.

The 33-year-old former England star who had fought his way into Walter Smith's regular starting line-up this season was diagnosed with the problem on Monday and immediately checked into hospital.

Gascoigne damaged his thigh when he slipped in taking a free-kick against Aston Villa in November and had already missed Everton's last four matches.

It is a second major blow for Smith this week with the teenage striker Francis Jeffers also ruled out until February after an ankle operation.

Alan Shearer has suffered a recurrence of tendinitis in the knee that troubled him so much during England's Euro 2000 campaign that.

He will miss Newcastle's match at Arsenal on Saturday, leaving Bobby Robson to head for Highbury without a recognised front-line striker as Carl Cort is also still missing with his knee problem.

David James, the Aston Villa goalkeeper, has responded angrily to Paolo di Canio's descriptions of him as a "cretin" and a "moron".

The pair argued after the 1-1 draw at Upton Park in January and Di Canio describes the row in his autobiography. He claims that James refused to shake his hand after the game because the Villa goalkeeper was still angry with him for allegedly diving to earn a penalty in the Hammers' Worthington Cup defeat to Villa three days earlier.

"This cretin would not shake my hand," Di Canio said in his book. "James was sticking two fingers up to British sportsmanship."

James said:"Di Canio brands me unsporting which is all very contradictory coming from him."

Carlos Marinelli, the 18-year- old Argentine bought by Middlesbrough from Boca Juniors for £1.5m, has been dropped because of stress. He did not play against West Ham last weekend because he was depressed after being sent off against Bradford in the previous game.

Bryan Robson, the Middlesbrough manager, said: "Carlos has been a bit down in training, but he is starting to look a little better. He was very down after being sent off but he's a bit brighter and a reserve game will do him good."

Aston Villa have re-signed the Republic of Ireland defender Steve Staunton from Liverpool on a free transfer, subject to him passing a medical. Staunton has agreed to a wage cut at Villa Park to resurrect his career. The 31-year-old is reported to have earned up to £28,000-a-week during his spell at Anfield.

The European Commission said yesterday that it was optimistic of reaching a deal with Fifa on the future of transfer regulations. The two sides will meet for decisive talks next Tuesday.

webTitle: Eriksson faces 11 days of 'life or death'

fields.headline: Eriksson faces 11 days of 'life or death'
fields.trailText: Whether Sven-Goran Eriksson's immediate future lies with Lazio or England could be decided in the next 11 days.
fields.body:
Whether Sven-Goran Eriksson's immediate future lies with Lazio or England could be decided in the next 11 days. The Rome derby looms large on Sunday week and the Swede admits every game from here is "life or death".

Defeat by Leeds on Tuesday has left Eriksson's position increasingly insecure. Although Lazio's general manager Massimo Cragnotti insisted the coach was "untouchable" and would see out the season, the truth is that surviving this month could be tricky.

Lazio face two critical matches before they can contemplate the Serie A leaders Roma. First comes Sunday's league game at Vicenza, then the second leg of their Italian Cup quarter-final at Udinese, into which they take a 2-1 lead.

The Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti is unlikely to make a change while the club are within reach of all three of their targets: a second consecutive scudetto and the domestic and European cups. But poor results in the next two matches would heap added significance on to the derby.

Despite this, Eriksson sounded confident and defiant after the poor display against Leeds. "What if we lose? I never think about those things," he said. "I have a contract until June and when I wake up in the morning I will try to be positive and think things will change.

"We are seven points behind the first team in the league and three points behind second place in our Champions League group. Every game is life or death more or less. From now on it's extremely important if we want to have a season like last season.

"We must score more goals, play better football and never give up. We didn't give up last season and we won the league because of that. I still believe I can turn things round. As long as you have a contract you must give 110% for your club. As far as I'm concerned the relationship between Lazio and myself has not changed. As far as the club is concerned, I don't think they will change anything."

Certainly there was no feeling of mutiny at Lazio's quiet Formello training ground yesterday lunch time. Disgruntled fans were conspicuous by their absence and the captain, Alessandro Nesta, refused to hold Eriksson responsible for the decline. "Mr Eriksson is not the problem," he stressed. "It is not his responsibility. There are a lot of players in the team who can do much better." The squad is thought to be genuinely supportive of the coach.

Eriksson has, of course, rescued lost causes before. Lazio trailed Juventus by nine points last March but won the title and Massimo Cragnotti is hoping for a repeat this season. "Eriksson is untouchable," he said. "He will be here until the end of the season and we will be back. You can't expect us to question Eriksson's future every time we lose a match."

The Football Association, meanwhile, said that "nothing has changed. Sven continues to be the coach of Lazio and for us it's business as usual," said the FA's executive director David Davies. "He will continue his contacts with Peter Taylor, and [his assistant] Tord Grip is a very active employee of the Football Association."

Meanwhile, Leeds's matchwinner Alan Smith has been offered a new contract with a pay rise of more than 300%. It would take the 20-year-old's weekly salary from £3,000 to around £13,000 and keep him at Elland Road until 2006.

fields.headline: BSkyB boss pockets £6m shares windfall
fields.trailText: 10.15am: BSkyB boss Tony Ball has bagged a £6m windfall after selling shares in the company, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB boss Tony Ball has netted a £6m windfall after selling shares in the company.

Mr Ball earned £5.95m before tax by disposing of 570,000 BSkyB shares yesterday, just under the 600,000 shares he was awarded this year.

He had been entitled to sell the shares since last month, but had to wait until an Office of Fair Trading investigation into BSkyB's pay-TV channel supply business became public knowledge before he could cash them in.

Mr Ball sold his shares at £10.44.

BSkyB's share price rose nearly 5% yesterday to £10.95, but was still well below this year's high of £21.58. He has an interest in another 2.1m BSkyB shares, but most cannot be sold until after November 2001.

Martin Stewart, BSkyB's chief financial officer, sold 237,500 shares in the company.

fields.headline: Text messaging boom shows no sign of ending
fields.trailText: 9.30am:Mobile phone users send more than 700m text messages per month according to latest research, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone users send more than 700m text messages per month, according to the latest research.

The text message boom is showing no sign of ending since the first short message service (SMS) signal was sent in 1992.

The monthly figures are increasing 1,000% year-on-year, bringing a considerable boost to the coffers of mobile phone companies.

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone company, earns 5% of its revenue from SMS services.

Teenage use of text message has boosted traffic for all phone companies, many of which are now advertising the "hip" aspect of text messaging instead of straight-forward phone conversations.

Text messaging is also being pioneered in shopping centres as a means of relaying news about in-store promotions and discounts.

The IDC survey added that about 8.6bn messages will be sent in the UK this year, which translates to around 24m each day.

A further survey by internet giant AOL showed that one in five teenagers aged between 13 and 16 only use their phone for text messages.

The soaring figures for SMS products will boost companies' hopes that data services will become a big money-spinner for mobile phones in the future.

webTitle: Snooker faces biggest break in 75 years

fields.headline: Snooker faces biggest break in 75 years
fields.standfirst: Old order under threat as 40 top players back rival 10-event tour
fields.trailText: Internet company the Sportsmasters Network (TSN) is behind a plan that will spark the biggest shake-up in the 75-year history of professional snooker, writes Clive Everton.
fields.body:
Forty of the world's leading players, including the world champion Mark Williams, Ronnie 0'Sullivan and Stephen Hendry, are to support a 10-tournament tour to rival the existing world-ranking events.

A new internet company, The Sportsmasters Network (TSN), is behind the plan which will spark the biggest shake-up in the 75-year history of professional snooker and directly challenges the authority of the World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association which has governed the game since 1971.

The move means that next spring's Embassy world championship in Sheffield will be the last in which all the leading players will compete. That will be greeted with dismay by the BBC, which has recently signed a six-year deal reported to be worth £23m.

Snooker's dependence on tobacco companies for sponsorship has been a key element in the TSN decision to go it alone.

George Smith, TSN's chief executive, said: "Over the last decade, snooker has found it impossible to attract new sponsors who are concerned that their own brands would suffer from indirect association with tobacco, while legislation has also severely limited broadcast opportunities.

"For all these reasons, TSN will be working to attract a new range of global sponsors to the sport, also pre-empting the legislation for a complete ban on tobacco sponsorship scheduled for 2003."

Tobacco sponsorship covers three of the current eight world-ranking events, and Benson and Hedges sponsor the game's most prestigious invitation event, the Masters at Wembley. Four of next season's world-ranking events have no sponsor.

Links with tobacco are not the only reason why WPBSA has failed to attract backers. The business and sponsorship worlds have become increasingly reluctant to deal with an organisation perceived to lack commercial experience.

TSN, which received a £10m investment from the City finance house Warburg Pincus last May, spent last summer on the brink of a three-year deal which would have given the governing body £3.3m in exchange for the title sponsorships of four events: the Champions Cup (ITV), British Open (Sky), Grand Prix (BBC) and Nations Cup (ITV).

In addition, TSN would have become WPBSA's internet partners, bearing the costs of that operation but giving the association 45% of any profit.

Having already concluded a 10-year £6m deal with the International Billiards and Snooker Federation, which has 60 national associations affiliated to it, TSN has simply decided to go head-to-head with the governing body.

TSN's five-man board is chaired by Ian Doyle,who manages Williams, Hendry, O'Sullivan and 20 others. The key to the deal is the internet product. TSN's information website is attracting 3.5m hits per month from 110 countries. But to make any real money, not immediately but a couple of years down the road, it needs moving pictures of important tournaments.

For October's Regal Scottish Masters, the only event Doyle promotes, TSN obtained permission from BBC Scotland TV to show its pictures live on the internet. This was supported by TSN's own studio coverage.

The response was immense from established snooker nations, particularly China when Marco Fu made his 147, and unexpectedly positive from Brunei, Mongolia, Nepal, Lebanon, Uruguay, Saudi Arabia, Bulgaria, Ukraine and Tonga, hitherto unconsidered as hotbeds of snooker.

webTitle: Medical errors led to diabetes death

fields.headline: Medical errors led to diabetes death
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old woman with diabetes died because of a catalogue of errors by GPs and a hospital trust, according to a special report from the health service ombudsman published yesterday, reinforcing anxiety about the way diabetics are cared for in the NHS.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old woman with diabetes died because of a catalogue of errors by GPs and a hospital trust, according to a special report from the health service ombudsman published yesterday, reinforcing anxiety about the way diabetics are cared for in the NHS.

The woman, referred to only as Miss J in the ombudsman's report, was diagnosed as suffering from mature-onset diabetes of the young, known as MODY, in July 1996. This condition, now called type 2 diabetes in the young, is on the rise in the UK in parallel with the increase in obesity and has become a major concern in the United States. Sufferers do not need insulin, but control their symptoms by diet.

However, the ombudsman found that Miss J had probably been misdiagnosed by a consultant who jumped too swiftly to his conclusion. She was probably suffering from type 1 diabetes, which event-ually needs insulin.

The following summer, Miss J felt unwell, and visited three GPs, none of whom tested her blood or urine for signs that she was losing control of her diabetes, even though she told them all that she was diabetic. All diagnosed gastritis.

But the day after her third consultation, Miss J was admitted to hospital suffering from ketoacidosis, a dangerous condition relating to insulin-dependent diabetes. She was admitted to intensive care.

The ombudsman, Michael Buckley, found that, at Halton General Hospitals NHS Trust, there was confusion within the intensive care unit as to which consultant was responsible for her, which led to "a degree of confusion and a lack of leadership to doctors in training".

Miss J complained of a headache, but nursing staff did not pay enough attention to her concerns or those of her family. She was not improving, but nobody reviewed the treatment she was getting. Early the following morning, she collapsed and was put on life support. A brain scan revealed cerebral oedema, a swelling inside the skull which is a rare side effect of ketoacidosis. She died on 31 July 1997.

The ombudsman concluded that there were a number of mistakes, beginning with Miss J's diagnosis. "Avoiding any of these mistakes would have improved Miss J's chance of survival. It is not possible for me to say that one or more of these mistakes individually led to her death; but together they almost certainly did."
