webTitle: Journalist 'was killed to save drugs empire'

fields.headline: Journalist 'was killed to save drugs empire'
fields.standfirst:
Shooting plan was dictated from foreign hideaway, court told

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The assassination of investigative journalist Veronica Guerin was ordered by an Irish drugs baron, who from abroad directed members of his gang to execute her, a Dublin court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The assassination of investigative journalist Veronica Guerin was ordered by an Irish drugs baron, who from abroad directed members of his gang to execute her, a Dublin court heard yesterday.

John Gilligan, 48, denies murder and 15 counts of smuggling drugs and firearms into Ireland between 1994 and 1996.

The special criminal court in Dublin, which sits without a jury, heard that Gilligan ordered the hit as he was facing the threat of jail because of a case brought against him by Ms Guerin.

She had pressed assault charges against him after she had confronted him at his home, and Gilligan feared a jail sentence would threaten his lucrative drugs empire, the prosecution alleged.

The court also heard evidence that Gilligan phoned Ms Guerin and threatened to murder her, the day after she had "doorstepped" him.

The murder of Ms Guerin, married with one young son, led to one of the biggest criminal investigations in Ireland to hunt down the killers.

Ms Guerin, 37, was crime correspondent of the Sunday Independent newspaper and had won awards for her work exposing criminals in the Irish Republic.

She was shot dead on June 26, 1996, on the Naas road in Dublin, when a man on a motorcycle fired six bullets from a .357 Magnum revolver into her body.

Opening the prosecution case, Peter Charleton said Gilligan was the "controlling mind" behind the assassination. "He committed this offence through his agents, his agents being members of a gang under his control who all of the while acted according to his will."

Mr Charleton said Gilligan commanded the gang, which operated in secrecy with "a cloak of terror" using "vicious and violent threats" against anyone who threatened his will, including Ms Guerin.

The prosecution alleged that Gilligan had smuggled hundreds of kilograms of cannabis into Ireland, and laundered the proceeds through Amsterdam.

Mr Charleton said: "John Gilligan had Veronica Guerin killed in order to protect his drugs empire and to ensure he did not go to jail at a time when he was making a great deal of money and perhaps his absence would have resulted in damage to that empire."

The prosecution said that Gilligan's "motive and intention" towards Ms Guerin was made clear the day before her murder.

Gilligan went to court for a scheduled hearing of the assault charge brought by the re porter. On his way in to court, Gilligan said to two Garda officers: "She is a fucking stupid bitch, this case will never get off the ground."

Later that same day Gilligan left Ireland, flying from Dublin to Amsterdam, but called his gang members to check on the progress of the murder plot. "John Gilligan deliberately left the jurisdiction, having put in place the elements for Veronica Guerin to be murdered, and from abroad directed that murder," Mr Charleton alleged.

On the day of the murder, Gilligan is alleged to have called Russell Warren, who will testify against him, from Amsterdam. Warren kept Ms Guerin under surveillance as she went to a court hearing after she had been stopped for speeding.

After her case, Ms Guerin drove back towards central Dublin with Gilligan's gang keeping her under surveillance.

Brian Meehan, convicted at a previous trial of Ms Guerin's murder, drove a Kawasaki motorcycle with the gunman, who was not named in court, riding as a pillion passenger.

Ms Guerin's car had stopped at traffic lights at the junction of Naas road and Boot road. At 12.54pm Ms Guerin made a call to a Garda officer on her mobile, which was taped.

The recording shows that Ms Guerin's conversation was in terrupted mid-sentence by a bang, with the prosecution saying she was shot at 12.55pm.

Felix McEnroy, a barrister, testified that on September 15, 1995, Gilligan phoned Ms Guerin while she was with him and threatened to shoot her, and to kidnap and rape her young son, Cahal.

Mr McEnroy had previously represented Gilligan in the late 1980s. He told the court that the day after Gilligan is alleged to have assaulted Ms Guerin, the reporter went to his office. Mr Mc Enroy said: "She had a bruising or swelling over her left eye."

He said Ms Guerin received a call on one of her two mobiles, during which she became afraid.

Mr Mc Enroy said he was basing his testimony on what he could hear of the call and on what Ms Guerin told him of its contents.

He said he heard abuse and then the caller said: "This is John Gilligan".

The call continued and then Mr McEnroy said he heard the voice alleged to be Gilligan say: "If you do one thing on me, or if you write about me, I will kidnap your son and ride him. I will shoot you, do you understand what I am saying?"

Mr McEnroy said he advised Ms Guerin to end the call and make a statement to police.

The trial continues.

Felix McEnroy, a barrister, testified that on September 15, 1995, Gilligan phoned Ms Guerin while she was with him and threatened to shoot her, and to kidnap and rape her young son, Cahal. Mr McEnroy had previously represented Gilligan in the late 1980s. He told the court that the day after Gilligan is alleged to have assaulted Ms Guerin, the reporter went to his office. Mr Mc Enroy said: "She had a bruising or swelling over her left eye." He said Ms Guerin received a call on one of her two mobiles, during which she became afraid. Mr Mc Enroy said he was basing his testimony on what he could hear of the call and on what Ms Guerin told him of its contents. He said he heard abuse and then the caller said: "This is John Gilligan". The call continued and then Mr McEnroy said he heard the voice alleged to be Gilligan say: "If you do one thing on me, or if you write about me, I will kidnap your son and ride him. I will shoot you, do you understand what I am saying?" Mr McEnroy said he advised Ms Guerin to end the call and make a statement to police. The trial continues.

fields.headline: £1m bounty offered to dot.com students
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Students are being offered £1m to come up with the next big dot.com idea, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Just months after Channel 4 offered a £1m prize to a dot.com entrepreneur, another million pound giveaway is being launched.

Students across Britain are being offered a bounty of £1m to come up with the next big dot.com idea by high-tech, education and banking communities.

With more and more dot.com businesses failing, venture capitalists are hoping that academics will become the next wave of e-entrepreneurs.

The competition, called launchit2001.com, is open to anyone currently in higher education but teams of people that include a student or academic staff member will also be accepted.

The funding, which will be split between the best two winning ventures, has been provided by Cross Atlantic Capital Partners and incubator Brainspark, who between them will pick the winners.

The winning entries will not only receive finance but will be given management guidance to get the project off the ground.

The deadline for online registration and submission of a two-page executive summary is January 26 with full business plans to be submitted by March 30. Winners will be announced in June.

Launchit2001 is also backed by Silicon Valley Bank, Hewlett Packard, McDermott, Will & Emery and Pearson Education.

fields.headline: Speculation mounts over Emap sell-off
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Speculation is mounting that Emap's communications division, which includes Broadcast and Retail Week, is about to be sold, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Speculation is mounting that Emap's communications division, responsible for titles such as Broadcast and Retail Week, is about to be sold.

Emap's relegation from the flagship FTSE 100 index has intensified rumours within the company that talks are under way with Reed Elsevier or Wilmington about a possible sale.

Analysts believe the sale of the division would be worth £750m.

Emap would use the cash to strengthen its presence abroad and boost its consumer publishing arm, as the company's plunging stock has ruled out the use of shares as an acquisition currency.

The publishing and broadcast company was kicked out of the FTSE after seeing its share price crash from a year-high of nearly 1800p to last night's 774p.

A debt mountain of £650m, combined with demotion from the FTSE, will make fund-raising difficult in an already fractious market.

Emap's most recent results showed a dip in advertising growth and flat profits, although revenues at the communications division rose 8%.

Anthony de Larrinaga, analyst at SG Securities, said: "Emap Communications is a more parochial, UK-orientated business and the market is becoming more global. If they can get a good price for it, it would not be an absurd idea to sell."

One analyst suggested that Emap may seek to fill its coffers in preparation for a buying spree in the radio sector, if the government relaxes radio licence ownership rules in the forthcoming communications white paper.

The company's radio assets include Kiss FM, Piccadilly Radio in Manchester and Radio City in Liverpool, but broadcast regulations are preventing consolidation in the radio industry, with Capital Radio, GWR and Emap itching to become more powerful players.

It is understood that Emap has not received any firm bids for the titles, which would give a significant boost to any publisher's UK portfolio.

fields.headline: BA braced for rivals' onslaught
fields.standfirst: Dec 5: BA loses court battle
fields.trailText:
8.15am British Airways is bracing itself for an onslaught of abuse from rival airlines following its high court defeat this week, writes Jade Garrett.
Dec 5: BA loses court battle
fields.body:
British Airways is bracing itself for an onslaught of abuse from rival airlines following its defeat at the high court this week.

Ryanair wasted no time in getting one over on its larger rival by launching national press ads yesterday that said, "BA are expensive. It's official. The high court says so!".

The ads refer to its victory in the courts on Tuesday when a high court judge said it was fair to call British Airways "expensive bastards".

Virgin will almost certainly capitalise on BA's misfortune. A spokesperson at its ad agency, Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, said this morning: "We have a reputation for being fleet of foot in responding to tactical opportunities."

Previous BA-bashing ads from Virgin included a millennium campaign that read, "BA's Millennium Bug*. *Virgin Atlantic" and "BA doesn't give a shiatsu".

The dramatic ruling was made during a court case brought by BA against Irish rival Ryanair which had cheekily run adverts asterisking the word bastards using the slogan "Expensive BA****ds".

But the two-day hearing ended in defeat for BA, with the judge ruling that "in substance" the adverts were true.

"I suspect the real reason BA do not like it is precisely because it is true," said Mr Justice Jacob.

webTitle: Maps chart flood risk as Britain braces for new storms

fields.headline: Maps chart flood risk as Britain braces for new storms
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the weather
Flood plain maps from the Environment Agency
fields.trailText: As large parts of Britain face heavy rain and warnings this weekend of a repeat of November's floods, the environment agency today for the first time publishes maps of the flood plains of England and Wales.
fields.body:
As large parts of Britain face heavy rain and warnings this weekend of a repeat of November's floods, the environment agency today for the first time publishes maps of the flood plains of England and Wales.

Most of central London, including the houses of parliament, Downing Street and the Isle of Dogs are in a flood plain and have a greater than 1% annual chance of being flooded, according to the agency.

Internet users will be able to enter their postcode or place name and see whether their property is at risk from river or sea flooding.

Some fear that putting the maps on the internet will make property harder to sell and insurance hard to come by. The agency believes that people should be warned of the risks, and wants to discourage local authorities from further building in the areas.

The countryside minister, Elliot Morley, said: "People need to know if they are at risk, indeed they have a right to know, so I commend the agency for making the maps available."

The agency said the maps indicated a greater than 1% chance of being flooded by a river and 0.5% chance of being flooded by the sea. The agency's floodline received more than 500,000 calls during October and last month when the floods were worst.

There were 40 flood warnings in operation yesterday and one severe flood warning on the River Wye after heavy rain in Wales. Over the next 24 hours this is expected to increase as western England and Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales are likely to be hit by severe gales, heavy rain and flooding as a vigorous depression moves in off the Atlantic.

Storm force winds of more than 80mph are expected in some areas as the depression moves north, with structural damage possible. This week end's weather could be a repeat of the storm on October 30 when tornadoes hit the south coast of England.

"Some parts of western Britain will get around 2 inches of rain which will cause problems for rivers already on alert," said a forecaster.

The depression is forecast to strike south-western England and Wales this evening.

The Floodline number is 0845 9881188

fields.headline: Partnership scheme for modernising surgeries
fields.standfirst: Society Unlimited
fields.trailText: Money from banks and pension funds will be used to modernise GP surgeries, particularly in the run-down inner cities, under a public private partnership established by a NHS and Social Care Bill to be published later this month.
fields.body:
Money from banks and pension funds will be used to modernise GP surgeries, particularly in the run-down inner cities, under a public private partnership established by a NHS and Social Care Bill to be published later this month.

Ministers expect this first private finance initiative in primary health care to generate £1bn to renovate up to 3,000 of England's 10,000 family doctor premises by 2004.

They hope to attract a bank or pension fund as a partner. Long-term returns would come from rents from GPs, pharmacists, opticians and non-medical commercial outlets that would be clustered in newly-built or modernised high street premises.

The government expects the scheme to be less controversial than other recent private partnerships because GPs already lease premises from private landlords, often in unsatisfactory buildings with upkeep problems.

The scheme will be run by an "equity stake company" to be called the NHS Local Improvement Finance Trust (NHS Lift).

Over the next four years it will get £175m from the Department of Health, £175m from the Treasury's equity stake initiative Partnership UK, and a similar amount from a commercial partner.

The equity fund will be used to support borrowing from other financial institutions to raise £1 bn over four years.

A Department of Health spokesman said the company's priority would be to invest in parts of the country, such as inner cities, where primary care services were most in need of expansion.

The initiative would assist regeneration and relieve GPs from the commercial risk of developing premises in the run-down areas where they were most needed.

Leases would be made available to GPs whether they were salaried, independent or working in partnerships.

The terms would make it easier for a GP to move after a few years and pass the practice to a successor.

The British Medical Association said it could not tell whether the scheme would work until the government gave more details. "Nonetheless, the intention to improve GP premises, particularly in inner cities, is clearly one we would support," said John Chisholm, chairman of the association's general practitioners committee.

Other parts of the bill will give Alan Milburn, the health secretary, more power to intervene against poorly performing hospitals. In cases of "persistent or catastrophic failure", he will be able to sack the whole management team.

All health authorities will benefit from a £500m performance fund. The best performers will get discretion on how to spend this to improve standards, but the worst will be told what to do by a new NHS modernisation agency.

The King's Fund, an independent health research charity, said the system was unfair. If it had been in place this year, Manchester and Liverpool would have been identified as the worst performers, while Dorset and East Surrey would have been the best.

The bill will also:

 Give more prescribing rights to nurses, chiropodists, physiotherapists and pharmacists.

 Encourage health authorities and local councils to integrate NHS and social services by merging their powers under "care trusts" - with a reserve power for ministers to require this.

 Make the NHS responsible for paying for nursing care in homes for older people, but not personal care as a royal commission recommended.

A second health bill will ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco. Ministers wanted this to be done through an EU directive, but that was struck down by the European court.

Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the legislation was "the beginning of the end for the tobacco industry in Britain".

He congratulated the government on ignoring "the persistent bleatings of the tobacco manufacturers, who even now refuse to accept responsibility for the needless deaths of millions of people worldwide".

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, said the advertising ban would save up to 3,000 lives a year. The brands most heavily advertised were those most heavily smoked by children, she said.

fields.headline: Crackdown on black economy
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Persistent benefit fraudsters will lose their right to state support, as part of a crackdown on the black economy in a social security fraud bill.
fields.body:
Persistent benefit fraudsters will lose their right to state support, as part of a crackdown on the black economy in a social security fraud bill.

The government will withdraw or reduce benefits for anyone convicted twice of committing a benefit offence over the previous three years.

The department of social security said the scheme would deter hard-core fraudsters. DSS and local authority investigators would be able to demand information from banks, building societies and specified private and public sector bodies where fraud was suspected.

The DSS would also be able to exchange information with overseas social security departments to combat international fraud rings.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said: "This is the 43rd time that the government has promised to crack down on welfare fraud. It is time we finally saw some action."

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said the "two strikes and you're out'" proposal was unacceptable. "Benefit fraud is already a criminal offence and there is a criminal justice system in place to deal with it. Fraudsters, not their families, should pay for their crimes in the courts.

"Benefit fraud is fast becoming another Dutch auction. Labour are proposing savings of £1bn. The Tories, who never even managed to measure benefit fraud let alone tackle it, have pledged to double that. This is a meaningless war of words."

The bill will also let the DSS offer a fine of between £1,000 and £5,000 as an alternative to criminal prosecution in cases of employers colluding with employees to commit benefit fraud.

webTitle: French acclaim cartoon vision of Rwandan horror

fields.headline: French acclaim cartoon vision of Rwandan horror
fields.trailText: One would not have thought it ideal material for a comic book. In three months in 1994, 800,000 people were killed in Rwanda as extremist Hutus tried to eliminate the minority Tutsi population. That genocide is now the subject of a book by a French cartoonist which has been hailed as resembling a Shakespearean tragedy.
fields.body:
One would not have thought it ideal material for a comic book. In three months in 1994, 800,000 people were killed in Rwanda as extremist Hutus tried to eliminate the minority Tutsi population. That genocide is now the subject of a book by a French cartoonist which has been hailed as resembling a Shakespearean tragedy.

Déogratias by Jean-Philippe Stassen, published in Paris this week, is an 80-page comic book dramatising the ethnic tension which led to the Rwandan genocide.

"The book is inspired by anger," Stassen said.

At the outset Hutus and Tutsis are living peacefully together. Déogratias, the boy hero, is a Hutu and is in love with Bégnigne, a Tutsi. As the massacres take place and his Tutsi schoolmates are killed, Déogratias does nothing except drink to forget what is going on around him. As he does so, he mutates into a dog, symbolising his cowardliness and disappearing humanity.

Stassen indicts not only Hutus but the Catholic church, for cynicism during the genocide, and the colonial powers, for creating the tribal strife in the first place.

"Hutu, Tutsi - it's the whites who invented the differences between us," a disgusted Rwandan soldier tells Déogratias at one point. "They wrote those words on our identity cards. They came and sowed the seeds of division."

Reviewing Déogratias in Le Monde, Yves-Marie Labé called it "a story both distancing and moving, like a Shakespearean tragedy".

Such comic books, known in France as bandes dessinées , or BDs, are regularly used to explore serious themes. Last week saw the publication of L'Enqu te Corse, by René Pétillon, an adventure story in which the detective hero, Jack Palmer, becomes embroiled in a topical debate about Corsican nationalism as police and activists trade bombs and bullets.

Meanwhile the publisher Delcourt has produced two extremely abridged, though colourful, cartoon versions of Marcel Proust's seven-volume novel, Á La Recherche du Temps Perdu.

Surveys show that 41% of the population regularly buy and read BDs.

webTitle: Hague scorns Blair's programme as 'all spin and no delivery'

fields.headline: Hague scorns Blair's programme as 'all spin and no delivery'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was last night accused of arrogance in offering a "thin" legislative programme aimed purely at securing good press coverage in the run-up to an expected May general election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was last night accused of arrogance in offering a "thin" legislative programme aimed purely at securing good press coverage in the run-up to an expected May general election.

In a boisterous response to the Queen's speech, the Tory leader William Hague told the prime minister the speech was a thousand words long but could be summed up in the single sentence: "All spin and no delivery."

"It is designed to produce better headlines not better services. All these measures will not speed up one train or one hospital operation. It will not improve discipline or standards in a single school, it will not cut crime on the streets, it will not reduce tax for a single family," Mr Hague said.

Commenting on the government's lightest legislative programme since coming into office - just 15 bills in contrast to last year's 28 - the Tory leader said: "There was so little in it, it was very good of her majesty to come down here and deliver it."

The government had failed to deliver on manifesto pledges for a referendum on proportional representation or on regional government, to introduce a water bill or a bill to implement the urban white paper, or to introduce measures on adoption law and vaccine damage payments which would have won cross-party support.

Instead, it was an "arrogant government", which flaunted this most clearly in its determination to bring back a bill to curb the right to trial by jury for a third time - despite widespread opposition - and in its decision to abolish community health councils.

Moreover, it was guilty of "abusing democracy" by pushing through government legislation which, because of the "complete mismanagement of the parliamentary timetable", had not been debated in the Commons."They are producing the least considered legislation in the history of the country," he added.

To rowdy cheers, Mr Hague then accused the government of being weak on crime, pointing out levels had risen, while police numbers had fallen. Curfew orders had also been promised in this administration's first Queen's speech in 1997 but none had been imposed.

He jeered at Mr Blair's admission that the NHS was in crisis, coming four years after he pledged to save it, and said schools were facing a recruitment crisis, as secondary school class sizes and levels of paperwork had risen, despite the pre-election pledge of "education, education, education."

The leader of the Liberal Democrats, Charles Kennedy, also mocked this mantra by describing the speech as about little more than "re-election, re-election, re-election". Ministers were now just "clearing the decks" for the poll and made little pretence it was a programme for a full legislative year, he added.

The speech was a failure in its refusal to tackle the transport chaos, the overcrowding in hospitals, and the fact secondary schools had the highest class sizes since 1979 while pensioners were falling behind in the nation's prosperity.

Moves to penalise benefit fraudsters would just affect their children, and the government was offering Tory policies, with "knee-jerk measures" on criminal justice and the reintroduction of the mode of trial bill.

He sometimes wondered if there was "an Ann Widdecombe" inside the prime minister. To laughter, he added that one was enough.

In a robust response, the prime minister stressed he had inherited a failing NHS and education system from the Tories, but that waiting lists were falling for the first time while primary school sizes had been slashed. Teacher recruitment was also up.

He attacked Tory claims of cutting £16bn in public spending, analysing the areas the Tories said they would cut back on and showing these would not provide the necessary money. He insisted Mr Hague "does not have the faintest clue where this £16bn would come from."

"There is virtually not a single area of Tory policy which could not be ripped to shreds even by a cursory examination," he continued.

There was one area in which Mr Hague excelled, however: His jokes were good.

webTitle: Election looms as Labour launches drive against drunks to woo swing voters

fields.headline: Election looms as Labour launches drive against drunks to woo swing voters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: There is a remarkably close similarity between Labour's Queen's speech yesterday and John Major's last legislative programme in 1996-7. Both programmes were designed as a shameless, populist appeal to the swing voters in marginal seats.
fields.body:
There is a remarkably close similarity between Labour's Queen's speech yesterday and John Major's last legislative programme in 1996-7. Both programmes were designed as a shameless, populist appeal to the swing voters in marginal seats.

For the single-minded focus of those who assemble a government's final legislative programme is middle England, and their enemies - drunks, drug pushers, benefit fraudsters, car thieves, kerb crawlers, teenage yobs, and liberal judges.

Thus, in the autumn of 1996 Mr Major published no less than five law and order bills, beating Mr Straw's current four. Michael Howard, the then home secretary, described his programme "as the most radical attack on crime this century", highlighting plans to impose mandatory minimum sentences on people convicted more than once for drug trafficking or burglary. Like Labour yesterday, Mr Major also added a social security fraud bill and introduced measures to give councils powers to confiscate alcohol being consumed by anyone under-18 in public places, a theme to which Mr Straw has returned with his anti-yobs package.

The Conservatives' hope in 1996 was that Tony Blair's "tough on crime" message could be punctured by manoeuvring Labour into opposing sentencing measures that had outraged the judiciary. Mr Blair saw a political trap and declined to oppose any of it. It was left to the appeal court judge Lord Bridge to fulminate against "the Satanic pact between the two main political parties to see that this ill-considered legislation is forced through".

Mr Blair even urged Mr Howard to introduce extra measures to hit paedophiles and stalkers. Fearing he was being outbid in an anti-crime auction, Mr Howard hastily tabled the measures.

Four years later, Mr Blair has now returned to the same auction with his own package. The message was supplemented last night with an anti-crime TV political broadcast advertising the Crimestoppers number.

Mr Blair has been prompted by a stream of eloquent messages from his pollster, Philip Gould, in the spring that William Hague was gaining ground on crime. Fear of crime is on the rise.

Labour strategists also concede that the overall drop in police numbers in this parliament could be its achilles heel in the election. The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, certainly intends to cite the figures in every TV studio in the country right through the election campaign. As to the bills themselves, Miss Widdecombe will not oppose them - just dismiss them.

Labour clearly hopes that the headline measures, such as fixed penalty fines and extended curfews, will reassure its doubters. Most Labour MPs yesterday swallowed the anti-crime gimmickry as a necessary evil. But they fear overall that the speech looks too thin and too obviously constructed with a spring election in mind. The relative thinness is, in part, because Labour struggled with its previous legislative programme, due to its lack of overall majority in the Lords.

Again a comparison with the 1997 election run-in is instructive. In the run-up to the May 1997 election, the house started meeting from October 23 to March 21 with 86 sitting days over 718 hours. The late start to this session, the latest for decades, leaves only 14 weeks before Mr Blair will fire the election starting pistol.

But Labour strategists insist there is enough to keep the New Labour coalition together. There is a nod to Labour activists through the fox hunting measure, even if Mr Straw does not expect the bill reaches the statute book. Human rights activists may be mollified by jam tomorrow on arms exports.

The laws needed to impose the NHS plan may be obscure, but they are a sign of intent, along with the shedloads of cash for the NHS in the summer spending review. And in the end it will be the economy and the state of public services which will determine this election.

Bills in brief

Education

Children with disabilities and special educational needs will have greater rights to be educated in mainstream schools under the terms of a bill unveiled in the Queen's speech. Schools, colleges, universities and local authorities in England and Wales would have to ensure they do not treat disabled pupils less favourably than non-disabled children.

Northern Ireland

A radical overhaul of the criminal justice system in Northern Ireland is planned in the Criminal Justice System in Northern Ireland (Draft) Bill, which seeks to put in place a raft of recommendations of a review group set up under the Good Friday agreement.

The draft bill, which will be published in April 2001, will seek to implement the review's conclusions - which range from banning the practice of saying: "God save the Queen" when a judge enters a court, to setting up a commission for the appointment of judges, to ending the RUC's role in prosecuting 30,000 minor offences each year.

Armed forces

Military law will be updated to bring it in line with civilian law in the armed forces bill, which is introduced every five years to iron out anomalies. Procedures for investigating offences committed by service personnel will be altered, to bring them in line with the Police and Criminal Evidence Act.

Child protection

The powers of the children's commissioner in Wales - a post introduced this year in the wake of the Waterhouse report - will be greatly extended ensuring the as-yet-unappointed commissioner can review and monitor arrangements for complaints and advocacy on behalf of children in schools and NHS hospitals, not just those in the care of local authorities.

Will Woodward and Sarah Hall

webTitle: Riviera runs red as activists gather

fields.headline: Riviera runs red as activists gather
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The mayor of Nice, Jacques Peyrat, was not taking any chances yesterday: between the gendarmes, the riot police, anti-terrorist units, and undercover intelligence, he had 6,000 officers on hand.
fields.body:
The mayor of Nice, Jacques Peyrat, was not taking any chances yesterday: between the gendarmes, the riot police, anti-terrorist units, and undercover intelligence, he had 6,000 officers on hand.

That was roughly one police officer for every 10 demonstrators parading through the rain-drenched streets of the riviera resort demanding such things as an end to genetically modified crops, more support for small farmers, and greater restrictions on world trade.

Most of those demonstrating before the EU heads of state begin their summit to agree the reforms needed to enable the EU to expand were trade unionists calling for greater social rights and an improved charter of fundamental rights.

Under a sea of red banners, French, Italian and Spanish trade unionists rubbed shoulders with those from Poland, Slovenia and Luxembourg. Some Dutchmen were dressed up as Father Christmas.

Anti-globalisers organised a separate but equally jovial procession, in disagreement with the trade unionists on the status of the charter. "Our march is not in competition with theirs," said Michel Rousseau, an anti-unemployment activist. "We do not want the charter to be enforced by law, because it's a lousy charter."

Dancing the tango and singing in the rain, the protesters gathered in the city centre before splitting in two for their respective marches.

The trade unionists say that the charter, much watered-down since it first appeared, is still a useful starting point, but must be enforced by law. At present, thanks largely to British opposition, it may become a non-binding declaration.

Up to 40,000 protesters from about 90 organisations in 25 countries - French small farmers, Italian Zapatistas, British socialists, Turkish Workers Against Globalisation and Portuguese communists - are expected today.

The banners being unfurled at Nice station, where protesters arrived in a chartered train, included "All rights for everyone", "Say No to mad cows and GM crops", "Down with social dumping", "End tax havens now", "Down with liberalism", and "Capitalism kills".

But the hopes of up to 1,000 Italian anti-globalisers, known as the Ya Bastas ("Enough"), were dashed when their Global Action Express train was cancelled.

The mayor failed to lay on special treatment, too. "There are people who are going to protest," Mr Peyrat said. "That is their right ... But it is not my responsibility to provide them with food, a bed for the night and all the rest.

"My responsibility is to make sure the heads of state can work in relative calm."

webTitle: EU told to rise above national interests

fields.headline: EU told to rise above national interests
fields.standfirst:
Scepticism and bureaucracy threaten to prolong the 'waiting fatigue' of candidate countries

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: EU leaders must put Europe-wide interests before narrow national ones at the Nice summit, the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said yesterday in an effort to reassure worried candidate countries that enlargement is safely on track.
fields.body:
EU leaders must put Europe-wide interests before narrow national ones at the Nice summit, the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said yesterday in an effort to reassure worried candidate countries that enlargement is safely on track.

Visiting Warsaw hours before flying to the French Riviera, Mr Schröder told Polish leaders: "We should carry out our historic duty, the idea of constructing one Europe."

The Polish prime minister, Jerzy Buzek, will meet Mr Schröder again in Nice today, when all 15 EU leaders join their colleagues from the 13 candidate countries to underline their commitment to the union's biggest expansion.

"I will tell my colleagues in Nice: Let's be brave. Let national interests remain in second place and European interests be the priority," Mr Schröder said

But no one, current or aspiring members, is expecting miracles from the summit, which has to solve a series of tough and interlocking institutional problems if the EU is to be able to almost double its size in the coming years.

Without changes to the rules for taking decisions by majority votes, the voting weight given to individual members states, and the size of the European commission, the machinery designed for the six founder members in 1957 will seize up.

France, ending its rocky six-month presidency, has resisted repeated demands to set a firm date for the first entries, sticking to the long-standing formula that the union will be ready to accept newcomers "from January 2003".

But candidates complain of "waiting fatigue" and shifting goalposts, even as they meet the rigorous political, legal and economic conditions required for joining.

"It often seems," the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, joked bitterly recently, "that we have been five years away from joining since 1990."

Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus began negotiating their entry two years ago.

Earlier this year they were joined by a second wave comprising Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Malta, Lithuania and Latvia.

Turkey, the 13th hopeful, is in a category of its own and has not yet begun talks, because of complications with human rights, the Kurds and disputes over Cyprus and with Greece in the Aegean.

The candidates are counting on the EU's leaders to seal the reforms at the three-day summit.

"We see this as a historic turning point in the process of enlargement," President Vaira Vike-Freiberga of Latvia said during a visit to Brussels.

Poland's president, Alexsander Kwasniewski, said this week that Warsaw could be ready by the end of next year, while the Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, said Prague could end talks early in 2002.

No new date is now expected until Sweden, like Britain a keen champion of enlargement, takes over the EU presidency in January.

Only then will it begin to become clear whether the EU should admit a few countries quickly or wait to admit 10 countries. Romania and Bulgaria are considered unlikely to be ready to join for a long time. Turkey is completely off the screen.

Public opinion in member countries remains to be convinced about the benefits of the EU's expanding beyond the former Iron Curtain, and candidate country leaders fear that delayed entry could turn their people against the idea.

The slogan "Moscow yesterday, Brussels today" has already been heard in Poland as farmers press for subsidies which the existing member states are unwilling to pay.

"If we are condemned to wait and if the horizon changes all the time, you can not exclude the rise of Euroscepticism," Mr Zeman said this week.

There will be many fine words in Nice about reuniting Europe, but there is no disguising the fear that the summit will not bring good news for the candidates.

webTitle: London blames Paris for Nato warning

fields.headline: London blames Paris for Nato warning
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: British and Nato officials blamed France yesterday for provoking the stark warning by the US defence secretary, William Cohen, that the EU's plans for stronger military cooperation could cause Nato to become a "relic".
fields.body:
British and Nato officials blamed France yesterday for provoking the stark warning by the US defence secretary, William Cohen, that the EU's plans for stronger military cooperation could cause Nato to become a "relic".

Stung by Mr Cohen's outburst at a meeting of Nato defence ministers in Brussels on Tuesday, senior British diplomats and officers pointed the finger a hard core of anti-US sentiment in France.

But clearly annoyed by Mr Cohen's warning of a developing "EU caucus" in Nato, British officials - already besieged by Tory Euroscepticism at home - described his intervention as "valedictory remarks, a last shot". One said he was talking as though it was "apocalypse now".

Mr Cohen, they insisted, was primarily "talking to the French" - and specifically to what one called 5% of French opinion.

"That 5% has to be suppressed," the official said. He did not identify where this hard core was located, though the foreign ministry and some advisers to President Jacques Chirac have adopted a much tougher line than the French defence ministry.

That sentiment was shown earlier this week in a proposal to enshrine EU military cooperation in a treaty which would let some member states act on their own without the unanimous agreement of the rest. The proposal, which angered Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has been ditched.

In an attempt to limit the damage, the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, maintained that Mr Cohen had made clear "his fundamental support for the European defence initiative".

Mr Hoon added: "We will not sign up for anything that in any way jeopardises Nato."

British officials pointed out yesterday that the EU had unanimously agreed in a document for today's Nice summit that EU peacekeeping tasks would be based on the "sovereign decisions" of member states.

British service chiefs drove home the point yesterday, say ing there would be no separate European command structure.

They no longer describe the proposed body of up to 60,000 troops to carry out joint peacekeeping and humanitarian operations as a "rapid reaction force", let alone a "standing European army", but talk of "a pool of national forces".

Nato officials say that French obstruction is blocking a key agreement on how the EU and Nato would cooperate on military matters.

"How will Nato speak to the EU?" a Nato source said. "We need permanent arrangements to lock Nato in."

Britain and France are acting from very different motives. An influential body of French opinion wants an autonomous EU military role, as distant from Nato as possible. To Britain, military affairs is one area of EU activity in which it has the capacity to lead.

A further consideration was expressed by a senior UK military commander. "The Americans are going to do less, and if Europe does not do more, [they] are going to do much less. Can we blame them?"

British service chiefs drove home the point yesterday, say ing there would be no separate European command structure. They no longer describe the proposed body of up to 60,000 troops to carry out joint peacekeeping and humanitarian operations as a "rapid reaction force", let alone a "standing European army", but talk of "a pool of national forces". Nato officials say that French obstruction is blocking a key agreement on how the EU and Nato would cooperate on military matters. "How will Nato speak to the EU?" a Nato source said. "We need permanent arrangements to lock Nato in." Britain and France are acting from very different motives. An influential body of French opinion wants an autonomous EU military role, as distant from Nato as possible. To Britain, military affairs is one area of EU activity in which it has the capacity to lead. A further consideration was expressed by a senior UK military commander. "The Americans are going to do less, and if Europe does not do more, [they] are going to do much less. Can we blame them?"

webTitle: Hungarians cherish their vines before Brussels lets in foreigners

fields.headline: Hungarians cherish their vines before Brussels lets in foreigners
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: A freezing wind blows up from Lake Ferto, unchecked by the young vines on the slopes above. A long hot summer has given way to a grey autumn. Snow whitens the Austrian alps, on the western horizon.
fields.body:
A freezing wind blows up from Lake Ferto, unchecked by the young vines on the slopes above. A long hot summer has given way to a grey autumn. Snow whitens the Austrian alps, on the western horizon.

Kurt Taschner is proud of his latest plantation. The stems of the vines are spindly and red against the dark soil. Here and there a bunch of grapes dangles, left unnoticed by pickers during the harvest.

Mr Taschner is happy. This will be a good year for Hungarian red wines - at least in those places where the soil was rich enough to protect the vine roots from drought.

Here, as in most of Hungary's 22 wine regions, the race is on to plant new vineyards, rescue old ones and improve technology before joining the European Union.

EU regulations allow member countries to replace old vines but not to establish new vineyards. With Hungary perhaps only three years away from membership, farmers are trying to take advantage of their last seasons of freedom.

The approach to membership has already benefited them. As many as 135,000 people own vineyards, but only 350 are classed as big producers. Kurt Taschner, who owns 11.5 hectares (28 acres), sells most of his wine by the barrel - either at home or in Slovakia and the Czech Republic.

Under an agreement signed last week, Hungary will be able to export 41.5m litres (9m gallons) of wine to the EU each year, duty free - about an eighth of what it produces. A similar amount is sold to non-EU countries.

"We are both hopeful and fearful of the EU," Mr Taschner said, leaning against a barrel in his cellar, which is set into the rocks on the outskirts of Sopron.

"Hopeful because of the market it will open up, fearful because foreigners may buy our vineyards, and cheap foreign wines flood our market."

State-owned vineyards have been privatised at the same time as production techniques have been revolutionised. Vineyard owners like Mr Taschner are selling less wine to big companies, and bottling more under their own label.

In north-east Hungary, Vilmos Thummerer is one of the most famous producers of Bull's Blood - a wine named after the Hungarian tactic of staining beards red to frighten the Turks besieging the town of Eger in the 16th century.

"In several recent years Eger accounted for more than half of all new vineyard acreage in Hungary," Mr Thummerer said recently. "If we go on planting like this, we will have fewer problems with quality, and even fewer with quantity, when and if we join the EU."

A serious problem for Hungary is that old vineyards are being abandoned, almost as swiftly as new ones can be planted. Only the older villagers were interested in working the vineyards claimed back from the state in the 1990s; their children have opted for a less arduous life in the cities. And there is little money to invest in technology.

That has opened the doors of many of Hungary's 12,000 wine-selling cellars to foreigners. Still prevented from owning land, foreign citizens now own about 40% of HUngary's wine production, according to one official. With EU membership, they will soon be able to buy the land as well.

webTitle: ANC loses key city as voters shun poll

fields.headline: ANC loses key city as voters shun poll
fields.trailText: The African National Congress has been stung by a significant drop in support, which cost it control of one of South Africa's most important cities in yesterday's municipal elections.
fields.body:
The African National Congress has been stung by a significant drop in support, which cost it control of one of South Africa's most important cities in yesterday's municipal elections.

Backing for the main opposition party surged in some parts of the country.

The ANC took four of the six new "megacities", which bring the old white cities and their surrounding black townships into single administrations. But it lost Cape Town, after failing in a vigorous attempt to win over the mixed-race or "coloured" vote.

It was also unable to secure an outright majority in Durban, despite a collapse in support for Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom party.

With most of the votes counted, the ANC had taken about 60% of the popular vote, down 7% on last year's national elections.

The drop in support was significantly more marked in cities such as Johannesburg.

The main beneficiary was the Democratic Alliance, which increased by more than 6% the combined totals of the Democratic and National parties, which merged to form the alliance earlier this year.

"These elections signal a very significant victory for the DA, in particular in some of the metropolitan areas where it increased the percentage of its vote by as much as 20%," David Pottie of the Electoral Institute in Johannesburg said.

"They will certainly hail this as a vindication of their campaign effort as well as maintaining the momentum of building an effective opposition. They've been very tenacious in building themselves up in the minds of voters as the official opposition, even though that concept does not really exist in a proportional representation system."

The alliance's rise is all the more significant given that, as the former Democratic party, it picked up just 2% of the vote in South Africa's first free elections in 1994.

Now it commands more than a quarter of the ballot.

In part this is because in absorbing the old National party, which gave South Africa the nightmare of full-blown apartheid, it acquired many Afrikaner and "coloured" votes.

But although it is technically a joint venture, no one is in any doubt that the Democratic party element of the coalition is dominant and driving the surge in support.

The alliance has also built on the collapse of support for the Inkatha Freedom party in its former stronghold KwaZulu-Natal, where it lost about a quarter of its vote compared with last year's ballot.

The alliance took the bulk of Inkatha's loss, the rest going to the ANC.

But while the elections entrench the alliance as the real opposition to President Thabo Mbeki's government, the party has little prospect of gaining power nationally without a big increase in support from black people.

Because the breakdown of the vote will not be available until today, it is not immediately clear whether the alliance picked up many black votes from the ANC - which would prepare the ground for it to become a broad church rather than the voice of disaffected minorities - or the fall in ANC support reflected a failure to vote rather than a shift in the voting pattern.

Fewer than half the potential voters bothered to cast their ballot. The ANC attributed that to apathy, but Mr Pottie is sceptical.

"I think that they should be worried by voter turnout," he said.

"What is so worrying is that so much effort has been put into trumpeting the allure of strong local government that it is possible to connect the low voter turnout to dissatisfaction with the way things are being run."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Italy convicts Argentines
fields.body:
Italy convicts Argentines

A Rome judge yesterday found two Argentine generals guilty of kidnapping and murdering eight Italians during Argentina's 1976-83 military regime and sentenced them in absentia to life imprisonment.

Five other Argentine officers were each sentenced in absentia to 24 years in jail.

Reuters, Rome

Tajiks urged to take refugees

The UN High Commissioner for Refugees urged Tajikistan yesterday to admit up to 10,000 Afghans stranded on the border between the two countries. The UNHCR office said the refugees, who are fleeing fighting in north-east Afghanistan, were marooned on islands and peninsulas in the Pyandj river, which marks the border.

AP, Geneva

Norway reveals jets' Kursk role

Norway sent fighter jets in August to intercept Russian planes apparently scouring the Barents sea for a foreign submarine suspected of sinking the nuclear submarine Kursk.

Oslo reiterated that it had no evidence that any foreign submarine, including the USS Memphis, which docked in Norway about a week after the sinking, might have collided with the Kursk. Reuters, Oslo

Dinosaur 'bird' found in China

Chinese researchers have unearthed possibly the smallest fossil of an adult dinosaur. The 125m-year-old crow-sized creature appears to have had feathers and to have perched in trees. The researchers hope it may ultimately prove the theory that flight evolved in tree dwellers rather than in ground-bound animals.

AP, Massachusetts

Countries agree Congo pullback

Defence chiefs from six African countries, together with rebel groups, agreed in Harare yesterday to begin withdrawing troops from their opposing frontline positions in the Democratic Republic of Congo later this month.

Reuters, Harare

Bride dies on walk up aisle

A New Zealand bride who collapsed and died as she walked up the aisle was buried yesterday. Laney Whitchelo, 23, died moments before she was due to marry Stephen Bull in Hawke's Bay, on New Zealand's north island.

Patrick Barkham, Sydney

fields.headline: California faces power struggle
fields.trailText: The lights are going out all over California. Well not yet, but they soon could because power is close to running out.
fields.body:
The lights are going out all over California. Well not yet, but they soon could because power is close to running out.

While the hardship involved in the newly declared emergency simply requiring people not to turn on the Christmas lights, and to lower their thermostats, any power emergency in resource-rich California is a significant comment on the extent of US energy overuse.

A "stage two emergency" has been declared, meaning that California is within 5% of running out of power and electricity companies can cut supplies to consumers. The next stage will be rotating blackouts. The normally gung ho power suppliers are worried and admit that they are "riding the edge".

The governor, Gray Davis, set the tone when he turned on the Christmas lights in the state capital, Sacramento, but then switched them off five minutes later. "In some parts of California, people are going without power," he said, blaming thecrisis partly on the recent Republican deregulation of supplies.

Such shortages highlight the complex energy issue in the US. While demand is high, some power plants stand idle, to stay within air-pollution limits. There is also a lack of cleaner natural gas after a cut in drilling, and, in the north-west,even less power to import, due to bad weather.

webTitle: Virgin Rail tests new trains in Belgium

fields.headline: Virgin Rail tests new trains in Belgium
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail yesterday embarked on a £1bn plan to introduce 78 new trains in the UK over the next two years.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail yesterday embarked on a £1bn plan to introduce 78 new trains in the UK over the next two years.

The first train, Maiden Voyager, passed its first test on a trial 15-mile run with Sir Richard on board, above, between Bruges and Ostend in Belgium without incident. It reached a top speed of 90 miles per hour but can travel at up to 125mph.

The new trains, which will operate between 130 towns and cities from Penzance to Aberdeen, will provide quality travel. Audio entertainment, with the choice of 10 different channels will be on offer at every seat, and an on-board shop will replace the old style buffet car.

Passengers will be offered a new electronic seat reservation system to allow last minute bookings.

If the high-risk plan succeeds, Virgin will double the capacity on Britain's regional network within five years, serving 30m passengers a year.

If it fails, Virgin will have to increase its fares and ask the government for more subsidies to bail it out.

Under the terms of its current franchise with the government, which expires in 2012, it should be returning up to £200m a year to the Treasury from its profits in the last three years of the franchise. Sir Richard said that the new fleet presented a formidable challenge, but added "we are confident we can pull it off".

The venture, launched by Virgin Rail's joint shareholders, Stagecoach and Virgin, is divided between a capital cost of £390m for the new trains and a £670m maintenance contract until 2012.

The trains are owned by a leasing company and Lombard, a subsidiary of NatWest. Virgin is responsible for the high maintenance cost which will come out of its fares and profits.

Sir Richard said that the first trains on a new route between Birmingham, Swindon and Paddington would start service next May with the rest of the fleet in place by the end of 2002. All existing rolling stock, some of it dating back 35 years, will be scrapped.

webTitle: Democrats urge court to exclude absentee votes

fields.headline: Democrats urge court to exclude absentee votes
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In a tense Florida courthouse yesterday, a circuit judge heard claims of Republican irregularities in the handling of the absentee vote system which could, if accepted, overturn George W Bush's provisional victory and hand the presidency to Al Gore.
fields.body:
In a tense Florida courthouse yesterday, a circuit judge heard claims of Republican irregularities in the handling of the absentee vote system which could, if accepted, overturn George W Bush's provisional victory and hand the presidency to Al Gore.

Judge Nikki Clark, a Democrat, turned down Republican attempts to have the case dismissed and to force her to withdraw on the grounds of a conflict of interest. She called for an accelerated one-day trial. A judgement is expected by this morning.

The case, brought by individual Democrats in Florida's Seminole county, called for up to 15,000 absentee ballots to be declared invalid because the county election supervisor, a Republican, allowed a Republican party worker to fill in incomplete ballot application forms, an infraction of a 1998 state election law. Democrats say that they were not offered the same opportunity.

As it is impossible to trace actual ballots to application forms, the Democrats want all absentee ballots in the Republican-majority county to be invalidated, or for a formula based on known voting patterns to be used to exclude a fraction of them. Either way, a favourable ruling by Judge Clark would overturn Mr Bush's 537-vote lead in Florida.

In the same courthouse, a parallel case got under way concerning Martin county, another Republican stronghold, in which Democrats claim that Republican activists removed absentee ballot applications from government buildings to fill in voter identification numbers. Lawyers there want up to 10,000 ballots excluded.

In both cases, Republican lawyers argued yesterday that the addition of electoral identification numbers on applica tion forms was a "hyper-technicality" and did not pervert or influence the intent of voters. Rejecting thousands of votes would be mass disenfranchisement, said Terry Young, a lawyer for the Seminole election supervisor, Sandra Goard.

Any decision in either case will almost certainly be taken on appeal by the losing side to the Florida supreme court, whose seven judges are already considering a formal challenge by the Gore camp to the Florida election result.

Mr Gore's lawyers formally presented written arguments to the court yesterday, challenging a lower court decision to deny the vice-president's call for a hand recount of disputed ballots. They argued that the judge in that case failed to examine the most important evidence - 10,000 ballots in Miami on which vote-counting machines failed to detect any vote in the presidential election.

fields.headline: Brown used to be red
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor is happy to display his firebrand socialist roots - but only when it suits him
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Without hesitating, Gordon Brown refused. Twice. We should have realised that it was an unlikely scenario: the City-friendly chancellor addressing a group of socialists about his plans to nationalise everything.
fields.body:
Without hesitating, Gordon Brown refused. Twice. We should have realised that it was an unlikely scenario: the City-friendly chancellor addressing a group of socialists about his plans to nationalise everything.

But with fake naivety, this was more or less what we had in mind when we asked him to attend our conference last week at Aberdeen, marking the 25th anniversary of his own classic text, the Red Paper on Scotland.

The jubilee is well worth commemorating, even if many in the Labour party share Mr Brown's own advanced amnesia about a book that argued forcefully for "economic democracy" and "workers' power".

It is a startling fact, however, that the new generation of Scottish Labour MPs and MSPs have not so much forgotten about the Red Paper but have reached political maturity without ever having heard of it.

Intended to disturb the torpid Scottish Labour movement of the 1970s, the Red Paper was a daring political tract, not least for putting devolution squarely on the socialist agenda and thereby upsetting the die-hard unionism of old Labour.

The young Scots politician Robin Cook's contribution to the Red Paper was a passionate commentary on the Victorian-style privation that characterised Glasgow's housing stock well into the 1970s. Drawing from Marx and Engels, he contrasted the squalor of an earlier period with the "heroic building achievements of our local authorities".

Twenty-five years later, one wonders what withering turn of phrase Mr Cook circa 1975 would have used to describe the Labour party's current plans to transfer Glasgow's council housing out of the public sector.

Mr Brown's own vision was of a dramatic redistribution of power away from centralised government and corporate capital. This was, he said, "an urgently felt moral imperative" that was "not merely state control or more or less equality". Rather it was an explicit rejection of then Labour premier Harold Wilson's statist bias in favour of devolved decision-making, local public ownership and "free universal welfare services controlled by the people who use them".

The 24-year-old Brown's introduction to the book could not be mistaken for a stylish essay. In true dialectical fashion, his 10,000 words of artless prose invoke the struggle aspect of class struggle. The basic theme of the book is that the "private control of industry has become a hindrance to the further unfolding of the social forces of production". With "economic democracy" as the key objective, young Mr Brown goes on to lament "the failure of taxation to erode the power of private property".

Mr Brown's latest fury at the alleged corporate collusion with fuel protesters may have a historical antecedent in the Red Paper, where he identifies oil multinationals as "standing in the forefront of the fight against socialism in Britain". The solution? The "nationalisation of the offshore oil and gas industry... banks, insurance companies and pension funds... could be enacted without compensation".

Today, when the occasion demands, Mr Brown does still make great play of his Labourist and even socialist credentials, in deliberate contrast to Tony Blair. In many ways he owes his political standing - uniquely among the New Labour standard bearers - to his image as the keeper of the flame for the party faithful.

From the Red Paper, to his PhD thesis on the Labour party in the 1920s, to his biography of Glasgow socialist icon Jimmy Maxton, Mr Brown built a strong reputation within the Scottish Labour movement as someone in tune with its radical traditions.

For many of the Red Paper contributors who remained on socialist territory, Mr Brown is considered to have fulfilled his aspirations only by forsaking his politics. He has gained a reputation as a skillful politician, whose prime ministerial ambition has often been hidden behind a subterfuge of high-brow intellectualism. Nevertheless Mr Brown's apologists continue to claim that his socialist conscience remains sensitive. As evidence they cite his Fabian pamphlet Fair Is Efficient - which appeared as late as 1994.

Then there are various policies offered as supply-side socialism: the minimum wage, the New Deal and taxation of pension contributions. His oratory is also replete with the lexicon of fairness and social justice which was used to powerful effect at former Scottish first minister Donald Dewar's recent funeral. Mr Brown was perhaps publicly airing the late first minister's core values in the hope that this might jog a memory of his own ideological past.

fields.bodyText: Without hesitating, Gordon Brown refused. Twice. We should have realised that it was an unlikely scenario: the City-friendly chancellor addressing a group of socialists about his plans to nationalise everything. But with fake naivety, this was more or less what we had in mind when we asked him to attend our conference last week at Aberdeen, marking the 25th anniversary of his own classic text, the Red Paper on Scotland. The jubilee is well worth commemorating, even if many in the Labour party share Mr Brown's own advanced amnesia about a book that argued forcefully for "economic democracy" and "workers' power". It is a startling fact, however, that the new generation of Scottish Labour MPs and MSPs have not so much forgotten about the Red Paper but have reached political maturity without ever having heard of it. Intended to disturb the torpid Scottish Labour movement of the 1970s, the Red Paper was a daring political tract, not least for putting devolution squarely on the socialist agenda and thereby upsetting the die-hard unionism of old Labour. The young Scots politician Robin Cook's contribution to the Red Paper was a passionate commentary on the Victorian-style privation that characterised Glasgow's housing stock well into the 1970s. Drawing from Marx and Engels, he contrasted the squalor of an earlier period with the "heroic building achievements of our local authorities". Twenty-five years later, one wonders what withering turn of phrase Mr Cook circa 1975 would have used to describe the Labour party's current plans to transfer Glasgow's council housing out of the public sector. Mr Brown's own vision was of a dramatic redistribution of power away from centralised government and corporate capital. This was, he said, "an urgently felt moral imperative" that was "not merely state control or more or less equality". Rather it was an explicit rejection of then Labour premier Harold Wilson's statist bias in favour of devolved decision-making, local public ownership and "free universal welfare services controlled by the people who use them". The 24-year-old Brown's introduction to the book could not be mistaken for a stylish essay. In true dialectical fashion, his 10,000 words of artless prose invoke the struggle aspect of class struggle. The basic theme of the book is that the "private control of industry has become a hindrance to the further unfolding of the social forces of production". With "economic democracy" as the key objective, young Mr Brown goes on to lament "the failure of taxation to erode the power of private property". Mr Brown's latest fury at the alleged corporate collusion with fuel protesters may have a historical antecedent in the Red Paper, where he identifies oil multinationals as "standing in the forefront of the fight against socialism in Britain". The solution? The "nationalisation of the offshore oil and gas industry... banks, insurance companies and pension funds... could be enacted without compensation". Today, when the occasion demands, Mr Brown does still make great play of his Labourist and even socialist credentials, in deliberate contrast to Tony Blair. In many ways he owes his political standing - uniquely among the New Labour standard bearers - to his image as the keeper of the flame for the party faithful. From the Red Paper, to his PhD thesis on the Labour party in the 1920s, to his biography of Glasgow socialist icon Jimmy Maxton, Mr Brown built a strong reputation within the Scottish Labour movement as someone in tune with its radical traditions. For many of the Red Paper contributors who remained on socialist territory, Mr Brown is considered to have fulfilled his aspirations only by forsaking his politics. He has gained a reputation as a skillful politician, whose prime ministerial ambition has often been hidden behind a subterfuge of high-brow intellectualism. Nevertheless Mr Brown's apologists continue to claim that his socialist conscience remains sensitive. As evidence they cite his Fabian pamphlet Fair Is Efficient - which appeared as late as 1994. Then there are various policies offered as supply-side socialism: the minimum wage, the New Deal and taxation of pension contributions. His oratory is also replete with the lexicon of fairness and social justice which was used to powerful effect at former Scottish first minister Donald Dewar's recent funeral. Mr Brown was perhaps publicly airing the late first minister's core values in the hope that this might jog a memory of his own ideological past. For in the past 25 years, socialism has not so much lost the argument as been dropped from the question. It was a trend that also concerned Mr Brown in the Red Paper. fields.headline: Sainsbury's on Egyptian boycott list
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: All over the Middle East - in government and private offices, in universities and schools - the list that has sent shudders through western companies is passed around. It names US firms and products which Arabs and Muslims are urged to boycott in protest at American support for Israel.
fields.body:
All over the Middle East - in government and private offices, in universities and schools - the list that has sent shudders through western companies is passed around. It names US firms and products which Arabs and Muslims are urged to boycott in protest at American support for Israel.

Sales of Coca-Cola in the United Arab Emirates are reported to have fallen by 20% since the boycott began.

In Egypt, sales in US fast food chains have dropped by 35% and Procter & Gamble, the maker of Ariel washing powder (which has the misfortune to share its name with the Likud leader, Ariel Sharon), has suffered a fall in sales of more than 20%.

In Saudi Arabia, McDonald's appears to have won a respite by donating 18p from every meal bought to Palestinian hospitals.

But in Egypt there is an odd victim on the boycott list: the British supermarket giant Sainsbury's - which is neither American nor a supporter of Israel.

The first Sainsbury's opened in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, only three years ago and the company now has almost 100 branches employing more than 2,500 people. When its first store opened in the Pyramids Road, small shopkeepers became alarmed, fearing that its price-cutting on basic commodities such as sugar, milk, cooking oil and wheat would drive them out of business.

To the average Egyptian, earning £40-£70 a month, Sainsbury's was a boon. The Pyramids Road branch was busy almost round the clock and people queued to get in.

Other shopowners quickly realised that the best way to slow down its expansion was to spread the rumour that the Sainsbury family was of Jewish origin and donated money to Israel - which Sainsbury's vehemently denies.

Long before the current violence between Israel and the Palestinians began, mosque preachers and pro-Islamist newspapers denounced the company, claiming that its low prices were part of a plan to gain a monopoly of the Egyptian market.

When the violence started, there were at least three incidents in which school students, protesting at Israel's treatment of the Palestinians, stoned Sainsbury branches.

Now, Sainsbury's says it may pull out of Egypt altogether, though no final decision has been announced. A spokeswoman said yesterday that its Egyptian arm generated sales of £40.5m and an operating loss of £10.2m in the first half of this year.

"Losses were higher than expected as a result of delayed store openings due to local licensing difficulties and, more recently, through a deterioration of the trading environment in the Middle East," the spokeswoman said.

Since 1979 - when Egypt became the first Arab country to sign a peace agreement with Israel - opponents of the deal, mainly leftwingers and political Islamic groups, have been leading a campaign to boycott Israeli products and institutions. Since the clashes with the Palestinians broke out more than nine weeks ago, the boycott campaign has become stronger than ever.

Even the state-run television has recently allowed opposition figures to call openly for boycotts of US and Israeli products, disregarding the fact that Egypt has been a key ally of Washington in the region since the late 1970s.

The latest influential figure to join the boycott call was the Mufti of Egypt, Sheikh Nasser Farid Wassel, the country's highest Islamic religious authority. He was quoted by local newspapers as saying that buying US and Israeli products at this stage was haram (forbidden) because of the killing of Palestinians.

Meanwhile, warnings by local businessmen that thousands of Egyptians would lose their jobs if companies like Sainsbury's closed have fallen on deaf ears.

Mustafa Bakri, the editor of a local opposition weekly and an Arab nationalist, said: "These warnings should not scare us or discourage us from continuing our campaign. Many businessmen support us, and if a few hundred workers were fired, they should be able to offer them jobs."

webTitle: BA to shed 1,000 jobs at Gatwick

fields.headline: BA to shed 1,000 jobs at Gatwick
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Airways, Europe's least profitable big airline, said yesterday it will cut 1,000 jobs at Gatwick and withdraw flights from there to at least 18 long-haul destinations.
fields.body:
British Airways, Europe's least profitable big airline, said yesterday it will cut 1,000 jobs at Gatwick and withdraw flights from there to at least 18 long-haul destinations.

The move marks BA's abandonment of London's second airport as an alternative operational hub to Heathrow and will mean a 40% drop in capacity on BA flights from Gatwick in two years.

Around 1,000 employees, including pilots, cabin crew and ground staff, are expected to lose their jobs in the restructuring, with another 800 being transferred - along with about 10 of the routes - to Heathrow.

Rod Eddington, the chief executive, said the cuts would make the airline profitable within two to three years, and would "ensure BA has a long-term viable future as Gatwick's leading airline".

The carrier lost £310m on long-haul flights last year, much of it from Gatwick operations.

Mr Eddington said it made no sense to maintain Gatwick as a European hub because it was too close to Heathrow.

"Gatwick is a key airport in our home market, and our activities there must operate on a sound financial footing. Despite the very best efforts of our team there, this has not previously been possible to achieve."

BA is to reduce the number of long-haul routes operating from Gatwick from 43 to 25. The reduction will mean cutting six routes and transferring more than 10 to Heathrow by 2003. Flights to Miami, Rio and Sao Paulo will be among the first to move next summer.

A BA spokeswoman said the Gatwick operation would concentrate on short-haul business and on customers within its natural catchment area in South-east England. However, short-haul capacity would also be cut by 10%.

BA plans to reduce its overall capacity by 20% by 2003.

A spokesman for the Air Transport Users Council said: "It would be a pity if some of those routes were lost for good. We would hope that other airlines would take them up. The demand is there."

BAA, which owns Gatwick, said the restructuring was unlikely have a significant effect because many other carriers - including Virgin, easyJet, US Airways and Delta - had announced plans to expand. Jobs at Gatwick were expected to rise by 6,000 to 34,000 within eight years.

T&GWU, the union that represents more than 20,000 staff at Gatwick, was surprisingly upbeat.

"We are pleased that BA have committed themselves to a long-term future of Gatwick," said George Ryde, national secretary for civil air transport. "Above all we are confident that there will be no compulsory redundancies."

Many T&GWU members had been alarmed by reports that BA would abandon its Gatwick operation entirely.

BA shares closed up just 3.8% at 407p. Analysts described the Gatwick shake-up as a positive move but said it had been largely anticipated.
