fields.headline: Freeze frame
fields.standfirst: When a painter is inspired by a movie, something ephemeral can become monumental.  Jonathan Jones is thrilled by Mario Rossi's latest exhibition
fields.trailText: When a painter is inspired by a movie, something ephemeral can become monumental. Jonathan Jones is thrilled by Mario Rossi's latest exhibition.
fields.body:
On a visit to London after the second world war, the "hardbitten" movie star Edward G Robinson - in reality a sensitive art lover with a substantial collection of paintings - saw a picture of himself in an art dealer's shop. It was a menacing image, focusing on the luridly lit, sepia-toned faces of Robinson and co-star Joan Blondell in the 1936 film Bullets or Ballots, in which he played a goodie for a change.

But the painting by Walter Sickert, famous for his dark impressions of women in lonely London rooms, makes Robinson look evil, his narrow-eyed face monstrously dominating the canvas. Robinson bought it at once; you can now see it in the National Portrait Gallery's Painting the Century show.

Cinema holds a fatal attraction for painting. In the 20th century Hollywood created a new mythology, a new Olympus of gods and goddesses, and a new hell. Painters found the mythic narratives they had once taken from classical legends and the Bible remade, larger than life, in the dream world of cinema. At the same time Hollywood was the enemy, the Babylon of cheap popular entertainment - the kingdom of kitsch, according to critic Clement Greenberg, champion of high abstract art in the 1940s.

Painting and cinema are still handcuffed together on a one-way ticket to the morgue. When artists appropriate images from film they always seem to be drawn to the melancholy underside of the tinsel factory. This week painter Mario Rossi's fascinating series of 100 pictures, The End/Untitled, goes on show at the windswept, modernist 1930s De La Warr Pavilion in Bexhill-on-Sea.

They depict the moment the words "The End" appear in 100 films. To see so many ends is hypnotically sad. Here are the two words written - in black and red, in gothic letters, in straight capitals - across terminal scenes you may or may not recognise: the car being pulled out of the swamp in Psycho; the assassins standing with their guns in The Killers; a man dead at the centre of a hammer and sickle in Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment.

It doesn't matter whether or not you recognise the film. In each case there's a suggestive juxtaposition of word and image, inviting the viewer to complete the circle, to hypothesise a narrative. A plane flies over a landing strip; The End, say bold white letters superimposed over the screen. Two cigarettes smoulder in an ashtray; The End, say florid pink letters. An ocean liner sails against a spectacular sunset; The End, reads the ornately painted text.

When did films stop saying The End? Except for the odd self-consciously camp exception (Rossi thinks the most recent in his collection is from Strictly Ballroom) the practice seems to have disappeared. Today films conclude with an interminable list of credits, but once they concluded properly with those magic words that tie up a story and give the weight of finality to a death or an embrace.

Rossi's method is simply to use his video recorder to grab the final few moments of films, which he then paints in acrylics. He shows the paintings without labels, as a single large grid. The films in his collection are almost all classics, and part of the pleasure is recognising the last moments of some great movies: Cape Fear (the original), True Grit, The Big Sleep, Citizen Kane, The Wizard of Oz, The Rise and Fall of Louis XIV and, ahem, Ice Station Zebra and Live and Let Die.

Painting and cinema both create fictional spaces, but the space of painting is static. So when a moment in a film is snatched and turned into a painting, it becomes deathly: you might call it painting noir. Painting takes a living, moving image and slows it down, making a monument to that which otherwise flits before our eyes. The movement of cinema is, of course, illusory. Painting kills the movement, reveals the stillness of the separate frames that underlie cinema, reveals death in the heart of life. The End.

No wonder Edward G Robinson, who in the 1940s and 1950s appeared in such film noirs as Double Indemnity and The Woman in the Window, responded to the morbid, shadowy sensibility of Sickert's painting. It's a classic noir painting. So is another great cinema painting from the period, Edward Hopper's New York Movie (1939), set inside a 1930s cinema with palatial architecture.

We only catch a glimpse, at the far left, of the silver screen and the backs of the heads of moviegoers, sitting alone as if they have gone by themselves to a matinee on a wet afternoon. The painting has panned back, away from the screen, to focus on an usherette standing at the side of the theatre under a yellow electric light, in front of a red-curtained exit. She's lost in misery and boredom, hand on chin, with no interest in the movie, and we are invited to imagine her story, a New York movie, a tale of solitude and loneliness.

Hopper's sensibility influenced the look of film noir; his vision of solitary people in an all-night diner, Nighthawks, might be a storyboard painting for Robert Siodmak's The Killers, or Jacques Tourneur's Out of the Past. When Hitchcock filmed the darkness at the edge of town in Psycho he based the gothic Bates mansion partly on Hopper's House by the Railroad.

Mario Rossi's paintings are funny, charming but noirish too, because whether the characters are killers or lovers, their final destination is always The End. Even without those two words, the end of a film is an oddly destitute moment.

All that light, all that action, all that absorption in a fictional world is gone. The words - the great, static final scenes - in these paintings mark the passing of the film; the cinematic equivalent of a gravestone. They are a cemetery of cinema and have the same romantic appeal as an overgrown Victorian graveyard or those Hollywood tours that show you where the stars died horrid deaths.

The artist who used painting to make the deathliness of cinema explicit was Andy Warhol. Beginning with his portraits of Marilyn Monroe shortly after her death in 1962, Warhol froze the faces of screen icons and spectacular, cinematic moments from real life (a car crash with bodies thrown about, as in James Dean's death) in silkscreen paintings that dwell on mortality. Warhol took a film noir aesthetic and applied it, as Hopper did in Nighthawks, to everyday life. In Warhol's art The End is never far away. An electric chair waits to be used in a room with a sign that says Silence. A suicide throws herself out of a window.

These are the images of everyday life on which Warhol fixated, moments that don't need the words The End for us to recognise their terminal nature. In an extraordinary series of noirish photographic works he made in the 1970s, to be seen shortly in the exhibition I Am a Camera at the Saatchi Gallery, Warhol records a world in which all the people seem to have disappeared, as in some 1950s sci-fi film, leaving only traces of themselves everywhere.

In one picture a suitcase sits menacingly on a chair, perhaps containing the means of universal destruction, like the case the characters fight over in the film noir Kiss Me Deadly. In another monochrome shot, taken in a hairdressing salon and repeated melancholically four times, two overhead hairdryers hang above two empty chairs. To great emotional effect, one of the hairdryers is twisted round the face the other, as if the women had disappeared, dematerialised, in the middle of a gossipy chat. It makes you think of the casts of bodies at Pompeii.

Mario Rossi's paintings are more optimistic because they look back to a Hollywood where The End came with due pomp, at the right time. For Warhol it doesn't come with a sign that says The End.

Painting and making underground films at the end of the Hollywood studio era, Warhol captured the way The End interrupts the action just when you don't expect it, leaving everything in a mess, without finality, without a gravestone, without credits. Perhaps the reason cinema has abandoned those words The End is that we don't believe things are all tied up any more. But as Rossi's paintings ask, we can dream, can't we?

 Mario Rossi: The End/Untitled is at the De La Warr Pavilion, Bexhill-on-Sea (01424 787900), from Saturday to February 5. I Am a Camera is at the Saatchi Gallery, London NW8 (020-7624 8299), from January 18 to March 25.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Warkworth Beach, North Sea
fields.trailText: Warkworth Beach, North Sea
fields.body:
Spring tides and rough weather had cast up an undulating strand line of kelps, wracks, shells, carapaces and corpses below the sand dunes. Scores of pale grey "sea potatoes" (feather-light calcareous skeletons of burrowing sea urchins, fragile as egg shells) had come to rest on the piles of seaweed.

Then there were carapaces of masked crabs - another burrower that lurks below the low water mark, with just its nippers exposed, drawing a current of oxygenated water through a tube formed from its long, whiskery antennae. It doesn't take much imagination to see the image of a scowling human face formed by the undulations of the shell.

Just why there should be so many sea potato and masked crab casualties was something of a mystery, until a tug pulling a barge hove into view, slipping between the breakwaters into the River Coquet, where dredging cranes filled the barge with sand and mud. Mystery solved: they'd been dredged from the river mouth, dumped offshore and washed onto the beach.

But other strand line casualties had come from deeper water - exquisite little bottlebrush hydroids entangled in the seaweed, each the shape and size of a small spout brush. The tips of their branches, like minute glassy vases, are home to hydroids resembling microscopic sea anemones. Crouching to pick these up, I saw pink flesh under a heap of seaweed.

Two dead, curled octopuses, arms entangled in the wracks. Octopuses lay eggs under rocky overhangs until the late summer, guard them for nearly three months until the young hatch, and then die. These, presumably, had done just that.

fields.headline: The Speaker could do it
fields.standfirst: Join the debate online
fields.trailText: The two most important legacies we have given to the free world are parliamentary government and trial by jury. Both eroded the powers of the monarch and transferred power to the people. The wresting of political power from the monarch to parliament developed over a long period. It involved Magna Carta, civil war and the death of thousands of our ancestors in the process.
fields.body:
The two most important legacies we have given to the free world are parliamentary government and trial by jury. Both eroded the powers of the monarch and transferred power to the people. The wresting of political power from the monarch to parliament developed over a long period. It involved Magna Carta, civil war and the death of thousands of our ancestors in the process.

The Americans did not have to build parliamentary government brick by brick over hundreds of years as we did. As a result of one glorious revolution a small band of men drafted a Declaration of Independence which is still the most sublime and simple statement of the rights of ordinary people. And then came the constitution beginning with those magic words "We the people..."

With one document the links with the monarchy were severed and with it went all classes of privilege: the aristocracy and all those silly titles. The greatest honour was and remains to be called Mr, Mrs or Miss. This was more than 200 years ago when the modern egalitarian United States republic was born.

Somehow we got left behind. We were on the way but took a wrong turning. None of our rights is safe from a marauding government seeking to increase its grip over the institutions of the state. An American government would not be able to meddle with the citizen's right to trial by jury as Jack Straw proposes and the president of the United States cannot appoint his chums and financial supporters to the second chamber of parliament. They have to be elected by the ordinary people. That is what democracy is about.

I have never understood the merit of the leader of a nation getting the job because a parent had it. We would roundly condemn such a practice in industry or in any other walk of life. We believe in a meritocracy. You can get from a council house to the House of Commons or 10 Downing Street or the high court bench, but you can never become head of state. That is reserved for the house of Windsor.

That's how it is and from past precedent if we ran out of Windsors we would get out the family tree and trace some unknown German prince (whose title is not recognised in his fatherland) and import him to reign over us. We have done it before. His surname may need anglicising of course. And then there is the huge cost of it all.

It is easy to make cheap jokes about operating a medieval system in the 21st century but the usual argument against change is what could we put in its place? Can we imagine having Mrs Thatcher or Tony Benn as president? I suppose the short answer is that it is easier to get rid of an elected someone than an hereditary monarch as the French and Russian revolutions demonstrate. In fact the Speaker of the House of Commons is the obvious candidate.

It reminds us of the past - the struggles our forebears had to obtain for us the rights we now take for granted. We should preserve them but there is no reason why new traditions should not develop.

It was parliament which gave we ordinary people our chance. It was parliament who stood up to the king and wrestled power away to the representatives of the people.

At first the Speaker of the House of Commons was the representative of the crown but it all changed and he became the champion of the House of Commons.

And ever since it has been the Speaker, the holder of that office unique to our parliament, who controls the debates of the elected members, who has the power to discipline them and it is they who give their respect.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Work in progress

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Rob Minkoff, animator/director
fields.trailText: Rob Minkoff, animator/director
fields.body:
When you work in animation, everyone starts on the bottom rung. You don't even draw your own pictures, you just fill in the movements in between the drawings of more experienced animators. There's never any question of anyone in animation not having paid their dues. Personally, things really got under way for me when I eventually got to direct a couple of Roger Rabbit shorts and co-directed The Lion King.

There's been a definite learning curve. I honestly think that half- animated/half-live action movies like Stuart Little are the way forward: technology now achieves photorealism. The impossible is now possible, like much children's fiction.

Of course, some things you can't do in terms of theme - for instance, in EB White's book, Mrs Little (a human) gives birth to Stuart (a mouse). Now, I don't think either children or adults would believe or want to see that. And in the book Stuart has a girlfriend - a sparrow. And we just didn't have the time to open that can of worms first time round.

Right now, we're working on the sequel. This type of film is supposed to be a nightmare to make - full of children, animals and countless special effects - but it went like a dream first time round, so hopefully we're keeping the ball rolling. And animated characters demand relatively little time from the actors voicing them, so you can have quite a starry cast.

I got virtually all my first choices: Jeffrey Jones, Chazz Palminteri, Nathan Lane, Jennifer Tilly, Steve Zahn and, of course, Michael J Fox. I can't say enough nice things about that guy. We all know what he's been through, and he just gave so much to us. He kept coming in to give more dialogue and bits of stuff. We're hoping they're all coming back, and now that audiences know what to expect, Stuart might just get lucky and get his little girlfriend!

 Interview by Phelim O'Neill

 Rob Minkoff's Stuart Little is out now on video and DVD (Columbia TriStar)

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Kerr-Blatt! | Music Restored
fields.body:
David Stafford lends an affectionate ear to the work of the small group of 20th-century musicians who achieved a lasting influence on millions who will never know their names. Carl Stalling, Raymond Scott, Milt Franklyn, and Scott Bradley wrote the extraordinarily evocative background music for hundreds of animated cartoons. As the programme title, Kerr-Blatt! (11.30am, Radio 4) implies, they also invented the splendid gamut of orchestral effects without which the antics of Tom and Jerry and Bugs Bunny would never have seemed quite complete.

At the opposite end of the musical spectrum comes another of Lucie Skeaping's occasional excursions to Venice. In Music Restored (4.0pm, Radio 3) she visits places associated with the republic's 17th-century Master of Music, Claudio Monteverdi. Naturally, much of his work was written for St Mark's cathedral. But the programme also features the Gabrieli Consort performing one of his surviving secular operas.

fields.headline: Cherchez les femmes
fields.standfirst: You've never heard of Carole Tongue - and why should you care? Because her story tells us all we need to know about the missing women in British public life. By Yvonne Roberts
fields.trailText: You've never heard of Carole Tongue - and why should you care? Because her story tells us all we need to know about the missing women in British public life. By Yvonne Roberts.
fields.body:
Meet Carole Tongue. She is articulate, smart and appears accustomed to achieving what she sets out to do. But recently the tides of change haven't swept in her favour. She is a passionate European and a devoted Labourite, and public service, she says, "runs in her blood". But she finds herself adrift and she is not alone - a fact pointed up by a new report into women in public life.

Eighteen months ago, Tongue unexpectedly lost her seat as the Labour MEP for London East. Thus ended two decades of working for the European Union, first as an employee and then, for 15 years, as a politician. Now, as Nice gets under way and the talk is of vetos, Euro-armies and the EU as a British curse, Tongue, 45, paints a far more positive, feminised portrait of Europe. One in which, for instance, the loss of cultural identity is about as likely as a revival of the ducking stool for suspected witchcraft.

Tongue says she would enjoy a role "making Britain more European in outlook". She wishes the government would "proselytise and extol", and go more on the offensive. She points out that, however flawed, much of the legislation that has made an impact on women's lives in the UK originated in Strasbourg: sex discrimination, equal pay for work of equal value, pro rata rights for part-timers.

Focus groups conducted by the women's campaigning group the Fawcett Society reveal, however, that many women lack basic information about Europe. Labour may have female voices at Westminster happy to make the positive case - but when are they allowed to be heard?

Tongue, who speaks English, French and German fluently, was born in Lausanne; her parents divorced and her father married a Hungarian. Now, in her north London home, between frequent dives into her bag for yet more fags, she talks enthusiastically of the way in which the EU, for example, is trying to dismantle the class divide in culture. She speaks in short bursts, leaving long pauses - a habit presumably gained in Strasbourg, working to the rhythm of interpreters.

During her years as an MEP, she concentrated first on regeneration, helping to secure over £150m in European funding in east London over a two-year period. Then, in 1994, she was elected socialist group coordinator for the EC's culture, youth, education and media committee, becoming the European Parliament spokesperson on public service broadcasting. She continues to be one of its fiercest defenders.

She is involved now in a project called Cybercinema which, she says, is a striking example of what a Pan-European perspective can achieve. The aim is to create a network of digital cinema "spaces", reaching disadvantaged areas here and across Europe. Dubbed films will be offered each week, mostly European, with an opportunity for interactive links between audiences. World cinema, Tongue says, makes up only 1% of the UK market; American films swallow 75-90% of European distribution. Cybercinema will offer an alternative.

"If you don't give people the images that carry within them the clues to the identity of others," Tongue says, "how can we expect the citizens of tomorrow to feel an empathy with those in neighbouring countries? If you give children the audiovisual equivalent of a hamburger, then how can they appreciate diversity?"

Tongue patently does not share New Labour's delight in all things American. She was strongly critical of Murdoch's anti-European views when Blair was wooing the Sun and has always supported proportional representation - the system that ousted her from her seat.

Others say these streaks of independence were the reason she was placed fifth on the party list in the last European election - and joined the growing band of women undervalued by the party. In modernised, transparent Britain, the panel who made the selection was not required to make its reasoning known. "Such is life in politics," is Tongue's guarded comment.

Later, when Tongue was offered a second chance, she decided against returning to the EC. As a divorced parent, she says her daughter, aged seven, needs her at home more. She has co-founded a consultancy but would also like to move into public service - an ambition that brings her up against another hard place.

Last month, Public Service Week was held, designed to raise awareness, particularly among women and ethnic minorities, of the establishment's need for people to sit on quangos, such as NHS trusts, boards of museums and health and safety committees. Tongue is one of a number of women, black, brown and white, who have not found it easy to break into this world. She is a trustee of several organisations and an international speaker - but none of this adds up to the cv of the individual most favoured for a quango: a middle-aged man in a senior position in industry.

Ten years ago, the Hansard Society published Women on Top, an investigation into why women were invisible in the higher ranks. Next week comes an updated report. Over the decade, targets have been introduced and the post of public appointments commissioner was created to act as a watchdog but, overall, according to Dr Karen Ross of Coventry University, author of the new report, progress has been slow. The proportion of women public appointees stood at 23% in 1991 and 30% in 1995, but since then there has been an increase of only 3%. Exceptions exist. At the Department of Health, for instance, 44% of public appointees are women.

The 1990 report indicated that a major hurdle was attitudinal and Ross says the problem remains. The public appointments unit, which finds suitable candidates for significant appointments, has increased the number of searches it has made for women candidates by 75% over the past five years, yet the number of placements is static (105 in 1995, 104 in 1999-2000). Women are now at the top of the queue but still failing to find a seat on the bus.

"The rhetoric has improved but not the reality," Ross says. "The previous report believed that as half the professions were recruiting females, more and more would filter up to the top. Well, it's 10 years on and they haven't."

Tongue was only 28 when, in 1984, she stood for selection for London East. "Fired up by mother's part-time work experience," she said, "[I argued] that working people must unite across frontiers to achieve common goals of social justice, economic prosperity and a sustainable environment in a multinational economy." That's not so scary, is it? Unless Labour wants a resounding female non in the referendum, it's time the voices of Tongue and others like her were heard.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Freddie Mercury documentary

fields.headline: Mercury rising
fields.standfirst: It's nine years since Freddie Mercury died and his place in rock's hall of fame is still secure. But not because of the music, says Ben Marshall
fields.trailText: It's nine years since Freddie Mercury died and his place in rock's hall of fame is still secure. But not because of the music, says Ben Marshall.
fields.body:
Dead singers normally have to wait at least 10 years before TV producers see fit to bestow posthumous hagiographic honours upon them. Freddie Mercury: The Untold Story jumps the gun by a year, but then, as Mott The Hoople's Ian Hunter points out, Freddie was always a man in a hurry.

He was hurried off to England in 1964, when his native Zanzibar enjoyed another of its periodic and bloody revolutions. He hurried off to Ealing Art School when a co-worker at a packing plant told him he had women's hands. Fame took a little longer to come, but that had nothing to do with Freddie, and a lot to do with the British public, yet to develop a taste for Queen's kitschy juggernaut of soft metal and ersatz opera.

And when he was finally famous, he hurried, positively hurtled, around the world's gay bars in a long orgiastic one-night stand. Even in his later years, when his cruising and cottaging had matured into a series of relationships with male lovers, he was in each case epically unfaithful. His last lover, Jim Hutton, who's interviewed extensively in this documentary, describes Freddie and the gay scene as fickle, but fickle hardly covers it with Freddie. The clothes, parties, performances and, above all, the sex were all symptoms of an ego that was monstrously out of control.

Most pop stars have a relationship with themselves that is at best tinged with self-doubt and occasionally self-loathing. Freddie fell in love with himself at first sight and it was a passion, indeed the only passion, to which he'd always remain true. His self-love, best expressed in his explicitly masturbatory performances, never went unrequited.

That the world should have fallen for Freddie as hard as Freddie fell for himself is a little tougher to explain. Queen, despite the tearful tributes and sycophantic drivel they've been afforded since the death of their singer, were a truly terrible band, a farrago of inept clichés and mostly meaningless verbiage.

Their most famous song, Bohemian Rhapsody, managed to distil into a mere six minutes every pompous, moronic and vainglorious sin committed against pop in the mid 70s. Only Yes's Brain Salad Surgery achieved a similar feat, but that was a triple album and lasted well over two hours. Bohemian Rhapsody found a perfect home for itself in the back of Wayne and Garth's car in Wayne's World.

Their other work, though never quite matching the nauseating heights of that first big hit, could be both anodyne and offensive, Fat Bottomed Girls for instance, or the camp but oddly thuggish We Are The Champions. It took Freddie to front this pantomime and make it work. Like Elton John, the star he most closely resembled, Freddie took an act that was already grotesque and sent it so far over the top that it had to be huge just to be visible.

And visible it certainly was. With the aid of garish costumery and his permanently penile microphone stand, Freddie turned himself into the icon of über-naff, admirable in the same way that Jeff Koons's giant pornographic porcelain sculptures are admirable. You're simply staggered by the gall.

In July 1985 when Bob Geldof declared that Queen, following their performance at Live Aid, were the best band of the day, the world agreed, and Queen, who until then had failed to crack America, went stratospheric. Live Aid was watched by more than 1.4 billion people across 170 countries. Mercifully the country it was aimed at, starving Ethiopia, was short on TV sets, and even shorter on champions and fat-bottomed girls.

Now Freddie could indulge himself like never before. Mountains of cocaine were shovelled up his aquiline nose. Further mountains were carried about on trays strapped to the heads of dwarves at parties that would have had Caligula raising a disapproving eyebrow. Rent boys were consumed and dispensed with like so much chewing gum. Freddie's 39th birthday party, featuring trolls, ogres, thieves, ballerinas, transsexuals and, naturally, dwarves, was one of the largest and most expensive ever held in rock'n'roll.

According to Trip Khalaf, Queen's sound engineer and by far the most affable and frank of all the interviewees featured in The Untold Story, "It was wretched excess that I'll probably go to hell for."

By this time Freddie's HIV, ignored and not spoken about despite the deaths of two former lovers, had developed into full-blown Aids. His lover Jim Hutton decided to stick with him, but it was only now that they began to practise safe sex. Even then he hurried away from the reality, never referring directly to Aids again.

Before his death he was a skeletal shadow of his former self. The cropped muscular hero of Live Aid was now so thin and ill that when he filmed the video for Great Pretender he needed two layers of thermals beneath his Pierrot costume to give him the illusion of substance. Even then, beneath the hot studio lights, he was freezing.

But he remained a showman to the last. It's worth asking though, given the horror of his circumstances, why he should have chosen to do so. The answer might be that nothing, not even his looming demise, could stand between him and a performance. In the end Freddie's love for Freddie proved stronger than death.

The Untold Story plays out on Only The Good Die Young. Freddie was living, and indeed dying, proof that this is plainly not so.

 Freddie Mercury: The Untold Story, tomorrow, 10.40pm, BBC1

In July 1985 when Bob Geldof declared that Queen, following their performance at Live Aid, were the best band of the day, the world agreed, and Queen, who until then had failed to crack America, went stratospheric. Live Aid was watched by more than 1.4 billion people across 170 countries. Mercifully the country it was aimed at, starving Ethiopia, was short on TV sets, and even shorter on champions and fat-bottomed girls. Now Freddie could indulge himself like never before. Mountains of cocaine were shovelled up his aquiline nose. Further mountains were carried about on trays strapped to the heads of dwarves at parties that would have had Caligula raising a disapproving eyebrow. Rent boys were consumed and dispensed with like so much chewing gum. Freddie's 39th birthday party, featuring trolls, ogres, thieves, ballerinas, transsexuals and, naturally, dwarves, was one of the largest and most expensive ever held in rock'n'roll. According to Trip Khalaf, Queen's sound engineer and by far the most affable and frank of all the interviewees featured in The Untold Story, "It was wretched excess that I'll probably go to hell for." By this time Freddie's HIV, ignored and not spoken about despite the deaths of two former lovers, had developed into full-blown Aids. His lover Jim Hutton decided to stick with him, but it was only now that they began to practise safe sex. Even then he hurried away from the reality, never referring directly to Aids again. Before his death he was a skeletal shadow of his former self. The cropped muscular hero of Live Aid was now so thin and ill that when he filmed the video for Great Pretender he needed two layers of thermals beneath his Pierrot costume to give him the illusion of substance. Even then, beneath the hot studio lights, he was freezing. But he remained a showman to the last. It's worth asking though, given the horror of his circumstances, why he should have chosen to do so. The answer might be that nothing, not even his looming demise, could stand between him and a performance. In the end Freddie's love for Freddie proved stronger than death. The Untold Story plays out on Only The Good Die Young. Freddie was living, and indeed dying, proof that this is plainly not so.  Freddie Mercury: The Untold Story, tomorrow, 10.40pm, BBC1

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Bizarre love triangle
fields.trailText: Brookside | The Gambler
fields.body:
Brookside 's weak grip on reality slipped altogether last night in a double episode which gave us, among other things, British soap's first ever mother-daughter lesbian love triangle. The Channel 4 drama seems, these days, to have nothing left to do but break taboos - perhaps someone has a list of contentious situations which they are dutifully working their way through.

This is not to say that Brookside isn't great entertainment: last night's show was a scream. If John Waters was allowed to get his hands on British soap, the results would be something like this.

Lindsey was coping badly with the discovery that girlfriend Shelley had fallen in love with someone else - an older, married woman, but she wouldn't say whom. So Lindsey went home to confide in her mother, Jackie - coincidentally an older, married woman, who looked shifty and wet-eyed every time Lindsey screamed something like "When I find out who she's been seeing, I'm going to kill her."

For Lindsey - single mum, former club owner and drugs moll - the penny just didn't drop. But then there are few of us who would suspect our own parent of copping off with our first gay lover for a night of passion while the old man's away in hospital pumped full of tranquillisers.

It was only when Lindsay found Shelley actually straddling her mother on the carpet that her darkness was enlightened. Sadly this was not an onscreen love-tussle, but rather the aftermath of a top-notch bout of hair-pulling and name-calling between the guilty twosome ("Shut up! You're a spiteful perverted little bitch!" screamed Jackie, tugging at Shelley's salon-fresh locks.) Sadly the credits rolled before Lindsey could say "My girlfriend! My mother! My God!"

Just across the Close, things were taking a decidedly necrophiliac turn as Max Farnham, the man with no personality, had problems coming to terms with Susannah's death. Not so much problems, in fact, as complete denial; he had his ex-wife's remains delivered to the house, and snuggled round the coffin with the two children in queasy domestic bliss.

"She wants to be at home", he started saying to anyone who would listen, and, "She forgives you." Will Max start wearing Susannah's clothes and stabbing people in showers? Will Susannah somehow become involved in a Lindsey-Jackie- Shelley love quadrangle? In the funny old world of Brookside, being dead is the least of anyone's problems.

And before you accuse Channel 4 of throwing good money away, they did exactly that in The Gambler, the first of three programmes in which writer and gamester Jonathan Rendall works his way through £12,000 of the station's money. Rendall is an odd cove: he dresses like a permanent postgrad, looks like Marcus out of Eldorado, and has a dazzling repertoire of facial and verbal tics.

He has also won the Somerset Maugham Prize - but, as one of his bookies helpfully pointed out "That was for writing, not for gambling." Last night he flexed his gambling muscles with a flutter on the gee-gees and a session in the Golden Nugget, Great Yarmouth, where, to nobody's surprise, he failed to win the penny fountain. He had all the chat, and spoke knowledgeably of "yankees" and "sweating between the legs" - a bad sign in a horse, we were told, and probably in a punter as well. He sat in an old blokes' pub rubbing away at £100's worth of lottery scratch cards, and emerged with just £38 in winnings.

The highlight to a rollercoaster evening came at the end, when Rendall attended Cheltenham during Gold Cup week, and placed £1,000 on one horse, possibly called Flagship Uber Alles. "It's just something I've got to do", he muttered, a man possessed. We saw nothing of the race; the camera remained mercilessly on Rendall's face as he went through the full gamut of gambler's emotions.

Childlike excitement at having placed the bet, studied indifference as the race began, mounting hysteria as victory seemed to be within reach - and then horrible, stomach-turning disappointment when the horse fell at the penultimate fence. Flagship limped across the finishing line, but it was all over for Rendall. "It's totally done me in," he said, suddenly looking very much older.

Next week Rendall takes his dwindling stake abroad, but we can only wonder whether his nerves can stand it.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Guilt by Suspicion | Absence Of Malice | Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead | The Killing
fields.body:
Guilty By Suspicion

(Irwin Winkler, 1991)

12.45pm, 2.25am, Sky Cinema

Director Irwin Winkler was better known as a producer, with Robert Chartoff, of hefty films from Point Blank to Raging Bull. His directorial debut is a decently crafted story of the 50s Hollywood witchhunts, when the HUAC suspected there was a red under every bed. This film is good on the feel and fear of the times, with Robert De Niro playing a director blacklisted after admitting having attended a few communist meetings in his youth. Annette Bening is outstanding as the ex-wife he can lean on.

Absence Of Malice

(Sydney Pollack, 1981)

8pm, FilmFour

Pollack's exploration of press freedom and responsibility finds an unscrupulous Miami reporter all but ruining mobster's son Paul Newman when she wrongly implicates him in the disappearance of a union man. Absorbing, and an interesting counterpoint to the scrupulous journalism of Pakula's All The President's Men - though issues get a little clouded by the stars' emotional wrestling match.

Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead

(Gary Fleder, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

The problem with such a great title is living up to it, but Fleder largely succeeds, with a refreshing Runyonesque take on gangster fare. Andy Garcia's Jimmy The Saint is going straight until Christopher Walken's sick, desiccated villain draws him and his old buddies back in, with deadly consequences. And Steve Buscemi's assassin is a hoot.

The Killing

(Stanley Kubrick, 1956)

12midnight, FilmFour

This ripping heist movie, which was an an inspiration for Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs, has Sterling Hayden hand-picking a team of crooks to hit a racetrack. Problem is, it all goes horribly wrong. The convoluted narrative, full of flashbacks, is deftly handled, and Lucien Ballard's black-and-white photography really is the essence of film noir. Even the shadows seem to have cutting edges. An ace cast too, featuring the likes of Elisha Cook Jr, Mary Windsor, Jay C Flippen and Tim Carey.

webTitle: G2: Sean French on journalistic responsibility

fields.headline: Playing the judge and jury
fields.trailText: Sean French on why no one can win in child abuse cases and whether sex really is the new art
fields.body:
Believe it or not, I have some friends out in the real world. They are doctors, teachers and surveyors. They have to deal with problems, administer complex policies and if they make mistakes then people get hurt, walls fall over.

How much better to be a journalist. You report on things and then comment on them in hindsight. If somebody gets something wrong, you say it shouldn't have been done. If they get it right, you say they should have done it earlier. If you take strident, contradictory positions on the same issue, well, memories are short.

Take two major stories in yesterday's Daily Mail. One filled the front page, the other was on page 19. The trial of a former soccer manager, David Jones, for child abuse collapsed at Liverpool crown court. The Mail's reporters were not just sympathetic with the halting of the trial. They wrote that "major questions hung over the way child abuse cases are investigated".

They prominently quoted the defence lawyers, also involved in "similar cases" in Merseyside, who claimed that Jones was "not the first innocent victim of the system of 'trawling', where police investigating allegations about a children's home contact other former residents to ask if they have complaints".

They wrote that the first allegation against him, "which was widely reported, prompted other accusers to come forward". There is of course a pressure group with a tendentious acronym. Fact - Falsely Accused Carers and Teachers - said that the case showed "how easily false allegations can be made and how people's lives can be ruined". After paragraphs and paragraphs of complaint, there was a dutiful final sentence to the report: "But both Merseyside Police and the CPS defended the way they had handled the case."

If you turn to page 19, you come to the headline "Oratory priest at the centre of probe". It reads: "Police and social workers are investigating whether Father David Martin, who died of an Aids-related illness, may have abused scores of boys as young as seven while he was a chaplain at the London Oratory School." The inquiry was started after a couple of pupils rang ChildLine with allegations that he had abused them. On Tuesday a team of social workers visited the school. A police source commented: "It's a very sensitive investigation and we don't want to scare boys off from coming forward to talk to us."

Jones has been acquitted and the investigation into the allegations against Martin has only just begun. But my real concern is the way the stories were reported. The investigations seem to be fairly similar. Of course they are. They are both in the same murky, horribly complicated area of inquiry. Both started with slightly weird allegations. Both accusations were followed by an investigation.

Fact described the Jones investigation as "trawling" but the same could be said of any police investigation. The police and social workers are currently "trawling" the London Oratory in search of evidence, aren't they? There is the sensational coverage. The Mail photograph of Martin is accompanied by a caption reading, "Confession: David Martin admitted he was HIV-positive".

It may be that Martin was a serial abuser of boys as young as seven. Or it may be that a couple of boys heard that he had died of Aids and made the anonymous accusation as a malicious joke. That will be the job of the investigation to establish. But I didn't see any sign in the Daily Mail article suggesting that the investigation shouldn't be permitted because the allegations were anonymous and there was no concrete evidence. That would be grotesque and irresponsible. The problem is you then have to extend this to other investigations, even if they occurred 18 pages ago, in the same newspaper.

In the same issue there is an article on the Jones case headlined "This cruel perversion of justice" by Professor Mike McConville, a lawyer and academic. He seems to accept that at least some abuse is occurring but he rightly points out the problems in prosecution: the accusations are made years afterwards, there is no independent evidence, and, because the abuse is of people in care, the accusers don't make very good witnesses.

As he puts it: "In my opinion, character and lifestyle are important when establishing the credibility of a witness in such a case." But isn't it also true that abusers are drawn to children in care because they are vulnerable, unlikely to speak up and unlikely to be believed if they do? And couldn't dubious character and lifestyle be influenced by years of abuse?

It is slightly to McConville's credit that he reaches a meaningless conclusion. He believes that a specialised, highly trained police squad should be set up to deal with abuse. Fine, if improbable. Then he concludes resonantly: "We must have justice - but not at all costs." Eh? At a guess, I think this is a coded way of expressing the painful fact that protecting the rights of the wrongly accused - which we must do - will inevitably mean that many abusers will get away with it.

I think I share rather a lot of the concerns of the Daily Mail, McConville and Fact about the effect of false accusations. But about true accusations? The problem is that the self-righteous Daily Mail tone works either way. You can imagine the story if Jones had been found guilty, the tributes to the dedication of the police. I was going to say the same of the Martin case, if the allegations turn out to be fraudulent, but I can't go that far. Martin was gay, HIV-positive and he's dead. He really doesn't stand a chance either way.

Fiddling out of tune

The finest moment in Simon Hattenstone's very enjoyable Guardian interview with Sir Peter Hall earlier this week was, needless to say, about sex. Hattenstone had dug up an old quote in which Hall had asserted that "making love to a woman is the closest most men will get to being an artist".

It's a wonderfully old-fashioned remark and for best effect really ought to have been delivered around 1950 by a Frenchman with a waxed moustache, wearing a dressing gown, and flourishing a cigarette holder. Ideally it should be followed by advice in an Inspector Clouseau accent to the effect that a woman's body should be played like a violin.

I suspect, as Hattenstone did, that Hall was hinting that he was an artist in the bedroom as well as in the theatre. Maddeningly, however, he didn't press him hard enough as to the specific artists he had in mind. I've got a horrible feeling that Hall-in-bed considers himself a mixture of Michelangelo, Mozart and, of course, Wagner - by which I mean going on for a really, really long time.

The problem is that the more you think about it, the better a comparison it seems. It's just that the artists whom sex enables me to feel like seem to be rather different. For a start, there's the pop artist Claes Oldenburg, whose gimmick was that he did floppy sculptures of objects that are famous for being rigid, such as telephones or typewriters.

Then, regarding audience response, I think of Carl Andre's celebrated bricks: "Is that it?" "Yes." "But there's not much of it?" "It's minimalist." I won't even start with Waiting for Godot in which virtually every line seems apposite: "I can't go on like this." "That's what you think." Or: "You want me to pull off my trousers?" "Pull on your trousers."

It's all so true. And, come to think of it, I do play a woman's body like a violin, but then you haven't heard me play the violin.

 Catherine Bennett is away.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these films will be the first to be released in a large-frame Imax format?
fields.trailText: Which of films will be the first to be released in a large-frame Imax format?
fields.body:
Shrek 2-1

Dungeons And Dragons 3-1

Star Trek 10 4-1

Alien Pet Boy 8-1

Large-format cinema has grown up since its inception way back in 1967: The Old Man And The Sea was the first Imax film to win an Academy Award this year.

However, it's an expensive way to make movies, and the films have to justify the extra detail the bigger frames allow for. "It's a format that I don't think will be the future of cinema", says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "It costs more, and it will limit spin-off earning potential from video, DVD and network deals."

He points out that most likely to go big is "a high profile flick", acting as a showcase for a studio. Enter films heavy on the use of computer generated imagery (CGI), the current battlefield.

The 10th Star Trek film is a strong candidate. "It has the following to justify the cost of converting it to Imax - about $10m", says Andy. "But that might work against it: wouldn't the Trekkies go and see the flick whatever format it took?"

More likely are the upcoming fantasy animation films, Dreamworks' Shrek and Nickelodeon's Alien Pet Boy. Shrek boasts a high-profile cast including Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz and Eddie Murphy, and could be a major hit. It's using a mixture of full CGI for Shrek, the ogre-turned-good knight, and real humans.

"Nickelodeon's Alien Pet Boy is perfect for 3-D," says Andy - a Toy Story-style plot about a boy who's cruel to animals until he's sold to a family of aliens as their new "pet".

But ultimately, reckons Andy, it's a mundane peek at release dates that helps determine the best bet. Shrek is only six months away from release, and Dungeons And Dragons (pictured) is due shortly. "But of the two, Dungeons is less likely to be converted to Imax. It's one of those genres that you either love or hate, and one thing's for sure about big screen - you need universal appeal."

 Interview by Jennifer Rodger

Shrek boasts a high-profile cast including Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz and Eddie Murphy, and could be a major hit. It's using a mixture of full CGI for Shrek, the ogre-turned-good knight, and real humans. "Nickelodeon's Alien Pet Boy is perfect for 3-D," says Andy - a Toy Story-style plot about a boy who's cruel to animals until he's sold to a family of aliens as their new "pet". But ultimately, reckons Andy, it's a mundane peek at release dates that helps determine the best bet. Shrek is only six months away from release, and Dungeons And Dragons (pictured) is due shortly. "But of the two, Dungeons is less likely to be converted to Imax. It's one of those genres that you either love or hate, and one thing's for sure about big screen - you need universal appeal."  Interview by Jennifer Rodger

webTitle: Merrill may have got it Plum wrong

fields.headline: Merrill may have got it Plum wrong
fields.standfirst:
Slowdown could become a slide

Net news
fields.trailText: It is difficult to visualise someone called Plum Shipton delivering anything other than an upbeat message on economic and market prospects over the coming year. That is precisely what we got from the co-head of global European equity strategy at the American investment bank Merrill Lynch yesterday as the annual season of 12-month punditry kicked off in London.
fields.body:
It is difficult to visualise someone called Plum Shipton delivering anything other than an upbeat message on economic and market prospects over the coming year. That is precisely what we got from the co-head of global European equity strategy at the American investment bank Merrill Lynch yesterday as the annual season of 12-month punditry kicked off in London.

The City does not really have an option over whether it listens to what Merrill thinks is going to happen to money in all of its various guises. There are no ifs or buts. As a bank, it handles at least a quarter of the entire London equity market. Its opinions count, and so we should perhaps be thankful that the message from Ms Shipton and her colleagues is benign.

In fact, the forecast is almost comforting, building on the warming words of Alan Greenspan, who seemed so determined to get his calming message across to the markets this week. The Fed chairman knows that the swingeing re-rating endured by equity investors on both sides of the Atlantic over recent months has hurt, and he now wants everyone to know that the pain was worth it. Call it rational paranoia.

Merrill is with him, all the way. The bank claims to have "learnt to stop worrying and love the slowdown," arguing that, after recent price falls, shares are actually discounting a so-called hard landing which, in turn, is not going to happen. Its analysts reckon global growth will slow from 4.2% to 3.2% during 2001, triggering rate cuts in the US and Europe of up to half a point, while the euro will stabilise at or just above current levels against the dollar which, in this scenario, is not going to come crashing down.

This year is on track to be the most grisly for equity markets since the dark days of 1974 but, with the long-term cocktail of high spending on technology and globalisation pointing to sustained low inflation, Merrill says the secular outlook for asset prices remains positive.

Sure, there will be more pain in some quarters, such as those businesses (including newspapers) sensitive to advertising spending. Merrill also knows the internet sector has still to emerge from its first harsh winter - the root cause having been too much capital chasing too few opportunities. But its list of "global focus" recommendations for 2001 still includes names such as America Online, Nortel Networks and our own Vodafone.

In terms of old fashioned Footsie guesstimates, Merrill foresees a mild rally from here (6,273 points) to 6,500 in the top 100 by Christmas next year.

Of course, this bank, in line with all the other bulge-bracket investment houses which will be rolling out their forecasts over the next few weeks, is talking its book. A hard landing would equate to evaporating bonuses, vicious job cuts - particularly in the City - and, incidentally, sharp price deflation at the higher end of the London property market.

It is worth noting that, while the week may have begun with headlines on the euro bottoming out, Nasdaq posting its biggest ever one-day rise and all the usual wonderment over Mr Greenspan's magic words, the Dow Jones index on Wall Street slammed into reverse again yesterday, wiping out some of Tuesday's gains.

The short-term issue now is whether companies (and individuals) are still increasing their spending on technology at anything like the rate witnessed over the past three to four years, which is rather central to Merrill's assumptions on long-term trends for inflation and asset price growth.

Apple's warning on first-quarter trading, issued late on Tuesday, showed an extraordinary shortfall in projected revenues. There was every reason for investors to throw its rivals, such as Dell and IBM, out of their portfolios yesterday. On top of this came a warning from Bank of America that its fourth-quarter earnings will not meet expectations and next year's profits will also disappoint. Alarmingly, the biggest bank in the US blamed a sharp rise in bad debts.

On this side of the Atlantic, there are constant reminders about just how sour the whole tech thing has gone. Lastminute.com, for example, has just been turfed out of London's Techmark 100 index. Its brand is instantly recognisable, but in terms of market capitalisation it is fast becoming an irrelevance.

The nagging worry is that so much cash has been spent on computing over recent times that, herd like, consumers and businesses have opted for a long pause. If it is true that the extraordinary productivity gains over the past five years in the US have been fuelled by spending on technology, then even a pause is reason for investors to ponder long and hard about whether the time has arrived to stop worrying.

Merrill may love the slowdown, but gut instinct says sentiment is still sliding away.

webTitle: G2: Pass Notes on Bob the Builder

fields.headline: No: 1777
fields.standfirst: Bob the Builder
fields.trailText: Bob the Builder
fields.body:
Bob the who? Builder... favourite to top the pop charts this weekend.

Nice work if you can get it. It'll be good to see a construction worker at number one instead of all these pampered pop brats they usually have. Actually, he's not a real builder.

You mean he's one of those cowboy rip-off merchants who feature on TV's House of Horrors? Calling yourself a builder when you're not qualified is illegal, you know. No, he's a cartoon character from the hit children's TV series of the same name. Bob's voice is done by Neil Morrissey, from Men Behaving Badly.

Is Neil Morrissey a builder then, on the sly? No, he narrates the programme ... Look, forget about builders. According to the midweek chart placings, Bob's record is currently head to head with Eminem's single, Stan. But HMV reckons that once all the parents have gone out and bought the Bob tune for their kids this Saturday, the lovable builder will pip Eminem for the top spot. What's more, Bob's odds for a sought-after Christmas number one have been slashed to 11-8, after William Hill was inundated with bets of up to £500.

Eminem? You know, the bad-boy white American rapper who sings about kidnap and murder. Funnily enough, he's facing gun and assault charges in real life, after he pistol-whipped someone in Michigan.

Crikey! I'm siding with Bob then. Hope he wins. So does the Sun, which is getting behind Bob's fight against "the rap yob".

How progressive of them - and at the same time the government is launching a new war on yob culture. Er, yes. Buy Bob's culture and battle for the moral soul of the nation - and give any gambling parents the chance to make a few bob to pay for their brats' expensively violent computer games this Christmas.

Do say: "Can he fix it? Yes he can! Bob the Builder ..." (ad lib, repeat till fade)

Definitely don't say: "Bob the Builder? Yes, I'm interested in a quote for a partition wall ..."

webTitle: Monthly meetings too much for Bank

fields.headline: Monthly meetings too much for Bank
fields.trailText: Bank of England policymakers and staff believe monthly interest rate meetings should be dropped in favour of a less demanding timetable.
fields.body:
Bank of England policymakers and staff believe monthly interest rate meetings should be dropped in favour of a less demanding timetable.

Their views emerged yesterday from publication of an external review of the monetary policy committee by Don Kohn, director of the division of monetary affairs at the US Federal Reserve.

Mr Kohn, who spent seven weeks at the Bank during the spring, was asked to make recommendations about internal procedures of the MPC but he said that there was widespread support inside Threadneedle Street for a change in the MPC's marching orders from the government.

In a footnote to his report, he said: "One nearly universal recommendation of policymakers and staff I talked to was to change the legislation to allow fewer meetings each year.

"The monthly frequency was seen as not justified by the amount of new information becoming available between meetings, and in that context, as imposing considerable and unnecessary demands on policymakers and staff."

Unlike the MPC, the Fed meets eight times a year but in an emergency can change interest rates between meetings. The European Central Bank meets fortnightly.

The Treasury was quick to reject any alteration, saying it was outside the remit of Mr Kohn's report.

"Monthly meetings are required by the legislation. There are no plans to change," said a spokesman.

webTitle: The national vetoes which must go

fields.headline: The national vetoes which must go
fields.standfirst:
The president of the European Commission gives his hopes for Nice
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Many people may think that institutional reforms at a European level are dull, too abstract to be meaningful, too tiresome to deserve attention.
fields.body:
Many people may think that institutional reforms at a European level are dull, too abstract to be meaningful, too tiresome to deserve attention. The European Council meeting in Nice, however, is of crucial importance to all of us. It will, quite simply, determine whether we have a European Union that works in future.

The most important question is the extension of qualified majority voting. Only a really ambitious set of changes will make decision-making more efficient. When I say ambitious I mean that quality is more important than quantity. I would find it difficult to call the treaty of Nice a success unless we make advances in external trade questions, tax provisions that affect the functioning of the single market, asylum and immigration, social policy and structural funds.

It is crucial to improve the way we take our decisions. Our competitors know they are dealing with a community where every member has a veto - and the opportunity is there for our rivals to play us off against each other. Europe depends on trade for its prosperity and its employment. Rules governing our decision-making in this area were written at a time when the community consisted of six member countries and commercial policy was mainly about reducing technical barriers to movement of goods.

European companies depend on our ability to defend their interests. If we are not able to open foreign markets or ensure sufficient protection for our cultural or industrial productions, jobs will suffer. Trade policy is not a theological debate, but a policy with very practical consequences for European employment.

I understand how sensitive taxation policy is some countries. So let's be clear: I do not believe, and I am not proposing, that the EU should set tax levels in the member states. They are a matter for national budgets. I am not against a reasonable degree of tax competition, either, which is essential for a healthy economy and good for consumers. I do, however, believe that we must begin to take some tax decisions by majority vote, where only this will keep the single market operating smoothly.

As to asylum and immigration, it is in the interests of everyone that we should prevent decision-making being held up by the unanimity rule. It serves no one for would-be entrants to the union to have the opportunity or incentive to "shop around" between member states with different conditions and procedures. But agreeing a common framework for action that the Tampere European Council called for in 1999 is difficult as long as one member state can hold up the others. The answer, again, is a move to majority voting.

Social policy should be similarly coordinated, not because I wish to see national social legislation harmonised: that is not the point or the objective, but we need better coordination of policy for those citizens who are on the move. If a French person retires in Italy, a self-employed Spaniard sets up in Belgium, or a German youngster studies in Sweden, they should be able to count on their social rights. We will only be able to guarantee this, I believe, if decisions are taken by majority vote.

Lastly, structural funds cannot remain subject to the unanimity rule. Of course this is an area where member states will always fight their individual corner energetically. But given the struggles we already experience, no one should relish the prospect of trying to reach a deal when there are nearly 30 member states. Either we will fail to reach agreement at all, or we will constantly risk taking decisions that will sprinkle funds too widely across Europe without any real effect.

The arguments for more majority voting are not ideological, but pragmatic. Of course, member states have different areas where they find giving up the veto difficult. But if every state sticks to its position, every state will be worse off. And every citizen will be less well served.

Alongside the voting rules, there will be some lively discussion in Nice about the size of the commission. Keeping the number below a certain ceiling is one approach. But it is just as important to look at the way the commission is organised internally, ensuring that the president has the power to organise his team, whatever the size.

Those attending the intergovernmental conference should not delude themselves that difficult decisions we face in Nice can be put off. There can be no "leftovers" this time, no fudges left to sort out another day. Our neighbours to the east are knocking at the door. They are working hard to deserve membership of the union and we must be ready to receive them.

 Romano Prodi is president of the European Commission. George Monbiot returns next week.

webTitle: ICL warns of more jobs to go

fields.headline: ICL warns of more jobs to go
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: ICL, the Fujitsu-owned e-business services group which four months ago pulled its long-planned flotation and fired most of its senior management, yesterday warned that more jobs are likely to be lost as the company is restructured.
fields.body:
ICL, the Fujitsu-owned e-business services group which four months ago pulled its long-planned flotation and fired most of its senior management, yesterday warned that more jobs are likely to be lost as the company is restructured.

Since August people in more than 100 senior roles have left the company and 650 other staff have left or will leave over the next three months.

Acting chief executive Richard Christou was yesterday confirmed in the position full-time, replacing Keith Todd, who fell on his sword after the float was cancelled.

Mr Christou said there were no plans to reattempt the float and he would instead focus on restoring profitability and growth.

"We will continue to build our e-business services capability but not at the expense of our customers, many of whom are moving to e-business services," he said. "We will run our existing systems and services businesses more efficiently, and at the same time, provide the bridge that will enable them to make the transition to internet-based systems at a pace that suits them."

Mr Todd spent his last five years as chief executive promising that ICL would float but the Fujitsu board abandoned the strategy when it became clear that ICL's transition from a computer hardware seller to an e-business unit was taking longer than expected.

"ICL anticipates there will be further headcount reduction as it continues to review staffing levels and reprofiles its business," a statement said.

Around 56,000 square metres of property will also be sold over the next five years as staffers are encouraged to work remotely and connect to the office via mobile phones and lap-top computers.

ICL's plans would have required it to retrain 22,000 workers. The company now plans to focus on growth in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. It said it will examine acquisition opportunities, particularly in Europe.

In the year to March 31, ICL booked revenues of £2.77bn.

webTitle: The farcical state opening of the election campaign

fields.headline: The farcical state opening of the election campaign
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister manipulates the agenda to suit his electoral needs
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The state opening of Parliament is normally rich in farce, the only one of its kind in the world. What we see is absurdly at odds with the political season it is supposed to inaugurate. The Queen extracts her specs from the depths of the Privy Purse of Oculist Pursuivant, borne to her presence on the Silken Mat of Maintenance, and explains straight-faced how her government will curfew housing estates, deport paedophiles and legislate against a host of social aberrations of which We in Our finery know little.
fields.body:
The state opening of Parliament is normally rich in farce, the only one of its kind in the world. What we see is absurdly at odds with the political season it is supposed to inaugurate. The Queen extracts her specs from the depths of the Privy Purse of Oculist Pursuivant, borne to her presence on the Silken Mat of Maintenance, and explains straight-faced how her government will curfew housing estates, deport paedophiles and legislate against a host of social aberrations of which We in Our finery know little.

But yesterday it was different. This year, the charade of the Queen's Speech matched reality with a precision that was more offensive. For the reality this time is itself largely a pretence. The joke was a double-take. The tabards and the ermine and the backwards-walking and the doffing and crawling, all accompanied by the reverential commentary of David Dimbleby, disguised a new kind of story. Instead of being witnesses to a comical disjunction between roseate myth and gritty reality, these people were stage extras in a masquerade, whereby the Gracious Speech was converted from a government statement into an election address.

It was followed by earnest assessments of what, in the legislative programme, was most significant, what interesting directions the government was taking, how its proposed assaults on delinquency, now the epicentre of the third way project, might work. But few of these things will come to pass. Every conversation I've had in government circles assumes, with revealing incaution, that the election will of course be next May. That means a dissolution in March. It is clear that very few laws will be passed by Commons and Lords before then. So what we heard yesterday was something new: pre-election monarchical soundbites put to the service of the Labour party, in a theatre where the empress has all too many clothes.

At the heart of this is a kind of theft of democracy which could do with more attention. In 1997, the people gave Labour a five-year mandate which, it's now taken for granted, can gratuitously be reduced to four. That, after all, was what the Thatcher government did in 1983 and 1987. But yesterday's performance makes one see more clearly how unacceptable such manipulations are. No need of state presses the case for an election next year. No parliamentary or political crisis is in the wings, demanding therapeutic closure by the people. The product of the queenly charade will either be no laws, or else, in the few cases to which priority time is given, bad laws hustled through without proper scrutiny to meet the artificial deadline of a premature election.

The case for fixed parliaments, disallowing such blatant exploitation, is perhaps less urgent than it was before the Bank of England took control of monetary policy. That shift removed from chancellors one of the tools with which they have often organised economic policy to fit short-term electoral needs, and to hell with long-term effects. But Gordon Brown is demonstrating that budgetary policy can serve a similar purpose. Timing the disgorgement of billions on public services has been finely calculated. It's partly because of fears for an economic downturn later in 2001 that ministers are keen to get the election out of the way as soon as possible.

Fixed-term parliaments, of four or five years, would not be easy to run. There would need to be a mechanism to accommodate a government's loss of a confidence vote. Germany, a parliamentary system where the fixed-term principle applies, has a let-out clause requiring a dissolution if a confidence vote is lost. In 1972 and 1983, incumbent governments that wanted a dissolution manoeuvred to lose their own confidence votes, and thus precipitate an election. But since then the constitutional court has stepped in to prevent such finagling. If Britain adopted a similar rule, the no-confidence problem could be dealt with - Ferdinand Mount, a former Thatcher adviser, suggested this in his book, The British Constitution Now - by enlisting the judicial committee of the Privy Council to advise the monarch, who now has exclusive dissolving power, on whether the objective conditions for a dissolution had really been met. Updated, this can be Young's contribution to the Guardian campaign to down-scale the monarchy, though I'm not for abolition.

The case for fixed terms is that the summoning of parliaments should be beyond the manipulation of monarch, faction or prime minister. The system should enhance citizenship not subjecthood. "The fixed periodicity dignifies the people's choice," writes Mount, meaning that "the result of the election is the outcome of a regular constitutional process, instead of, as at present, a more or less successful confidence trick by the prime minister". A firm framework of election dates would make life more predictable, in one respect at least, for the interests that now have to wait on the whim of the prime minister.

Fixed-term government, it's true, produces a fixed-term build-up of campaigning. No sooner will George W Bush have been installed as president than Al Gore and a clutch of Democrat rivals will start preparing for the 2004 election. There's no escaping, in modern times, the sense of the permanent campaign. But when the timing is orchestrated by one leader, it seems quite excessive to mobilise the state landau, and the Australian coach, and the whole trotting throng of Horse Guards and Life Guards, together with processions of heralds and bishops and judges, to help him arrange it to maximum advantage a year ahead of time.

We now face four months of incessant election campaigning. That's the only thing government will be about. It won't produce better laws or wiser long-term decisions. Not only will the anti-crime laws be a series of hasty knee-jerks, but consider how different Britain's conduct of this week's negotiations at Nice might be if Blair wasn't tied to an election in May. With 18 months rather than four to go, he would be less conscious of the Sun's noxious fumes coursing down his neck. As it is, boxed in by his own decision to prepare everything for going early, he's pushed all the time to talk something like the same language of veto and national sovereignty as John Major.

That, too, may be a given of modern political life. The power of the British media tends to ensure that the government thinks it has to be campaigning for survival all the time. But the scenes in the throne-room of the Lords yesterday were especially unhappy. Somehow they debased both the government and the Queen. Ministers embrace the flummery with evident pleasure, but also with calculation. The Queen, unvoted and unvoting, is their electoral creature. fields.trailText: • Bargain Britain has lower prices for residential off-peak and peak metered internet access than France, Germany, Italy or Sweden, and only California has cheaper residential unmetered internet access for residential customers, according to a survey from telecom regulator Oftel . The UK also has the cheapest unmetered internet access for businesses in Europe but for metered business internet access is the second most expensive of the countries surveyed.

webTitle: Do It All takes over Great Mills for £285m

fields.headline: Do It All takes over Great Mills for £285m
fields.trailText: Focus Do It All yesterday bolstered its position as Britain's biggest independent DIY stores group, by agreeing to buy RMC's Great Mills retail chain for £285m.
fields.body:
Focus Do It All yesterday bolstered its position as Britain's biggest independent DIY stores group, by agreeing to buy RMC's Great Mills retail chain for £285m.

The deal, only three months after FDIA's £289m acquisition of the Wickes DIY chain, means the expanded group will have about 430 stores controlling 15% of the UK retail home improvement market.

RMC put its Great Mills retail business up for sale in July in order to concentrate on its heavy building material operations - ready mixed concrete, cement and aggregates.

It had hoped to get £300m for the business, but the final sale price is in line with analysts' expectations. Great Mills, which has 98 superstores across the country, employs about 4,000 people.

Neither FDIA nor RMC were prepared to say how many jobs would be lost as a result of the deal. An FDIA spokeswoman said there would be some overlap as a result of the acquisition and this would be "dealt with".

RMC last month announced 1,000 job losses at its building material operations, largely in Germany. The group, which is also planning to sell its US joinery business, said yesterday that the proceeds of the Great Mills sale would be used to reduce debt. The Great Mills deal, which is not conditional on financing or regulatory approval, is due to be completed by the end of the month.

FDIA, which is owned by the British venture capital firm Duke Street Capital, has been determined to grow by acquisition, though it recently pulled out of talks to buy Sainsbury's Homebase, the DIY market leader.

Great Mills, which had 3.3% of the market, last year made a trading profit of £25.3m on sales of £318.5m.

Economies of scale and the need for national coverage have been among the main drivers behind the recent con solidation in DIY retail market. Stores are expanding to take in gardening, pet and craft ranges so that the needs of the public are met under one roof.

Focus, an independent DIY business, with operations in the north of England and in Scotland, bought the Do It All chain from Boots in 1998 after the high street group - and its former partner WH Smith - had struggled to make a success of the DIY business.

"The combination of FDIA, Wickes and Great Mills creates a powerful new force in the market able to compete effectively to fully exploit these opportunities," said Bill Archer, chairman and chief executive of FDIA.

Graham Lee, managing director of Duke Street Capital, said: "We believe that this latest acquisition demonstrates our determination to support our management teams with the resources and funding necessary to build their businesses successfully."
