webTitle: Analysis: EU tax harmonisation won't be welcome here

fields.headline: French without tears
fields.standfirst:
European economies may be humming but attempts to force through tax harmonisation in Nice will find no support on this side of the Channel

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Nice is a French show. The success of the summit and the resolution of disputes over votes, defence and vetoes depends more than anything on French give.
fields.body:
Nice is a French show. The success of the summit and the resolution of disputes over votes, defence and vetoes depends more than anything on French give. Leave aside the problem of "cohabitation". There are differences of view between a French president beset by sleaze allegations and a French prime minister keenly eyeing the job (along with at least a couple of his close colleagues in the socialist party). But French attitudes are most heavily conditioned by the strength of the economy and so, in turn, by Paris's confidence that it has an exportable formula for success.

Since Lionel Jospin came to power in 1997 at the head of a socialist-green-communist coalition, 1.6m new jobs have been created, superior to anything since the 70s (and better than the Blair government too). The French economy is humming. Growth is projected at 3.2% next year, the same as 2000. That is high compared with the past. And with the UK, even though we are at a different stage in the economic cycle (though plotting it is a lot more difficult these days). France also enjoys historically higher levels of productivity per head than here, though its rate of increase has been slowing.

But beneath Gallic pride and detestation of neo-liberalism in all its forms, Paris is uncertain. Is this economic wellbeing a formula or a happy accident? Mr Jospin was this week as good as told by Jean Pisani-Ferry, head of the council of economic analysis, that measures so far adopted are running out of steam. Cuts in social security contributions by employers and the length of the working week have done their bit. What is needed now are radical "supply side" measures to boost training and help the unemployed find work. Mr Pisani-Ferry even suggests "a loosening of immigration policy".

The first report* from the Policy Network - a new think tank dedicated to cross-Europe comparisons - suggests the French have to do more. They face having to do something they have found highly unpalatable and put financial pressure on the unemployed to find work.

Much as the French left affects to despise Labour's third way, two of its tenets command fair assent across the Channel. One is that you cannot have socialism in one country - François Mitterrand tried and the experi ment came to grief. French economic destiny depends not just on the euro-economy but conjuncture in the world at large.

The second belief is labour market reform based on what experts call "conditionality" - making it hard for the unemployed to refuse reasonable offers of jobs or training. The chart shows the dimensions of France's problem: unemployment is still at nearly one in 10 of the working population. As in Germany (where total unemployment is less) a considerable proportion of the unemployed have been out of work for a long time. One of the unsung success stories of the Blair government has been to reduce this hard core of long-term adult unemployment. Among young people long-term joblessness has been almost entirely abolished.

Writing in the Policy Network report, Geoff Mulgan, the Number 10 policy guru who is now a civil servant and head of the performance and innovation unit, says British success rests on "active" measures requiring the unemployed to take jobs or training plus new tax incentives for single mothers and the disabled. This is not just a UK preoccupation. The same formula seems to be behind the remarkable success of the Dutch and the Danes in cutting unemployment to historically low levels.

But Mr Jospin is turning out to be something of a social-conservative. Big reform schemes, for education, savings and the civil service were checked by France's vested interests. At the French socialist party congress in Grenoble recently he was hailed as the most leftwing socialist leader in Eu rope. But lately that has come to mean not doing a great deal beyond increasing public sector employment and stymying the liberal inclinations of his finance minister Laurent Fabius, who seems as if he would like to be friendly to business in the Gordon Brown manner.

The French public finances meanwhile are in a bit of a state. Despite tax revenues pouring in, a budget deficit of 200bn francs, equivalent to 1.5% of GDP, is projected for the current year. Still, this might have been a golden moment to tackle some of the structural problems facing French social security and health insurance. The system looks healthy at the moment but as France ages and the balance between the working and retired populations shifts, deficits may grow. The word on pensions, however, is that there will be nothing doing before the presidential elections in 2002.

It is at this point we get back to Nice. In Mr Pisani-Ferry's report there is some ominous language about policy harmonisation in precisely the area the Blair government says it wants to stand firm - tax. "It is in French interests to set up tax coordination to counter the risks of harmful intra- European competition."

The Blair and Jospin governments see eye to eye on the desirability of full employment but disagree on methods. The intellectual case for the "Anglo-Saxon" approach to pushing the jobless back to work by a combination of sticks and carrots is a strong one. Unless the French accept it, their recipe for tax harmonisation could look like a bid to lock Europe into a policy that the French themselves concede does not work.

 Achieving full employment at Policy Network
david.walker@theguardian.com

webTitle: Sage delivers more profit than expected

fields.headline: Sage delivers more profit than expected
fields.trailText: Sage, the accountancy software firm, yesterday brushed aside continuing uncertainty in global IT markets to deliver slightly better than expected full-year profits and a confident trading outlook.
fields.body:
Sage, the accountancy software firm, yesterday brushed aside continuing uncertainty in global IT markets to deliver slightly better than expected full-year profits and a confident trading outlook.

The Newcastle-upon-Tyne firm said the increasing range of its products and geographic spread of its operations had better isolated it from the depressed conditions that have hurt other software firms.

Pretax profits for the 12 months to September 30 climbed 46% to £108.7m. Turnover was up 34% to £412.2m and the dividend was raised 10% to 0.386p per share.

Paul Walker, the chief executive, said depressed market conditions in France slowed overall growth. He warned that spending by firms with 50-250 employees had still not returned to levels seen before the millennium shutdown.

"Market conditions are still challenging," he said. "We're generating lots of sales leads but turning those leads into sales is sometimes proving more difficult than thought."

Sage offers accountancy products to 2.5m businesses ranging in size from one man bands to large corporations. It sells support contracts to 780,000 firms and is examining ways of generating new revenues by selling other types of products, Mr Walker said.

The shares climbed sharply in early trading but eased back to close up 3.5p at 434p.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: I discovered that Théodore Monod (Obituary, November 30) was a very great and good man for myself in 1972, when I was planning to cross the Sahara from the Atlantic to the Nile, alone and on camels.
fields.body:
I discovered that Théodore Monod (Obituary, November 30) was a very great and good man for myself in 1972, when I was planning to cross the Sahara from the Atlantic to the Nile, alone and on camels.

It seemed prudent to consult the two greatest living desert travellers, the other being Wilfred Thesiger, who over lunch at the Travellers' Club, made it plain he thought I was engaged in a stunt which had little hope of success. Monod - who knew far more about the Sahara - encouraged me from the start: in correspondence, where his utterly practical advice was seeded with quotations from Edward Lear; at his country retreat at Colomieres where we spent hours poring over maps while Théo suggested possible routes; and at his Paris apartment where we would discuss the impenetrable topicality of Giles cartoons and the relative merits of the English and the French prismatic compasses.

Everything he said was designed to make me believe that I might become the first man to complete that crossing alone. (I didn't, having to give up through illness after 2,000 miles). His last piece of advice was: "Take plenty of string. It's always very useful."

When my account of the journey was published, Théo wrote to say how pleased he was that it had been reviewed in Paris together with one of his own titles that had just been reprinted. He sent me a copy of Méharées and inscribed it "To my fellow méharist". I was, and am, very proud of that.
Geoffrey Moorhouse

webTitle: Dot.force sets out to break the log-on barrier

fields.headline: Dot.force sets out to break the log-on barrier
fields.trailText: The technological revolution may have offered the rich, industrialised nations the prospect of boosting growth and productivity, but for the poorer countries of the globe it could widen the gap between the world's "haves and have-nots".
fields.body:
The technological revolution may have offered the rich, industrialised nations the prospect of boosting growth and productivity, but for the poorer countries of the globe it could widen the gap between the world's "haves and have-nots".

In Nelson Mandela's words: "Eliminating the distinction between information-rich and information-poor countries is critical to eliminating the other inequalities between north and south."

Hence UN general secretary Kofi Annan's call earlier this year on all member governments to review their policies to ensure they were not contributing to the so-called digital divide.

The Group of Eight nations - United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy and Russia - responded in the summer by setting up Dot.force, a high-level working party comprising three representatives from each country, one from business, one from the civil service and one from civil society.

It met for the first time in Japan last week and now Britain's proposals for action are beginning to emerge.

Next week's white paper on globalisation, the second to be published by Clare Short's Department for International Development, will make clear that the basic goal of increasing access to information and communication technology (ICT) will not be achieved unless developing countries can be persuaded to dismantle state-run telecoms monopolies and replace them with a competitive and well-regulated private market.

"Without this, there is no hope of attracting the necessary investment in infrastructure or encouraging the competition needed to bring costs down," says the paper, part of which has been which has been leaked to the Guardian.

While it is possible to surf the internet in almost every country in the world, logging on in developing countries is much more expensive than in developed countries.

In Uganda for example, it costs $92 (£63) a month, 107% of GDP per head, compared with $29 in the US, 1.2% of GDP per capita.

Deregulation of telecoms markets sounds fine in theory, except that, in practice, it means the loss of a significant source of state revenue. Eventually, the economic and social benefits of the spread of ICT will outweigh the short-term costs but the process of adjustment could be extremely painful.

To make up for the revenue shortfall, Britain is proposing the international community offer developing countries both financial and technical support, including covering the costs of a good market salary for an effective independent telecoms regulator.

"Each countries' circumstances are specific but there are general principles to apply, including avoiding turning public into private monopolies," said one senior DFID official.

The official said that Britain, with its track record of privatisation, could be ideally placed to offer technical advice. Britain is also suggesting that the international community subsidise the lowering of tariff barriers in the developing world to hi-tech imports as a spur to the growth of ICT.

The white paper says that developing countries should help themselves by making sure access to the internet is not limited to urban elites. "In Bangladesh, for example," the white papers says, "there is a scheme through which poor people can get a loan to buy a mobile phone and set up a tiny telecentre. The scheme has proved highly successful: the loans have been paid back and the communities have access."

Developing countries are also urged not to ignore the potential of combining new technologies with the old. "For example, although less than one in 1,000 Africans currently has access to the internet, radio has wide penetration, even in the remotest villages. A growing number of community radio stations are getting connected to the internet, allowing new material to be shared with much larger audiences of poor people."

Vernon Ellis, international chairman of Anderson Consulting, Britain's business representative on Dot.force, says that ensuring there is demand on the ground for ICT will be crucial to the success for any strategy of bridging the digital divide.

Rather than foisting inappropriate hardware on the developing world, he believes that encouraging the growth of of locally relevant ICT applications and skills will help to ensure it contributes towards a sustainable cycle of development.

"Without the skills and access to the internet, you won't be able to be part of worldwide supply chains," he says. "You won't be able to be part of the international trading community. You won't get productivity gains in your own production facilities and therefore that cycle won't develop. On the back of that cycle developing, you can use ICT to help accelerate remote diagnosing of illnesses in villages, to involve civil society and in particular you can use ICT in education."

fields.headline: IMF puts Turkey on £7bn trial
fields.standfirst:
Aid eyed warily

Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: The International Monetary Fund announced details yesterday of a financial package worth more than £7bn to try to stabilise the Turkish economy after weeks of turmoil in the banking sector and on the financial markets.
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund announced details yesterday of a financial package worth more than £7bn to try to stabilise the Turkish economy after weeks of turmoil in the banking sector and on the financial markets.

Analysts have been worried that prolonged instability in Turkey could spill over into Russia and eastern Europe. Failure of Turkey's economic reforms would also be a blow to the prestige of the IMF.

"Talks about additional financial resources from the IMF to support a strengthened economic programme have ended in full agreement," Turkey's prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, told a news conference yesterday before he flew to Nice to attend the European summit.

In return for a huge injection of IMF funds over the next 12 months, the government has agreed to reinvigorate its programme of economic restructuring. Mr Ecevit promised that tenders for the part privatisation of Turk Telecom and Turkish Airlines would be announced next week, and moves towards the rapid privatisation of the electricity sector would begin.

There will also be further reforms in the banking sector, which has been plagued by corruption allegations. A statement from the IMF's managing director, Horst Koehler, said the government's package of measures "should provide the basis for restoring confidence and sustaining growth in the Turkish economy."

The economic crisis was prompted by a widening criminal investigation into a number of banks which have been taken into receivership over the past few months. As allegations of huge fraud began to appear on a daily basis in the local media, the market lost confidence.

Since mid-November some banks have refused to deal with each other and billions of pounds of capital have been withdrawn from the country. Some short-term interest rates rose by more than 1,000%, and there were heavy losses on the Istanbul stock exchange. Many of the losses have been reversed this week - yesterday the main share index gained nearly 20% after posting similar gains on Tuesday.

The shake-out in the banking sector may just be beginning, however.

Another bank - the eleventh - was taken into receivership yesterday and there might be more to come. Most analysts believe the banking sector needs to slim down dramatically if confidence is to be restored.

The government has said it will continue to guarantee ordinary bank accounts and any loans to the banking sector, unless criminal activity is proved. That promise has prevented panic withdrawals by members of the public over the past few weeks.

"In the end we have to tackle the curse of corruption", one financial analyst said yesterday. "Only then will the rest of it become worthwhile."

In a statement from Washington, Mr Koehler emphasised the importance of Turkey's commitments to strengthening the banking sector, "tackling the root causes of the current problems".

The new programme "moves forward decisively the country's structural reform and privatisation agenda".

The programme, still be approved by the IMF executive board, will include a new $7.5bn (£5.2bn) supplemental reserve facility on top of $2.9bn that Turkey may draw on from its "standby" arrangement with the IMF.

The markets will be watching closely to see whether the government has the po litical will to push through the reforms it has promised. The IMF credits will be released only gradually over the next year in an effort to ensure that Turkey sticks to its programme.

There will be opposition because austerity measures will be painful. Last week demonstrations in support of a one-day strike by public sector workers drew tens of thousands of people across the country. "IMF get out, this country is ours", their banners proclaimed.

Many workers blame the IMF for keeping pay rises well below the level of inflation, and they fear that further privatisation will lead to massive job losses.

So the pressure from the markets to speed up reform is not the only political consideration the government has to face. Both trade unions and nationalists within the governing coalition are deeply suspicious of the IMF's role in the country.

fields.headline: Gwendolyn Brooks
fields.standfirst: Poet who called out to black people everywhere
fields.trailText: Poet who called out to black people everywhere
fields.body:
The literary career of Gwendolyn Brooks, who has died aged 83, was distinguished enough to be coveted by any writer but it is also axiomatic that, being black and a woman, she achieved more than her fair share of "firsts" in a vocation that spanned eight decades. The first African-American to win the Pulitzer Prize (1950) and to be appointed to the American Academy of Arts and Letters (1976), she became poet laureate of Illinois in 1968.

She was born in her grand mother's home of Topeka, Kansas, the first child of David Brooks - son of a runaway slave - and Keziah Brooks. The month-old Gwendolyn was taken by her parents to Chicago and remained a "Chicagoan" all her life. A shy, bookish child, she developed an early passion for poetry and in 1930 her first published verse appeared in American Childhood magazine. By the age of 17 Brooks was submitting work to the weekly poetry column of the Chicago Defender, in which she published almost a hundred poems.

Graduating from college during the Depression, she did secretarial work, then in 1939 married Henry Blakely, also an aspiring writer. They divorced in 1969 but were reunited four years later. Her first collection of poetry, A Street in Bronzeville (1945) depicted everyday black life on Chicago's South Side, peopled with memorable characters. In 1946 she won a Guggenheim fellowship, as well as a $1000 award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

It was for her second collection, Annie Allen (1949), that she was awarded the Pulitzer. A sequence of poems about a black girl growing up in Chicago, it won particular praise for Brooks' innovation in poetic technique, the sonnet-ballad. A poetic oeuvre grew to include more than a dozen books, including Bronzeville Boys and Girls (1956), The Bean Eaters (1960), Selected Poems (1963) and In the Mecca (1968), nominated for a National Book Award.

Her reputation as a poet somewhat overshadowed her only novel, Maud Martha (1953), which is, in many ways, a significant precursor of more recent fiction by African-American women. Written with an affecting precision that details the process by which the young woman protagonist gradually matures, Brooks acknowledged its similarities to the trajectory, if not the specifics, of her own life: "There's fact-meat in the soup, among the chunks of fancy."

More specific autobiogra phy was included in her 1972 book, Report From Part One - a medley of reminiscences, interviews, photographs and vignettes, in which Brooks tellingly writes: "Are you aware of a fact-that-should-be startling about the High Days of my youth? All were Europe-rooted or America-rooted. Not one celebration in my black household or in any black household that I knew featured any black glory or greatness or grandeur. A capricious bunch of entries and responses has brought me to my present understanding of fertile facts. Know-nows: I know now that I am essentially an essential African, in occupancy here because of an indeed 'peculiar' institution. I know that the black emphasis must be, not against white, but FOR black ."

Though she had become an established and respected talent after starting out as a "literary integrationist", Brooks might have been marginalised by more strident black writings of the civil rights era, had she not been open to change and development in herself. She was clear about the moment that she rediscovered awareness of her blackness: it was in 1967 at a Fisk University writers' conference addressed by an angry LeRoi Jones (Amiri Baraka). Thereafter she was increasingly concerned with accessibility: "My aim, in the next future, is to write poems that will somehow successfully 'call' all black people: black people in taverns, black people in alleys, black people in gutters, schools, offices, factories, prisons, the consulate; I wish to reach black people in pulpits, black people in mines, on farms, on thrones; not always to 'teach' - I shall wish often to entertain, to illumine."

Her increasing concern for accessibility and affordable pricing led her to move publishers, to small local presses such as the black imprint Broadside Press - with whom she published the chapbooks Riot (1969) and Family Pictures (1970). She also established her own outlet, the David Company (named for her father). She also produced many works of non-fiction, works for children, essays and reviews. Her idealism was untarnished by age and she was almost 80 when Report From Part Two appeared in 1995.

Her commitment remained steadfast - "I am interested in telling my particular truth as I have seen it" - yet her tone was gently insistent rather than dogmatic. Typically, she wrote in Corners of the Curving Sky:

Our earth is round, and, among other things

That means that you and I can hold

Completely different

Points of view and both be right.

The difference of our positions will show

Stars in your window I cannot even imagine.

Your sky may burn with light,

While mine, at the same moment,

Spreads beautiful to darkness.

Still, we must choose how we separately corner

The circling universe of our experience.

Once chosen, our cornering will determine

The message of any star and darkness we encounter.

She is survived by a daughter and a son.

Gwendolyn Elizabeth Brooks, writer, born June 7 1917; died December 3 2000

webTitle: Leader: Monarchy debate is not just about a bigoted law

fields.headline: Crowning achievement
fields.standfirst:
It is not just about a bigoted law
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: It is not just about a bigoted law
fields.body:
Two myths may have been shattered yesterday. First to go was the old saw that says debates about constitutional reform are always boring - that they rank low on the priorities list of all but the most anorak-wearing of Charter 88 chatterers. The Guardian's clarion call yesterday for a full-blooded national conversation on the crown has proved that the opposite can be true. On dozens of radio stations, websites and TV networks in Britain and throughout the world our demand for a change was debated from early morning till late at night. Traffic on the message boards and chat rooms of the internet was heavier than usual, as Britons lined up to discuss the place of their head of state. For all their supposed indifference to the topic, they were anxious to make their voice heard.

Second of the myths to be shattered was the received wisdom that says all debate is useless, that the ancient order is so stubborn it can never be budged. Yesterday we drew attention to the absurdity of a Human Rights Act - passed this year - which bars all discrimination on grounds of religion sitting alongside a 1701 Act of Settlement which bans any Catholic, Hindu, Muslim or Jewish Briton from serving as the country's head of state. The two are just not compatible, we argued.

Already our case has made headway. Today MPs will have the chance to sign an early day motion calling for the discriminatory aspects of the act to be repealed, tabled by the Scottish National Party. Far from dismissing the effort, Downing Street has admitted that our case is right - that the anti-Catholic thrust of the 1701 act is indefensible, even if it is not yet an immediate priority for reform. Even veteran royalists, like Charles Moore of the Daily Telegraph, has conceded that the act cannot be defended. In Mr Moore's case, that forced an awkward contortion: he had to argue that the act could be amended without any change to the monarch's position as supreme governor of the established church - in other words, Mr Moore sees no problem with a Jew or a Muslim serving as the head of the Church of England.

Such are the distortions of our present system. Our effort, only just begun, is to start a discussion not just of a bigoted law left over from the 18th century, but of an entire institution more suited to our national past than our future. Buckingham Palace says it will "follow the debate with interest". So will we.

webTitle: Leader: Labour has poor crime policy

fields.headline: Hardline headlines
fields.standfirst:
This is a political not a policy package

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: This is a political not a policy package
fields.body:
Downing Street described yesterday's Queen's Speech as a demonstration of a Labour government "gaining momentum in its fourth year, not losing it". William Hague saw it as a cut-and-run exercise, a bundle of cosmetic measures covering up the complete failure of the government in the run up to a spring election. Yesterday's debate was not an edifying occasion. And compared to Labour's three previous legislative packages, it was thin gruel: a mere 15 bills compared to last year's 28. But historical constitutional changes - a Scottish parliament, a Welsh Assembly and Lords reform - are by their nature unrepeatable events.

Ministers have clearly decided crime will be a major election issue - and got their retaliation in first. In the 60 years up to 1985, there was an average of one criminal justice bill a decade. Michael Howard ended that tradition introducing one every 18 months. Now Labour has even exceeded that with a package of one social security fraud and five crime bills in a single session. The tactic is exactly the same as the Tories in 1996-97: a tough, blood-curdling, law'n'order package in the last parliamentary session in the hope the opposition will oppose it. Like Labour before them, the Tories are not going to fall into that trap, but stand by for a debilitating decibel auction on which party is the toughest on crime.

Jack Straw described the package as "the most major attack on crime and disorder in 20 years". Simon Hughes, his liberal democratic shadow, more accurately summed it up as "the government's usual mixture of sensible reform and simplistic gimmickry".

Few will quarrel with new police powers to shut down rowdy pubs and arrest hit-and-run drivers, tougher regulations to stop motor salvagers profiting from stolen cars, or even fixed penalties for drunken and disorderly yobbos (now that the police are no longer expected to frogmarch them to a cashpoint). There is a need for a better seizure procedure of criminal assets but as the proceeds of crime bill has not yet been drafted, do not expect a national confiscation agency before the next election. The gimmicks include extending child curfew schemes, ignored since they were introduced, from under-10s to up to 16-year-olds. Children's charities rightly complained yesterday this would only further marginalise young people from mainstream society on the poorest estates. Meanwhile, seemingly intent on maintaining his hardline reputation, Mr Straw will try for the third time to reduce the right to jury trials.

Welcome new health measures include a belated ban on tobacco promotion, the extension of prescribing rights to nurses and allied health professionals, and a new fund to refurbish 3,000 family doctors' premises by 2004. Education reforms will include a drive against adult illiteracy, the extension of the literacy and numeracy strategies into secondary schools and new rights for disabled pupils. The new homeless bill has Shelter's endorsement and there will be a second chance to end hunting.

What is missing, alas, is almost as long as what is in. Despite the promises at this year's Labour conference, there is no bill abolishing asylum vouchers. There is no adoption reform, no urban regeneration bill, nor the prospect of a renewed gay rights fight with the Lords on the abolition of section 28. Although yobbo culture is being tackled, a wider drive against alcohol, promised in August, has been dropped. Tough on crime yes, but not tough on the causes. In short a political rather than policy package, with the main eye on hardline headlines.
fields.bodyText: Downing Street described yesterday's Queen's Speech as a demonstration of a Labour government "gaining momentum in its fourth year, not losing it". William Hague saw it as a cut-and-run exercise, a bundle of cosmetic measures covering up the complete failure of the government in the run up to a spring election. Yesterday's debate was not an edifying occasion. And compared to Labour's three previous legislative packages, it was thin gruel: a mere 15 bills compared to last year's 28. But historical constitutional changes - a Scottish parliament, a Welsh Assembly and Lords reform - are by their nature unrepeatable events. Ministers have clearly decided crime will be a major election issue - and got their retaliation in first. In the 60 years up to 1985, there was an average of one criminal justice bill a decade. Michael Howard ended that tradition introducing one every 18 months. Now Labour has even exceeded that with a package of one social security fraud and five crime bills in a single session. The tactic is exactly the same as the Tories in 1996-97: a tough, blood-curdling, law'n'order package in the last parliamentary session in the hope the opposition will oppose it. Like Labour before them, the Tories are not going to fall into that trap, but stand by for a debilitating decibel auction on which party is the toughest on crime. Jack Straw described the package as "the most major attack on crime and disorder in 20 years". Simon Hughes, his liberal democratic shadow, more accurately summed it up as "the government's usual mixture of sensible reform and simplistic gimmickry". fields.headline: A stab in the dark
fields.standfirst:
David Walker tests a new government website given the job of making sense of it all for us
Net news
fields.trailText: David Walker tests a new government website given the job of making sense of it all for us
fields.body:
The British state has long lacked a decent portal to the myriad sites put up by Whitehall, councils, the NHS, quangos and agencies and the launch this week of www.Ukonline.gov.uk is a stab in the right direction.

It is a lot more user-friendly than the existing Central Computer and Telecommunications Agency (CCTA) site www.open.gov.uk, which is little more than an alphabetical listing of departments and agencies. But if you no longer need a degree in public administration to make sense of government online, you probably still need a GCSE in politics and a diploma in civics to make much sense of the information offered.

The new site is being presented as a test version. Ian McCartney, the Cabinet Office e-minister, said it was iterative - civil servants would monitor the way it will be used and improve it accordingly. It offers links to 1,000 or more other public sector sites. An effort has been made to organise its home page intuitively For example a bunch of links have been pulled together under the label "life episodes". This turns out to cover "going away", "dealing with crime", "having a baby" and so on.

The trouble is that a lot of the information accessed via these links is text based - imagine a frightened 16 year old having to plough through pages detailing NHS policy when what she really wants is specific information about doctors and clinics. Some sort of "Ask Jeeves" system for inquiries about public service is needed.

UKOnline is interactive. Four clicks under the crime rubric and you get to a page allowing you to report any internet site you have found offensive or potentially illegal. You can get information on how to report a crime or where to go for victim support.

This is useful but if you have to work hard to get solid information, especially data on local areas and services. Like most government websites, Ukonline persists with a hard and fast division between "central" and "local" government, assuming people know which services belong in which category, which they often do not.

Ukonline has been born with a handicap, which is that a private ISP had already bagged the title UKOnline at www.ukonline.co.uk

webTitle: Leader: Cures will allay fears about biotechnology

fields.headline: Down on the pharm
fields.standfirst:
Cures will allay fears about biotechnology
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Cures will allay fears about biotechnology
fields.body:
Yet again the Roslin Institute is pointing the way for the future of biotechnology. Yesterday, it announced a joint project with a US biotech company, Viragen, to genetically modify chickens so that their eggs contain antibodies for skin cancer. This is the brave new world of pharming. Just as we have tamed and adapted animals to provide us with food and material for clothing, so we can launch a new chapter in animal husbandry in which we develop them with genetic modification for medicines.

The ground for this development was in fact laid a while ago when scientists first started using eggs to develop vaccines. Transgenic animals for pharming simply takes this a step further. The hope behind the Roslin-Viragen golden eggs is that they will transform the supply of anti-cancer protein-based drugs which are currently difficult to produce in large quantities. It is a similar principle to another Roslin-associated project in which Tracey, a genetically modified sheep, could produce more than the total world supply of a protein vital for drugs to combat cystic fibrosis. Another project is for the production of factor nine in cloned lambs for the treatment of haemophiliacs. But it is important to remember that the arrival on the market of any of these products is still many years away. Tracey has been 12 years in development and is still in clinical trials. The anti-cancer eggs are years away from any appreciable effect on cancer treatment. In the meantime, the hopes of investors - and the price of shares - have to be kept high, hence yesterday's announcement.

Pharming will play a critical role in allaying consumer scepticism about genetic modification. It is easy to see how consumers took against GM soyabean which offered no benefit to anyone except Monsanto, but when a cure for cancer is at stake - one in three dies of the disease - biotechnology will no longer be seen as a playground for multinationals but as a vital hope to relieve suffering.

webTitle: Start here... How to dress Windows

fields.headline: Start here... How to dress Windows
fields.trailText: One of the nice things about Microsoft Windows is that you can sit down and use almost any PC anywhere. That's the theory. But Windows is so easy to tweak that most of us customise it so much that when we sit down at someone else's PC, it looks wrong. Why aren't the icons we need handy? Why are some utilities? And why does it look so... strange?
fields.body:
One of the nice things about Microsoft Windows is that you can sit down and use almost any PC anywhere. That's the theory. But Windows is so easy to tweak that most of us customise it so much that when we sit down at someone else's PC, it looks wrong. Why aren't the icons we need handy? Why are some utilities? And why does it look so... strange?

This is a good argument for sticking to the standard configuration, with its bilious background colour and inconvenient icon arrangement. But no one else does, so why should you?

First turn off the Auto Arrange feature that moves all the icons to the left hand side of the screen. Click the right mouse button, select Arrange Icons, then the Auto Arrange label, and press Enter to untick it. Now you can position the two most important icons on the right hand side of the screen, where they are handiest (if you are right handed). One of these is the Recycle Bin. Left-click it with the mouse and move it. The other is Windows Explorer, and it isn't there, so you have to make one.

Go to the Start button, right-click it, and Open the Start Menu folder. Double-click the Programs folder to open that, and select the Windows Explorer icon to highlight it. Now right-click it to pop up the menu, and select Create Shortcut. You now have a second icon, though you may have to scroll down to see it. Use the mouse to drag this icon on to the desktop, and place it just above the Recycle Bin.

Your icons may not be neatly spaced. Right-click on any blank bit of desktop, then select Line Up Icons (Enter) to tidy them up.

Windows Explorer is your window on to the hard drive holding your programs and, more importantly, your data. You need to be comfortable with your data files to benefit from a "data centric" view of computing.

In the 1980s, with MS DOS, it was tedious to handle data files, unless you bought an extra utility such as XTree or TreeView. So people tended to focus on running programs, and let the programs do much as they liked with data files. Often this meant storing them in a program subdirectory. Bad idea.

Windows changes things, because - like the Mac - it makes it easy to put the data at the core of what you do.

For example, suppose you are putting on a play. The data-centric way is to find a place for the data: you could create a My Play subdirectory in the My Documents folder in Windows. As the play progresses, that directory will hold an increasingly varied collection of files. These may include email messages, Word documents, text files, a spreadsheet (financial planning), desktop publishing files (the programme), photographs, accounts files, a database, some HTML pages downloaded from the web etc.

To work on your play, don't run a program then hunt for the file to load. Instead, use Windows Explorer to go to the data file you want, then double-click it to run the appropriate program. You may never use Windows' awful File Open dialogue box again. To start a new file, select the folder name and use Windows Explorer to create it. That way you can create it where you plan to keep it, and give it a usefully long and explanatory name.

To create the file, select File|New and then pick the type of file you want from the drop-down list. Now you can load the file, and the appropriate program, by double-clicking it as usual. (If the file type is not offered, you can always try creating a text file and giving it the right extension.)

One problem with this approach is that Windows Explorer's default setting is to hide the three-letter file extensions (.doc, .txt, .jpg etc) that tell Windows which program should load a particular file. The solution is to change the default. Go to View|Folder Options and click on the tab that says View. Find the box labelled Hide file extensions for known file types, and untick it. Click OK.

With this kind of set-up, there is another handy way of loading files and programs, known as drag-and-drop. For example, if you have a Microsoft Word icon on the desktop, you can load a Word document by using the mouse to grab it in Windows Explorer, dragging it until the file is over the Word icon, and letting go. This is, of course, pointless. However, you can use the same technique to load a text (.txt) file by dropping it on Word, or load an Excel spreadsheet (.xls) file, or whatever.

If the application is already loaded and open, you can also drop the file on the background or surround frame (the cursor will show a plus sign) to load it. If it is loaded and minimised, you can load the file by holding it over the task bar entry until it opens, then dropping the file on the background or surround.

I'm not sure why you are not allowed to drop a file on a program in the taskbar. It is one of Microsoft's little mysteries. Windows has no shortage of those.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: PS2 speak | Sega up
fields.body:
PS2 speak
Taito is due to release a speech recognition system and a companion game, Greatest Striker, for the Sony PlayStation 2 in Japan today. The triangular Taito Speech Recognition System, which attaches to a headset and microphone, plugs into a USB serial communications port. A compatible Mah Jong game is expected to follow next week.

Sega up
Sega, the Japanese games giant, received a boost last week when it signed an agreement to develop games for the next generation of Motorola mobile phones. The first phone, to be launched next year, will feature one game, a block puzzle game called Borkov. Consumers will be able to upload other games written in the Java language. The Motorola iDEN handsets also have built-in pagers and two-way radios, and are sold in the US and Canada. See www.motorola.com/iden

Star stories
SMAC fans - people who play Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri - can now buy the first of three novels based on the strategy game. They have been written in house by Firaxis's Mike Ely and published by Pocket Books in the US. "Centauri Dawn takes us into the world of Alpha Centauri as the Unity survivors struggle to rebuild human civilization on this strange and mysterious alien world." The next two books, Journey to Centauri and Centauri: Arrival, can be downloaded free from the Firaxis website at www.firaxis.com/smac/story.cfm.

Online games
Netgames UK, has launched an unmetered internet service aimed at online games players, especially fans of Half-Life, Quake 3 Arena and Unreal Tournament. The service, run by Cable and Wireless, uses an 0800 number, and will cost £25 per month from January 1. Until then, the company is running a free beta test service for people who want to try it first.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: SSX | Super Runabout | Escape From Monkey Island
fields.byline: Jack Schofield, Andy Bodle and  Greg Howson
fields.body:
SSX
Sony PlayStation 2 £44.99 Electronic Arts ****
Don't ignore this game just because you think snowboarding is silly. If you enjoyed playing WipEout, Road Rash and Tony Hawk's Skateboarding, you will probably love this because it has elements of all three.

The tracks in SSX (short for Snowboard Supercross) are immensely long, imaginatively designed and full of beautiful detail. You may not appreciate it when your head bounces off iron rails, or you crash through plate glass walls (not the kind of hazard the Olympic committees add to tracks, unfortunately), or go completely off track, but WipEout is rigid in comparison.

The Tony Hawk's element comes from the ability to do stunts, which increase your adrenaline, which increases your speed. (Crashing slows you down, of course.) And if other snowboarders get too close, you can exchange punches, as in the old Road Rash bike racer.

This game will last you a long time, because it gets hard fast. You have to earn each new track by coming in the top three in each challenge, which involves three races. You can usually win the first one easily, but winning the third gets progressively difficult. The catch is that if you finish out of the points, you have to repeat the first two races as well. It's very annoying but it does add tension to the final race.

Winning also provides access to better boards, and the chance to improve the capabilities of your character.

If you complete the game or get stuck, there's still lots to do. For example, you can try the Showoff mode, where you do stunts for points, or switch to two-player mode and race a friend.

The game graphics are smooth and usually sharp. The best aspects are that they don't slow down in high-speed action, and there are no pop-ups, with scenery appearing out of nowhere. The music tracks are also good, though perhaps not up with the best of WipEout. The commentary is amusing at first but quickly becomes wearing - don't they all?

It must be admitted that, after Cool Boarders and 1080, snowboarding games have become somewhat tiresome. However, SSX really has very little to do with snowboarding: that's just the peg for a very fine racing game. And it is one of the best games you can get for the PS2. (JS)

Super Runabout
Dreamcast £39.99 Climax Entertainment/ Interplay ***
Ah, this takes me back. Back to the scorching summer of 1968, when Steve McQueen's Mustang defied the laws of gravity in the sloping streets of San Francisco. Back to late 1987, when Richard McCracken passed his driving test and celebrated by writing off his dad's Volvo and three parked cars. But most of all it takes me way back to December 1999, when Crazy Taxi came out.

Sure, so the city is real this time (a worryingly accurate reconstruction of the aforementioned San Fran). You can also choose from several vehicles, everything from a phut-phutting moped to a tank. Everything you see is destructible: shop windows, rubbish bins, other vehicles. And your missions are, nominally at least, more complex. Instead of taking passengers from A to B, you now have to collect things as varied as bombs and ingredients for a hot dog.

But in terms of look, feel and substance, Super Runabout is Crazy Taxi with a paint job - and a dodgy one at that. The variety in the missions is superficial: it's still basically a matter of driving from one place to another, as fast as possible, without crashing. Then there are the clipping errors, the Dali-esque physics, the mediocre soundtrack and the banal, overarching story.

None of this is to say that Super Runabout is not fun. Its 16 levels are challenging, nice-looking, and ultimately more than capable of pumping life back into those adrenaline glands. But the niggles, coupled with the fact that we've been down this road too many times before (CT, Driver, Grand Theft Auto), leave Super Runabout some way down the starting grid. (AB)

Escape From Monkey Island
PC £39.99 LucasArts ****
Back in 1990, Gazza and Maggie weren't the only ones shedding tears. The first Monkey Island game had just been released and PC owners everywhere were laughing themselves silly for the first time. One of the first "point and click" adventure games, Monkey Island stood out for its humorous storyline and sparkling dialogue, though it was often the devilish puzzles that caused the waterworks to flow.

The formula was successfully repeated in two sequels. Now, three years later, we are being treated to some more Caribbean comedy. The big change this time is the move to 3D, which, in many ways, is a disappointment. The original interface was so good that losing the mouse control seems a revolution too far.But, in 2000, 3D seemsthe only dimension for games to inhabit, and EFMI is no different.

By using a combination of keys you can make hero Guybrush Threepwood manipulate the numerous objects scattered throughout the game as well as converse with the general populous. And you'll be wanting to talk. The writing is Frasier-sharp throughout, and it's a pleasure to play a game that treats you like an adult (albeit a wisecracking amateur buccaneer).

Veterans will be pleased to see that most of the conundrums are as obscure as ever, although the self-referential tone throughout could annoy any newbies. Still, once you get used to pairing seemingly disparate objects and competing in verbal gymnastics, you'll be fine.

The move in to the third dimension is not a total success but, a decade on, Monkey Island still rules the waves. (GH)

But most of all it takes me way back to December 1999, when Crazy Taxi came out. Sure, so the city is real this time (a worryingly accurate reconstruction of the aforementioned San Fran). You can also choose from several vehicles, everything from a phut-phutting moped to a tank. Everything you see is destructible: shop windows, rubbish bins, other vehicles. And your missions are, nominally at least, more complex. Instead of taking passengers from A to B, you now have to collect things as varied as bombs and ingredients for a hot dog. But in terms of look, feel and substance, Super Runabout is Crazy Taxi with a paint job - and a dodgy one at that. The variety in the missions is superficial: it's still basically a matter of driving from one place to another, as fast as possible, without crashing. Then there are the clipping errors, the Dali-esque physics, the mediocre soundtrack and the banal, overarching story. None of this is to say that Super Runabout is not fun. Its 16 levels are challenging, nice-looking, and ultimately more than capable of pumping life back into those adrenaline glands. But the niggles, coupled with the fact that we've been down this road too many times before (CT, Driver, Grand Theft Auto), leave Super Runabout some way down the starting grid. (AB) Escape From Monkey Island PC £39.99 LucasArts **** Back in 1990, Gazza and Maggie weren't the only ones shedding tears. The first Monkey Island game had just been released and PC owners everywhere were laughing themselves silly for the first time. One of the first "point and click" adventure games, Monkey Island stood out for its humorous storyline and sparkling dialogue, though it was often the devilish puzzles that caused the waterworks to flow. The formula was successfully repeated in two sequels. Now, three years later, we are being treated to some more Caribbean comedy. The big change this time is the move to 3D, which, in many ways, is a disappointment. The original interface was so good that losing the mouse control seems a revolution too far.But, in 2000, 3D seemsthe only dimension for games to inhabit, and EFMI is no different. By using a combination of keys you can make hero Guybrush Threepwood manipulate the numerous objects scattered throughout the game as well as converse with the general populous. And you'll be wanting to talk. The writing is Frasier-sharp throughout, and it's a pleasure to play a game that treats you like an adult (albeit a wisecracking amateur buccaneer). Veterans will be pleased to see that most of the conundrums are as obscure as ever, although the self-referential tone throughout could annoy any newbies. Still, once you get used to pairing seemingly disparate objects and competing in verbal gymnastics, you'll be fine. The move in to the third dimension is not a total success but, a decade on, Monkey Island still rules the waves. (GH)

fields.headline: No to abolition: a little reform is all that is needed
fields.trailText: I would have thought the present situation in the US is sufficient evidence of the dysfunctional outcome of politicising the head of state.
fields.body:
I would have thought the present situation in the US is sufficient evidence of the dysfunctional outcome of politicising the head of state. As an institution there is no doubt that the monarchy is outmoded, but it is possible to modernise and render the institution more democratic without abolition. First stage would be to get rid of the royal prerogative - the whole raft of things from the honours list to dissolving parliament to declaring war that can be done without consulting parliament.

The Queen herself does not exercise these powers, any more than she writes the Queen's Speech: they are powers exercised by the executive without regard to parliament. Alternative democratic structures could easily be put in place.

Secondly should come the long-overdue disestablishment of the Church of England. Finally, it could be recognised that both England and Scotland have only had hereditary monarchs since the 12th century. Before that the monarchy was elected by the peers of the realm. It should not be beyond our powers to devise a similar elective monarchy for the 21st century.
Colin Pilkington
Burscough, Lancs
colin@filitalia.demon.co.uk

 The cardinal weakness of your republican programme is the vulnerability of actually existing democracy to corporatism. There is no need to look to America for that: our present government is an excellent example. And nowhere do you say how re moving a constitutional monarch would increase resistance to this, much the most serious danger facing us. It might well do just the opposite.
Patrick Curry


London

 To transpose the well-known phrase - monarchy is a poor method of selecting the head of state; but all the others are worse. The personal qualities of the potential monarch are largely irrelevant. The major requirement is that they carry out their ceremonial (ie figurehead) duties with dignity and decorum.
Philip Stanley Bromley, Kent

 Could the tiresome nonsense about citizen and subject not be dropped? In relation to my country, I am a British citizen, and am so described on my passport. In relation to my Queen, I am a British subject.
RL Sturch
Kidlington, Oxon

 It is in the interests of those who are prepared to subsume our sovereignty into a federal Europe to weaken the monarchy. There is no popular demand for the republic you advocate.
Richard BL Fitzwilliams
London

 Eight whole pages of a much loved newspaper to discuss an issue that is about 907 on most rational people's list of priorities. Railtrack, the NHS and every individual exercising power must be breathing easily today.
Mark Stobbs
Lewes, E Sussex

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Euro loans no cheaper
fields.body:
Euro loans no cheaper

Halifax, the mortgage bank, says British homebuyers are no worse off without the euro.

The average mortgage rate in the UK, taking into account fixed and discount loans, is 6.9%, compared to 6.6% in Germany and 6.2% in Italy. Only Spain is significantly cheaper, at 4.9%, it reported yesterday.

Halifax suggests that tax harmonisation would harm British homeowners, because of favourable capital gains tax treatment of house sales. The bank confounds the popular belief that Britain has Europe's highest level of home ownership, with Spain and Italy significantly ahead.

Union chooses new chief

Left-winger Mark Serwotka, 37, a branch official of the Public and Commercial Services union, has beaten beaten assistant general secretary Hugh Lanning by almost 7,000 votes in a ballot to become general secretary.

200 jobs to go at Fyffes

Fyffes, Europe's biggest fresh food distributor, said yesterday that 200 job losses would result from its decision to close two Geest UK ripening centres and a reduction in the number of employees at the Geest head office. A Fyffes ripening centre will also close.

fields.headline: A chorus on the national anthem
fields.trailText: The need for a new national anthem is a key issue. To acknowledge it with any honesty one must: believe in the existence of god; accept that god is willing to save and takes due notice of our petitions; regard the monarch as top priority for salvation.
fields.body:
The need for a new national anthem is a key issue. To acknowledge it with any honesty one must: believe in the existence of god; accept that god is willing to save and takes due notice of our petitions; regard the monarch as top priority for salvation. As we accept none of these things, the hymn which is called our "national" anthem has no relevance to us.

A useful approach might be to ask whether people think their grandchildren should have the possibility open to them of aspiring to this position. Put this way, the issue could be seen in a new light, with the majority in favour.
DH and Y Kedge
Sonning Common, Oxon y.kedge@lineone.net

 In the 1947 edition of the hymn book of the Union of Liberal and Progressive Synagogues the third verse of the national anthem was: Not on this land alone/But be God's mercies known/From shore to shore./Lord, make the nations see/That men should brothers be, And form one family,/The wide world o'er.

I do not know its origin, but I do know that this made more people want to sing it.
Rabbi Lawrence Rigal
London lawrence@rigal.freeserve.co.uk

 Perhaps a start could be made in the necessary culture change by dispensing with the imposition of the "loyal toast" at official functions. If it was replaced with something like "Our Country and all who cherish her" I imagine there would be no prob lem. Otherwise it will just have to be accepted that some will not stand for "The Queen, Gor bless 'er".
D Mitchell

 It will be difficult for Prince Charles to fulfil his ambition to be "defender of faith" when he is required to swear allegiance (and give preference) to one small, dying sect. There is a half-hearted debate within the church about disestablishment, but there seems little stomach for it at the top. The government has made clear that it will not initiate any moves without the church's agreement. If the church will not grasp the nettle then it is right that the Human Rights Act should do it for them.
Keith Porteous Wood
National Secular Society

fields.headline: Reptile ruffles feathers
fields.standfirst: A fossil seems to have settled the bitter arguments over the relationship between dinosaurs and birds, reports  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: A fossil seems to have settled the bitter arguments over the relationship between dinosaurs and birds, reports Henry Gee
fields.body:
As any visitor to Winnie The Pooh's Hundred-Acre Wood will tell you, Tiggers Don't Climb Trees. Dinosaurs, however, might not have had such scruples. Today's Nature contains a report of a new and very small feathered dinosaur that could have made its home in the Six Pine Trees.

From a distance, Microraptor zhaoianus would have looked like a bedraggled blackbird. Indeed, we might have had a hard time telling the difference between microraptor and birds.

And this would have been a nice conundrum - for microraptor was much more closely related to ground-living predators such as velociraptor than to early birds such as the magpie-sized archaeopteryx.

As Xing Xu of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleonthropology in Beijing and his colleagues report, microraptor is the first, full-grown dinosaur to be found that is smaller than archaeopteryx, the canonical first bird. As such, microraptor - from the 125-million-year-old rocks in north-east China that have yielded many fossils of birds and feathered dinosaurs - crosses the palaeontological rubicon.

Here's why. Most palaeontologists accept that birds evolved from somewhere within a large group of two- legged predators, the theropods. Conventional wisdom has it that these creatures kept both feet firmly on the ground, while the first birds took off from it. However, the evolution of birds was accompanied by a general diminution, so that the earliest known bird, 150-million-year-old archaeopteryx, could have alighted on your shoulder - unlike a Tyrannosaurus rex. A small and vociferous group of researchers has argued that birds and dinosaurs are not close relatives at all, that archaeopteryx evolved from a tree-like creature, which took off from branches rather than from the ground.

Although few would now seriously doubt the close relationship between birds and theropod dinosaurs, the difference between the two camps has been marked by the assumption that if birds and theropods were closely related, then the ancestors of birds would have taken off from the ground, not from trees. But evidence of relationship - deduced by close study of the anatomy of living and fossil creatures - need say little about how those creatures behaved. For example, goats, unlike Tiggers, are excellent tree-climbers, even if their anatomy suggests a ground-living lifestyle.

Nevertheless, Alan Feduccia of the University of North Carolina (a leading critic of the bird-dinosaur consensus) has shown how the claws of archaeopteryx look more like those of modern perching birds than ground-living birds.

This influential study might say something about the habits of birds, but less about archaeopteryx, but nothing at all about bird-dinosaur relationships. Even so, the value of this comparative study has been lessened by the presumption that the behaviour of ancestral birds is a clue to relationships, and the assumption of Feduccia's critics that the ancestors of birds were ground-living runners anyway.

Enter tiny, feathered microraptor, a midget version of velociraptor with a long tail, a head the size of a thumbnail and an incomplete trunk thought to be less than two inches long. Xu and colleagues, strong advocates of the bird-dinosaur consensus, are in no doubt that microraptor is a dinosaur, and a member of a group of otherwise ground-living theropods that were close cousins (if not the ancestors) of birds. Nevertheless, in a significant nod to Feduccia, they show that the claws of microraptor are stronglysuggestive of a life spent in the trees rather than on the ground. "The theropod ancestors of birds may have passed through an arboreal phase", the researchers suggest. Although the legs, tail and skull are well-preserved, little remains of the trunk or arms, so the researchers have no idea if microraptor could have flown, as archaeopteryx is believed to have done. If microraptor were a flyer, it would be the first case of a dinosaur, other than birds themselves, taking to the skies.

The line between birds and dinosaurs was challenged by the discovery of archaeopteryx in 1861. But it has become dangerously thin since the discovery of a series of feathered dinosaurs from China and elsewhere in the 1990s. With microraptor, in 2000, the line has vanished.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Eve and the dawn of man... | Hot air and some cold water
fields.body:
Eve and the dawn of man...
The last common ancestor of all Homo sapiens walked the plains of Africa about 171,500 years ago, give or take 50,000 years, according to Nature today. A team from Uppsala in Sweden and Leipzig in Germany used the mitochondrial DNA of 53 people of widely different backgrounds as a kind of clock to date humanity. MtDNA is inherited only from the mother. It acquires mutations with time. The difference between any two people is a clue to ancestral distance. The research puts Africa back on the map as humanity's motherland. The same research shows that Africans and non-Africans diverged about 52,000 years ago (give or take 28,000 years).

Hot air and some cold water
Cornell University in Ithaca, New York has been thinking deeply about renewable energy. Quite specifically, it has been air conditioning its campus buildings by sucking up cold water from nearby Cayuga Lake. This cost $60m but it will save 20m kilowatt hours of electricity for cooling, and thus 2m tons of burned coal each year. The university had to replace its central cooling system anyway, but $60m was quite a premium. "We have built something that will last 75-100 years, whereas convential chillers last about 30 years," said William Joyce, project director. "It's a much more passive system with fewer moving parts."

It's not curtains for coral in the US
President Clinton has announced an 84m acre ecosystem reserve around the northwest Hawaiian islands. This is the largest protected area in the US. The area contains two thirds of all the US coral reefs, along with pristine remote islands, atolls and submerged lagoons. Coral is under threat everywhere: most of the coral reefs in the Indian ocean have perished. Theodore Roosevelt established a wildlife refuge in Hawaii, just about a century ago, setting a precedent for succeeding generations, Clinton said. "Today we do just that, incorporating the refuge he created into a new, vast and wonderful Yellowstone of the sea."

fields.headline: Guardian Republic Debate
fields.trailText: Congratulations on your excellent initiative in opening a debate on the establishment relics that hold us back from being a truly democratic society. I hope it doubles your circulation.
fields.body:
Congratulations on your excellent initiative in opening a debate on the establishment relics that hold us back from being a truly democratic society. I hope it doubles your circulation.
Ian Metherell
London

 My wife and I, my family, my many friends and I suspect the majority of the citizens of Scotland will wholeheartedly support your campaign to democratise the royal family. Thank you, Mr Rusbridger.
Francis Wheeler
Moffat, Dumfrieshire

 When the UK strives to present itself to the world as a modern, pluralist, tolerant society, the fact that non-Protestants are forbidden from succession to the throne can only be described as a festering sore.
Simon McDonnell
London

 First "The Manifesto", now a Human Rights Act challenge so that Catholics and daughters can "reclaim their birthright". Maybe the Guardian should take itself a little less seriously.
Andrew Matheson London

 To save me time trawling the email site, could you please tell me what rank I am and how soon I should get my tiara out of the pawn shop.
Ruth Rhoden
Brierley Hill, W Midlands

 Two words for republicans: President Thatcher.
Philip Parker
Leamington Spa

 Why not privatise the monarchy? Offer the job to the highest bidder. Or even a 30-year PFI contract. Being Queen can't be harder than running the underground. Joseph Hanlon
London

fields.headline: Sleeping sentinels of the deep
fields.standfirst: Maxine-Fay Miller  explains how dolphins keep an eye on things even while slumbering
fields.trailText: Maxine-Fay Miller explains how dolphins keep an eye on things even while slumbering
fields.body:
Some of us are quite helpless first thing in the morning, only half awake barely able to face the day. But the dolphin stays totally in control and completely aware of its surroundings even when half asleep.

Dolphins are extraordinary creatures. They are mammals, they breathe air with lungs and can make a large gulp last up to an hour when plunging into the depths of the ocean. They give birth to live young which suckle milk.

They are highly agile predators with a torpedo-shaped body, an elongated head with a bulging forehead, and a beaklike snout. They are renowned for their high intelligence, which enables them to home in on unsuspecting prey and communicate effectively with each other. They have a special waxy body in their swollen forehead known as a melon which focuses sound produced in the nasal passages and enables them to use echolocation to find prey such as squid and krill in deep, and often dark, waters.

Dolphins communicate with a variety of high-pitched squeaks, squeals and clicking sounds. However, there are times when even dolphins need to sleep. Yet they still manage to remain in contact with one another. They do this by sleeping with one eye open. At the same time only one hemisphere of the dolphin's brain enters into slow wave or deep sleep mode. This leaves the other brain hemisphere wide-awake allowing a dolphin to remain alert while never being more than half-asleep throughout the night.

Patricia Goley from Humboldt State University, California, wanted to unravel the reason for this weird sleep pattern. Did it allow one dolphin to serve as a sentinel for his or her group mates? Did it permit all the dolphins to keep one eye peeled for approaching danger?

During the night, when they sleep, dolphins swim around slowly in a counter clockwise direction. Individuals are spaced in tight schools, no more than two body diameters away from neighbouring dolphins in their group. And when an entire group of Pacific white-sided dolphins is half asleep the open eye of each dolphin is directed at the other group members, towards the centre of the swimming group.

Swimming with one-eye open and facing the group enables dolphins to maintain a cohesive, integrated and tight formation. As well as keeping a close eye on other group members the dolphins can scan the environment past their schoolmates looking for any signs of danger.

Dolphins sporadically switch their positions within the group when half-asleep swimming. They also change the open eye, and alter the sleeping hemisphere, to ensure that they always have one eye on their schoolmates. The other half of the brain, the one that's been on watch, can rest when they switch sleeping hemispheres. Thus dolphins can fully rest their brains during their sleeping session while still being able to breathe and swim voluntarily. Changing positions gives dolphins a short break in formation, which may help school members to inspect their immediate vicinity for predators such as killer whales, at a time when they are most vulnerable. They remain silent when swimming in this half-asleep formation. Scientists believe this allows them to listen for predators and prevents them from advertising their whereabouts. It may also be essential for the restoration of their sound-making machinery, which is active when they are fully awake.

Swimming closely together enables sleeping dolphins to be aware of other school members in the absence of vocalisations.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.standfirst: Laptops with clip-on DVD
fields.trailText: Laptops with clip-on DVD
fields.body:
Samsung is entering the ultra-portable notebook PC market with a pair of super slim, lightweights - the NV-5500TL and NV-5500TX.

Both laptops feature a 12.1 TFT XGA screen, an Intel Mobile P111 500 LV processor, an external digital camera with video conferencing software and a 56kbps modem.

Samsung claims that the notebooks are the first to be accompanied by a clip-on docking station which houses a DVD or CD-rom drive and a floppy disk drive. Also new is the PC's integrated MP3 player which, if hooked up to a remote control/headphones unit, can still be used when the unit is switched off.

The more expensive NV-5500TX (£2,499 inc VAT) boasts 128MB of memory, a 20 gigabyte hard disk, a DVD-rom drive and a battery performance of around 7.5 hours.

The NV-5500 TL (£2,000 inc VAT) has 64MB of memory, a 10 GB hard disk, CD-rom drive and a battery life of around 2.5 hours. They will be on sale in January.

Further models in the NV ultra portable notebook series are expected in May, almost certainly featuring Bluetooth and SmartMedia compatibility.

Get more on Mini Discs
Sony is targeting MiniDisc fans who store music on their PCs with its latest home MD recorder. The £350 MDS-PC3 comes with a software and connection pack that enables users to transfer music stored on their hard disks to a MiniDisc.

In typical Sony fashion this means not using MP3, but via the company's Atrac compression system.

Atrac works in a similar way to MP3 in losing the bits of the sound spectrum the ear cannot hear, to enable further compression.

The MDS-PC3 can be hooked up to a hi-fi system and sports both analogue and digital inputs and outputs.

Recording time is rated at 320 minutes per disc no matter what the source (PC or hi-fi system) courtesy of the recently launched MiniDisc Long Play (MDLP) technology. However, discs recorded using the MDLP format will not play back on non-MDLP MiniDisc players.

RecordTV's new alliance
RecordTV, the controversial internet based-VCR system, may soon be coming to Europe. The company has confirmed that it is has been in talks with German media giant Bertelsmann with a view to offering programmes via the web.

Users simply state what they want to record and then watch the programmes online at their own convenience.

The move is indicative of Bertelsmann's recent approaches to web companies. Several months ago it sealed an alliance with online music swapping service Napster.

Earlier this year RecordTV suspended its US-based virtual VCR service after members of the Motion Picture Association of America filed a lawsuit against the company. The lawsuit is still pending with a trial date of July 2001.

fields.headline: Working IT out
fields.standfirst: Athlete Iwan Thomas is Britain's 400 metre record holder and one of the hottest prospects in UK athletics
fields.trailText: Athlete Iwan Thomas is Britain's 400 metre record holder and one of the hottest prospects in UK athletics
fields.body:
How is new technology affecting athletics? Personally, using my mobile is my main mode of communication. Whether I'm in South Africa training or racing somewhere, it's great to be able to call my coach or to stay in touch via email or SMS messaging. For athletics journalists I guess the beauty is being able to send results and photos from anywhere in the world to be downloaded immediately back in Britain. Obviously, for athletics, things such as timing have to be spot on. With some events world records are set and broken all the time and the difference can be hundredths of a second so reliable technology is vital for things to be exact.

Could you see the net being applied to more areas of athletics? I think the internet is big business and it's expanding into different areas all the time so I don't really see why not. At present, for an athlete who's looking for competition, you can go on to the International Amateur Athletics Federation website which lists all the competitions in Britain and everywhere else. There might be a small athletics meeting out in Italy that no one knows about so it's a great way of getting information out to interested individuals. It is also a great way for people to find out about sportsmen or women. With my own website I know we get a lot of hits from journalists as it is updated weekly.

What made you decide to set up your own website? It was organised before the Olympics and I was hoping that I'd go there and do really well but I got injured so we decided to do it while I was recovering. It's a good way to keep fans up to date and for them to get in touch. It has been a hard two years for me and there have been some really encouraging messages in the guest-book on the site. When I didn't get selected this year, the feedback and support through the site was amazing.

Why don't more sportsmen and women have their own websites? I really don't know. I was fortunate to get a company willing to help set it all up but it needn't be too difficult for others to get a basic website up and running. We release a fair bit of exclusive information via the site and it has very convenient being able to direct people there with questions.

Have you been using the net long? Not really. Setting up the site helped me get more involved with it. The most time I've spent on it was at the Olympics training camp in Australia. We had a lot of spare time and I used that to search a lot of web pages and have a laugh in some of the chatrooms.

Any favourite sites? I was fascinated by sites like Mingers.com and Rotten. I do go to the IAAF site a lot and I was doing a diary for the BBC while I was at the Olympics so I still go to their site.

Are you into gadgets? I'd be completely lost without my mobile phone.

For more information visit: www.iwanthomas.com
