fields.headline: Confetti sweeps up wedding competitors
fields.standfirst:
Justin Hunt finds getting hitched is a costly business as he looks at Britain's leading wed-site
Net news
fields.trailText: Justin Hunt finds getting hitched is a costly business as he looks at Britain's leading wed-site
fields.body:
Organising any wedding is usually very stressful. Family rows can easily erupt over anything from the numbers on your guest list to who keeps an eye on granny's gin-drinking at the reception. But David Lethbridge, co-founder of Confetti, the UK's leading wedding site, believes the web can help to substantially reduce the traditional tensions.

Chat rooms on Confetti's site let brides-to-be pour out their frustrations to one another and they can also confide in Betti, the site's online wedding agony aunt. "They want advice and they want to discuss friends and family," Lethbridge says. "Their normal network is a problem. Having an independent network is very powerful."

As well as helping its customers to tie the knot, Confetti has been busy over the last couple of months seeking new partners for itself. In September, Confetti snapped up its two arch-rivals, Wedding GuideUK.com and WebWeddings.co.uk and at a stroke became the major UK online player in a market which Forrester analysts estimate is worth about £7.6 billion annually when you take into account wedding advertising, gifts and honeymoons.

Coupled with its French site and two sister sites in Germany, Confetti is shaping up to become a major European player and appears to be advancing swiftly towards its goal of becoming an indispensable resource for people organising weddings. On the site, you can chat to online vicars, plan your budget, book limos, prepare speeches, hire venues and buy wedding dresses.

"We are doing more than 10 million page impressions across Europe a month. Six million of those are in the UK," boasts Lethbridge. But he knows that page impressions by themselves are not worth much to hard-nosed investors unless they are generating serious amounts of revenue.

Having expanded ambitiously into Europe at a time when grabbing land was the mantra of most VCs, Confetti is now consolidating and focusing on making its UK operation profitable. They hope to generate substantial revenue as the result of a major e-commerce deal which has recently been struck with the wedding list business, Burley House.

The deal gives Confetti access to a wide selection of gift products produced by a range of well-known retail partners including Jasper Conran. Another key leading gift service provider will be Marks and Spencer who have agreed to cross promote Confetti's services to their own customers.

But most significantly, the agreement with Burley House means that Confetti now owns a personalised fulfilment service which is being run out of Bradford in Yorkshire. Lethbridge can barely conceal his delight. "It's going to be a killer service," he says, adding that Confetti will have the capability to deliver wedding gifts all in one go to a bride's address rather than in dribs and drabs when they are bought from the list.

On the surface, Burley House does look like the perfect match for Confetti but analysts point out that there could be problems negotiating with the different retailers before the service goes live in January next year.

"Getting the e-commerce up and running is their next big challenge," says Forrester analyst, Rebecca Ulph. She points out that Marks and Spencer's gift offering might not be the ideal choice for all couples who often like to place their lists with different shops. Furthermore, with retailers replicating each other's gift products, Confetti faces difficult negotiations with them to agree which of their products will actually make it onto the final online list.

To generate repeat business from newly weds, Confetti plans to extend its business beyond weddings. Lethbridge says: "We believe we can keep people longer by using us for special occasions."

However analysts think the decision to diversify into special occasions such as anniversaries and birthdays needs to be carefully managed otherwise Confetti could dilute its brand and drift into potentially damaging competition with the likes of LastMinute and Expedia.

With its main UK competitors in the bag and considering the deals with Marks and Spencer and Burley House, Lethbridge believes Confetti is now virtually impregnable against any rival onslaughts. "I would not want to launch against us.There will always be niche competition but I think we will have the core share of the business."

Alafolie, the French-owned wedding organisation portal, begs to differ. Although the company claims to respect Confetti, it is making plans to launch a rival offering in the UK. "There is definitely room for another player," says Roshan Shetty, Alafolie's co-founder. "The UK is an extremely key market for us. It is a pretty big wedding market and there is high internet penetration."

Alafolie has already tried to court Confetti and at one stage there were rumours of a merger. But Alafolie's advances were spurned and now the French-owned e-business is in discussions with several potential strategic partners to try to sweep Confetti out of its primary position in the wedding marketplace . "If we take on Confetti on their own turf, we're going to have to be clever," says Shetty, who likes to portray his portal as more upmarket and far more "tasteful" than Confetti's.

Shetty rejects suggestions that a French-owned site will have difficulties shaping its content to match the customs and traditions of the UK wedding market and points out that Alafolie is already providing services to brides- to- be in Germany and Italy.

A s the online wedding market consolidates in the UK and continental players weigh up their chances of success, analysts are questioning the impact that interactive wedding sites will have on traditional UK wedding magazines. "I don't think a website will ever replace a bridal magazine. I see it as a comple mentary tool," says editor of Brides magazine, Sandra Boler. The magazine has its own web site (see www.bridesuk.net and is happy to publish adverts for Confetti which Boler does not see as a threat.

While she accepts wedding sites are efficient, she thinks they still lack the personal touch of a magazine. She says her readers have a physical relationship with Brides magazine which a site could never match. "They clutch and hold the magazine. A site is not as warm or dear or as personal."

Confetti argues that it can offer advertisers more targeted opportunities by for example giving dress makers listings on dedicated data bases but there is no evidence yet that wedding sites have made any serious impact on the advertising revenue of traditional wedding magazines. But Boler does recognise the popularity of chat rooms on wedding sites where women can talk openly with their peers.

While she replies to readers' letters as quickly as she can, she says she would never agree with someone that their mother-in-law is awful. By the end of next year Confetti expects to have become profitable. At this stage the owners claim to be doing well, but the site refuses to disclose any actual revenue figures. Whatever the true sit uation, its success as an online wedding service will depend on the scale of the response to their new gift service, its ability to fend off the appeal of a French rival, and, as the big day approaches, whether or not frustrated brides-to-be continue to complain to Confetti about their in-laws and gin-drinking grannies.

fields.headline: What the tortoise taught us
fields.standfirst: A primitive robot has been brought back to life to inspire a new generation, reports  Sanjida O'Connell
fields.trailText: A primitive robot has been brought back to life to inspire a new generation, reports Sanjida O'Connell
fields.body:
In the 1940s Dr. William Grey Walter built some of the first artificial animals. More than half a century later, these first robots are providing the inspiration for a new race of mechanical creatures.

Walter called his machines tortoises, after the tortoise in Alice in Wonderland. The mock turtle explains to Alice that "we went to school in the sea. The Master was an old turtle, we used to call him Tortoise." Alice interrupts to ask why he called him tortoise if he wasn't one. "We called him tortoise because he taught us," replies the mock turtle angrily.

Walter was one of the most distinguished neurophysiologists of his day. He developed these robot tortoises to help him understand how the brain functions. The first two, Elmer and Elsie, were cannibalised to create another six tortoises with the help of his technician, "Bunny" Warren.

Two were destroyed in a house fire in Australia, others were turned into scrap metal, or lost in transit between museums; fortunately one, possibly two, survived. Before his death, Walter passed a tortoise on to his son Nicholas, who kept it safe until Brunel University decided to repair it and use it for an exhibition in 1985. Some time later, Nicholas Walter discovered that it was about to be thrown out and rescued it; the last tortoise languished in his basement in Islington until 1995.

Then Owen Holland, from the University of the West of England, restored it to Bristol where Walter lived and worked. Holland, senior technician Ian Horsfield, and Bunny Warren, restored the turtle to working order and have built replicas.

What Walter's tortoise did was travel towards a light. He called the creature Machina speculatrix because, "it explores its environment actively, persistently, systematically, as most animals do". Most of the time the robot behaved as expected, but when put in front of a mirror, it began "flickering, twittering and jigging like a clumsy narcissus," wrote Walter.

He argued that this behaviour was evidence of self-awareness. Most scientists today do not believe robots can show self-awareness, but as Holland says, "Walter wanted to prove that rich connections between a small number of brain cells produces very rich behaviour." Few of Walter's theories about neurophysiology and the brain are respected today, but his work on the artificial animals has taken on new life. Even more importantly, the tortoises helped scientists to realise that complex behaviour can be generated by using just a few components, and that biological principles can be applied to the field of robotics.

These lessons have been taken to heart by the intelligent autonomous systems laboratory at the University of the West of England where a replica of Walter's tortoise is housed in its original hutch. The first thing one sees when one walks into the robotics laboratory, is a large arena full of robots bumbling around, carrying out seemingly purposeless tasks. These U-bots, as they're called, have no eyes, they can't count, they don't know who they are, and they're not aware of anyone or anything else, yet they manage to sort coloured plates into piles of the correct colour. It takes them hours, but they get there in the end.

They are an example of an intelligent robot according to Dr Chris Melhuish, a director of the lab. They are "doing the right thing an adequate amount of times," he says, which is his current definition of intelligence. Strangely, for the director of a robotics department, he doesn't seem to know what a robot is. The definition he eventually settles on is that robots are "a collection of technologies, probably mobile, hopefully autonomous, capable of acting on the environment in a seemingly goal oriented way." By trial and error, Melhuish and his team came up with four very simple rules which enabled the U-bots to carry out their task adequately.

According to him, the robots behave like ants. "Ants are a miracle of evolution and engineering," he says. "An individual isn't very sophisticated and isn't capable of doing very much on its own, but put 20 million army ants together and watch out! They're capable of work scheduling, seeking their own energy, building homes and looking after the brood. They carry out everything that goes on in a city, and yet no single ant has the blue-print for their workload." In Antz, the movie, the queen constantly issued instructions, but this is not what happens in an ant colony. "Ant colonies are actually examples of a wonderful de- centralised intelligence," says Melhuish, "without consciousness and self-awareness. They are our inspiration."

The lab also houses a small group of robots; Jason Welsby, the PhD student who created them, was inspired, not by ants, but by birds. The robots themselves look neither like birds nor even vaguely like robots. Called Blimps, they're small helium balloons with propellers and a battery slung beneath. They float in small silver flocks round the lab. Each one uses ultrasound to determine how far away the floor and the ceiling are. They keep track of each other with infrared transmitters and receivers and they follow three very simple rules: (1) Keep together; (2) Head in the same general direction and (3) Don't stay too close to other individuals. It sounds like a motto for the office.

"The hardware is not particularly useful because it's very vulnerable. The robots can't travel outside," says Welsby, "but the software could be useful." He envisages more robust robots being sent to disaster areas to sweep paths looking for survivors. He adds: "They could also be used in space exploration. You could send 50 together - it doesn't matter that some will die."

Animal behaviourist Professor David McFarland has recently joined the lab from Oxford University. He says: "My main aim is to make self-sufficient robots that do real things in the real world. They'll get their energy from somewhere, they'll make decisions outside of human control, and they'll be able to travel in the ocean, in space, in nuclear reactors - all those places where people don't want to go." McFarland is working on an undersea robot project. These robots will shoal like fish: they will dive into the sea, communicate with each other, collect data on salinity, temperature, tidal currents, etc, and send their data back to researchers via satellites. He imagines they will get their energy from tidal currents.

There is another way of making self-sufficient robots: these would actually ingest food just as animals do. For instance, the undersea robots might feed on plankton. Melhuish, McFarland and researcher Dr Ian Kelly are in the process of creating a Slugbot which will obtain its energy by eating slugs. This is the theory, but they admit progress is somewhat slow: the Slugbot has yet to take as much as a nibble out of a garden pest.

A little further down the line of munching robots is the Gastrobot, created by Dr Stuart Wilkinson from the University of South Florida, Tampa. His robots convert carbohydrates found in food into an electrical form. They do this by exploiting the metabolising power of micro-organisms, such as bacteria or yeast. "Bio-electro chemical processes are harnessed in a device called a microbial fuel cell containing selected microbes. Such a living battery can be made self- sustaining with just an input of food, water and air," says Wilkinson.

However, like a small horse, the researchers have to feed it sugar lumps. "What we're interested in is a robot predator," says Melhuish, "robots that go out and find their own energy like wild animals." Eventually he and his team hope to create working flocks or shoals of robots, not particularly intelligent, but certainly "small, cheap, cheerful, replenishable, mass produced and homogenous".

One of his ideas is to develop a type of electrically activated polymer, a substance that would act almost like muscle. Melhuish envisages teams of worm-like robots, cleaning out escalators for instance. In the dark they would burrow about randomly eating grime. If someone shone a light into the escalator's innards, they would move towards it where they could be relieved of their dirt, or thrown away while new creatures are added.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
We got email
Louis Halpern's article, You've got email: are you using it? (Online November 30) misses out one element that I come across every day working in the internal comms side for a large company.

Emails take up a lot of the bandwidth and storage space of hard drives. By sticking to plain text format emails, you can reduce the amount of bytes needed to send and store the message - thus minimising the cost of maintaining email systems and download times especially for people accessing via a modem.

Including graphics and logos, and using the other features available in packages such as Outlook, as suggested by the author, and presumably also Edesigns.co.uk, greatly increases the space and bandwidth required.

This also eliminates people who use text-only email.
Name and address supplied.

I dread the day when every email comes with a company logo, as if there were not enough of the wretched things infecting public space already. More HTML, more attachments, more time to download emails - and more nooks for viruses to hide in.
David Harris,
Wheatley, Oxon

Halpern and Edesign are quite wrong to suggest that using branded emails would demonstrate professionalism in communications.

Their insight is a description of a potentially virulent development of e-junk mail. In fact the beauty of real email communication is the relief at not having to create a "professional" logo-dominated letter.

Professional communications are judged on content not on design. Our emails are not indistinguishable because they have no logo. That is sheer advertising hype!
Anthony Hoskyns
hoskyns@btinternet.com

Despite reading like a bit of advertorial, Louis Halpern (CEO of the only company mentioned in the article) makes some very useful points about how to approach writing business emails.

He moves on to discuss how to "brand" email but forgoes the analysis and precise recommendations of the earlier part of the article.

"Your logo says a lot about your business" is the only insight presented about email branding. Considering that the discussion about branding in the real world moved on from logos almost 20 years ago this appears banal.

Moreover, inserting a logo into an email requires using non-ASCII formats, which could result in recipients receiving a screenful of HTML - not very brand-friendly. If your intended recipients are on a dialup connection then opening such an email may force their modem to make an unrequested phone call.

Better that clients learn about potential recipients and brief their designers to apply their brand accordingly. If this requires using ASCII-formatted email then so be it.
Nico Macdonald ,
London WC2

No sale
Do all of your correspondents have shares in Tesco? We tried Tesco shopping and were very disappointed. It took over two hours to choose our shopping from the typed list.

When we placed our order we had to wait two days for a delivery slot. When the order arrived 16 items were missing, many of them needed for that night's meal.

You cannot beat choosing your own produce. The time taken to place our order over the internet was the same as going to the supermarket.

We have tried Sainsbury's with just a fraction more success.
Sandra Worden
thewordens@ic24.net

System wars
Is the Feedback column really the best place for platform and OS sniping? (Alun Griffiths, Online, November 30).

The views expressed by such snipers usually amount to little more than this: "I know this system really well - it's great; I know that one not at all - it sucks."

The truth is that Apple excels in hype, and Microsoft excels in marketing, but in reality, neither product is nearly as good as it should be. I have hopes for Mac OS X, which I understand will be Apple's first fully-featured modern operating system.

Then again, I've believed Apple's hype before...
Huw Thomas
hthomas@cix.co.uk

Thanks to Alun Griffiths for providing such a good example of the stunning ignorance of Mac users. Of course you can drag and drop files or folders around anywhere you want in Windows.

In fact, Windows offers greater flexibility, especially with right mouse click functionality and in open and save dialogue boxes, than with the overrated and overpriced Mac system.
D Hill,
London W12

Now I know why Mac users are sceptical about Linux. Like Alun Griffiths, I have an iMac. It runs a full RDBMS, web server, software development tools, graphics packages, email server, network file server and is an internet gateway allowing it and a W98 box to connect together over a single dialup line.

But I haven't come across anything that allows me to drag and drop files around anywhere I want.

Thanks, Alun, for reminding what an excellent system Linux really is.
Julian Rawcliffe
julian.rawcliffe@ntlworld.com

In reply to Alun Griffiths, it should be fairly evident that "D:\data" is the name of a directory (or folder if you prefer) that someone might reasonably create, in this case on a logical drive "D".

Logical drives are quite a useful feature once you get used to taking advantage of them, and as a result are increasingly less supported by Microsoft.

It certainly is possible to set up hierarchies of directories as you like on a PC, but with each new release of Windows it appears more and more that Microsoft wishes to bully or nanny users away from making sensible choices.

Having just moved to Windows 98 I find myself tearing my hair out at the operating system's insistence on trying to force files into places with twee names like My Little Documents and My Little Computer.

I haven't seen My Little Pony yet but I'm sure it's there.
Roger Musson Edinburgh

webTitle: Speech highlights crime as Labour sets sights on May election

fields.headline: Speech highlights crime as Labour sets sights on May election
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday defended his government's legislative programme from accusations of blatant electioneering by challenging voters to demonstrate the "individual responsibility" needed to make Labour's vision of the good society become a reality.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday defended his government's legislative programme from accusations of blatant electioneering by challenging voters to demonstrate the "individual responsibility" needed to make Labour's vision of the good society become a reality.

During brutal exchanges across the Commons dispatch box after the ritual pomp and flummery of the annual Queen's speech ceremonies, both the prime minister and William Hague provided abundantly clear outlines of the campaigns they plan to run once the date of the coming general election is fixed - probably for May 3.

The government's emphasis on fighting "yob culture" - notably public drunkenness - on NHS reforms, and another attack on welfare fraud, prompted an immediate charge that ministers are obsessed with "clearing the decks", their eyes fixed firmly on the Middle England segment of Labour's winning 1997 coalition of voters.

The Conservative leader, who repeatedly accused Mr Blair of being "all spin and no delivery" and wasting £25bn worth of extra taxes, joked that it was "very good of her majesty to come down here and deliver" her speech, considering how "thin" it was.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, echoed Mr Hague's complaint that the speech was "unambitious" in terms of the most urgent problems facing voters - crumbling schools, hospitals, transport and police services. The prime minister doggedly refused to plead guilty.

So short is the time now available for reforming legislation that the speech read from the throne contained only 15 bills and four draft bills, which will not be enacted unless unexpected calamity forces Labour election strategists to postpone their bid for a second full term until October or - the 11th hour - spring 2002.

But, if the speech itself contained no content that had not been heavily trailed in advance, Mr Blair did surprise some MPs - in boisterous election mood on both sides - by the contempt he showed for the Conservative leader and his advisers.

"Good jokes, lousy judgment," Mr Blair explained, in contrast to his own earnest appeal to the electorate to transcend narrow self-interest. With voter apathy and cynicism leaving ministers worried that their biggest enemy is stay-at-home voters - not the Tories - Mr Blair set out what aides call chapter four of Labour's campaign "narrative" and coupled it with an appeal for responsibility.

After putting the economy on a stable path, tackling hard-core unemployment via Gordon Brown's welfare-to-work schemes and what he called "mending our schools", this fourth Queen's speech package was about crime and health: five bills on everything from car crime to social security fraud, plus a wide-ranging health and social care bill to implement last summer' s ambitious NHS plan.

In his keynote message Mr Blair told MPs: "Across all these areas there is a clear narrative to what we have achieved. Laying the foundations of economic stability, getting people off welfare and into work, investing in public services, all of it designed to build opportunity.

"What this Queen's speech does is then, in return for that opportunity, [demand] responsibility. We are giving the police the powers they need, and we are giving the people the support they need to win back their communities," he claimed.

To Mr Hague, in a long but witty speech, that was simply more hot air. In a crucial counterblast, later hammered home by the shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, he complained: "Police numbers have been cut, offences are up and 20,000 criminals have been realised early to offend again."

"Without adequate police numbers all this will come to nothing," the shadow home secretary predicted on Channel 4 as ministers spoke of community involvement in fighting crime and antisocial behaviour.

The Conservative leader accused Mr Blair personally of routinely abandoning everything he has claimed to believe in over 20 years in public life and said that the government's executive arrogance was responsible for "the least considered legislation in the history of the country". NHS waiting lists, transport "chaos" and the storm clouds over this weekend's EU summit in Nice all provided Mr Hague with targets. "It is designed to produce better headlines, not better public services," he said of yesterday's package.

But his failure to address seriously either the economy or alternative Tory policies allowed Mr Blair to puncture him without much difficulty. Mocking Mr Hague's tax-and-spend package he quipped: "If they want to save £1 bn on fraud they should start with their own programme."

Mr Blair rattled off details of the Conservative legacy after 18 years in power - from "cock-eyed" rail privatisation to 15% mortgages and leaking school roofs - and predicted: "We will not forget. More important, neither will the country."

Focus group findings and opinion polls, which have seen Labour bounce back to a 10% lead - according to an ICMGuardian survey last week - after the Tory bounce during the fuel crisis, suggest he is right. Labour and Tory MPs are starting to wonder if Mr Blair may increase his 179-seat majority in 1997.

While Tory MPs on both left and right brace themselves for a second hammering at the polls, Labour strategists are puzzled by Mr Hague's failure to make a serious impact on public opinion. "His combination of 19th parliamentarian and 21st century management consultant should have been ideal," conceded one.

"Without adequate police numbers all this will come to nothing," the shadow home secretary predicted on Channel 4 as ministers spoke of community involvement in fighting crime and antisocial behaviour. The Conservative leader accused Mr Blair personally of routinely abandoning everything he has claimed to believe in over 20 years in public life and said that the government's executive arrogance was responsible for "the least considered legislation in the history of the country". NHS waiting lists, transport "chaos" and the storm clouds over this weekend's EU summit in Nice all provided Mr Hague with targets. "It is designed to produce better headlines, not better public services," he said of yesterday's package. But his failure to address seriously either the economy or alternative Tory policies allowed Mr Blair to puncture him without much difficulty. Mocking Mr Hague's tax-and-spend package he quipped: "If they want to save £1 bn on fraud they should start with their own programme." Mr Blair rattled off details of the Conservative legacy after 18 years in power - from "cock-eyed" rail privatisation to 15% mortgages and leaking school roofs - and predicted: "We will not forget. More important, neither will the country." Focus group findings and opinion polls, which have seen Labour bounce back to a 10% lead - according to an ICMGuardian survey last week - after the Tory bounce during the fuel crisis, suggest he is right. Labour and Tory MPs are starting to wonder if Mr Blair may increase his 179-seat majority in 1997. While Tory MPs on both left and right brace themselves for a second hammering at the polls, Labour strategists are puzzled by Mr Hague's failure to make a serious impact on public opinion. "His combination of 19th parliamentarian and 21st century management consultant should have been ideal," conceded one. webTitle: Arms to Iraq inquiry affects control on exports

fields.headline: Arms to Iraq inquiry affects control on exports
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Campaigners against the arms trade yesterday voiced concern that the government is still refusing to allow parliament proper scrutiny of exports.
fields.body:
Campaigners against the arms trade yesterday voiced concern that the government is still refusing to allow parliament proper scrutiny of exports.

Parliamentary control would increase transparency in a notoriously secret area. But the Department of Trade and Industry is refusing to contemplate handing over to a Commons select committee power to look at all applications for arms exports licences.

At present almost anyone in the UK can set up as an arms dealer, virtually free of control. The government promised yesterday to bring forward an arms exports control bill but signalled that time was unlikely to be found in the coming parliamentary session.

The bill aims to close the loopholes exposed by the arms-to-Iraq inquiry that allow allow arms to be exported worldwide without proper control. A draft bill is scheduled for the spring.

The export control bill will replace legislation that has not fundamentally changed since 1939 and will put in place many recommendations made by Sir Richard Scott in his 1996 arms- to-Iraq report. The bill would:

 introduce controls on trafficking and brokering in weapons, including light weapons and small arms;

 prohibit trafficking and brokering of torture equipment;

 provide new powers to prohibit any trafficking and brokering of the equipment covered by embargo;

 introduce controls on export of military technology by "fax, email and telephone and, in relation to weapons of mass destruction, by person". Existing export controls are restricted to export of intellectual property by paper or computer discs.

Arms campaigners expressed disappointment that the government was not proposing to legislate in the coming parliamentary session. Andy McLean, a spokesman for Saferworld, said he was disappointed that the government would not give a parliamentary committee the right to look at export licences before the DTI gave permission.

webTitle: Medical errors led to diabetes death

fields.headline: Medical errors led to diabetes death
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old woman with diabetes died because of a catalogue of errors by GPs and a hospital trust, according to a special report from the health service ombudsman published yesterday, reinforcing anxiety about the way diabetics are cared for in the NHS.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old woman with diabetes died because of a catalogue of errors by GPs and a hospital trust, according to a special report from the health service ombudsman published yesterday, reinforcing anxiety about the way diabetics are cared for in the NHS.

The woman, referred to only as Miss J in the ombudsman's report, was diagnosed as suffering from mature-onset diabetes of the young, known as MODY, in July 1996. This condition, now called type 2 diabetes in the young, is on the rise in the UK in parallel with the increase in obesity and has become a major concern in the United States. Sufferers do not need insulin, but control their symptoms by diet.

However, the ombudsman found that Miss J had probably been misdiagnosed by a consultant who jumped too swiftly to his conclusion. She was probably suffering from type 1 diabetes, which event-ually needs insulin.

The following summer, Miss J felt unwell, and visited three GPs, none of whom tested her blood or urine for signs that she was losing control of her diabetes, even though she told them all that she was diabetic. All diagnosed gastritis.

But the day after her third consultation, Miss J was admitted to hospital suffering from ketoacidosis, a dangerous condition relating to insulin-dependent diabetes. She was admitted to intensive care.

The ombudsman, Michael Buckley, found that, at Halton General Hospitals NHS Trust, there was confusion within the intensive care unit as to which consultant was responsible for her, which led to "a degree of confusion and a lack of leadership to doctors in training".

Miss J complained of a headache, but nursing staff did not pay enough attention to her concerns or those of her family. She was not improving, but nobody reviewed the treatment she was getting. Early the following morning, she collapsed and was put on life support. A brain scan revealed cerebral oedema, a swelling inside the skull which is a rare side effect of ketoacidosis. She died on 31 July 1997.

The ombudsman concluded that there were a number of mistakes, beginning with Miss J's diagnosis. "Avoiding any of these mistakes would have improved Miss J's chance of survival. It is not possible for me to say that one or more of these mistakes individually led to her death; but together they almost certainly did."

fields.headline: Parents mourn on Damilola's birthday
fields.standfirst:
Father says murdered boy had told of bullying torment 'to the point where he could not bear it any more'
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Damilola Taylor would have been 11 today. His parents Richard and Gloria made a real fuss of him last year, hosting a party and pantomime, so he was expecting less of a celebration this time round.
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor would have been 11 today. His parents Richard and Gloria made a real fuss of him last year, hosting a party and pantomime, so he was expecting less of a celebration this time round.

But Mr and Mrs Taylor still had a treat or two in store for their "lovely, innocent boy". One was a Bible - a present he had asked for.

They also wanted to buy him biscuits and chocolates to take to Oliver Goldsmith primary school to share with his classmates - something of a tradition for children in Nigeria.

Instead of sharing his excitement, Mr and Mrs Taylor will mourn him this morning at a service in Southwark, south London, and pray those same schoolfriends provide detectives with the clues that will catch his killer.

Yesterday, Mr Taylor, 55, spoke of the son he lost on Monday last week in a series of interviews at Scotland Yard.

He broke down once, but gathered himself quickly to de scribe how he missed Damilola, his expectation of "traditional British justice", and his sadness that his son - "who must have suffered terribly" - was bullied at school for being good, diligent and hardworking.

"It is not the prayer of any parent to outlive their children and have to witness this calamity... it will be the sad part of our lives which will remain with us forever.

"I cannot tell you how aggrieved I am at the sad loss of Damilola, my last son and child. His mother wanted him and he took 10 years to come and he gave us only 10 years of happiness.

"I cannot imagine where his body is but I am sure his soul is in a happier place. We all miss this lovely boy and I think my life can never be the same without Damilola."

Mr Taylor was in Nigeria when his son was found in a stairwell leading to the North Hordle Promenade of the North Peckham estate in Southwark.

He had been stabbed once in the left leg, probably with a knife, as he walked along nearby Blake's Road. The wound had cut his femoral artery, causing uncontrollable bleeding.

Four months ago, Damilola moved to London with his mother because his sister needed treatment at a London hospital. Mr Taylor, a Nigerian ministry of defence manager working in Lagos, knew he was finding it difficult to settle.

In phone calls to Nigeria, Damilola told his father he was being taunted and bullied. "They were harassing him, beating him up, calling him names. They were scratching him with implements.

"It got to the point that he could not bear it anymore. Whenever he wanted to play, they used to beat him up. He told me he was being bullied.

"He was crying. He was being called names and he was being called 'gay' and said [to me] 'what is gay?' In our country the name is not used by kids."

Mr Taylor said his spirit broke when he visited the spot where Damilola died.

"There was no one to help, no one to take him to hospital."

Mr Taylor said he had been horrified by the housing and poverty on the North Peckham estate. He said the UK seemed to have changed since he lived in Middlesex in the 1970s.

"I never saw violence or a child attacked. It was peaceful. Since I have arrived here I do not think I have seen a policeman on the beat.

"They used to come round and find out your problems. They were friendly. That is not the situation now. That must have led to the deterioration of family values."

Damilola, he said, had led a disciplined life "cut short by the acts of persons who could never have thought that his life was of great value to us.

"We think the killers should be caught immediately. Somebody somewhere knows something and for some reason is sheltering the perpetrators of this crime. If [they] are not brought to justice in time, the crime will be repeated," he said.

"Somebody like me will come up to make an appeal. The police must be given all assistance to investigate this case."

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt said a new witness had seen three youths, aged between 12 and 14, in Blake's Road moments before Damilola was stabbed. He said they may have "crucial" evidence and urged them to come forward.

webTitle: Church seeks to ease Carey's burden

fields.headline: Church seeks to ease Carey's burden
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Church of England is being asked to consider appointing a third archbishop to help relieve the burden of work on the Archbishop of Canterbury.
fields.body:
The Church of England is being asked to consider appointing a third archbishop to help relieve the burden of work on the Archbishop of Canterbury.

The church, whose congregations have declined to fewer than a million Sunday worshippers in recent years, is also being urged to think about appointing as its next candidate for the see of Canterbury an archbishop from outside England for the first time in its modern history.

That could in turn pave the way to the first black archbishop - there is at least one potential candidate from withing the Church of England - though not the first woman as the church, unlike some Anglican congregations overseas, has not yet got round to appointing female bishops.

The proposals were outlined yesterday in a consultation paper drawn up by a committee headed by the Conservative former foreign secretary Lord Hurd, set up this year to review the Archbishop of Canterbury's workload and make recommendations about how it could be eased.

Beside being Primate of All England, the archbishop is also diocesan bishop of Canterbury, metropolitan of the southern province of the Church of England and leader of the worldwide Anglican communion.

Although previous archbishops have periodically considered reforming their role, the Hurd committee is the first systematic review.

George Carey, the current incumbent, said: "This document is a necessary first step along the road... it will be right to await the considered conclusions and recommendations in due course.

"I set up this review because I judged it was an opportune moment to take a measured look at the future development of the office of archbishop of Canterbury in a changing world."

The consultation paper said that the church might consider reducing the archbishop's burden by delegating more responsibilities to other senior bishops such as London and Winchester or by splitting the two provinces of England into three more equal parts.

Lord Hurd's committee is calling for responses from church members by the end of February and is due to firm up its recommendations in a final report next summer.

fields.headline: Hunting ban 'possible by next summer'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Hunting with dogs faces an outside chance of being finally banned by next summer, a leading anti-blood sports MP predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
Hunting with dogs faces an outside chance of being finally banned by next summer, a leading anti-blood sports MP predicted yesterday.

Mike Foster, the Worcester Labour MP who attempted to get a private member's bill banning hunting through the Commons, said the government's decision to promote legislation could signal the end of the blood sport within a few months.

"If we get some early stages (of the bill) through before Christmas this could mean that hunting with dogs could be in its last season," he said.

But he hinted it was more likely that the Lords would obstruct legislation, thus making hunting an issue during the forthcoming general election campaign. He warned peers against blocking a bill which probably would get widespread support after the independent Burns inquiry raised questions about the blood sport and encouraged a lively national debate on the subject.

But the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance warned last night it was going ahead with a "massive" civil liberties demonstration in London on March 18 next year, in response to the government's inclusion of an "options" bill in the Queen's Speech.

The bill will offer MPs three options: an outright ban on all forms of hunting with dogs, more limited statutory regulation or self-regulation.

Richard Burge, chief executive of the alliance, criticised the government for including hunting in the Queen's Speech while failing to address a crisis in rural Britain with no hint of how to push forward ideas in last week's rural white paper. He said the bill would simply curtail a rural minorities civil liberty with no benefits to the rural majority or for animal welfare. "We will not sit back and allow the prejudice and bigotry of MPs to triumph."

Douglas Batchelor, chairman of the Deadline 2000 campaign against hunting and chief executive of the League Against Cruel Sports, said only an outright ban would be satisfactory. "It is impossible to regulate cruelty. This is an historic opportunity to finally end this cruel and barbaric practice which has no place in a modern society. Parliament has debated hunting many times before but never with a government bill and a guarantee of parliamentary time."

webTitle: Blair bid to avert EU stalemate

fields.headline: Blair bid to avert EU stalemate
fields.standfirst:
PM sees enlargement as priority in reform agenda

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair flies to the EU summit in Nice today with his officials saying they are willing to engage in yet another round of negotiations on EU institutional reform in four years' time - but only if this does not delay the goal of enlarging the union to the east.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Nice and  Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Tony Blair flies to the EU summit in Nice today with his officials saying they are willing to engage in yet another round of negotiations on EU institutional reform in four years' time - but only if this does not delay the goal of enlarging the union to the east.

If the leaders at Nice defer an issue as key as voting weights on the council of ministers, however, the summit will be open to the accusation that after much fanfare it ended with important matters unresolved, as did the Amsterdam summit in 1997.

Downing Street is trying to portray itself almost as a bystander in an essentially Franco-German row over voting rights on the council of ministers, the senior body of political decision-makers from EU member states. The Germans are seeking more seats than the French on the council, on grounds of population. Paris regards this as a threat to the whole post-war Franco-German settlement.

The Germans and the Italians are pressing for another round of reform in 2004. Downing Street believes a further inter-governmental conference - the rolling process through which structural reform is negotiated in the EU - can be used to project the British agenda of an end to further integration.

In the short term, Mr Blair goes to what is being billed as potentially the longest and most difficult summit in the turbulent history of the EU determined to defend the British veto in key areas on which the council of ministers votes. He believes he can return home without having done political damage to him or Labour.

Britain's prime minister will insist that any reform agenda after the Nice summit must be formulated in a way that does not delay the enlargement of the EU to formerly communist countries such as Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

He will argue that further negotiations can start only once the likes of Poland have joined, though perhaps before their membership has passed the long ratification process.

The British will resist demands by Germany, Italy and other integrationist-minded countries for the EU's charter of fundamental rights to be incorporated in a future treaty.

The charter, watered down to remove significant social or economic rights after a long offensive spearheaded by Britain, is signed in Nice today.

As thousands of banner-waving protesters converged on the Cote d'Azur, speculation mounted about a deal under which Germany and France would retain an equal number of votes in the council of ministers in return for agreement that a future inter-governmental conference will undertake more changes.

Diplomats said it might be politically impossible for President Jacques Chirac to give Chancellor Gerhard Schröder even a symbolic margin of votes in ministerial councils, despite Germany having added 20m people since reunification a decade ago.

Mr Schröder's key political aim in any new negotiations over changes to EU structures would be to put clear bound aries around EU institutional competences, so it is clear how power is distributed between the council of ministers, the nation-state and the region.

The Nice summit is likely to go into the small hours of Sunday morning. No agreement is expected until the last minute on the three stickiest items: vote reweighting, the size of the European commission and extension of qualified majority voting.

Writing in today's Guardian, Romano Prodi, president of the commission, insists he does not seek majority voting on tax in sensitive areas.

"I understand how sensitive taxation policy is some countries. So let's be clear: I do not believe, and I am not proposing, that the EU should set tax levels in the member states. They are a matter for national budgets. I am not against a reasonable degree of tax competition, either, which is essential for a healthy economy and good for consumers.

"I do, however, believe that we must begin to take some tax decisions by majority vote, where only this will keep the single market operating smoothly. These are modest changes." But Mr Blair remains opposed to any erosion of the national veto over tax and social security. Most other countries, including France, have their own no-go areas, but some movement is still expected.

"I do, however, believe that we must begin to take some tax decisions by majority vote, where only this will keep the single market operating smoothly. These are modest changes." But Mr Blair remains opposed to any erosion of the national veto over tax and social security. Most other countries, including France, have their own no-go areas, but some movement is still expected.

fields.headline: Transport staff face drinks curbs
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Measures to improve safety on the railways and tackle alcohol and drug use by transport workers could come into place after legislative plans were unveiled yesterday.
fields.body:
Measures to improve safety on the railways and tackle alcohol and drug use by transport workers could come into place after legislative plans were unveiled yesterday.

A safety bill is to be drafted which will take in the recommendations of Lord Cullen's inquiry into rail safety in the wake of the Ladbroke Grove rail crash.

But the inquiry is not expected to report back until after the election - ensuring the bill cannot go through parliament before then and leading the Tories to accuse the government of missing an opportunity to crack on.

The draft bill also aims to align controls on drug and alcohol use by cabin crew, air traffic controllers and shipping personnel with those in place on the railways and roads. Blood alcohol limits will be introduced for staff in civil aviation and shipping and police will be able to test those they suspect of drinking, as well as conducting tests for drugs.

Police powers will also be extended so that on the roads they can test drivers they suspect of drug abuse.

Increased penalties for road traffic offences are also promised, though the final details have not yet been worked out.

On the seas and in harbours, the safety standards will be improved, while fire authorities will be able to recover costs when fighting fires on boats.

The bill also aims to "revitalise" health and safety at work, bringing in more stringent penalties and ensuring public bodies are no longer exempt from being prosecuted if an accident occurs on their premises.

Last night, the proposed bill was welcomed by the Rail Maritime and Transport union, while the train drivers' union Aslef stressed it hoped it would include provision for the widespread introduction of the automatic train protection system.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who has come under sustained attack for failures in the transport system, admitted: "There have been a number of disturbing safety issues raised in recent years, both among the travelling public and in the workplace.

But he insisted: "We are determined to do something about this. This bill should go a long way to making life safer for both workers and travellers."

webTitle: Commons motion tabled on reform of laws of succession

fields.headline: Commons motion tabled on reform of laws of succession
fields.standfirst:
Join the debate online
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: A Commons motion is to be tabled today calling for the repeal of the 299-year-old Act of Settlement that excludes Roman Catholics, Muslims and other non-Protestants from succeeding to the throne.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Nicholas Watt  and Stephen Bates
fields.body:
A Commons motion is to be tabled today calling for the repeal of the 299-year-old Act of Settlement that excludes Roman Catholics, Muslims and other non-Protestants from succeeding to the throne.

The motion, which will be put down by the Scottish National party, will say that such discrimination has "no place in modern society". The motion is expected to attract support from across the political spectrum.

The move came as the debate on the future role of the monarchy, initiated by the Guardian with a call for a referendum on whether the head of state should be elected after the present queen's death, gathered momentum yesterday: most of the focus was around the Act of Settlement.

Downing Street refused to rule out the possibility of legislative change in the future, but said that it would require nine acts of parliament to be amended. "It would be wrong to suggest that the government supports discrimination against Catholics," the spokesman said. "But the legislative problems associated with this are great. We are not saying never. But we are not saying now."

Buckingham Palace reacted diplomatically yesterday, noting that the Queen had had a busy day, with the state opening of parliament in the morning and a function at the British Museum in the evening. But a source at the palace, asked if the Queen had read the Guardian, replied: "Everybody here has read it."

Stressing that the Queen was a constitutional monarch, a spokesman said: "A lot of points made are not actually for Buckingham Palace to answer but are for the government and other organisations to consider." By other organisations, the Palace meant the Church of England.

He added: "Buckingham Palace will follow this debate with interest."

The Scottish National party put down a motion in the Scottish parliament yesterday expressing regret that Westminster had not followed Holyrood's lead last December in calling for removal of "institutionalised discrimination".

Mike Russell, an SNP member of the Scottish parliament, said: "The time for talk on this matter is surely over, and the time for action is now."

In the Commons, as MPs were summoned by Black Rod to hear the Queen deliver her speech in the Lords, Dennis Skinner, the Labour left-winger, quipped: "Tell her to read the Guardian."

Another Labour MP, Norman Godman, a mainstream Labour MP who is a member of the Commons foreign affairs committee, said he was likely to sign today's motion. There was no place for discrimination: "It needs a vigorous assault or the government will meander along with a system that is out of kilter with the 21st century."

The Liberal Democrats' leader, Charles Kennedy, came out in support of change. The Conservatives, while reluctant to be seen as backing the act, suggested it would be best to leave things alone. But the party's view is far from unanimous.

The debate created as much of a dilemma for the right-wing, monarchy-supporting media as it did in the Conservative party.

The editor of the Daily Telegraph, Charles Moore, a strong royalist, said on the BBC World Service when asked to justify legislation that allowed only Protestants to be the monarch, he did not feel any offence, even though he was a Catholic. He saw the issue as Church of England reform.

In sign of the muddle that the issue has created, he said: "I think that a Catholic or a Jew or a Muslim could, in fact, be the supreme commander of the Church of England."

The Archbishop of Canterbury's press secretary said: "We are very aware of the human rights issue, but that is by no means the only factor."

The editor of the Guardian, Alan Rusbridger, last night wrote to the attorney general challenging him to prosecute him under the Treason Felony Act of 1848 for supporting a republican government.

webTitle: Royal variety performance brings the house down

fields.headline: Royal variety performance brings the house down
fields.standfirst: Join the debate online
fields.trailText: A copy of yesterday's Guardian tucked in my back pocket, I went to the gallery in the House of Lords. I was anxious. As the only representative of Britain's leading republican organ, I would be face to face with the Queen. Admittedly 100 yards away, but her glare can famously carry further than a 12-bore cartridge from a Purdey. And  if she misses, she wrings your neck.
fields.body:
A copy of yesterday's Guardian tucked in my back pocket, I went to the gallery in the House of Lords. I was anxious. As the only representative of Britain's leading republican organ, I would be face to face with the Queen. Admittedly 100 yards away, but her glare can famously carry further than a 12-bore cartridge from a Purdey. And if she misses, she wrings your neck.

Exile to Australia is the traditional punishment for lese- majeste. The worst could happen! I might not be transported, so would have to spend winter here, lashed with rain, unable even to take a train somewhere nice.

But the state opening is still an astonishing sight. Bench after bench of ambassadors' and peers' wives gleaming, glittering and shimmering in the TV lights. Yards of silk, of silver and gold thread, of spandex, of lurex, and for all I know, Durex. All that big hair, some festooned with tiaras, as if they'd been walking past a Christmas tree and the baubles stuck. Necklaces, chokers, brooches, bodices and pashminas: the effect was of a Miss World 40th anniversary reunion party.

One peer, plump, jolly Angela Billingham (Labour), flapped her arms and even tried to get a Mexican wave started. But some standards remain, and instead they went for a chorus of "Who ate all the pies?" (I made that last bit up, as you well know.)

I scanned the ambassadors. Japan, maybe explaining how their monarchy had held them back, making it impossible to sell cars and cameras abroad. In the corner, Luxembourg, per capita the world's richest country, but still a monarchy. Not Guardian readers, perhaps.

As we waited, I wondered idly what all these mysterious heralds and royal household members do for the rest of the year. Garter King of Arms presumably runs a sex toy empire, like Anne Summers. The Keeper of Her Majesty's Privy Purse stores 20p pieces in case she's caught short. The Master of the Rolls selects the Lord Chancellor's wallpaper.

The Cap of Maintenance gives birth control advice, and the present holder, Baroness Jay, looks like someone who dispenses calm rational help to distressed teenage girls. Gold Stick in Waiting sells throat spray.

And then Fitzalan Pursuivant Extraordinary - I hesitate to say this, but I bet he and George Michael would have a lot to talk about. (No, sorry, Mr Alastair Bruce of Crionaich, just a joke! We're not against all medieval flummery at the Guardian!)

The Queen arrived and there was the traditional wait for the MPs, so we sat like passengers on a stranded train. In the Commons, Dennis Skinner sent his colleagues off, yelling "Tell 'er to read the Guardian!" In the west gallery someone laughed out loud at something or other. You could be topped for that once.

At last the MPs arrived, sounding in the distance like an invading army of football hooligans. Lord Irvine produced a huge brocade satchel thing (I like to think of him fighting through the mobe, the car keys and the Zubes) and produced the speech.

As ever, she fought her way wearily through the cliches - she looks more tired every year, and her head nodded a lot, sending a meteor shower of dazzling diamond reflections over us. "Economic objectives of high and stable growth", "improving the framework for meeting special educational needs" and "significant initiatives" she somehow mouthed.

Derry Irvine walked unsteadily up the steps again, collected the speech and then, with special permission, turned his back on her to shuffle down. It seemed an awful lot of fuss just to hear another Alastair Campbell press release.

fields.headline: Trawling for abuse victims defended
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Police yesterday defended the trawling methods used in investigating past abuse in children's homes and said they would continue to use them despite criticism that they were touting for victims.
fields.body:
Police yesterday defended the trawling methods used in investigating past abuse in children's homes and said they would continue to use them despite criticism that they were touting for victims.

After the former manager of Southampton football club, David Jones, was cleared of care home child abuse when his trial collapsed because an alleged victim refused to give evidence, campaigners for falsely accused carers said the "dip sampling" method used to collect evidence could lead to people fabricating stories of abuse to get compensation.

Under the method, used by Merseyside police who led the investigation against Mr Jones, officers first receive a written statement of complaint about past abuse at an institution. Police then "dip sample" people who attended the institution as children, writing to or interviewing them asking if they remember any abuse.

The assistant chief constable, Mike Tonge, of Merseyside police, said: "There is no other method of doing it. If an allegation was made about a crime committed this week, police would conduct house to house inquiries, stage reconstructions and call on the media to help us encourage witnesses to come forward.

"When an allegation relates to events that happened over 20 years ago, we can't do that. But we have to establish what the facts are and one way of doing that is contacting people who were there at the time. If there is a better way of doing it, I would love to find it."

Mr Tonge said police were not deliberately setting out to find victims, but were responding to complaints referred to them.

In the case of Mr Jones, further alleged victims had come forward after publicity over his arrest. Merseyside police's Operation Care, a model of best practice in its field, began in 1996 in response to child abuse allegations in care homes and special schools in north Wales and across the north-west.

More than 80 institutions have been investigated, leading to 27 convictions and five acquittals, including Mr Jones's.

The method has been used by other forces including Cheshire police, who three years ago spent more than £250,000 on inquiries codenamed Bugle, Emily and Granite after allegations of abuse at a children's home in Congleton.

During investigations, they traced former residents of homes where one social worker, Keith Laverack, suspected of being a career paedophile, had worked.

About 140 people were contacted by a letter which gave few details of the inquiry. Many former residents who rang a hotline in response said without prompting: "This is about Laverack, isn't it?"

He was later convicted of 11 charges of buggery and four of indecent assault on children aged 11 to 16.

A spokeswoman for Cheshire police said: "Our use of these techniques has been tested in court and, in our experience, the courts are happy with the techniques, which have resulted in a number of guilty verdicts."

Charles Mills, an Ofsted inspector and former headteacher of a residential school on Merseyside which was investigated using the method, said police had set up an office at his school to interview each of the 120 male pupils, aged between six and 18, after a former staff member was arrested over allegations relating to another home.

The police had conducted the interviews sensitively, he said, but there was a mindset that all care homes were infected with abusers. "I am not saying abuse has not occurred - it has - but the issue has been highly exaggerated."

Harry Fearns, whose brother-in-law was convicted after an Operation Care investigation, is chairman of the Campaign for Falsely Accused Carers and Teachers. "We feel that trawling methods are equal to touting for allegations. By the nature of police methodology they will collect false accusations as well as true," he said.

Stephen Pollard, David Jones's solicitor, said child abuse allegations must be more rigorously investigated to ensure innocent people did not suffer.

webTitle: How other salaried heads of state get by in modest palaces

fields.headline: How other salaried heads of state get by in modest palaces
fields.standfirst:
The division of power and privilege

Join the debate online
fields.trailText: It does not have to be like this. Other monarchs do not have so many prerogatives and privileges as ours - and most of them have fewer personal assets too. Even elected heads of state manage on much smaller salaries than our monarch.
fields.body:
It does not have to be like this. Other monarchs do not have so many prerogatives and privileges as ours - and most of them have fewer personal assets too. Even elected heads of state manage on much smaller salaries than our monarch.

France

The French president is elected for seven years, nominally appoints the prime minister and has to approve ministerial appointments. He is in charge of foreign policy, is head of the military, conducts weekly cabinet meetings, can dissolve parliament and call elections and referendums

The president is paid £46,000 a year and also receives £595,260 for the upkeep of the Elysee Palace, £781,990 for personal staff, £345,971 for travel costs and £196,208 to meet the costs of the car pool: a total of £1.96m. He has the use of several chateaux. On retirement, he receives a civil service-linked pension of £34,123 a year and can take senior governmental or official jobs. He is also entitled to free accommodation, a car, a chauffeur, a bodyguard and two secretaries.

United States

The President of the United States is elected every four years and can serve for two terms. His chief duty is to protect the constitution, enforce the laws made by Congress, and head the armed forces. Presidents can recommend legislation, call special sessions of Congress, veto bills, appoint federal judges, heads of federal departments, and ambassadors, conduct official business with foreign countries and grant pardons for offences against the US.

The current salary is £147,000 a year (fixed since 1969), plus up to £37,000 for expenses and £73,500, tax-free, for travel and official entertainment. Proposals to double presidential pay from next year were recently thrown out by Congress.

When he leaves office in January, Mr Clinton will draw an annual pension of $151,800 (£111,617) plus a similar amount for staff. Mrs Clinton will receive a pension of $20,000 (£14,705).

Japan

The emperor has no powers related to government and po litical activity is forbidden: though he appoints the prime minister and chief justice, they are first designated by the Diet (parliament) and the cabinet. Only members of the imperial family retain princely titles - Emperor Akihito's sisters, daughters of Hirohito, no longer have titles.

The emperor lives in a walled, moated 62-room palace, rebuilt in 1968, with 285 acres of grounds in the middle of Tokyo. There are 1,150 imperial employees costing £142m a year. An annual tax-free salary of £1,764,705 also pays for some personal staff members and the living expenses for the empress and their immediate family.

Denmark

In a monarchy modelled on British lines, the popular Queen Margrethe II has weekly briefings from the prime minister and foreign minister and is required to sign all legislation, which is only valid if counter-signed by a minister.

The royal family has a small palace, the Amalienborg, in the middle of Copenhagen, and a larger palace for official duties - the Christiansborg - elsewhere in the city. They also have a palace at Marselisborg near Arhus and often spend winter at the Fredensborg Palace.

Spain

The Spanish monarchy conforms to standard rules these days in having the King Juan Carlos I as head of state but not politically involved. The constitution says he "arbitrates and moderates the regular working of the institutions, assumes the highest representation of the Spanish state in international relations ... and performs the functions expressly conferred on him by the constitution and the law."

The royal family has the use of eight palaces, mostly in and around Madrid - though there's also one on Majorca and one in the Canaries.

Belgium

King Albert II's income is index-linked to a civil service list. The family has a formal palace in the middle of Brussels and a more modest Victorian mansion where they live a few miles away in the suburbs at Laeken.

The Belgian monarch has wide powers. Although on succession he must be approved by parliament, the king has the nominal right to nominate the government and to dissolve parliament.

He signs all laws and is responsible for executing them. No action of the monarch has any consequence, however, without a ministerial counter-signature.

Proposals to double presidential pay from next year were recently thrown out by Congress. When he leaves office in January, Mr Clinton will draw an annual pension of $151,800 (£111,617) plus a similar amount for staff. Mrs Clinton will receive a pension of $20,000 (£14,705). Japan The emperor has no powers related to government and po litical activity is forbidden: though he appoints the prime minister and chief justice, they are first designated by the Diet (parliament) and the cabinet. Only members of the imperial family retain princely titles - Emperor Akihito's sisters, daughters of Hirohito, no longer have titles. The emperor lives in a walled, moated 62-room palace, rebuilt in 1968, with 285 acres of grounds in the middle of Tokyo. There are 1,150 imperial employees costing £142m a year. An annual tax-free salary of £1,764,705 also pays for some personal staff members and the living expenses for the empress and their immediate family. Denmark In a monarchy modelled on British lines, the popular Queen Margrethe II has weekly briefings from the prime minister and foreign minister and is required to sign all legislation, which is only valid if counter-signed by a minister. The royal family has a small palace, the Amalienborg, in the middle of Copenhagen, and a larger palace for official duties - the Christiansborg - elsewhere in the city. They also have a palace at Marselisborg near Arhus and often spend winter at the Fredensborg Palace. Spain The Spanish monarchy conforms to standard rules these days in having the King Juan Carlos I as head of state but not politically involved. The constitution says he "arbitrates and moderates the regular working of the institutions, assumes the highest representation of the Spanish state in international relations ... and performs the functions expressly conferred on him by the constitution and the law." The royal family has the use of eight palaces, mostly in and around Madrid - though there's also one on Majorca and one in the Canaries. Belgium King Albert II's income is index-linked to a civil service list. The family has a formal palace in the middle of Brussels and a more modest Victorian mansion where they live a few miles away in the suburbs at Laeken. The Belgian monarch has wide powers. Although on succession he must be approved by parliament, the king has the nominal right to nominate the government and to dissolve parliament. He signs all laws and is responsible for executing them. No action of the monarch has any consequence, however, without a ministerial counter-signature. webTitle: Two killed, one injured in spate of Belfast shootings

fields.headline: Two killed, one injured in spate of Belfast shootings
fields.standfirst:
Fears grow of fresh outbreak of sectarian violence

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Fears of a fresh outbreak of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland were growing last night after two men were shot dead and another was seriously injured in Belfast in the space of 24 hours.
fields.body:
Fears of a fresh outbreak of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland were growing last night after two men were shot dead and another was seriously injured in Belfast in the space of 24 hours.

A Catholic workman was gunned down as he carried out building work on the predominantly loyalist Monkstown estate on the northern outskirts of Belfast just before 4pm yesterday.

A few minutes later a Catholic taxi driver was shot and seriously injured outside the depot where he worked on the Old Park Road in north Belfast.

The killings followed the shooting of a Protestant taxi driver, Trevor Kell, just before midnight on Tuesday as he sat in his cab waiting for what appears to have been a bogus fare.

Superintendent Campbell Dixon, the man in charge of the Monkstown investigation, described the attack as "a naked sectarian murder carried out by loyalist paramilitaries"

He said the 30-year-old man, from the Dungiven area of Co Londonderry, was approached by two men and shot several times in the head and body. He died instantly. The killers made off on foot through the housing estate.

The man injured in the Old Park shooting was shot outside a taxi office by a gunman on the pillion seat of a motorcycle. The RUC said the bike nearly collided with a car as it sped off.

Gerry Kelly, the Sinn Fein assembly member for Belfast North, said the shooting had "all the hallmarks of a loyalist attack on Catholics".

He said the victim was sitting in a car outside a taxi firm just on the Catholic side of the interface with the loyalist area when he was shot.

Earlier yesterday detectives investigating the murder of Mr Kell said they did not believe the shooting had a sectarian motive. However loyalist paramilitaries banded together to investigate the murder. They said they were convinced his death had nothing to do with the feud between the groups which has claimed seven lives since August.

In a statement the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the Ulster Volunteer Force and the Red Hand Commando said: "The three major loyalist paramilitary organisations are investigating the tragic death of Trevor Kell.

"We are convinced that Mr Kell's death has nothing to do with the so-called loyalist feud.

"Acts between the three groups are at an advanced stage and the hope is that there will be an early resolution to our differences."

Alban Maginness, SDLP assembly member for the area, said the attacks must be "unreservedly condemned".

"No one is the winner at the end of the day and the real losers are the people of north Belfast and the families of those who have lost their lives.

"As a society in Northern Ireland we must leave this barbarism behind us."

The Democratic Unionist assembly member for north Belfast, Nigel Dodds, said the spate of shootings and killings in the area marked a "terrible deterioration" in the security situation.

He said that those who have been demanding a reduction in security cover and the emasculation of the RUC "can now see the foolishness of their calls".

Mr Kell's widow, Margaret, said her husband, who had only started working full time for the taxi firm on Monday night, was an innocent man and she did not know why he had been targeted. "The ones who did this are scum. They have torn this family apart. Trevor was a completely innocent man, completely innocent.

"I have no idea why anyone would do this, they have ruined this family. How could they do this?"

webTitle: FA sideline Bates in bid to save new Wembley

fields.headline: FA sideline Bates in bid to save new Wembley
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: Senior officals at the Football Association (FA) are to take control of the rebuilding of Wembley stadium and marginalise the Chelsea chairman, Ken Bates, following concerns at his handling of the project.
fields.body:
Senior officals at the Football Association (FA) are to take control of the rebuilding of Wembley stadium and marginalise the Chelsea chairman, Ken Bates, following concerns at his handling of the project.

Senior members of the FA board - led by the chief executive Adam Crozier, the chairman, Geoff Thompson, and the deputy-chairman of Arsenal, David Dein - are to ensure that Mr Bates no longer leads the £660m project.

Earlier this month the Guardian revealed that a number of big banks shared the doubts of some FA board members about the business plan for the new Wembley. They saw Mr Bates's plans for a hotel, office space and lavish banqueting facilities as too costly in relation to how much money the facilities would generate.

The decision to marginalise Mr Bates, who is chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited (WNSL), the FA subsidary set up to oversee construction of the new stadium, is sure to cause heated debate in the FA as senior officals try to salvage a project that has not only become mired in financial problems but has generated much bad publicity.

"The top leadership of the FA is now involved in the Wembley project. They have moved in, they are now addressing the issues," a source close to the project said, in a clear effort to send a message that will win over the banks.

"There have been serious concerns at the way it has been run up until now. A number of meetings with interested parties will be held over the next few weeks. The FA has no intention of allowing this project to fail," he said.

"The likes of Adam Crozier and David Dein are all going to get involved. Obviously, if they were happy with those who had been running this project there would not have been this intervention."

Senior FA officals are also insisting that cost cutbacks be made, and have already said privately they plan to scrap proposals to build a new hotel.

An emergency FA board meeting has been called for tomorrow where all 12 board members will discuss how to scale the project down after the Guardian revealed that there were problems in raising finance for to build the new stadium, with 30 banks refusing to back it after being ap proached. This meant construction could not begin in November as planned.

Mr Crozier, who is also on the WNSL board, has already met Chase Manhattan, the US bank hired to raise £410m from other City banks and investors. More meetings are to be held in the coming weeks with the FA chief executive taking a personal role in negotiations in hopes of changing the minds of lenders who fear the project could be a financial disaster.

Mr Bates was not available for comment and his office referred all calls to WNSL.

The Guardian has also learned that the sports minister, Kate Hoey, has asked Mr Crozier for a report on Wembley and why it has run into so many problems.

The 12 FA board members have been issued with a report on the new Wembley, which they will discuss at tomorrow's meeting. Next Monday, the board of WNSL is to meet Chase Manhattan executives who will explain why they have had problems raising finance from other lenders. Many are said to be concerned at the projected revenue for the new stadium and are demanding firmer guarantees.

A spokesman for WNSL denied that the leadership of the FA was taking over the project because it was dissatisfied.

"The FA is already involved in the project and it's only natural that the involvement will vary as matters proceed," he said. "We are very closely related to the FA, many of our board members are also on the FA board. It is too premature to say if we will be changing plans for the new stadium because we will have to see what Chase report back to us."
