webTitle: 20 years jail for US 'spy' in Russia

fields.headline: 20 years jail for US 'spy' in Russia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A former American naval intelligence officer was found guilty of espionage by a Moscow court yesterday and was handed the severest sentence possible - 20 years imprisonment - in a case that threatens to further damage Russian-American relations.
fields.body:
A former American naval intelligence officer was found guilty of espionage by a Moscow court yesterday and was handed the severest sentence possible - 20 years imprisonment - in a case that threatens to further damage Russian-American relations.

The first US citizen to be convicted of spying in Russia for 40 years, Edmond Pope was imprisoned last night in Moscow's notoriously austere Lefortovo jail after being convicted of illegally obtaining classified blueprints for a high-speed torpedo used by the Russian navy.

Pope had consistently denied the charges, arguing that the information involved was no longer secret and had been published abroad.

Washington immediately condemned the court's decision. "We are deeply disappointed by [the] verdict," said a national security spokesman at the White House.

But a spokeman for Russia's Federal Security Service (the FSB, a descendent of the KGB), expressed satisfaction with the result: "Russia has its secrets. We will do our best to protect them," General Alexander Zdanovich said.

The case is expected to be on the agenda of the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, when she meets the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, in Brussels later this month.

The sharp exchange is the latest diplomatic dispute between Moscow and Washington. Last week, the state department criticised a Russian decision to end a five-year-old moratorium on sales of battlefield weapons to Iran.

In yesterday's court case, Pope's wife and his lawyers made last-minute pleas for clemency, saying the accused had a rare form of bone cancer. Prosecution lawyers questioned the severity of Pope's illness and said no illness would ex cuse him from a prison term.

President Bill Clinton had personally asked that Pope be released because of his health. Russia's leader, Vladimir Putin, responded that the trial should run its course.

In a pre-sentence appeal to the judges after a six-week closed hearing, Pope stated he still did not understand what he was accused of. "I have already spent eight months in prison in Russia. I am not a spy," Pope's lawyer, Pavel Astakhov, quoted him as saying.

Before he retired, Pope, 54, was an officer with the US Navy military intelligence service, gathering information about maritime weaponry.

He retired in the mid-1990s and founded CERF Technologies International, a company assessing and buying foreign naval equipment. He travelled to Moscow many times before his arrest in April.

The case rested on whether technical reports he obtained concerning the Shkval (Squall) torpedo were classified. Deployed for the first time in 1977, it could travel five times faster than any torpedo in western navies. In 1995 Jane's Intelligence Review said it had "no western equivalent".

Pope's wife, Cheri, sat with him in the caged defendant 's box while the sentence was read and hugged him through the bars as he was found guilty.

webTitle: Helping Uganda's disabled to help themselves to real power

fields.headline: Helping Uganda's disabled to help themselves to real power
fields.standfirst:
This month we are highlighting the work of the four charities chosen for our Christmas appeal. Today we look at Action on Disability and Development

Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: An overloaded passenger truck overturned on the road to Masindi on Sunday, just a few miles from where Uganda's annual celebrations for the international day of the disabled were taking place.
fields.body:
An overloaded passenger truck overturned on the road to Masindi on Sunday, just a few miles from where Uganda's annual celebrations for the international day of the disabled were taking place.

By the time the celebrations come round again, those maimed in the accident will have lost their livelihood, their status, even their names. They will be just "mulema", cripples.

There is nowhere easier to become disabled than Africa, and nowhere where the stigma attached is so great. More than 80% of Uganda's 2m disabled were born able-bodied, then fell victim to road accidents, war or disease. But tradition calls them cursed and has them shunned.

"People say the disabled's family must have been bewitched or that they have offended God," said Agnes Kalibbala, Uganda programme manager of the UK-based charity Action on Disability and Development. "It's difficult even to tell parents that their child is crippled because he wasn't immunised against polio and not because someone has cursed them."

ADD's campaign for disabled rights is changing this attitude. The agency arrived in Uganda in 1987 to find war amputees and polio cripples in every village, creeping around with only branches and broomsticks for support.

Since then it has encouraged thousands of disabled Ugandans, most of them illiterate, to form self-help groups and lobby for themselves.

As a result, Uganda boasts legal provision for the disabled which puts many much wealthier nations to shame.

The story of 50-year-old Simporosa Angella Amuge stands for those thousands. At the age of three, she caught measles and lost her sight. Overnight, she had become a lifelong victim: war and poverty, ever present in Uganda, always affect the disabled worst.

Dragged by her four young children, Simporosa was the last to flee her village when it was overrun by fighting in which her husband was killed. She was still destitute when ADD found her, six years later, camped out with seven other blind refugees in a ruined leper colony.

"When people saw us together they thought we were beggars, but we had a plot of land and wanted to work," she said. "ADD didn't tell us what to do. They said: 'What do you want?' They bought us slashers, boots and an ox plough and we began to support ourselves.

"Before, our hope was only to get food. Now we want to teach our fellow blind the skills we have learned."

Last year, Simporosa was elected to her district council. "Six years ago I was starving. I could never have believed this was possible."

Simporosa is testament to Uganda's affirmative action policy, drawn up after intense lobbying by the National Union of Disabled People in Uganda, which was formed and is funded by ADD. At least one disabled man and woman must sit on every decision-making body, from village groups, through district councils, up to parliament: making a total of 27,000 disabled leaders.

In the cabinet, Florence Naiga Sekabira, herself a polio victim, serves as minister for the disabled. "I say to people, 'see what I am'," she said. "Where would I be if my parents had hidden me away?"

Uganda's government guarantees primary school education for four children from every family, and insists that any disabled children be part of the four. But this is easier decreed than done.

"The problem is parents look at children as their own insurance. They don't consider the need for disabled people to live individual lives," said Ms Kalibbala. "They hide them in their homes and educate their healthy children instead.

"But disabled children need education even more than others because they depend on their brains and if they're not bright, well, if you're prepared to treat them as equals, that's the risk you take."

ADD is campaigning for government resources to implement this policy. In rural areas, where 90% of the population lives, it is still only token, says Ms Kalibbala: without teachers who know sign language, or braille machines, there is no place for deaf and blind pupils.

The disabled must claim these things for themselves, says ADD: on disabled issues, theirs was the most powerful voice. This year, for the first time, ADD trained polio victims to administer polio immunisation throughout Uganda's villages and saw turnout increase by nearly 25%.

"The disabled must speak for themselves," said Ms Kalibbala. "In a poor country, you could carry on handing out wheelchairs forever. To guarantee their own future, they have to persuade government to let them participate in working society."

Sometimes, however, a bit of wheelchair-giving is unavoidable, she added. In an oily workshop in Kampala, a small disabled women's group, supported by ADD, made light, folding wheelchairs from bi cycle wheels, canvas and metal piping: all cheap, easily-replaced, local materials.

"Before I made my own wheelchair I had to crawl around town," said 35-year-old Sharifa Mirembe, one of six technicians.

"I was always filthy and people were terrified of me. How can you turn up at an office like that."

Sharifa and her colleagues make eight wheelchairs a month and sell them to organisations and individuals.

In groups like Sharifa's, there is none of the awkwardness which so often dogs the disabled in society: the disabled cowed, the able-bodied embarrassed.

In its place is the happy confidence of knowing there is work being done.

And confidence, said Ms Kalibbala, was the key. "You can go into the villages and tell the disabled they can mobilise themselves, but it takes a long time to convince them. But when someone who was silent, who has spent his entire life terrified of being laughed at, comes out to greet you, laughing, saying 'You are most welcome', that is a wonderful feeling."

Confidence brings strength and with it, wit. Uganda's disabled groups have seized on a hated word with delight. "Mulema" their members now call each other laughingly.

Uganda is a country with some very old attitudes and some very new laws. To end Sunday's disabled day celebrations, a boy, his body twisted back to front by polio, was brought forward to write "a love letter to the president" with his feet.

Rows of dignitaries whooped in amazement, and half a dozen ministers sprang forward to snap close-ups. In Britain, such behaviour would be frowned on. Then again, in Britain, the ministers would not be there.


How they help


Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical abuse.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford the fees of commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

"The disabled must speak for themselves," said Ms Kalibbala. "In a poor country, you could carry on handing out wheelchairs forever. To guarantee their own future, they have to persuade government to let them participate in working society." Sometimes, however, a bit of wheelchair-giving is unavoidable, she added. In an oily workshop in Kampala, a small disabled women's group, supported by ADD, made light, folding wheelchairs from bi cycle wheels, canvas and metal piping: all cheap, easily-replaced, local materials. "Before I made my own wheelchair I had to crawl around town," said 35-year-old Sharifa Mirembe, one of six technicians. "I was always filthy and people were terrified of me. How can you turn up at an office like that." Sharifa and her colleagues make eight wheelchairs a month and sell them to organisations and individuals. In groups like Sharifa's, there is none of the awkwardness which so often dogs the disabled in society: the disabled cowed, the able-bodied embarrassed. In its place is the happy confidence of knowing there is work being done. And confidence, said Ms Kalibbala, was the key. "You can go into the villages and tell the disabled they can mobilise themselves, but it takes a long time to convince them. But when someone who was silent, who has spent his entire life terrified of being laughed at, comes out to greet you, laughing, saying 'You are most welcome', that is a wonderful feeling." Confidence brings strength and with it, wit. Uganda's disabled groups have seized on a hated word with delight. "Mulema" their members now call each other laughingly. Uganda is a country with some very old attitudes and some very new laws. To end Sunday's disabled day celebrations, a boy, his body twisted back to front by polio, was brought forward to write "a love letter to the president" with his feet. Rows of dignitaries whooped in amazement, and half a dozen ministers sprang forward to snap close-ups. In Britain, such behaviour would be frowned on. Then again, in Britain, the ministers would not be there. How they help Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs. Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical abuse. Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford the fees of commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences. The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

webTitle: Mixed Catholic reaction to the call for change

fields.headline: Mixed Catholic reaction to the call for change
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Join the debate online
fields.body:
Spokesman for the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, Archbishop of Westminster: "Changing the Act of Settlement would raise wider constitutional issues that would need careful thought and wide consultation."

John Wilkins, editor of The Tablet: "The Guardian is quite right as regards Catholics. There is a clear infringement of religious liberty. I think the act is a real anachronism and frankly insulting. I am sure Prince Charles thinks so too. That does not mean I support getting rid of the monarchy. There is a fear that this is the thread which when pulled unravels the whole constitution."

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary and convert to Catholicism: "Repeal would be inappropriate as long as the sovereign is also supreme governor of the Church of England. The sovereign can't be anything but a member of the Church of England until it is disestablished - and that would remove the last fig leaf of any claim to be a Christian country."

Charles Moore, editor of the Daily Telegraph and also a convert to Catholicism: "I would be prepared to see the Act of Settlement reformed. I think a Catholic or a Jew or a Muslim could in fact be supreme governor of the Church of England. It is not a theological role, it is a question of a balance of power in politics."

webTitle: 'Jodie is holding our hands much stronger - she is a fighter'

fields.headline: 'Jodie is holding our hands much stronger - she is a fighter'
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The parents of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary appear on television for the first time tonight, to talk about their unsuccessful fight to prevent the separation of their children and their ordeal since the operation, after the high court agreed they could be identified.
fields.body:
The parents of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary appear on television for the first time tonight, to talk about their unsuccessful fight to prevent the separation of their children and their ordeal since the operation, after the high court agreed they could be identified.

In a special edition of ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald, Michaelangelo and Rina Attard describe the agony of the court case, the subsequent death of Mary and their hopes for the surviving twin. The doctors involved in the children's care are also interviewed.

The programme has caused controversy because Granada TV agreed to pay the parents, from the Mediterranean island of Gozo, about £150,000 for the interview. The broadcaster pointed out that the money will go into a trust fund for Jodie's care, but pro-life groups have branded the payment unethical.

In the hour-long documentary Mr and Mrs Attard say they were devastated at the death of Mary, who depended upon Jodie's heart and lungs for life. "Even though we were prepared, it was a shock. We didn't accept that it was going to happen. Sometimes you just can't believe that she is dead, but you have to accept that she is," Mr Attard says.

Mrs Attard, 29, tells the interviewer, Martin Bashir, how she held Mary after the operation on November 6. "I wanted to see her straight away. I lifted her and I cuddled her. She was dead, but I was happy that I was holding her." Her husband, who is 44, adds: "It was good to hold her. It was the first time we could cuddle her. Although she was dead, she was free at that time."

The twins were born on August 8 at St Mary's hospital in Manchester. Doctors told the couple that if their children were not separated, both would die. If a separation was successful, Jodie could survive. Mr and Mrs Attard, who are Roman Catholics refused to give permission for the operation. They could not give their consent to an act that would kill one of their children, and wanted God's will to take its course instead.

Doctors, wishing to save Jodie, went to the high court to overrule the parents' wishes. A judge said the operation should go ahead, and three appeal judges - who heard representations from the Catholic church and the ProLife Alliance - later agreed. Eventually, the parents gave up their legal fight.

During the case, a court order had prevented the media from revealing the identity of the parents and their children. For the interview to go ahead, Mr and Mrs Attard had to ask for the order to be revised. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division at the high court in London, agreed yesterday that they could be identified, along with the doctors involved. But a ban on approaching the hospital where the operation took place remains in force, as does the injunction which protects the identity of Jodie.

In tonight's programme, to be screened at 10pm, Mrs Attard says that Jodie has been progressing well since the separation. "Although she was full of pipes and monitors and tubes ... she did not seem as if she was coming out from such a major operation. She looked settled.

"When we saw her for those two days [after the operation] she didn't smile and we were afraid something might have happened. But when they stopped the morphine she was back to normal again so we were very happy."

Three doctors, Adrian Bianchi, Mike Maresh and Alan Dickson, also appear in the documentary. They say the Jodie is making good progress.

Mrs Attard describes her feelings at being able to be close to Jodie. "She started holding our hands. She might notice that something has been separated from her so she's holding our hands much, much stronger.

"We are very happy because she likes to try to talk with us and she smiles at people and us. It makes us encouraged for the future. She's going to be a real fighter."

The Guardian revealed last month that Granada had agreed to pay the twins' parents for the interview. A Granada spokesman said the judge agreed yesterday that the trust fund was worthwhile. "The programme can hardly be unethical if the court has agreed with this course of action. It's a story of great national and international public interest."

The Tonight series began two years ago with an interview with the five youths suspected of killing the black teenager Stephen Lawrence. That, too, was carried out by Martin Bashir, who came to prominence when he interviewed with Princess Diana for BBC's Panorama.

Panorama is understood to have been in discussions with the twins' parents, and offered a similar sum.

Mr Attard tells Mr Bashir that the couple hope eventually to take their child back home to Gozo. "We don't think too much ahead. We only think day by day. Hopefully one day we will all go back together, taking Jodie back with us, and Mary because she is part of our family and will be close to us all the same. We still love them the same, they are both our daughters."

webTitle: Anglicans split over repeal of ancient act

fields.headline: Anglicans split over repeal of ancient act
fields.standfirst:
Human rights issue acknowledged but fears remain about role of religion in society

Join the debate online
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Senior members of the Church of England were divided yesterday over whether the 1701 Act of Settlement should be repealed to allow the monarch or heir to the throne to marry a Roman Catholic, reflecting fears for the implications of the move on the church's standing and its implications for society generally.
fields.byline: Stephen Bates,  religious affairs correspondent and  David Pallister
fields.body:
Senior members of the Church of England were divided yesterday over whether the 1701 Act of Settlement should be repealed to allow the monarch or heir to the throne to marry a Roman Catholic, reflecting fears for the implications of the move on the church's standing and its implications for society generally.

Fissures run deep within the church - an indication of the continuing symbolism and significance of a 299-year-old statute. All those contacted by the Guardian, however, had avidly read our coverage.

At Lambeth Palace, the Archbishop of Canterbury's press secretary asked incredulously: "You want a response from here? We think the simple answer is that very often seemingly straightforward proposals are often nothing of the sort.

"We are very aware of the human rights issue but that is by no means the only factor. It is difficult to grasp the whole thing. The process the Guardian is undertaking to raise the issue is obviously at its earliest stage and we will be watching closely to see whether it comes to anything. Palpably, there can't be a debate unless there is progress in bringing a case.

"You cannot presume that the archbishop would not oppose the prince marrying a Catholic. He would seek to follow the law of the land and he would uphold the constitutional settlement."

Dr David Hope, the Archbishop of York and a leading member of the Anglo-Catholic wing of the church, is on record as calling for change.

His spokesman, the Rev. Rob Marshall, said his views had not changed since he told a journalist at the end of last year: "It is a very negative kind of arrangement at the moment. I cannot really see why members of the royal family should not be free to marry whom they will.

"We are living in a different age and a different climate and the arrangements should reflect that. Some movement or accommodation is necessary, bearing in mind the warm relationships between Roman Catholics and other churches in this country."

The Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, bishop of Winchester, who speaks on constitutional matters for the church was cautious about any attempt to dismantle the legislation.

He said: "A monarchy stripped of its religious significance would not be of long standing. A state whose reference point was purely secular would be quickly markedly less tolerant not only to the broad range of religions but to secular organisations as well.

"I find it very frustrating that these things are bandied about as if thinking about issues which have been developed over 1,000 years is quite simple and straightforward. The Guardian should be thinking about the implications more."

Canon Paul Oestreicher, of Coventry cathedral, said: "The Act of Settlement is a joke and of course it ought to be repealed. It is a trivial anachronism and totally inappropriate both for a modern state and for the church. Why should the prime minister appoint bishops, or bishops sit in the Lords by virtue of their appointment?

"We have the situation where the heir to the throne can be an adulterer but not marry a Catholic. He can go against the most basic moral principles of the church and still be its supreme governor."

The Rev David Haslam, chairman of the Christian Socialist Movement, said: "We believe it is quite improper and wrong to discriminate against different Christian denominations and that aspect of the Act of Settlement should be set aside forthwith."

Members of other faiths welcomed the Guardian's move to challenge the Act of Settlement.

Padmesh Gupta, the president of the United Kingdom Hindi committee, said: "This kind of discrimination is not right at this time when people all over the world should think first of their humanity rather than their religion."

Yousuf Bhailok, secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain, said: "Prince Charles has been a good friend of the Muslim community and we share his views that he wanted the monarchy, in a multi-cultural society, to be the defender of all faiths."

Anthony Haviland-Nye, director of the British Buddhist Association, said: "In this day and age, everyone, whether they be at the bottom or the top, should have freedom in matters of conscience. The act is clearly incompatible with the human rights convention."

The Board of Deputies of British Jews, and a number of prominent Jewish commentators, did not wish to be drawn into the debate.

webTitle: Broad welcome for debate on monarchy

fields.headline: Broad welcome for debate on monarchy
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dem leader backs legal challenge to act

Join the debate online
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday voiced support for a new legal challenge to the Act of Settlement which bans Roman Catholics from succeeding to the British throne.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday voiced support for a new legal challenge to the Act of Settlement which bans Roman Catholics from succeeding to the British throne.

As MPs from all parties debated the future of the monarchy in the wake of the Guardian's campaign, Mr Kennedy made clear that he believed it was time to sweep away anachronistic 18th century laws.

"I am a confirmed monarchist," Mr Kennedy said. "But I am a Jacobite."

The diplomatic remarks from the Lib Dem leader, who is a Catholic, made clear that he supports James II, the Catholic king who was overthrown in the Glorious Revolution of 1688 by the Protestant William of Orange. Fear of a Jacobite takeover led to the Act of Settlement of 1701 which has ensured that no Catholic has been allowed anywhere near the throne since James II.

The Guardian challenge to the 299-year-old Act of Settlement provoked a passionate debate on the future of the monarchy among MPs from all parties.

The veteran Labour MP Dennis Skinner demonstrated his republican credentials by joking about the issue in the Commons. As MPs were summoned by Black Rod to hear the Queen's Speech in the Lords, he shouted out: "Tell her to read the Guardian."

Other republican MPs cocked a snook at parliamentary convention to call for an end to the monarchy. Standing near the Commons chamber, where MPs are banned from debating the monarch, the outspoken republican Paul Flynn said he was delighted that an "intelligent debate" had been opened up.

"Having a hereditary head of state is expensive and will collapse under its own absur dity," Mr Flynn said. "Young people are aware that the royal family are as frail and fallible as the rest of us."

Mr Flynn, who takes the oath of allegiance to the Queen "as a convinced republican and under protest", had first-hand experience of the difficulty of debating the future of the monarchy when he introduced a bill for its abolition before the last election. His private member's bill was given a first reading but was blocked when David Mellor, acting as a privy councillor, prevented it from receiving a more substantial second reading.

In the finest tradition of the Labour party, republican MPs were divided yesterday.

Tony Benn was disappointed that the Guardian had stopped short of advocating outright abolition of the monarchy. "The Catholic thing is a minor issue - I do not see why anyone should inherit the position of head of state," Mr Benn said. "It is better to present the argument in terms of the powers parliament has lost. The prime minister needs the crown because it is the source of power through the royal prerogative. The crown also needs the prime minister for political support."

Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned as a defence minister this year in protest at the government's neglect of Labour heartlands, agreed that the monarchy was an anachronism. But he thought there was no appetite for abolition of the monarchy or the reforms advocated by the Guardian. "The impression given in the newspaper suggests that this is an issue on a par with the outbreak of world war three," he said.

Republican-minded ministers, who are fearful of a rebuke from the "ardent" monarchist Tony Blair, were wary of putting their heads above the parapet yesterday. Mo Mowlam, who was slapped down by Downing Street recently when she suggested that the Queen should move out of Buckingham Palace, was unavailable for comment.

Another cabinet minister was more forthcoming, although he insisted on speaking anonymously. "It will be very interesting to see where the Guardian debate leads to," he said. The minister added that he took a pragmatic view of the monarchy, but was wary of "upsetting the apple cart".

The Liberal Democrats wel comed the new debate, saying that it agreed with Prince Charles's view that the monarchy was too closely linked to the Church of England. Paul Tyler, the party's chief whip, said: "It makes no sense for the crown to be limited to the anachronisms of the 18th century. We warmly welcome renewed debate about the role of the monarchy in a modern democracy. The best guarantee against destructive revolution is constructive evolution."

The Tories were solid in their support for the monarch. The Earl of Onslow, who fought an unsuccessful campaign to save hereditary peers, said he was horrified by the prospect of a president. "You've got to think of the alternative," he said. "The idea of Mrs Thatcher trotting up the Mall with an escort of the Household Cavalry is bizarre."

fields.trailText: The Scottish National Party yesterday tabled a fresh motion in the Scottish parliament calling for repeal of the Act of Settlement.
fields.body:
The Scottish National Party yesterday tabled a fresh motion in the Scottish parliament calling for repeal of the Act of Settlement.

In December 1999, the parliament had unanimously backed an SNP-led motion condemning the act as discriminatory and calling for its abolition.

The original motion was drawn up by the SNP's minister for education, Mike Russell, who also tabled yesterday's motion. "It is an issue that I feel very strongly about," he said. "It is institutionalised discrimination at the heart of the UK constitution. The time for talk on this matter is surely over, and the time for action is now. I am delighted that the Guardian is contemplating a legal challenge against its blatant discrimination. It is high time that Westminster followed the Scottish parliament's lead and got rid of this ancient discrimination once and for all."

The issue has had great resonance in Scotland in recent years. There has been a growing campaign against the blight of sectarianism, particularly in the west, and there have been a number of high profile attacks on anti-Catholic bias in Scottish society.

In a speech entitled Scotland's Shame delivered at the Edinburgh festival last year, the composer James MacMillan condemned what he said was a widespread prejudice against Catholics. At one point he likened Scotland to "Northern Ireland with out the guns".

The historian Tom Devine, said Scots felt very strongly about such issues. According to one poll taken in 1999, 34% of respondents felt there was a deep-rooted anti-Catholic attitude through Scottish society. "The situation is still very much alive here," said Professor Devine. "It is related to the broader issue of the Catholic position in modern Scotland which is itself related to the whole issue of the sectarian debate."

Cardinal Winning, the leader of Scotland's Roman Catholics, has described the Act of Settlement as an "insult". Yesterday, a spokesman for the cardinal said the church would be pleased to see the act erased.

The Church of Scotland also said the act had no place in contemporary society. "We would not have a problem at all with the Act of Settlement being repealed," said a kirk spokeswoman. "But we are very conscious of the Church of England position and we think there are very difficult and sensitive issues around this. But we also believe that it is not beyond the ability of people of goodwill to overcome this."

Lord James Douglas Hamilton, the Conservative whip in the Scottish parliament, initiated the debate on the Act of Settlement last year. "My passionate support for the monarchy does not alter the reality that the Act of Settlement contains anachronistic, discriminatry legislation," he said yesterday. "It is legislation which is badly in need of reform."

webTitle: Republicanism grows in the old empire

fields.headline: Republicanism grows in the old empire
fields.standfirst:
Sun setting on Queen's role as head of state

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Two Caribbean countries, Barbados and Jamaica, are leading the drive to abolish the Queen as head of state.
fields.body:
Two Caribbean countries, Barbados and Jamaica, are leading the drive to abolish the Queen as head of state.

Constitutional reviews are taking place in both countries. Feelings run strongest in Barbados, where there is embarrassment that the Queen is still head of state long after many of the country's neighbours have become republics.

The Queen is head of the Commonwealth, a position she was elected to by its 54 member countries including Britain. But she remains head of state in only 16 of the states. In addition to Britain, Barbados and Jamaica, the 16 are: Antigua, Australia, the Bahamas, Belize, Canada, Grenada, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, St Kitts and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Solomons and Tuvalu.

Richard Bourne, of the Institute of Commonwealth Studies in London, said the Queen made the Commonwealth central to her life when she became monarch. He did not know if the monarch's role as Commonwealth head could survive the end of the Queen's reign.

The possibility existed of a move to a respected figure who was non-British.

Almost all the Caribbean states are shifting towards becoming republics.

In Barbados, the National Democratic party, which favours a Barbadian head of state, said: "A referendum relating to head of state being a Barbadian speaks to the need to enhance our nationalist consciousness, removing all vestiges of colonialism."

Of the bigger Commonwealth members, New Zealand is another contender for moving towards republicanism. The prime minister, Helen Clark, has been outspoken in favour of a republic, arguing that it makes no sense to have a head of state 12,000 miles away. She has taken a first step by abolishing Buckingham Palace honours for New Zealanders.

Australia too is an eventual contender. Although the Queen survived last year's referendum on the issue, it was less from popular support for the idea of the monarchy than the unpopularity of the alternative - a president appointed by the Australian parliament.

Support remains strong in Canada, which sees the monarchy as a means of differentiating itself from the US. But the support does not extend to Canada's French-speaking areas or to new Asian communities on the Pacific coast.

webTitle: Police face charges after woman starved to death

fields.headline: Police face charges after woman starved to death
fields.trailText: Three police officers are to face disciplinary charges after a woman was allowed to starve to death in a car park.
fields.body:
Three police officers are to face disciplinary charges after a woman was allowed to starve to death in a car park.

Davina Rappai, 33, died in 1998 in Vault Beach car park, near Gorran Haven, Cornwall, after living there in her Escort for five weeks.

An inquest last February heard that Ms Rappai, from Rugby, Warwickshire, had been observed growing weaker and on several occasions the police were called. They claimed she refused their help.

The East Cornwall coroner, David Bruce, was told that in the 10 days before she died five people telephoned police but no officer visited her.

A verdict of death by natural causes was returned and the cause of death given as malnutrition due to mental illness.

The police complaints authority has ruled three officers should face disciplinary charges for their handling of reports from the public.

webTitle: Sticking to curbs on right to jury trial 'displays arrogance'

fields.headline: Sticking to curbs on right to jury trial 'displays arrogance'
fields.standfirst: Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: The government is to reintroduce a bill curbing the right to jury trial which has twice been thrown out by peers.
fields.body:
The government is to reintroduce a bill curbing the right to jury trial which has twice been thrown out by peers.

The controversial Criminal Justice (Mode of Trial) Bill will abolish the right of some 18,000 defendants a year who are charged with one of a range of middle-ranking offences to choose between a jury trial and trial by magistrates.

Under the bill, magistrates would take the decision whether to try the case themselves or send it to the crown court.

The reintroduction of the bill was attacked yesterday by civil liberties groups, lawyers and the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe.

John Wadham, director of Liberty, said the government was confusing being tough on crime with being tough on human rights.

Ms Widdecombe said the re-introduction of the bill demonstrated the government's "enormous arrogance". She added: "It has been dismissed twice and the government won't take the verdict of the democratic process. I hope it will now be thrown out again."

Mr Wadham said: "The right to jury trial is a crucial safeguard at the heart of our criminal justice system. Juries ensure that the criminal justice system is not dominated by professionals. Instead, ordinary people decide on guilt or innocence.

"The absence of sufficient numbers of magistrates from ethnic minorities also makes the cultural mix on most juries an important safeguard for black people who are often faced with courts who are otherwise made up entirely of white professionals."

The Law Society said the plans to "bulldoze through" the Bill were wrong. Its president, Michael Napier, said: "This Bill destroys the cornerstone of a fair justice system.

"Taking away the right to a trial by jury for certain offences risks increasing miscarriages of justice."

He said there was no evidence the bill would speed up the court process or cut costs.

The Home Office estimates the bill could save around £128 million, based on transferring around 14,000 cases currently heard in crown courts to magistrates.

Last year, the number of cases where defendants chose jury trial rose by 2.6%.

International criminal court

A surprise element in the bill to introduce an international criminal court is expected to bring substantial changes to the present immunity enjoyed by diplomats.

The court is to be established to try those accused of crimes against humanity. Twenty-three countries have so far ratified it and a total of 60 are needed for it to come into being.

Britain is pushing ahead with the bill in spite of resistance from the US, which does not want its citizens to be subjected to an international court. It is expected to be established in about two years.

The bill will enable the law-enforcement authorities in England, Wales and Northern Ireland to identify, arrest and transfer war crimes suspects to The Hague once the ICC is established.

It will also give the domestic courts powers to try UK nationals accused of war crimes, crimes against humanity or genocide. Separate legislation for Scotland will be introduced in the Scottish Parliament.

The bill is expected to be introduced in the Lords before Christmas.

Save the Children and other organisations had expressed grave concern that diplomats involved in war crimes would be exempt. The government has since hinted that the bill will end that immunity.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "The international criminal court bill will enable us to achieve our target of becoming a founding member of the court and send a clear message to the world's tyrants that Britain wants them to face international justice."

"We took the lead in the negotiations to agree the treaty on the international criminal court. We are now taking the lead in ratifying it."

fields.headline: Curfew plan gets cold shoulder
fields.standfirst:
Teenagers 'This will criminalise a whole group'

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Unsupervised teenagers will be expected to be off the streets by 10pm under new laws at the heart of the home secretary, Jack Straw's anti-"yob culture" package, which has been designed as much to wrongfoot Tory opposition in the run-up to the election as to continue to bear down on the falling crime figures due out next month.
fields.body:
Unsupervised teenagers will be expected to be off the streets by 10pm under new laws at the heart of the home secretary, Jack Straw's anti-"yob culture" package, which has been designed as much to wrongfoot Tory opposition in the run-up to the election as to continue to bear down on the falling crime figures due out next month.

But Mr Straw's plans to raise the age of local child curfews to 16 and to issue £100 fixed penalty fines for public drunkenness and disorder were immediately criticised by child welfare charities and youth organisations. The National Children's Bureau said it was dismayed by the plans, while the British Youth Council deplored the move as "the criminalisation of a group of people largely ignored by society."

The crime package also includes the long-awaited bill to license the 125,000 private security guards who operate in Britain, new moves to clamp down on the trade in stolen vehicles, and measures to tackle the link between alcohol and violent crime. Reform of the licensing hours, promised by Home Office ministers in August, which would have led to optional 24-hour opening for pubs seven days a week with the ban on children lifted have, however, been shelved until after the election.

A move to set up a national confiscation agency to seize the assets of organised crime will also have to wait until the next session. Instead only a draft bill is promised but in the meantime the Inland Revenue is to be given unprecedented powers to hand over to the police the tax records of individuals for a whole range of offences. Until now, such disclosure was limited to cases of treason and murder.

Criminal justice

Mr Straw yesterday defended the child curfew proposal, saying: "Why are there youngsters out on the streets at 10 or 11pm. Where are the parents? Children should be in their homes at 10 or 11pm not racketing around the streets." Ministers point to the limited success of a similar scheme in Hamilton, Scotland, to answer criticism that no local authority in England has used existing curfew powers for those aged 10 and under.

The bill will also include new fixed penalty fines - to be used like parking tickets - for public drunkenness and disorder, and powers for the police to immediately close down rowdy pubs and bars. The police are also to be given the power of immediate arrest over kerb crawlers and hit-and-run drivers and will be given new powers to remove material from premises for searching. It will also give the inland revenue power to disclose confidential tax details to the police.

Private security industry

This will license for the first time the private security industry in Britain, which has expanded rapidly since the 1980s to employ more than 400,000 people now employed. The industry's reputation has been badly damaged by criminal elements. The number of private security guards now outnumber the police. The bill will mean all individuals working in the industry will have to apply for a license. The protection in the Rehabilitation of Offenders' Act for those with criminal records will be waived in some cases. There will be a new offence of working without a licence in the security industry. Those who will be covered include security guards, "bouncers", wheelclampers, private investigators, security consultants and key-holders. Companies will also have to register, and, in the long term, private approved security officers could be used for street patrols to supplement police.

Car crime

The proceeds from speed camera fines are to be used for more cameras. There will be an increased effort to tackle the industry in stolen cars which are broken up and sold for parts.

Criminal assets

The draft Proceeds of Crime Bill is designed to set up a confiscation agency with the power to sue for the recovery of criminal assets using a civil standard of proof in the High Court.

Among the Home Office measures canvassed as possibilities but missing from this Queen's Speech are bills to introduce indeterminate sentences for the most serious offenders, to bring a new offence of "corporate manslaughter", or to reform the asylum voucher system

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Crackdown on stowaways
fields.body:
Crackdown on stowaways

Twenty-seven stowaways, including a baby, were found yesterday as P&O Stena Line launched a crackdown on illegal immigrants using its ferries. The company has hired security guards to check every lorry bound for Dover from Calais.

Radiohead tops poll

Forty leading music critics have voted rock band Radiohead's chart-topping Kid A as the album of the year in a survey compiled by online retailer Amazon.co.uk.

Warning on stolen tickets

West Midlands police yesterday warned football fans not to buy any of the 3,000 tickets for the Aston Villa v Manchester City match on December 16 which were stolen from a postal depot in Manchester last month. Fans with the tickets, which are green and for the R Block area of Villa Park, will not be admitted.

Journey into the Unknown

Up to 1,000 people will today attempt to transmit an image projected on to the Museum of the Unknown in London into the mind of a volunteer in a sealed room. The experiment will attempt to establish whether psychic effects can be boosted by a large number of people.

Preacher of the year

Margaret Hay, 58, a Salvation Army colonel from south London, was last night crowned preacher of the year at the Central Hall Methodist church in Walsall, West Midlands.

Message from vCJD mother

Helen Jeffries, mother of Zoe, 14, the youngest person to die of vCJD, is to give Channel 4's alternative Christmas Day message.

fields.headline: New breed
fields.standfirst:
Chickens help fight cancer

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The scientists who cloned Dolly the sheep yesterday unveiled a breed of genetically altered chickens that produce cancer drugs in their eggs, writes Kirsty Scott. The Roslin Institute in Edinburgh announced a joint project with the American biotechnology company Viragen which they say could offer a faster, cheaper and virtually unlimited supply of the drugs.
fields.body:
The scientists who cloned Dolly the sheep yesterday unveiled a breed of genetically altered chickens that produce cancer drugs in their eggs, writes Kirsty Scott. The Roslin Institute in Edinburgh announced a joint project with the American biotechnology company Viragen which they say could offer a faster, cheaper and virtually unlimited supply of the drugs.

The scientists hope initially to produce antibodies to skin cancer and a protein drug to treat lung cancer.

They say medication could be commercially available in two years.

webTitle: Arts: The new Sam Shepard's play

fields.headline: Sean Penn, Nick Nolte, Woody Harrelson. With a cast like that, how can a play go wrong?
fields.standfirst: Joe Mader is bemused by Sam Shepard's world premiere
fields.trailText: Joe Mader is bemused by Sam Shepard's world premiere.
fields.body:
San Francisco's Theatre on the Square is no stranger to media attention. But it has been at the centre of a rare feeding frenzy in recent days. Not only is it hosting the world premiere of Sam Shepard's play The Late Henry Moss, but the show brings together some of the biggest names in Hollywood. Shepard himself directs a cast that includes Nick Nolte, Sean Penn and Woody Harrelson. Unsurprisingly, the public has rushed to buy tickets for the five-week run; what is a revelation is how poor an evening awaits them.

In one sense, The Late Henry Moss is a culmination of Shepard's playwriting. There are the warring siblings of True West, the hidden family secrets and wounds of Buried Child, the symbolism of A Lie of the Mind and the themes of the frontier's end, the damage fathers do to sons and all the macho-mythic desperation and attempted poeticism that exist in so many of his works.

But Shepard doesn't enlarge these themes; he isn't exploring anything original or insightful. It's as if a college student completed an assignment to write in the style of the playwright. Shepard is half-heartedly cribbing from himself, and it makes for a very long evening.

The show opens with a quiet, funny malevolence. After a preliminary tango across the stage by veteran character actor James Gammon (who plays Henry Moss) and Sheila Tousey (as his native American girlfriend, Conchala), we see Henry's son Earl (Nolte) sitting at a table in a New Mexico house, drinking bourbon and smoking while his younger brother, Ray (Penn), stands with his back to the audience, swinging a wrench, its clicking ratchet the only noise. He's gazing at a corpse wrapped in a sheet on a bed - their father.

The brothers haven't seen each other in many years: Earl fled the family long ago after a drunken rampage in which Henry terrorised and battered his wife and broke the windows of their home. But there's something fishy in Earl's description of Henry's death. He tells Ray that Henry's neighbour, Esteban (Cheech Marin), had called him when Henry left the house in a taxi and didn't come back for a while.

Earl flew in to discover Henry already dead. Esteban, later making his usual delivery of soup for Henry, unaware that he has died, supports Earl's story about the phone call, though it's clear he's covering something up for Earl. Esteban explains that Henry, who went and got drunk after receiving a cheque, called a taxi to take him and Conchala on a fishing trip. Ray subsequently interviews the cab driver (Harrelson), who relates a somewhat different narrative.

There are several extended flashback sequences that get us to the "truth" of the matter. We watch Earl grapple with his guilt over abandoning his mother and brother, while Ray wrestles with his anger and sorrow.

There are stretches of ironic, banal dialogue. (Ray to the cab driver: "You're nothin'. Just like me." Henry to Earl: "You know me, Earl - I was never one to live in the past.") These are occasionally interrupted by desert-heartland poetry. (Earl to Ray: "You jump all over him like a cold sweat." Earl to Esteban: "I am nothing like the old man: We're as different as chalk and cheese.")

Plus, there's Conchala, Shepard's woman-myth character. In one flashback we find out that when she and Henry first met, in the jail drunk- tank, she pronounced Henry dead: "Dead for 20 years, a dead man living in a dead house." Shepard's telling us that women define men, even holding the power of life and death over them. Henry and Conchala return from the fishing trip with one tiny, four-inch catch. Conchala strips down to a slip, takes a bath and puts the fish between her legs. It comes back to life; she puts it in her mouth and swallows it whole. Gosh!

Nolte and Penn don't embarrass themselves, but the roles and dialogue limit them and prevent them from projecting. There's no sense of life, just generic abuse-survivor self-loathing and recrimination. Penn has a nice moment in the first act fighting back tears over his father's death, but you won't see it from the balcony. The secrets that get exposed are surprisingly anti-climactic, though; you get the Sturm und Drang of melodrama without the kick, and the brothers have nowhere to go, dramatically.

Gammon, in the flashbacks, bellows all his lines at the same pitch, and his make-up, for some unfathomable reason, is smeared on like mud.

In Shepard's direction of the play, you can see where compromises have been made. Characters who are not in a flashback sequence exit from the front of the stage, fully lit, violating the boundaries of theatrical space. Props and sets which are shifted during the various recollection scenes are dealt with awkwardly when the present-day action is returned to. The show is heavily amplified, but the voice levels shift depending on how close the actor is to one of the many mikes.

There's also no real rhythm to the production, as if the actors worked on their parts separately and were thrown together only as the opening night approached. Shepard discordantly slapsticks around with two funeral-home attendants as if they were Keystone Kops - they sport black suits and sunglasses, peek out insanely from the bedroom curtain and drop the corpse on the floor.

The one bright spot is Harrelson as the unnamed taxi driver. Saddled with the sometimes dangerous traits of being both hyper-friendly and a wimp (leading him to prolong relationships he should flee), Harrelson's cabbie is constantly in motion. His arms never hang at his side; his hands keep fluttering up as if he's afraid they might cause offence if they ever landed anywhere. He shifts from foot to foot, prattling on about his dreamland - the lucrative midnight pizza-delivery runs in Norman, Oklahoma, where every university-dorm door is opened by a Miss America student who wants to screw you. Throughout, Harrelson glows with an actor's love of his craft.

Despite the press's excitement, The Late Henry Moss is no triumph. But Harrelson's funny, sexy performance gives off a heat not otherwise found in Shepard's dim desert tale.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Plane crash victims named
fields.body:
Plane crash victims named

The four people killed when their light aircraft crashed in Berkshire on Sunday were named by police yesterday. The passengers were Peter Bevan, 44, his 11-year-old daughter Lauren, of Billingshurst, West Sussex, and his brother Roger Bevan, 48, from Kingswood, Bristol. The pilot was Alistair O'Byrne, 29, from Woking, Surrey.

'Sightings' of missing girl

Police searching for Leanne Tiernan yesterday said they were following up "unconfirmed sightings" of the 16-year-old from Bramley, Leeds, who was last seen 10 days ago.

Army chief takes up post

Lieutenant-General Alistair Irwin, 52, the new general officer commanding the army in Northern Ireland, took up his post yesterday.

webTitle: G2: Gulf War hostage John Nichol

fields.headline: Top-flight entertainer
fields.standfirst: Ten years ago he was the focus of one of the most enduring images of the Gulf war: a captive, battered airman paraded on Iraqi TV. But what happened next to John Nichol? Maggie O'Kane finds out
fields.trailText: Ten years ago he was the focus of one of the most enduring images of the Gulf war: a captive, battered airman paraded on Iraqi TV. But what happened next to John Nichol? Maggie O'Kane finds out.
fields.body:
The first thing you wonder is, what's a 36-year-old man, shot down in a Tornado fighter, ejected at 200mph into the skies over Iraq, tortured by his captors, a true British war hero, doing in a place like this?

We are in Hertfordshire, land of stud farms and signposts that all seem to end in either "green", "pond" or "private"; a Thunderbirds house, all plate glass and balconies, in a little village. A place where John Nichol makes a rather good living out of "the most humiliating moment" of his life.

Although he chucked the airforce in 1994, Nichol is still the hunky-chunky military type. His fifth book, Decisive Measures (Mercenaries, diamonds and a bit of old-fashioned British loving in Sierra Leone) is just out. And next month he'll be all over the papers again, as the 10th anniversary of his greatest hour looms.

On the back of his Boys' Own/Gulf war fame he has built a life as novelist, after-dinner corporate speaker and media pundit on things military: want to know about the Chinook disaster? Gulf war syndrome? How high pilots flew in Kosovo? Ask Nichol. And he is almost through a lucrative multi-book deal with Hodder and Stoughton.

He once said that he owed it all to "Some poor Iraqi conscript who probably got paid 10p a week with a missile that cost £750 on the black market shooting down my £20m Tornado." But that's not quite it. Nichol is a man of enterprise. After being bound, beaten and burned, his torturer told him he was going to appear on TV as one of Saddam Hussein's hostages. He obediently combed his hair as instructed, then when he got the chance, ruffled it up so that he looked even more beaten up than he was.

His books are a bit like him. They are stories about nice guys with names like Rudi and Jack. Decent men who get into big adventures around the world. More recently there are women in them. Is it difficult having to write sex into his books? "It's the formula," says Nichol, "the formula the publishers want."

But his love scenes are gentle, written by the kind of guy who would worry about doing it right: "A moment later she was in my arms. I pulled her closer and kissed her. She stiffened for a second, then leaned into me, holding my face in her hands, staring into my eyes."

Nothing too revelatory, but it is the insider's knowledge of military matters that is more interesting in his books - the insights of the people who normally never talk, but seem delighted to talk to him.

Decisive Measures has the advantage of the inside track. ("I didn't go there myself. I thought it was marginally too dangerous.") Instead he talked to those who had been there: military intelligence officers, mercenaries, SAS insiders. You can see how he carries it off. "Hi, my name's John Nichol, you probably don't remember, but I was one of the Tornado crew shot down in Iraq during the Gulf war. Look, would you have a moment, I'm writing a book about . . ." And wham, he has them eating out of his hand.

On the after-dinner circuit he earns £2,500 to £5,000 for a one-hour presentation with a distinct feel of M People's "'Reach For the Hero Inside Yourself". BT has engaged him for another year to give corporate talks. Doesn't he find it boring? Giving the same speech about Iraq and the torture? Nichol cringes. "I get well paid for it. It would be churlish to say I find it boring." But it is very clear he's been there. "I can't speak about it in any kind of detail."

It's not the torture that seems to bother him: "Classic stuff, sleep deprivation, mindless beating, burning tissue paper stuffed down your neck," but the fact that he talked. "I always hesitate to use the word torture. People have their fingernails cut out and hot irons shoved up their arse." So why didn't they do that to him? "Probably because I gave in before they got there."

They beat him up regularly, and badly. The worst part was listening to the screams down the corridor and knowing that he was next. "I knew I would give in. I knew some stuff, like what target we were supposed to be hitting the next day, but nothing that mattered to anybody or would change the price of butter. I realised pretty quickly that the Iraqis weren't really sure what to ask us. They captured us, thought they should probably torture us, but to what end? It was important to try and hold out for a while. If you broke first they could lean on you really hard."

So one day, facing beatings, burning newspaper down his back once again - and as electric shock treatment made its way down the corridor - he decided to tell them about the price of butter.

One of the nice things about Nichol is his honesty (or could it be another marketing ploy - "Nichol tells it how it is"?). He has made a documentary, and campaigned with the fathers of the two pilots blamed for crashing a helicopter in the Mull of Kintyre in 1994, killing 29 people including top intelligence officers. Nichol believes the pilots will not be exonerated because the airforce he served for almost 20 years "doesn't say sorry".

He left the airforce after Bosnia, because its role there had been "a joke". "We were supposed to be monitoring the no-fly zone. But we were being ignored and were left flying around in circles watching helicopters landing and then villages burning and pretending it wasn't happening. Putting our lives at risk so the politicians back home could make it look like our men and women in Bosnia were doing something."

On the subject of flying high, he doesn't support the view that if pilots had flown lower during the Kosovan war they wouldn't have hit and killed civilians: "At 600 miles an hour it doesn't matter if you're flying at 30 feet or 30,000 feet - you can't see anything out the window anyway."

The plans for a European army also get the refreshing Nichol treatment: "All the pilots are chatting about it on the internet. It doesn't mean that much in the military, because we've already been flying alongside Dutch, French, American, whoever."

This year, apart from the book, he has completed a series called Air-shows of the World; he has another TV series interviewing people about life-changing experiences; and three months ago he started on a 10th anniversary documentary, Going Back. It was dropped by the BBC, so he went back courtesy of the Daily Mirror.

There is plenty of "meeting with the enemy/we're just ordinary guys caught up in a lousy war" stuff. He visited a prison but scrapped plans to revisit the jail where he was tortured. The experience proved to be too much for the man whose idea of therapy on his return from captivity was 15 pints and a chicken vindaloo.

When I tentatively suggest we might hold this interview over until the 10th anniversary, I incur the clipped professional wrath of Nichol. The man who, although tortured had the presence of mind to ruffle up his hair, states that we are putting him in a very difficult position since he promised an exclusive anniversary interview to someone else.

On cue, his second phone rings. The father of one of the Chinook pilots is on the line. Nichol chats - military man to military man - and afterwards wonders if the Chinook story would be an angle, so we could do a profile to publicise him now and not spoil his 10th anniversary plans. So here is John Nichol, on being tortured, being a hero, making a living and not missing a trick.

 Decisive Measures by John Nichol is published by Hodder & Stoughton, price £16.99.

webTitle: Work begins on Britain's first new canal in 150 years

fields.headline: Work begins on Britain's first new canal in 150 years
fields.trailText: Construction of the first new canal to be built in Britain for 150 years begins today to fulfil a dream abandoned through lack of money at the end of the 18th century.
fields.body:
Construction of the first new canal to be built in Britain for 150 years begins today to fulfil a dream abandoned through lack of money at the end of the 18th century.

The Millennium Ribble link, as the four-mile stretch is known, contains nine locks and links the Lancaster canal with the river Ribble and the main part of the nation's canal network. It will enable people to reach the Thames from Cumbria.

The turning of the first sod of the new canal coincides with the first annual meeting of the Waterways Trust, a charitable body set up to extend and restore the canal network. Roger Hanbury, the chief executive, said the aim was to restore hundreds of miles of disused canal to add to the 2,000 miles already in use.

Another of the trust's proposed projects is a 15-mile cut from Milton Keynes to Bedford, linking the Grand Union canal between London and Birmingham and the river Ouse and the Broads. "It would be the first east-west link in the new canal age," said Mr Hanbury.

The trust will own the new Ribble link and take over other restored canals such as the Rochdale canal, all of which are expected to generate jobs and improved property prices.

The new canal, costing £1m a kilometre, about one tenth of the cost of new road, will be completed in 2001.

The original plan of the celebrated engineer John Rennie 200 years ago was abandoned as too expensive and replaced with a horsedrawn tram. It is still too ambitious for today's builders. He had in mind a viaduct over the Ribble to join up with the Leeds and Liverpool canal.

The modern version drops 20 metres (60ft) from the Lancaster canal at Preston to the Ribble along the course of the Savick stream.

The trip will not be for the faint hearted. The Ribble is tidal so narrow boat enthusiasts will have 4-4 hours to motor up river to reach the rest of the inland canal network at the Rufford branch of the Leeds and Liverpool canal. British Waterways staff will on hand to advise if conditions are suitable to venture on to the Ribble.

The Lancaster canal extends 58 miles from Preston to Kendal in the north but builders of the M6 in the 1960s did not leave enough headroom for boats to go under the motorway and three low bridges block progress to the Lake District.

The trust has a £30m development plan to restore the canal to use by raising the bridges, creating 2,000 jobs in the process.

fields.headline: Section 28 left out of plans
fields.trailText: William Hague was quick to spot holes in the government's legislative programme where promised bills on sensitive issues like adoption law and vaccine damage compensation have still not materialised.
fields.body:
William Hague was quick to spot holes in the government's legislative programme where promised bills on sensitive issues like adoption law and vaccine damage compensation have still not materialised.

The running controversy over repeal of section 28, the local government law which prevents the "promotion" of homosexuality, has also slipped off the official timetable, at least until after the coming election.

Ministers had accepted that it will not get past the Lords in the present climate, though the same calculation is being made about the bill to ban hunting with dogs - also likely to face stiff resistance in the upper house.

Some bills attracted Conservative criticism unfairly, including the promised transport safety bill which is being postponed until after completion of Lord Cullen's inquiry into the fatal Paddington rail crash.

Last night the prime minister's spokesman stressed that there may be many more bills introduced before election day - widely expected on May 3 - thus keeping his options open.

webTitle: Bill designed to cut through red tape

fields.headline: Bill designed to cut through red tape
fields.trailText: More late night restaurants and more after school care for pupils may be on the way as a result of a bill designed to simplify more than 20 regulatory burdens.
fields.body:
More late night restaurants and more after school care for pupils may be on the way as a result of a bill designed to simplify more than 20 regulatory burdens.

The move, designed to appeal to consumers, may also appease the growing disaffection of business fed up with extra burdens. The draft deregulation bill was published in April and has already been scrutinised by a Lords specialist select committee. The bill is required since existing laws prevent ministers from deregulating existing legislation, as well as removing burdens to be found in more than one bill.

The prime minister has put forward 20 areas likely to be subject to new deregulatory powers, but the Cabinet Office has asked the public to email other areas for deregulation.

Other burdens that could be removed include the remaining constraints on the number of partners that professions such as GPs, chartered surveyors and investment trust managers can have. At present no more than 20 people can form a partnership.

Rules surrounding weights and measures could be simplified, and pubs would be allowed to open late on New Year's Eve from next year. At present many restaurants cannot receive late licences unless they provide live music.

The bill would also remove from businesses the cost of having to adhere to two different set of regulations surrounding unfair contract terms.

The measures would also make it easier for directory publishers to gain repeat business by simplifying the process for renewing directory entries.

Innovators in the building and construction industry would no longer be penalised for doing things in a different way from what is laid down in guidance. Renewal of business leases could be accelerated and administrative burdens on charities also lifted. Corrections of errors on birth and death certificates would be simplified.

Licences for manufacturers and wholesale dealers for human and veterinary medicines would be simplified.

Cautions, reprimands and final warnings would be placed on the same footing as other criminal records.

Gambling legislation could also be simplified by allowing customers to use banknotes and smartcards when playing with gaming machines. A greater variety of gaming machines could also be installed.

fields.headline: THe best tunnel scene
fields.standfirst: Small Time Crooks
fields.trailText: Small Time Crooks
fields.body:
Brooklyn. Somewhere under a parade of shops, Ray (Woody Allen) and Denny (Michael Rapaport) are trying to tunnel their way into a nearby bank. The plan isn't going well. Less than 50 yards into the tunnel, Denny shouts ahead to Ray.

"Ray, wait. Which way are we supposed to be going?"

"Uh, straight on."

"No, we should have taken a left by now..."

Ray turns back to talk directly to his colleague. Only now does he realise that Denny is wearing his miner's helmet back to front, its flashlight pointing back behind him.

"Wait a minute, what the hell are you doing?"

"Whaddya mean, what am I doing?"

"You got your hat on backwards!"

"Yeah," Denny mutters defensively. "So?"

"Whaddya mean, so? The flashlight is supposed to go at the front."

"Yeah, but it looks cool like this."

"Ah, you got to be jerkin' with me."

"It's a lot more stylish."

A note of uncertainty enters Ray's voice.

"You think so?"

Hesitantly, he turns his own helmet back to front.

"Yeah," exclaims Denny, "that's it. Turn it around. Yeah, look at that. That's cool."

"You got a mirror?"

"Nah, I ain't got a mirror. But it looks good. You can see it when we get out. So let's go."

Ray peers dimly ahead.

"Wait a minute, I'm trying to figure the map out. I can't see so good any more."

See also: The Great Escape, The Taking Of Pelham One Two Three, Body Double

Don't see also: Daylight

Pointless trivia: Woody Allen's adoptive daughter with Soon Yi-Previn is called Manzie, after jazz musician Manzie Johnson.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Me or 2K | HP on AOL
fields.body:
Me or 2K
I have recently been offered a new PC with the alternative operating systems of Win Me or Win 2000 as part of the deal. I do not have a network, and don't know how otherwise to make suitable comparisons between the two. How might I best evaluate the offers? David J Leigh
d.j.leigh@staffs.ac.uk

Jack Schofield replies: Windows 2000 (aka NT5) is technically much better, but should be used only with products on the official compatibility list (see www.microsoft.com/windows2000/upgrade/compat).

This should not be a problem with new hardware but you may have old software that it will refuse to run, including games.

Windows Me (aka Windows 98 third edition) does its best to be compatible with any old rubbish, at some cost to its own stability. Currently, Windows 2000 is recommended for business users and Me for home users. Some suppliers are still dragging their knuckles on the ground when it comes to supporting versions of NT, even seven years after its launch. AOL is an example.

However, next year they will have no choice. Microsoft is working on a unified operating system, codenamed Whistler, which will replace both W2000 and 98/98SE/Me.

It will be available in both professional and consumer editions, and will offer the option of installing either "Windows classic" or a new user interface. It is currently on beta test.

HP on AOL
I have just bought an HP Jornada 720 handheld computer, which has a built-in modem. I want to use it for email and the web but so far haven't managed to. My internet service provider (ISP) AOL tells me that I need to install its (massive) program. Is there another, better way of doing it? Arthur Hughes
GArthurH@aol.com

JS: One problem with running a proprietary email service like AOL mail is that the company has to develop its own client software for every device it wants to support. This is why CE users are still waiting for PocketPC software. According to the information online (keyword: PALM), AOL claims to support a wide range of Windows CE machines running version 2.11 of the operating system or later, including the Hewlett-Packard Jornada models 420, 430, 680 and 820. However, the 720 is not on the list.

The Jornada 720 does support standard internet email and web browsing, so you should find it easier to use a standard internet service such as Freeserve or BT Click, which needs no registration procedure and does not charge a monthly fee.

You can still collect your AOL email using AOL Anywhere via the website at www.aol.com

Movie magic
I have a number of Video CDs (VCDs?) which I would like to play on my PC. What is the appropriate software to use; and where might I get it? Will I need special hardware to do this? David J Leigh
d.j.leigh@staffs.ac.uk

JS: Video CD is a forerunner of DVD, and in Asia, it is still hugely popular as a movie format. It uses MPEG-1 compression to provide a resolution of 352 x 288 (PAL) and 352 x 240 (NTSC), which is similar to VHS. MPEG-1 players are not all that common but Microsoft's Media Player 7 supports MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-3 and should do the job. If not, try Xing Technology's XingMPEG or Zoran's SoftPEG http://www.visiblelight.com/mall/.

No special hardware is required if you have a reasonably quick PC, with a 200MHz Pentium MMX or better.

There is also MpegTV, a Video CD player that runs under Linux and other versions of Unix, which can be downloaded from www.mpegtv.com/download.html. The same site offers PocketTV, a free award-winning program that plays MPEG-1 movies on a PocketPC or Windows CE machine.

Install that on your palmtop and you can download a bunch of shorts and movie trailers from www.pocketmovies.net.

TweakUI
As you suggested, I had a look for TweakUI on my Windows 98 SE CD, but without success. I then read \tools\reskit\readme.doc which said: "Note: TweakUI has been removed from the Windows 98 Resource Kit." Where can I get it? David Wood
dry@tesco.net

JS: It seems TweakUI was buggy and had not been updated for 98SE.

However, Version 1.33 can be downloaded from Microsoft's website at www.microsoft.com/ntworkstation/downloads/PowerToys/Networking/NTTweakUI.asp and can be used in Windows 95/98/Me as well as NT/2000.

You could also take a look at TweakAll, a free alternative from Abtons Shed. There is a comprehensive list of tweaking tools at www.tweakfiles.com/allinone.

OE ordered
When I open my Inbox in Outlook Express, how do I get it to go straight to the new messages, rather than the top (and oldest) one on the list? David Steed
David.Steed@ukgateway.net

JS: Thanks to more than a hundred readers who pointed out that the order of messages in the Inbox can be changed simply by clicking on the little arrowhead in the Received header panel (this is standard Windows behaviour, even if there is no little arrowhead), or by using the View|Sort By menu.

But I still cannot see a way of selecting either the first or last unread message...

Modem driver
Please could you let me know how I can download the driver and software for a US Robotics 14.4 Fax Modem? Ken Donkin knd@mweb.co.za

JS: Windows should already have supplied a driver for this. However, US Robotics has an official site with drivers to download at www.usr.com/support/s-main-menu.asp .

Other useful sites for driver hunters include1 WinDrivers and The Driver Forum.

Save the driver in your My Downloads directory, or on a floppy disk, then go to Start|Settings|Control Panel and run the Add New Hardware wizard.

If the modem is already installed, you can go to Start|Settings|Control Panel|Modems and remove it, then restart your PC. Windows should find the modem again.

When prompted for a driver, select Change or Have Disk and point it to the floppy drive or My Downloads directory.
