fields.headline: Curfew plan gets cold shoulder
fields.trailText: Unsupervised teenagers will be expected to be off the streets by 10pm under new laws at the heart of the home secretary, Jack Straw's anti-"yob culture" package, which has been designed as much to wrongfoot Tory opposition in the run-up to the election as to continue to bear down on the falling crime figures due out next month.
fields.body:
Unsupervised teenagers will be expected to be off the streets by 10pm under new laws at the heart of the home secretary, Jack Straw's anti-"yob culture" package, which has been designed as much to wrongfoot Tory opposition in the run-up to the election as to continue to bear down on the falling crime figures due out next month.

But Mr Straw's plans to raise the age of local child curfews to 16 and to issue £100 fixed penalty fines for public drunkenness and disorder were immediately criticised by child welfare charities and youth organisations. The National Children's Bureau said it was dismayed by the plans, while the British Youth Council deplored the move as "the criminalisation of a group of people largely ignored by society."

The crime package also includes the long-awaited bill to license the 125,000 private security guards who operate in Britain, new moves to clamp down on the trade in stolen vehicles, and measures to tackle the link between alcohol and violent crime. Reform of the licensing hours, promised by Home Office ministers in August, which would have led to optional 24-hour opening for pubs seven days a week with the ban on children lifted have, however, been shelved until after the election.

A move to set up a national confiscation agency to seize the assets of organised crime will also have to wait until the next session. Instead only a draft bill is promised but in the meantime the Inland Revenue is to be given unprecedented powers to hand over to the police the tax records of individuals for a whole range of offences. Until now, such disclosure was limited to cases of treason and murder.

Criminal justice

Mr Straw yesterday defended the child curfew proposal, saying: "Why are there youngsters out on the streets at 10 or 11pm. Where are the parents? Children should be in their homes at 10 or 11pm not racketing around the streets." Ministers point to the limited success of a similar scheme in Hamilton, Scotland, to answer criticism that no local authority in England has used existing curfew powers for those aged 10 and under.

The bill will also include new fixed penalty fines - to be used like parking tickets - for public drunkenness and disorder, and powers for the police to immediately close down rowdy pubs and bars. The police are also to be given the power of immediate arrest over kerb crawlers and hit-and-run drivers and will be given new powers to remove material from premises for searching. It will also give the inland revenue power to disclose confidential tax details to the police.

Private security industry

This will license for the first time the private security industry in Britain, which has expanded rapidly since the 1980s to employ more than 400,000 people now employed. The industry's reputation has been badly damaged by criminal elements. The number of private security guards now outnumber the police. The bill will mean all individuals working in the industry will have to apply for a license. The protection in the Rehabilitation of Offenders' Act for those with criminal records will be waived in some cases. There will be a new offence of working without a licence in the security industry. Those who will be covered include security guards, "bouncers", wheelclampers, private investigators, security consultants and key-holders. Companies will also have to register, and, in the long term, private approved security officers could be used for street patrols to supplement police.

Car crime

The proceeds from speed camera fines are to be used for more cameras. There will be an increased effort to tackle the industry in stolen cars which are broken up and sold for parts.

Criminal assets

The draft Proceeds of Crime Bill is designed to set up a confiscation agency with the power to sue for the recovery of criminal assets using a civil standard of proof in the High Court.

Among the Home Office measures canvassed as possibilities but missing from this Queen's Speech are bills to introduce indeterminate sentences for the most serious offenders, to bring a new offence of "corporate manslaughter", or to reform the asylum voucher system

fields.headline: Prize-winning gobbledegook
fields.standfirst: Luton council joins a record number of winners in taking home a 'golden bull' award from the Plain English Campaign
fields.trailText: Luton council joins a record number of winners in taking home a 'golden bull' award from the Plain English Campaign. By Simon Parker
fields.body:
Luton council has joined film star Alicia Silverstone in picking up a Plain English Campaign award for speaking gobbledegook.

The prizes are handed out to organisations or people that produce incomprehensible statements. This year, a record 11 "golden bull" prizes were handed out.

Luton won its prize after reportedly describing go-karting lessons for excluded children as: "A multi-agency project catering for holistic diversionary provision to young people for positive action linked to the community safety strategy and the pupil referral unit."

The actress and council join the Department for Social Security and the Ministry of Defence in the campaign's hall of shame. The MoD won the prize for a legal document that contained a single 166-word sentence.

The South West of England Regional Development Agency also took home a prize. A leaflet on the agency's regional economic strategy told readers: "Aligning the drivers, values and principles with the objectives is the key to unlocking the strategy. When they are fully aligned, they will illuminate the actions that need to be taken in the region."

Director of marketing and communications Michael Roberts said, "We accept that this award is in good nature. We take the point and we are endeavouring to make sure that our information is as readable in the future as we can possibly make it.

"Next year we're aiming to win the award for the clearest plain English and we've set up a campaign within our organisation to do this."

As for Ms Silverstone, she won the "Foot in Mouth" award for what the campaign termed "the most baffling verbal statement of the year". The actress described a film she had starred in as: "Very deep. I think it was deep in the way that it was very light. I think lightness has to come from a very deep place if it's true lightness."

We take the point and we are endeavouring to make sure that our information is as readable in the future as we can possibly make it. "Next year we're aiming to win the award for the clearest plain English and we've set up a campaign within our organisation to do this." As for Ms Silverstone, she won the "Foot in Mouth" award for what the campaign termed "the most baffling verbal statement of the year". The actress described a film she had starred in as: "Very deep. I think it was deep in the way that it was very light. I think lightness has to come from a very deep place if it's true lightness."

fields.headline: The EU summit in Nice
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
Italy
La Stampa
fields.body:
Italy
La Stampa

"The marathon has already been preceded by contentious and wearying preambles which will probably continue until Sunday and, in all probability, will conclude not with an accord between the 15 (member states), but with a compromise between the two principal protagonists and duellists: France and Germany. The others will follow."

Germany
Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung

"Neither the neo-Gaullist president [French president Jacques Chirac] nor the Socialist prime minister [Lionel Jospin] has dared tell the French people how he views Europe's future. With a presidential election looming in 2002, both appear afraid of making themselves vulnerable ... While Mr Jospin keeps mum about what he wants, Mr Chirac talks a lot. But he does not always act on what he says".

Belgium
Le Soir

"If it is unlikely to be a historical occasion on a fundamental level, the summit may be so on a superficial level: as far as negotiators can remember, never has such a meeting lasted for four days. So the pessimists forecast a conclusion on Sunday evening while the optimists announce the end for Saturday before the evening news. But they agree on one point: all will be played at the last minute..."

France
Libération

"If we are to base ourselves on past positions, [Lionel Jospin] will need to display much audacity to surprise us, to dispel his image of reluctant European, all the more unwilling as the time of making great choices approaches. A little like Jacques Chirac, in fact, obliged, but against his will, to 'make do' with Europe, but not very enthusiastic when it comes to the construction of tomorrow's Europe. A little as if it were a question of pushing back the deadlines, to limit the damage until the next national election, rather than to make a coherent choice, to assume it, explain it, apply it."

Spain
El Mundo

"Without reform to make government of the union more flexible, it is inconceivable that, in a sufficiently short space of time, the EU can accept the 12 candidates with whom there are already firm deals, to say nothing about the various other countries awaiting their turn. The paralysis of the EU would be complete, amid an ocean of vetos. ...Somebody will have to give way."

fields.headline: Manuel 'Puntillita' Licea Lamot
fields.standfirst: Cuban singer plucked from retirement to become a worldwide sensation with the Buena Vista Social Club
fields.trailText: Cuban singer plucked from retirement to become a worldwide sensation with the Buena Vista Social Club
fields.body:
Mañuel "Puntillita" Licea Lamot, who has died aged 73, was a Cuban singer whose life was transformed five years ago when he joined other elderly Cuban musicians and American guitarist Ry Cooder to form The Buena Vista Social Club, one of the most remarkable recording successes of the 90s.

If it had not been for their album - and the spin-off concerts and records that followed - "Puntillita" might have expected to spend his final years in retirement, honoured only by students of the history of Cuban music for his role as one of the great singers - the soneros - who worked with the Havana big bands back in the 40s and 50s. Instead, he found an international audience late in life, recording with other Buena Vista artists, and touring the world with their companion band, the Afro-Cuban All Stars. This September he sang with them at the Sydney Opera House, in October they toured Japan, and in November, just three weeks before his death, he gave his final show with the All Stars in Las Vegas.

It was a fitting farewell for a man who had started his career singing in the brash Havana clubs, in the years before Castro's revolution. In 1945 he joined trumpeter Julio Cueva's Orchestra, one of the most popular bands in Cuba during the war years. Here he earned his lifelong nickname "Puntillita", from the song Son De La Puntillita, that he sang with the band. From the start, he was known as a singer who matched power, clarity and perfect intonation - qualities he retained throughout his career.

In the 50s he was one of the soloists with the celebrated and long-established orchestra La Sonora Matancera, later made even more famous as the backing band for Celia Cruz, the "Queen of Salsa". "Puntillita" also sang alongside Cuba's greatest male singer, Beny Moré, the bandleader known as "the wizard of rhythm" and the finest performer in Cuban history. Unlike Celia Cruz and others who left Cuba at the time of the revolution, seeking fame and fortune in the United States and elsewhere, "Puntillita" refused to become an exile, though his appearances were limited to Cuba and the communist world.

It wasn't until the mid-90s that Cuban singer and band-leader Juan De Marcos Gonzalez, then the leader of the Sierra Maestra group, decided to try to revive the "golden age" of Cuban music of the 50s, and set out to discover how many of the former stars from that era were still living in Cuba, willing and able to keep playing and singing. "Puntillita" was one of those cheerfully coaxed back from retirement. He sang with De Marcos on the first album for his revivalist Afro-Cuban All Stars, A Todo Cuba Le Gusta, opening with Amor Verdadero - a song he performed with the All Stars on all their tours.

He was also invited to take part in a second project, the massively successful Buena Vista Social Club Presents . . . , performing alongside Ry Cooder, who produced the set. On the Buena Vista album he sings with Ibrahim Ferrer and guitarist Eliades Ochoa on the bawdy El Cuarta De Tula and leads on La Bayamesa, a patriotic Cuban song from the mid-19th century.

The sessions for both albums were recorded in just a few days in Havana in 1996, and have enjoyed quite extraordinary sales. Along with the subsequent solo albums by members of the Buena Vista team, they have now sold more than 7m copies worldwide, transforming the lives of all the elderly musicians involved, who were plucked from near-obscurity to enjoy four years of touring concert halls and festivals around the world.

The Buena Vista project produced three veteran superstars, pianist Rubén Gonzalez and singers Ibrahim Ferrer and Omara Portuondo, who all went on to record and tour as soloists. "Puntillita" Licea never had the chance to branch out like that, though he made further appearances on Ferrer's album, and on the second album by the Afro Cuban All Stars, entitled Distinto Diferente.

His funeral in Havana was attended by members of the Afro-Cuban All Stars and the Buena Vista Social Club. It must have felt like the beginning of the end of a classic era in Cuban music.

His wife of 45 years died earlier this year and he is survived by a son.

Mañuel "Puntillita" Licea Lamot, singer, born January 4 1927; died December 4 2000

webTitle: Pomp, pageantry and now a new challenge to the crown

fields.headline: Pomp, pageantry and now a new challenge to the crown
fields.standfirst: Speech highlights crime as Labour sets sights on May election
fields.trailText: Speech highlights crime as Labour sets sights on May election
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday defended his government's legislative programme from accusations of blatant electioneering by challenging voters to demonstrate the "individual responsibility" needed to make Labour's vision of the good society become a reality.

During brutal exchanges across the Commons dispatch box after the ritual pomp and flummery of the annual Queen's speech ceremonies, both the prime minister and William Hague provided abundantly clear outlines of the campaigns they plan to run once the date of the coming general election is fixed - probably for May 3.

The government's emphasis on fighting "yob culture" - notably public drunkenness - on NHS reforms, and another attack on welfare fraud, prompted an immediate charge that ministers are obsessed with "clearing the decks", their eyes fixed firmly on the Middle England segment of Labour's winning 1997 coalition of voters.

The Conservative leader, who repeatedly accused Mr Blair of being "all spin and no delivery" and wasting £25bn worth of extra taxes, joked that it was "very good of her majesty to come down here and deliver" her speech, considering how "thin" it was.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, echoed Mr Hague's complaint that the speech was "unambitious" in terms of the most urgent problems facing voters - crumbling schools, hospitals, transport and police services. The prime minister doggedly refused to plead guilty.

So short is the time now available for reforming legislation that the speech read from the throne contained only 15 bills and four draft bills, which will not be enacted unless unexpected calamity forces Labour election strategists to postpone their bid for a second full term until October or - the 11th hour - spring 2002.

But, if the speech itself contained no content that had not been heavily trailed in advance, Mr Blair did surprise some MPs - in boisterous election mood on both sides - by the contempt he showed for the Conservative leader and his advisers.

"Good jokes, lousy judgment," Mr Blair explained, in contrast to his own earnest appeal to the electorate to transcend narrow self-interest. With voter apathy and cynicism leaving ministers worried that their biggest enemy is stay-at-home voters - not the Tories - Mr Blair set out what aides call chapter four of Labour's campaign "narrative" and coupled it with an appeal for responsibility.

After putting the economy on a stable path, tackling hard-core unemployment via Gordon Brown's welfare-to-work schemes and what he called "mending our schools", this fourth Queen's speech package was about crime and health: five bills on everything from car crime to social security fraud, plus a wide-ranging health and social care bill to implement last summer's ambitious NHS plan.

In his keynote message Mr Blair told MPs: "Across all these areas there is a clear narrative to what we have achieved. Laying the foundations of economic stability, getting people off welfare and into work, investing in public services, all of it designed to build opportunity.

"What this Queen's speech does is then, in return for that opportunity, [demand] responsibility. We are giving the police the powers they need, and we are giving the people the support they need to win back their communities," he claimed.

To Mr Hague, in a long but witty speech, that was simply more hot air. In a crucial counterblast, later hammered home by the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, he complained: "Police numbers have been cut, offences are up and 20,000 criminals have been released early to offend again."

"Without adequate police numbers all this will come to nothing," the shadow home secretary predicted on Channel 4 as ministers spoke of community involvement in fighting crime and antisocial behaviour.

The Conservative leader accused Mr Blair personally of routinely abandoning everything he has claimed to believe in over 20 years in public life and said that the government's executive arrogance was responsible for "the least considered legislation in the history of the country". NHS waiting lists, transport "chaos" and the storm clouds over this weekend's EU summit in Nice all provided Mr Hague with targets. "It is designed to produce better headlines, not better public services," he said of yesterday's package.

But his failure to address seriously either the economy or alternative Tory policies allowed Mr Blair to puncture him without much difficulty. Mocking Mr Hague's tax-and-spend package he quipped: "If they want to save £1bn on fraud they should start with their own programme."

Mr Blair rattled off details of the Conservative legacy after 18 years in power - from "cockeyed" rail privatisation to mortgage rates of 15% and leaking school roofs - and predicted: "We will not forget. More important, neither will the country."

Focus group findings and opinion polls, which have seen Labour bounce back to a 10% lead - according to an ICMGuardian survey last week - after the Tory bounce during the fuel crisis, suggest he is right. Labour and Tory MPs are starting to wonder if Mr Blair may increase his 179-seat majority in 1997.

While Tory MPs on both left and right brace themselves for a second hammering at the polls, Labour strategists are puzzled by Mr Hague's failure to make a serious impact on public opinion. "His combination of 19th parliamentarian and 21st century management consultant should have been ideal," conceded one.

webTitle: Guardian Republic Debate: How the media reacted

fields.headline: Guardian Republic Debate: How the media reacted
fields.trailText: The following media organisations yesterday followed up the Guardian's call for a debate on the Act of Settlement and whether there should be a referendum on an elected head of state
fields.body:
The following media organisations yesterday followed up the Guardian's call for a debate on the Act of Settlement and whether there should be a referendum on an elected head of state

Television

The story was covered on most of the BBC's main news bulletins, starting with BBC Breakfast. Sky News carried a phone-in programme with the Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, and conducted a phone poll. ITN also covered the story, making it the lead item at one point on Channel 5 News

National radio

Most of the BBC national radio bulletins carried the story, including interviews with Mr Rusbridger.

Radio 4's Today programme carried a live interview with Mr Rusbridger.

Radio 5 Live, The World at One and the World Service also explored the debate.

Regional radio

BBC Radio Scotland carried interviews and the independent Scot FM ran the story. BBC Wales and BBC radio in Northern Ireland carried interviews.

Almost all local BBC radio stations in England carried the story. The BBC Asian Network and BBC London Live - which questioned passers-by outside Kensington Palace - also carried it.

ITN Radio, which supplies many independent local radio stations, carried the story. LBC in London conducted a phone-in debate.

fields.headline: Slash, the epitome of rock
fields.standfirst:
Slash's Snakepit
Underworld
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Slash's Snakepit
Underworld
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Not many men can legitimately claim to be rock heroes, but Slash is certainly one of them. Thanks to his hard labour in Guns 'n' Roses, the seminal rockers band that not only put sex, drugs and dodgy hairstyles back into the charts, but fulfilled the Spinal Tap dream thanks to Axl Rose's kilt-wearing tendencies and much in-fighting. Slash has been there, done that, but doesn't feel like wearing the T-shirt. Bare-chested, cigarette hanging from lips, guitar balanced on his hip in its trademark upright position, Slash is the epitome of rock.

And like any true star, he arrives late, building up the anticipation until the excitement in the air is unbearable. Wearing a leather top hat balancing on a mass of long, unruly hair that could only be acceptable on a man who can work magic with a guitar, he has charisma pouring from him, even as he finishes off a bottle of Jack Daniel's.

Since the untimely demise of Guns 'n' Roses, Slash has busied himself with a blues covers band and the tight and friendly Slash's Snakepit, in their second incarnation and here concluding the British part of a European tour. Singer Rod Jackson, all dreadlocks, dark glasses and throaty vocals, soon goes into stadium rock mode, running to the side of the stage, shaking his dreads fiercely, to be joined by Slash, who sings some harmonies, more for fun than effect. But while Jackson, and bass player Johnny Blackout, a Sid Vicious wannabe, do their best to entertain, it's Slash who remains transfixing.

The set is largely made up of songs from the new album, Ain't Life Grand, guitar workouts built around Slash's ability to strangle the life out of each note yet retain a pure melody and stunning grace. Been There Lately is real head-spinning rock 'n' roll with heavy riffs and even heavier drums, while Just Like Anything begins with a more challenging, subtle rhythm that's soon ravaged by more guitar gymnastics. This inevitably leads to an amp blowing up. "It was bound to happen," Slash smiles as he leaves the stage.

On their return, Slash's Snakepit resume their tour de force, the band watching in awe - and affection - as their leader roams the stage, stands on amps and does his mesmerising thing.

As Mr Brownstone, a Guns 'n' Roses favourite, is dusted down and kicked into life, everyone goes mad. Heads are shaken furiously as the soaring guitar reaches an ear-shattering climax. "We could just hang out all night," Slash concludes. And this night there's no better place to be.

fields.headline: Freeserve sells for £1.6bn
fields.standfirst:
Wanadoo gains British presence at knockdown price
Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, was sold yesterday to an arm of France Telecom for £1.6bn, a fraction of its valuation earlier this year. The all-paper deal with Wanadoo crushes any lingering hopes of a big windfall for the retailer Dixons, which owns four-fifths of Freeserve.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, was sold yesterday to an arm of France Telecom for £1.6bn, a fraction of its valuation earlier this year. The all-paper deal with Wanadoo crushes any lingering hopes of a big windfall for the retailer Dixons, which owns four-fifths of Freeserve.

Earlier this year, the company was rumoured to have been on the verge of being bought by a German rival for £6bn. But there was little sign last night that a third party would step in with a higher offer.

Wanadoo chairman and chief executive Nicolas Dufourcq said the new group would have nearly 4m users but was aiming for 10m, "so that means that more acquisitions may be made". Company officials confirmed it planned to play a lead role in further sector restructuring.

Freeserve chief executive John Pluthero said the Freeserve brand would remain intact but content would be boosted by Wanadoo and its €2m (£1.25m) war chest. There were also opportunities for tie-ups with other France Telecom companies such as the mobile phone operator Orange but Mr Pluthero denied Freeserve's links with the telecoms group Energis would be damaged.

Defending the price of the Wanadoo offer, he added: "This was the best deal we could get and it was also a very good deal."

Dixons chief executive John Clare dismissed speculation that he had turned down a bid of 600p per share in the summer from T-Online of Germany. "We never received any definite offers and even if we had they would have certainly been in paper and so Freeserve would be worth no more or less today."

The French deal will go with the backing of the Dixons board to an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders early in the new year. Dixons will be forced to hang on to the majority of its 12.7% stake in the combined company and only be able to sell it down in stages up to 2003.

Wanadoo, 88% owned by France Telecom which is in turn 54% controlled by the French government, has agreed to pay 157p per share for Freeserve. The float price in July 1999 was 150p and the trading value of the company was 920p per share in March this year.

Disappointment at the price and the lack of a cash element eroded Freeserve shares by 9% and they ended the day down 8.25p at 133p, while Dixons fell 16p to 235p.

Robin Hutchings, an analyst at West LB, said he expected the Freeserve share price to fall further over the coming weeks. "European ISPs still have a long way to come down to meet US valuation levels. At the end of the day this deal is about exchanging poor quality paper for slightly less poor quality paper."

Freeserve pioneered UK internet access for the price of a telephone call in 1998 and built up a rising revenue stream by attracting 2m users; but this was accompanied by mounting losses. Wanadoo, which floated on the Paris bourse at €19, has seen its share price fall 40% but is more than five times bigger in terms of capitalisation

The poor price for Freeserve could depress the prospects for LineOne, another British ISP up for sale.

Analysts say that if T-Online and Spain's Terra-Lycos remain serious about building a presence in the UK, Europe's second-largest market, they are likely to bid for LineOne. The BT-United News & Media joint venture, with 1.3m customers, is on the market for around £400m.

Meter made: How free access idea took off

 Freeserve was the brainchild of chief executive John Pluthero in 1997, when he was working at Dixons, together with colleague Mark Danby and Peter Wilkinson, managing director of Planet Online

 In July 1998 the three had worked out the model and Freeserve was soon after launched by Dixons as a free internet access service where customers paid phone charges only

 On July 26 1999 Dixons floated Freeserve, with shares issued at 150p, valuing the business at £1.5bn

 By March, shares had risen to above 900p but soon fell back and rumours began that Deutsche Telekom's T-Online was considering a bid

 In May, Dixons confirmed it was considering selling at least part of its 80% stake in Freeserve, and introduced an unmetered internet access package

 In June, shares fell to around 350p after talks with T-Online collapsed

 In September the group announced its two-millionth customer and that first-quarter losses had doubled to £17.8m

 In October its shares fell below the float price for the first time and it was relegated from the FTSE 100

 In November it said it was in fresh talks. Wanadoo was widely tipped as a bidder

fields.headline: Supermarkets cut petrol prices
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the petrol war
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leading supermarket chains Sainsbury, Tesco and Asda yesterday cut the prices of unleaded petrol and diesel as international oil prices tumbled.
fields.body:
Leading supermarket chains Sainsbury, Tesco and Asda yesterday cut the prices of unleaded petrol and diesel as international oil prices tumbled.

Sainsbury was first to act, cutting unleaded by 2p a litre to 79.9p and diesel to 83.9p. It was quickly followed by Tesco, which cut unleaded by "at least 2p a litre" and Asda, which cut unleaded to "a maximum of 79.9p".

The moves came as the wholesale price for premium unleaded last night dropped by 19% on the European spot market to $228 a tonne, the lowest level since January.

Discontent over high fuel prices sparked nationwide fuel protests in mid-September, when wholesale crude was priced at $330 a tonne.

Analysts said that the fall in crude had boosted retail margins and opened up the possibility of lower pump prices. "Certainly, at the very least, at $250 a tonne we are looking towards two or three pence off a litre unleaded," said Stephen Brooks, a petrol consultant at Wood Mackenzie.

Leading oil companies were slower to react. BP Amoco said it had no plans to change prices, which typically stood at 81.9p a litre for petrol. "The position is unchanged," a spokesman said.

Shell said it had cut unleaded petrol prices at "more than one-half of our network" to 79.9p a litre in November. Esso was, as usual, tracking prices at 10,000 of its competitors' outlets. - Reuters

fields.headline: Exemption problem areas
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue is uncompromising on what constitutes a gift and would take a very dim view of, for example, a gift made to a friend on which you still earn interest. Similarly, the taxman won't look too kindly on any arrangement where you give your home to your children, but continue to live in it rent free.

Similarly, the taxman won't look too kindly on any arrangement where you give your home to your children, but continue to live in it rent free.

Indeed, giving away a home is riddled with pitfalls. If you intend to continue living in it, you will have to prove that you pay your new landlord a proper market rent. Your new landlord would have to pay income tax on that rent and could possibly face a capital gains tax bill when the property is eventually sold, not to mention the inheritance tax liability should you die within seven years of making the gift.

webTitle: How do I make a will?

fields.headline: How do I make a will?
fields.trailText: Most people think they have to go to a solicitor to write up a will. Certainly this is a safe option as a solicitor's help should avoid any mistakes, but you can draw up a will by yourself or go to a dedicated will writing company.
fields.body:
Most people think they have to go to a solicitor to write up a will. Certainly this is a safe option as a solicitor's help should avoid any mistakes, but you can draw up a will by yourself or go to a dedicated will writing company.

Personal finance website moneyextra.com has a WillWizard service which talks you through writing your own will. Alternatively, the Society of Will Writers should be able to help you find a local will writing service. And you can also try the Inland Revenue.

Solicitors charge upwards of £50, excluding VAT, to draft a will. The more complicated your requirements the more it will cost.

But, by the same token, the more complicated your requirements, the more you should use a solicitor. A large number of issues are bought to bear on will writing. For example, might any children you want to leave money to be under 18 when you die? If yes, should the money be left to them in trust? And what about your partner or spouse? They might die before you, and if they do your will must be able to accommodate this.

fields.headline: Planning your inheritance tax
fields.trailText:
Many people leave inheritance tax planning until the last minute, which may be too late. If you're not taking the following avoidance action already you could be, if you'll excuse the pun, digging your own grave.

  • Do your sums. Check the total value of your assets, as you may be worth more than you think.
fields.body:
• Do your sums. Check the total value of your assets, as you may be worth more than you think.
    • Make a will. Otherwise your estate will be distributed according to certain statutory rules. For example, your spouse may only be absolutely entitled to £125,000. If you have no living relatives, your assets will go to the government.
    • Use your exemptions. Assets left to your spouse in a will are not subject to inheritance tax. But if you leave everything to your spouse, you will waste your tax-free allowance of £234,000. If you are wealthy enough it is more tax efficient to leave this £234,000 to others, such as your children, and any amounts over this to your husband or wife. Make sure, of course, that your spouse has enough to live on. Then, when your spouse dies, he or she also has a tax-free amount. So you get two allowances and not one.
    • Review your death in service benefit. This is paid by most employers to dependants when you die, and is not included in your estate for inheritance tax purposes. Again, if you have sufficient other assets, and/or your spouse has an independent income, it is more tax efficient to ask an employer to pass this sum directly on to your children, say, rather than your spouse. Otherwise it will fall to your spouse's estate and become taxable when he or she dies.
    • Consider life insurance. If this is written in trust, the sum payable on death will also escape inheritance tax. It can thus be paid direct to your children tax free. Writing a policy in trust is simple, and you can ask a solicitor or insurer to help.
    • Be charitable. Gifts to charity are exempt from inheritance tax, so you can save tax and save the whales at the same time.
    • Make lifetime gifts. When calculating whether you are liable for inheritance tax, you need to include not only the value of your assets on death, but any sums given away in the seven years before. If you survive seven years after the date of the gift, the amount is excluded from your estate for tax purposes.
    • Use your £3,000 allowance. You can make one or more gifts of up to £3,000 each tax year without it counting for inheritance tax. If you have not used up your allowance it can be carried forward for one year.
    • Encourage wedlock. Each parent can give £5,000 to a child when he or she gets married; grandparents can give £2,000, and anyone else £1,000.
    • Give away your surplus. If you have more income than you need, you can give the rest away without it counting for inheritance tax. The technical name for this relief is "normal expenditure out of income". To qualify you need to make regular donations.
    • High earners may want to consider special inheritance tax reliefs, such as through the transfer of businesses and agricultural properties. In some circumstances this might even justify a purchase as part of a long term tax reduction plan, though only people with a legitimate interest in the business can obtain the relief.
    • Don't panic. If someone close to you dies and leaves a tax-inefficient will, it is possible to vary it within two years of death. But all the beneficiaries have to agree to this variation.
    • Do it in trust. One of the most effective ways of providing tax free cash to meet an inheritance tax liability is by using a whole-of-life assurance policy. In the case of married couples, for example, this would normally involve writing a policy on both of their lives which pays a death benefit on the second death, which is when the inheritance tax arises. Alternatively, if you want the policy to meet any inheritance tax liable because you die within seven years of a lifetime gift, you can buy yourself a special form of temporary cover. Under this temporary assurance, the death benefit would normally reduce as the potential tax liability reduces. This type of policy is often called a "gift inter vivos" policy. It's important, however, to write any policy under trusts.

fields.headline: Inheritance tax
fields.trailText: Inheritance tax is the one tax most people do not have to worry about, not just because they'll be dead when it bites, but because, according to the Inland Revenue, more than 96% of estates don't have to pay it. They either fall below the threshold for the tax or have been organised in a tax efficient way to avoid it.
fields.body:
Inheritance tax is the one tax most people do not have to worry about, not just because they'll be dead when it bites, but because, according to the Inland Revenue, more than 96% of estates don't have to pay it. They either fall below the threshold for the tax or have been organised in a tax efficient way to avoid it.

But is this true of you? Two major myths surround inheritance tax.

The first is that it's a tax which only affects the rich. Wrong. Inheritance tax is now an issue for the middle income families of middle England, as well as middle Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Inheritance tax is currently charged on estates of more than £234,000, but when you consider that the value of your home, assets and proceeds of any life policies will all be taken into account, the figure of £234,000 begins to look less generous. And, with increasing property prices, this figure hardly covers the cost of a two bedroomed flat in central London, let alone your family home.

The second myth is that inheritance tax is levied only on what you leave upon your death. Wrong again. Yes, the tax is charged on your estate, but it is also levied on some gifts you make in your lifetime, especially if you die within seven years of making them. What you own when you die is merely treated as your final gift and is added to the running total for the previous seven years.

Unfortunately, the "can't pay, won't pay" approach to inheritance tax doesn't work. Tax is paid out of the deceased's estate by his or her personal representatives, but in many cases the children or heirs can find themselves having to pay the tax bill from their own funds. Inheritance tax is due just six months after the end of the month in which the death occurred, and some people are forced to take out bridging loans just to meet tax liabilities while they try to sell the house they have inherited.

If you don't want that on your afterlife conscience you would be wise to make some inheritance tax arrangements now.

fields.headline: What is my tax allowance?
fields.trailText: You are allowed to make gains up to a certain amount each tax year which are tax-exempt. For 2000/2001 it has risen to £7,200. Everyone has their own allowance, so couples can make gains of £14,200 (£14,400 for the year 2000/2001) before they fall into tax. Children have their own allowance as well. If your profits come to more than your allowance, you only have to pay tax on the excess over the tax-free limit.

webTitle: Do I have to pay tax on everything else?

fields.headline: Do I have to pay tax on everything else?
fields.trailText: No. Any gain you make when you sell your home is tax-exempt, unless you have let part of your home, or used it to run a business. In those circumstances, a proportion of the gain may be taxable, depending on a new sliding scale.
fields.body:
No. Any gain you make when you sell your home is tax-exempt, unless you have let part of your home, or used it to run a business. In those circumstances, a proportion of the gain may be taxable, depending on a new sliding scale.

You also escape tax on money made in various other circumstances, including gains from: the sale of your car; Personal Equity Plans or Individual Savings Accounts; UK Government gilts; personal belongings worth £6,000 or less when you sell them; and betting, lottery or pools winnings.

fields.headline: The Young Gods
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
What less likely venue to host this Geneva trio's guitarless industrial din than the genteel Queen Elizabeth Hall? Before the interval, there was the art: keyboardist Al Comet playing a guitar in the manner of a sitar; naked dancer Nuria de Ulibarri gyrating to Franz Treichler's doodling soundtrack; a lecture by anthropologist Jeremy Narby on the hallucinogenic visions of rainforest shamans. But while all this was more imaginative than a support band, it lacked structure.

However, once the Young Gods became a band again, they soared. Treichler looks more like a seedy Neil Morrissey than a goth icon but he is an excellent growler. With a spotlight at the base of his microphone and a yen for Christ poses, he has a beguiling presence. Comet marshals samples with the air of a TV chef in a hurry, and Trontin, all big sticks and ginger afro, attacks his kit as if it had offended him.

The set was based on their forthcoming fourth album (the first since 1995), Second Nature. Stick Around and Attends snake along with unpleasant undertows, but the louder and faster the Young Gods are, the more thrilling. Thus, Lucidogen, The Sound In Your Eyes and Supersonic, rather black-and-white on disc, come to colourful life on stage.

During In the Otherland, the heavily backlit Treichler whips out a megaphone and waggles his microphone in front of it to produce a discordant wail, Trontin stands up and hammers the life out of his drums and Comet layers sample upon sample. The effect is hypnotic and surprisingly melodious - rather like the Young Gods.

webTitle: No change again in interest rate

fields.headline: No change again in interest rate
fields.trailText: The country's homeowners got an early Christmas present from the Bank of England today when the monetary policy committee left interest rates unchanged at 6% for the 10th month in a row.
fields.body:
The country's homeowners got an early Christmas present from the Bank of England today when the monetary policy committee left interest rates unchanged at 6% for the 10th month in a row.

Mortgage prices should now remain stable, helping the millions of homeowners who are mortgaged to the limit because of the country's runaway housing market.

This should help allay the fears of Financial Services Authority chairman Howard Davis who, earlier this week, warned that new buyers are over-stretching themselves - often borrowing more than three times their annual income - and could find themselves in negative equity if house prices fall.

It will not come as such good news to savers who, for nearly a year now, have seen the interest on their deposits remain static.

The decision to not to change marks the longest period of static interest rates in 10 years and, according to market commentators, is evidence of a slow-down in the British economy spurred by weak industrial production and a sluggish retail sector.

If this slowdown continues, and it certainly looks set to with a similar slowdown in the US having knock-on effects in the UK, rates could be cut even further.

At 2%, the rate of inflation is well below the government target of 2.5%, which means the Bank of England does not need to keep interest rates high to control inflation. However, analysts say a rate cut is unlikely before next spring. Christmas bonuses and end of year pay settlements may distort economic figures in the New Year and the bank will need the situation to settle down before it can properly assess the state of the economy.

webTitle: How can I pay less capital gains tax?

fields.headline: How can I pay less capital gains tax?
fields.trailText: Invest in an Individual Savings Account (Isa). Enjoy every pound of this year's £7,000 Isa allowance.
fields.body:
Invest in an Individual Savings Account (Isa). Enjoy every pound of this year's £7,000 Isa allowance.

An Isa wrapper allows you to invest free of income and capital gains tax. There are two ways to use your Isa allowance: a maxi Isa or a series of mini Isas. With a maxi-Isa, you can put your whole annual allowance into one Isa run by one manager. The Isa can hold a combination of cash savings accounts, stock market investments and life insurance.

Alternatively, you can have up to three mini Isas, one for each of the three types of savings options. In the current tax year you can shelter £3,000 in a cash mini ISA, £3,000 in a stocks and shares mini Isa and £1,000 in a life insurance mini Isa.

Take a gamble. If you've still got some spare cash to invest after you've used up your Isa allowances, add a little excitement to your tax planning by exploring the world of Enterprise Investment Schemes (EIS) and Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs).

An EIS allows you to claim tax relief of 20% on investments of up to £150,000 in shares in unquoted companies issued after January 1994. There is no capital gains tax to be paid when the shares are first disposed of. What's more, losses on disposal can be offset against an income or capital gains tax bill.

The beauty of an EIS is that if you have a capital gains liability following the disposal of an asset, you can defer the tax by re-investing the money in EIS shares. And there's no limit on the amount of chargeable gains you can defer in this way.

VCTs offer pretty much the same kind of tax advantages, but are actually companies quoted on the stock market. They operate like conventional investment trusts, but invest in small, risky, unquoted trading companies. The Revenue permits you to invest up to £100,000 a year in VCTs and there are three tax advantages for investors. Firstly, when you buy shares in a VCT you get income tax relief at 20%, provided that the shares are held for at least five years. Secondly, dividends from VCTs are free of income tax, and thirdly any gains you make when you dispose of your shares are free of capital gains tax too.

Split up your gains. You may be married and living as one, but that's not how the taxman sees it. A husband and wife are treated as individual taxpayers for both their investment income and investment gains. If you own an investment jointly, each of you is taxed on half the income or gains unless you have made a declaration that you actually own the investment in unequal proportions.

Consider changing the proportions in which you own investments if one of you pays tax at a lower rate than the other, or if one of you tends to use up the annual capital gains tax exemption while the other does not. You could, for example, make an outright gift of shares to your husband or wife if he or she has no taxable income. But be careful: it must be a real gift and you are not permitted to keep control of the money.

fields.headline: Where can I get help?
fields.trailText: If you feel you really don't have the time or the confidence to handle your own tax affairs, then reach for the phone book and find yourself a good tax return service or accountant. The best way to find a good tax adviser is through personal recommendation. Failing that you could call one of the professional bodies (see below), but how much they charge varies enormously.
fields.body:
If you feel you really don't have the time or the confidence to handle your own tax affairs, then reach for the phone book and find yourself a good tax return service or accountant. The best way to find a good tax adviser is through personal recommendation. Failing that you could call one of the professional bodies (see below), but how much they charge varies enormously.

For a simple tax return service you can expect fees of at least £100 to £200. The level of fees will, of course, depend on the complexity of your affairs. For the specialised help of an accountant with a top firm, the fee could easily be £300 or £400.

Institute of Chartered Accountants in England & Wales: 020-7920 8682
Chartered Institute of Taxation: 020-7235 9381

webTitle: Can I offset losses against gains?

fields.headline: Can I offset losses against gains?
fields.trailText: Yes, and there is no time limit within which losses of any year must be used. But there is a nasty twist, as you have to use up losses from the current year first. They are set against your gains before taper relief is applied, and they are used to take your gains back to zero if they are big enough, not just to the level of the annual exempt amount.
fields.body:

They are set against your gains before taper relief is applied, and they are used to take your gains back to zero if they are big enough, not just to the level of the annual exempt amount.

Losses carried forward from earlier years get more favourable treatment, as they are used just to bring gains down to the level of the exempt amount. Anything left over can be carried forward again to be set against gains made in the future.

webTitle: Homes bill aims to improve property checks

fields.headline: Homes bill aims to improve property checks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers will next week unveil a new housing package designed to help people priced out of property 'hotspots' and improve the image of council housing. The aim is to underpin a homes bill, announced yesterday with a 'starter homes initiative' involving interest-free top-up loans and cash for deposits to help people on average incomes, particularly in the south east, get a mortgage.
fields.body:
Ministers will next week unveil a new housing package designed to help people priced out of property 'hotspots' and improve the image of council housing. The aim is to underpin a homes bill, announced yesterday with a 'starter homes initiative' involving interest-free top-up loans and cash for deposits to help people on average incomes, particularly in the south east, get a mortgage.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford is also keen to persuade many more councils to transfer their housing stock to new 'social' companies and trusts which can borrow on the open market to push improvement schemes ahead.

New measures announced yesterday include plans to accelerate the buying and selling of houses and improving protection given to homeless people. A sellers' information pack will be brought forward as part of the new bill, which will see the onus on property checks passing from buyers to sellers in England and Wales.

The pack, which is expected to cost from £500 to £1,000 will include information about house condition reports and local authority searches - while selling a property without a report will become a criminal offence. The move follows a pilot study in Bristol.

Industry experts warned that the study did not prove the efficiency of the scheme, with only 189 sellers volunteering for the experiment. The Council of Mortgage Lenders said the survey was not a clear enough indicator that the sellers' pack would work. It said further research was needed.

But other plans to scrap the current system of leasehold on many houses were welcomed. The government is proposing a new 'commonhold' system which would provide owners in flats the same security as freehold owners, while giving them greater rights to buy the freehold.

The charity Shelter welcomed plans to give the homeless new rights by extending the homelessness safety net to 16 and 17-year-olds and those who are vulnerable when leaving care.

But the Chartered Institute of Housing said it was disappointed by the government's failure to deliver on a manifesto pledge to licence houses in multiple occupation. Such houses represented "some of the worst housing conditions in the country, with tenants at risk from fire and unsafe appliances". It called for an additional draft bill to include this measure.

fields.headline: What is the tax rate?
fields.trailText: No tax is charged on the first £234,000 of your estate, known as the "nil-rate band". But if the total calculated by the Inland Revenue comes to more than £234,000, inheritance tax is charged at a rate of 40% on the excess.
fields.body:
No tax is charged on the first £234,000 of your estate, known as the "nil-rate band". But if the total calculated by the Inland Revenue comes to more than £234,000, inheritance tax is charged at a rate of 40% on the excess.

The tax on chargeable transfers made in your lifetime is slightly different. If the total of chargeable transfers which you have made in the last seven years exceeds £234,000, inheritance tax is charged on the excess at 20%.

As for PETs, if you die within the seven year period, the Inland Revenue will use a sliding scale to determine what percentage of tax is payable. If your death occurs within three years after you have made a gift, liability is the full 40% tax charge. If the gift was made between three and four years before your death, liability is reduced by a fifth and by another fifth if the gift was made between four and five years before your death. And so it goes on until the seventh year.

fields.headline: What is exempt from tax?
fields.trailText: Everyone has an annual IHT exemption which allows them to make a gift, or gifts, of up to £3,000 in any tax year. If you don't use all the exemption in one tax year, you can use the remainder the following year.
fields.body:
Everyone has an annual IHT exemption which allows them to make a gift, or gifts, of up to £3,000 in any tax year. If you don't use all the exemption in one tax year, you can use the remainder the following year.

You are also free to make any number of small individual gifts, such as Christmas or birthday gifts, worth up to £250 per person in each tax year. If you are married, transfers to your husband or wife during your lifetime or upon death are totally exempt without limit. The only exception is if your spouse does not live in the UK, but you do. In that, your exemption is limited to £55,000.

If you are a parent and your child is getting married, you are also allowed to give the happy couple gifts totalling £5,000 free of inheritance tax. A grandparent can give £2,500 and anyone else £1,000. If you yourself are the bride or groom, you can exchange gifts worth up to £2,500 before the wedding and then any amount afterwards.

If you are separated or divorced, any payments which you make in maintaining your spouse and children up to the age of 18, or while they are undergoing full-time education, are ignored.

Other gifts which are exempt from inheritance tax, whether you make them during your lifetime or in your will, include donations to UK charities, housing associations and political parties, gifts for national purposes or the public benefit, such as works of art to a museum. Death benefits payable on a pension are usually tax free provided they have been specifically assigned to a named beneficiary. If you are not residing in the UK, property situated outside the UK is not subject to inheritance tax.

These exemptions aside, any other gifts are subject to the seven year rule. You do not have to tell the taxman about the PETs you make, but if you die within seven years of making one, the recipient is required to report the gift within 12 months of your death.

fields.headline: What does inheritance tax cover?
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue will add up all the property you owned, anywhere in the world, at the time of your death; the proceeds of any insurance policies paid into your estate (although not policies in trust to your dependants); and any gifts made in the seven years before death which do not qualify for exemptions or reliefs.
fields.body:
The Inland Revenue will add up all the property you owned, anywhere in the world, at the time of your death; the proceeds of any insurance policies paid into your estate (although not policies in trust to your dependants); and any gifts made in the seven years before death which do not qualify for exemptions or reliefs.

From that total, the Revenue will subtract what it considers to be reasonable funeral expenses and any debts, such as an outstanding mortgage. However, the amount deducted may be restricted if some of the debts have arisen from gifts made previously.

The gifts you make during your lifetime fall into three broad categories: those which are tax-free, such as gifts to spouses and charities; gifts you make to certain types of trusts and gifts to companies, known as chargeable transfers; and other gifts that you make such as gifts to relatives and friends.

Inheritance tax is payable on chargeable transfers at the time you make them if the total value of such gifts you have made in the past seven years exceeds £234,000. Gifts you make to friends and relatives will not incur any inheritance tax liability in your lifetime, but when you die the value of such gifts you have made in the last seven years of your life will be added to your estate.

For this reason, these type of gifts are called "potentially exempt transfers" (PETs). Seven years after you have made such a gift, it falls out of the inheritance tax net if you are still alive.

webTitle: Why do I need a will?

fields.headline: Why do I need a will?
fields.trailText: If you want to be sure your estate - property, savings and possessions - will be passed on to the beneficiaries of your choice, you will need a will.
fields.body:
If you want to be sure your estate - property, savings and possessions - will be passed on to the beneficiaries of your choice, you will need a will.

Most people assume that all their possessions will automatically pass on to their husband or wife or other members of the family. However, if you die without making a will, your assets will be distributed among your family according to the somewhat complicated "intestacy rules", under which the State writes your will for you.

These rules could result in your assets not being distributed according to your wishes and, depending on your family circumstances, could also result in members of your family being left high and dry. It will, for example, take longer to finalise your estate if you haven't left a will.

fields.headline: Wills
fields.trailText: A will is a statement of how you want your possessions to be handled when you die. Without one you will have no control over how your assets will be distributed, which means partners and children could miss out.
fields.body:
A will is a statement of how you want your possessions to be handled when you die. Without one you will have no control over how your assets will be distributed, which means partners and children could miss out.

But once you've written up a will and appointed executors - usually family members, a bank or a lawyer - you can rest easy. Thankfully, wills are relatively cheap and easy to arrange - solicitors fees can start from as little as £50 plus VAT.

webTitle: Do I get taxed on the whole of the profit I make?

fields.headline: Do I get taxed on the whole of the profit I make?
fields.trailText: No. You are allowed to ignore profits from inflation made up to April 1998, using the indexation allowance. This allowance was replaced in the 1998 Budget by taper relief, which cuts the amount of gain on which you have to pay tax according to how long you have held the asset, dating from 5 April 1998. The maximum reduction is 40% (75% for business assets) on gains made on assets held for ten or more years.

fields.headline: Scottish Opera's Butterfly in full flight
fields.standfirst:
Madama Butterfly
Theatre Royal
Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Madama Butterfly
Theatre Royal
Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Productions of Madama Butterfly should be built to last. A core repertory piece such as this can expect frequent revivals, so what any opera company needs is a staging that doesn't date too fast and doesn't make elaborate technical demands. That is precisely what David McVicar has provided for Scottish Opera. In taking a straightforward approach, however, McVicar has not stinted on specifics, nor on the careful delineation of every emotional current running through the work; the power that is remorselessly built up through the second half testifies to that.

Yannis Kavakis provides the designs - Butterfly's house, all sliding translucent panels, is seen from the outside in the first act, and from within in the second; and extra touches of japonaiserie are kept to a minimum - and everything is lit with unfailing elegance by Paule Constable.

It is in the detail, though, that the production exerts its real fascination. Every performance is finely grained, each gesture is made to count. As portrayed by Ian Storey, this Lieutenant Pinkerton - bourbon-swilling, physically dominating and aggressive enough actually to push Butterfly's uncle, the Bonze, away from the house when he renounces her - is not just unthinkingly impulsive and finally callous, but also cruelly cynical. Before his marriage to Butterfly he not only tells Sharpless (Jason Howard) that he will eventually take an American wife, but also shows him a picture, presumably of the woman he is already committed to. And when Butterfly's family gather for the wedding, half of them arrive in western clothes, indicating that she is not the first among them to become embroiled with American culture.

The emotional ratchet is given further turns in the second act. Natalia Dercho's tiny, fragile Butterfly waits for Pinkerton's return in Miss Havisham style, wearing the dress he gave her on their wedding day. And as she drives out Goro the marriage broker, her son, astonishingly well played by Sam Aschavir, also attacks him - with his teddy bear. Goro himself (Peter Van Hulle) takes on a more usually sinister dimension; he even reappears with Pinkerton and his new American wife in the final scene, looking for yet another financial cut of the action.

Musically, it is just as enthralling. Guido Ajmone-Marsan's conducting is robust, never over-sweet; an occasional rough patch apart, the orchestral playing is fervent. Both Dercho and Storey are first rate - she with seemingly boundless reserves of compelling, well-focused tone, he matching his burly physicality with singing of equal forcefulness - while Jane Irwin's Suzuki is beautifully modulated. All hard to fault.

At the Theatre Royal, Glasgow (0141-332 9000) until December 30; at the Edinburgh Festival Theatre (0131-529 6000) on December 12, 14 and 16.

In taking a straightforward approach, however, McVicar has not stinted on specifics, nor on the careful delineation of every emotional current running through the work; the power that is remorselessly built up through the second half testifies to that. Yannis Kavakis provides the designs - Butterfly's house, all sliding translucent panels, is seen from the outside in the first act, and from within in the second; and extra touches of japonaiserie are kept to a minimum - and everything is lit with unfailing elegance by Paule Constable. It is in the detail, though, that the production exerts its real fascination. Every performance is finely grained, each gesture is made to count. As portrayed by Ian Storey, this Lieutenant Pinkerton - bourbon-swilling, physically dominating and aggressive enough actually to push Butterfly's uncle, the Bonze, away from the house when he renounces her - is not just unthinkingly impulsive and finally callous, but also cruelly cynical. Before his marriage to Butterfly he not only tells Sharpless (Jason Howard) that he will eventually take an American wife, but also shows him a picture, presumably of the woman he is already committed to. And when Butterfly's family gather for the wedding, half of them arrive in western clothes, indicating that she is not the first among them to become embroiled with American culture. The emotional ratchet is given further turns in the second act. Natalia Dercho's tiny, fragile Butterfly waits for Pinkerton's return in Miss Havisham style, wearing the dress he gave her on their wedding day. And as she drives out Goro the marriage broker, her son, astonishingly well played by Sam Aschavir, also attacks him - with his teddy bear. Goro himself (Peter Van Hulle) takes on a more usually sinister dimension; he even reappears with Pinkerton and his new American wife in the final scene, looking for yet another financial cut of the action. Musically, it is just as enthralling. Guido Ajmone-Marsan's conducting is robust, never over-sweet; an occasional rough patch apart, the orchestral playing is fervent. Both Dercho and Storey are first rate - she with seemingly boundless reserves of compelling, well-focused tone, he matching his burly physicality with singing of equal forcefulness - while Jane Irwin's Suzuki is beautifully modulated. All hard to fault. At the Theatre Royal, Glasgow (0141-332 9000) until December 30; at the Edinburgh Festival Theatre (0131-529 6000) on December 12, 14 and 16.

webTitle: When do you have to pay tax?

fields.headline: When do you have to pay tax?
fields.trailText: Strictly speaking, your executors are liable to pay tax due six months after the end of the month in which you die.
fields.body:
Strictly speaking, your executors are liable to pay tax due six months after the end of the month in which you die.

In practice, it often has to be paid earlier because your representatives will have to pay tax at the same time as they apply for the authority to administer your estate, known as probate in England and Wales, and confirmation in Scotland. Until this authority is granted your assets will be frozen. However, sometimes inheritance tax can be paid in instalments and in some cases the instalments do not attract interest.

On chargeable transfers, other than upon death, the Inland Revenue looks first to the giver to pay the tax. But if you don't pay it, the Revenue will go looking for the recipient. Payment of inheritance tax must usually be paid in the following April if the gift was made between April 6 and the end of September. If the gift was made between October and April 5, then you will have to pay tax six months after the end of the month in which the transfer took place. If you die within seven years of making a PET, the tax, if any, is due from the person you made the gift to.

fields.headline: Can I change my will?
fields.trailText: Making changes to your will is easy - just go back to your solicitor and write up a new one. You should do this if your circumstances have changed significantly, for example if you've remarried or inherited large amounts of money, but the standard advice is that even if your circumstances haven't changed, review your will every five years and make sure it still applies.

fields.headline: Wills
fields.trailText: Thinking about what will happen to your property and possessions when you die is not exactly fun. Neither is sitting through meetings with tax planners and solicitors to make sure they get distributed according to your desires. But the alternative is bequeathing, at worst, nothing, and at best, a protracted, drawn out battle with tax authorities over who should get what.

It's wrong to assume your estate will automatically pass on, tax free, to your family when you die. So, it's worth spend a few hours making sure your assets have been allocated in a tax-efficient way and will be left to the people or places of your choice when you die.

fields.headline: How much tax will I have to pay?
fields.trailText: You will pay tax at 20% if your total income and gains are below the limit for basic rate tax, and 40% if they go over the limit.

fields.headline: Capital gains tax
fields.trailText: Capital gains tax, or CGT, is the tax paid on profits from selling investments such as shares. The main exception to this is gains made from the sale of your home, which are tax-free if it is your main home.

fields.headline: Ian Bostridge
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall/Radio 3
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall/Radio 3
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Ian Bostridge is now such an institution in British music - his BBC lunchtime concert at Wigmore Hall could have been sold several times over - that it is hard to remember he has been a full-time singer for only five years. In tenor terms he is still at the beginning of his career, and his voice is still developing, his interpretations still deepening. What was remarkable about the two Schumann song cycles that made up his programme was how his lieder singing continues to gain in range and power.

Vocally it is the lower register that is gaining steadily in authority and focus; the way he used it to telling, resonant effect in the Liederkreis Op 39, based on Eichendorff poems, gave a whole extra dimension to his interpretations, firmly fixing the seventh song, Auf Einer Burg, as the emotional pivot of the sequence, so that the dark side of these ambiguous texts was as clearly illuminated as their rapture. He has always been meticulous with words and their meaning; emotional journeys are always charted very precisely, but now they seem to be taking on even more vividness.

His accompanist Malcolm Martineau was also a major factor in providing that extra dimension, and his limpid contributions were even more telling in the Heine poems of Dichterliebe, where every piano postlude unerringly crystallised the import of the words and their setting. Bostridge deals with these matchless songs even more directly, and more touchingly, than he used to. He has cut down his gestures and movement on the platform to a minimum, focusing attention much more on what he is doing with the music. Every detail registers, every phrase is floated with perfectly modulated tone, and now, instead of just admiring his musicality and intelligence, one is genuinely transported by his singing.

Repeated on Radio 3 on Saturday at 1 pm.

fields.headline: Nelson Rangell
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express Jazz Club
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express Jazz Club
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Jazz-funk sax playing can have an aspect of sound and fury signifying sweet FA. Since the groove is everything in that idiom, horn players often reduce their contribution to punching home the accents. And there's a widely-shared repertoire of low-note honks, squalling high dissonances and an automatic-fire of staccato repeated notes to make sure nobody misses it.

Nelson Rangell, the Denver-born multi-instrumentalist, sails close to these treacherous waters but is saved by a superb technique that gives every sound an extra resonance and grace. He has a broad, soulful tone on both alto and tenor (the sensuous sound of David Sanborn and Ronnie Laws are audible in Rangell's playing), and a luxuriously rounded sound on flute, with none of the flimsiness the instrument often exhibits in jazz settings.

For his London stopover, Rangell had regular accompanists Phil Mulford (bass guitar) and Chris Dagley (drums), with local pianist Steve Hamilton fitting in seamlessly. He delivered a roaring alto solo over a fast groove on Far Away Days, from his new CD, to kick off, following with a grittily tender tenor-sax soliloquy on a piece with strong echoes of Ronnie Laws's Always There. Over a Latin-tinged and melodically-devious Chuck Loeb tune called Starstream, Rangell then displayed the rich tone and affecting delicate quiver he adopts on flute, and got into a vigorously riffing conversation with Dagley's drums on its finale.

I Will, I Do began with a poetic slow electric bass over ture by Mulford, but interesting rhapsodies don't generally survive for long in this style of music before the storm troopers pitch in, and it soon became a wailing alto-sax outing. The same happened to a delectable piccolo melody called The Magician (Rangell said he found the sheet music for it on the floor of a gig and has never managed to locate the composer), its swirling reverie eventually turning into an uptempo blast like an old Chick Corea tune.

To celebrate the season, Rangell eventually found his way into Let It Snow, a choice guaranteed to test the sentimentality defences of hardcore jazz fans to the limit.

fields.headline: Archer's cardboard courtroom drama
fields.standfirst:
The Accused
Theatre Royal Haymarket
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
The Accused
Theatre Royal Haymarket
London

Rating: *
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer, in the character of a doctor on trial for wife murder, was proclaimed guilty last night by a majority audience vote of 333 to 254. A more considered verdict might be that, as the play's author, he is also culpable of taking West End theatre back about 50 years by creating a cardboard courtroom drama.

Agatha Christie, you might say, lives on, except she did trial drama better in Witness for the Prosecution: there was even an American 1920s play, Trial of Mary Dugan, with alternative endings depending on how a selected audience jury voted. Undeterred, Archer resuscitates an old form in which we are presented with conflicting evidence about the accused cardiac surgeon. Did he poison his wife with potassium chloride in order to claim her life insurance? Or is he being framed by a vindictive nurse with whom he may or may not have had an affair? Only those who desperately care need hasten to the Haymarket.

It would take a Freudian analyst, however, to work out what Archer is really up to in this musty museum piece. On one level, the play is naked self-display: the accused is called Sherwood - and Sherwood Forest was famed for its archers - and is not only an heroic war veteran but is described as having "a brilliant and subtle mind". Yet the play also feels like a self-accusatory ritual: without giving the game away, one can reveal that if the fictional protagonist Archer plays had admitted to the lesser sin of adultery he might have escaped on the more serious charge. Make of that what you will.

What one can say is that, as drama, the piece takes an age to get going and is full of plonking exit lines and musty forensic trickery. An illiterate porter, who has provided damning evidence for the prosecution, cries out: "I only told them what you told me to say." And the credibility of the nurse hinges on the fact that she writes with her left hand while claiming to be dexterous. I had the sensation of watching a conjurer pulling some very dead rabbits out of some very old hats.

The suspense, such as it is, rests on how Lord Archer will perform when it is his turn to act. To be fair, he inflicts cruel and unusual punishment on himself by being forced to witness his own play in virtual silence for the first two acts. But, in the third act, he takes the stand and delivers his lines with the over-rehearsed sing-song of a man apparently reading from an invisible autocue. Real acting is about creating a sense of spontaneity: Archer gives the impression he is studying to be an amateur.

Michael Feast and Edward Petherbridge as the opposing counsels show how these things should be done by investing their ponderous lines with measured irony. But the clunkiness of Val May's production is symbolised by Old Bailey chimes that come in too early and by pieces falling off the set. By the end the audience collapsed into laughter not, I fear, in sympathy but in sheer disbelief at the solemn ineptitude of the spectacle they had witnessed.

Until March 3. Box office: 020-7930 8800.
